HEADLINE: Despite Boom, Flea Markets Buzz

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MONROE, Ohio, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Darryl Haun has discovered yet another opportunity in the great American tradition of making a buck. Mr. Haun is a machinist during the workweek, but at amusement parks he has become an ace thrower of objects at targets, like rings around bottles and quarters on plates. "After you figure it out," he explained, "it's not total chance."
As a reward for his unerring aim, Mr. Haun wins stuffed animals that are bigger than most 7-year-olds. Every four or five months, he hauls his bounty off to the Traders' World flea market here. This weekend he was selling many of the animals for $29 each, a lot less than they would cost in a conventional store but a lot more than they cost him. 
 Traders' World, midway between Cincinnati and Dayton on Interstate 75, has almost half a million square feet of indoor and outdoor selling space for 1,200 vendors, who do business with more than 20,000 shoppers pouring through every weekend. And it is hardly alone: scores of giant flea markets like it dot the country, although most, unlike Traders' World, operate only part of the year. Even in a robust economy, it seems, the flea market can thrive by drawing enough bargain hunters, particularly those who crave the opportunity to find a product not only cheap but perhaps quite rare or even unique.
Traders' World, one of the largest, charges a vendor $40 a weekend to set up a table outside and $68 for a booth inside, prices that offer novice merchants a cheap way to enter the marketplace with their goods. Fall weekends are its busiest time of the year, and all available space was in use both Saturday and Sunday.
While no one keeps comprehensive statistics on flea markets, what evidence there is suggests that others are having at least some of the success enjoyed by the one here. Ron Simmons, president and general manager of the 1,800-vendor Traders Village near Dallas and senior vice president of the National Flea Market Association, says that when he surveyed 130 of more than 2,500 markets around the country last summer, he found that as a whole they were more than holding their own.
"The industry is up as a rule," Mr. Simmons said. "Fifty-three percent of the markets showed an increase in attendance and gross income" from the summer before. "About 20 percent showed a decrease, and the rest were showing the same. The decreases were the result of road construction, competition or extreme weather conditions."
Traders' World is a wonder of enterprising vision, the fantasy of a sod farmer, Jay Frick Sr., who opened it 15 years ago at the age of 62 and has made it a major contender for the dollar of southwestern Ohio's consumers. Starting with 3 buildings then, he has now erected 13, which look like ribs extending from a spine-like core building.
Mr. Frick pipes in polkas, waltzes and golden oldies, has decorated the interior with hundreds of rural artifacts and has strung aphorisms from the ceilings like "It's hard to be humble when you're as great as I am" and "Don't spend all your money on wine, women and song. Save some to spend foolishly."
It's all a little overdone to Becky Lugibihl, a visitor who said she preferred garage sales. Ms. Lugibihl, a 43-year-old word processor for the State of Ohio, had taken a bus tour to Traders' World from Lima, Ohio, an hour and a half away. "I got some zucchini for 39 cents a pound," she said, 40 cents less than what she can find it for at home. "And I got two cans of Sani-Flush for $1 each. At stores they're $2 something." But the savings did not pay for the $24 trip.
For every Becky Lugibihl, though, there is a couple like Scott Wood, 42, and his wife, Margie, 29, of Erlanger, Ky., 40 minutes away. They have seized on flea markets, where the vendors own the business and there are bargains galore, as an alternative to malls, where the sellers are sometimes ill-informed clerks.
"I love thrift shopping, so I can buy more," Mrs. Wood said. "Jeans. I got a pair for $1.50, and they're new." Mr. Wood said he was considering a leather jacket that costs $297 here and $429 at a mall. The Woods said they could find just about everything here: appliances and antiques, new wedding gowns and used boots, jeans and custom-embroidered sweatshirts, old compact discs and old videotapes, birdhouses and produce, fast food and pony rides. Few merchants carry silk purses anymore, but sows' ears are $1 each. Dogs use them to gnaw on.
On the other side of the transaction, there are at least some success stories. Flea-market merchandising has been a boon to Gary Berding, strictly a wholesale liquidator until he opened a booth here six weeks ago to try retail liquidation.
"We sell shelf-pulls," Mr. Berding said -- that is, he buys goods that big stores like Wal-Mart and Target cannot sell and that manufacturers therefore pull off the stores' shelves and sell to him. "I'm kind of like a cemetery," he said.
Mr. Berding's hottest items this weekend were Foster Grant reading glasses with original price tags of $13.49. He was selling them for $2 each or three for $5.
"We're averaging $2,000 a weekend," he said, or about four times the receipts that Jay Frick Jr., who has taken over management of the market from his father, estimates to be the average for all booths.
Business is slipping, however, among a mainstay of flea markets, vendors of limited-edition collectibles: thematic plates with images of Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley, Hummel figurines, Beanie Baby dolls. Nancy and Ron Dornbusch said their hottest line was Precious Moments, white porcelain figurines of children, every one with dewy black eyes. New ones are $30. Discontinued models can exceed $900.
But "something's going on," Mrs. Dornbusch said. "Ebay," she said, referring to the Internet auction service. "I have people coming in and saying, 'I bought the same thing on the Internet.' "
Tom and Linda Engelhaupt speculate that in the lush economy, too many merchants have sprung up to court the consumer, intensifying the competition. From a large indoor booth, the Engelhaupts sell jackets, shirts and baseball caps that they embroider on order on the premises.
"Fifteen years ago," Mr. Engelhaupt said, "there weren't a lot of embroidering machines. It was great. It peaked three years ago. Everybody and his brother has a machine now."
Outside, David and Maria Hamm sell a variety of collectibles and knickknacks. "Cookie jars are real hot," Mrs. Hamm said, as are Christmas items. But they said shoppers were tougher than ever.
"They want something real expensive," Mr. Hamm said, "that doesn't cost very much."

HEADLINE: BIG H.M.O. TO GIVE DECISIONS ON CARE BACK TO DOCTORS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The United Health Group said yesterday that it was returning decision-making power over patient care to physicians, breaking with a longstanding element of managed care that has infuriated many doctors and frustrated their patients.
United, one of the nation's biggest managed care companies, said that a patient's doctor would be able to decide without the insurer's interference whether to admit health plan members to a hospital or provide other treatment. 
 That does not mean the company, which is based in Minneapolis, is giving up cost controls. The company will still review decisions after the fact and urge doctors not to exceed certain averages. When persuasion does not work, doctors can be dismissed from the company's network of approved physicians -- thus forcing patients to transfer to other doctors -- but the company said that sanction was rarely used.
United, which insures 14.5 million people, including 8.7 million in health maintenance organizations and other managed care units, said the rules were being phased in nationally. United has 1.1 million members in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
With the decision, United, which said it approves 9 out of 10 care decisions anyway, will save about $100 million, much of which will be spent elsewhere. It also gets a chance to smooth relations with doctors and patients, attract more customers and perhaps avoid some future legal liability as health plans battle a backlash against managed care in Congress and the states and a series of class-action lawsuits. Those suits generally contend that managed care companies misrepresent that clients are getting the best possible care when in fact, the suits say, the cost of care is the determining factor.
The announcement by United is one of several changes by insurance companies that analysts attribute to the backlash. United, Aetna Inc. and several Blue Cross plans have separately offered their members the right to appeal denials of care to an independent panel outside the company. Such panels would be required in the Congressional measures and are already required in 30 states, including New York.
And several big nonprofit H.M.O.'s, like Kaiser Permanente, based in California, and Harvard Pilgrim in Boston, have long relied on doctors to decide when care is considered medically necessary.
Other managed care companies declined to comment on the United announcement, which was reported yesterday in The Dallas Morning News. Spokeswomen for Oxford Health Plans, Aetna U.S. Healthcare, and Empire Blue Cross said they had not seen United's official account.
Physicians and consumer advocates hailed United's move yesterday.
"It's a response to the consumer and political backlash," said Ken Jacobsen, a health care expert in New York at the Segal Company, a consulting firm. "This is a big, significant step."
Explaining its decision to stop requiring doctors to get prior approval for care, United said it was "no secret that state and federal lawmakers want to put an end to much of this practice."
But officials of the American Association of Health Plans, a managed care trade group in Washington, disagreed that the changes being made by health plans were prompted by developments like the "patients' rights" legislation that is awaiting action by a Senate-House conference committee. Provisions include the right to sue health plans for medical malpractice, the right to appeal denials of care to independent review panels and guaranteed access to specialists.
Susan Pisano, a spokeswoman for the trade groups, said the United announcement was "the next stage in the evolution of health care, the edge of a wave of change."
John Stone, a spokesman for Representative Charles Norwood, Republican of Georgia, who sponsored the House bill, said that managed care companies that turned over medical decision-making to physicians would not be liable to medical malpractice lawsuits under the bill.
Republican leaders in the House and insurance company lobbyists have argued that the right to sue the companies would increase costs for health plan members. But Mr. Norwood said in a statement yesterday that his bill would "very likely result in lower costs." He said, "the best care in the long run is less expensive than cutting corners."
"This action is historic," said Dr. Thomas Reardon, president of the American Medical Association. He said it was "a long overdue victory for American patients and the care they receive."
Jeffrey Roth, a Manhattan dermatologist, said the change would "help re-establish a sense of trust between the insurers and the doctors" and reduce burdensome paperwork in doctor's offices that they denounce as "the hassle factor."
Health care experts and critics of managed care said the prior review system had outlived its usefulness and was actually costing the companies more than they saved. "This is a confession that H.M.O. bureaucrats cost more than they save," said Jamie Court, a spokesman for the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, an advocacy coalition.
Wall Street investors reacted to the news by driving United Health Group stock up $2.375 yesterday, to $54.9375.
Robert Hoehn, a health care analyst with ING Barings, said that the higher stock price may reflect the belief of traders that the new policy would give United "an advantage over other companies in terms of marketing" and "further insulate them from the risk of litigation."
Dr. Archelle Georgiou, chief medical officer of the United Healthcare unit of the company, said that it had been spending $100 million a year to respond to requests for approval of care, which were almost always granted.
Some of the money saved will go toward programs for patients, she said, like telling patients what to expect in the hospital and keeping tabs on them so they get appropriate care promptly and can return home.
The company will still track doctors' decisions after they are made and urge physicians who exceed the average costs on certain types of health care to bring their practices in line. "When we are talking to physicians and not calling to deny a service, they are so much more willing to listen," Dr. Georgiou said.
"Doctors will still have to be mindful of economic outcomes," Mr. Jacobsen, the consultant said.
Like other health care companies, United will still negotiate discounts on payments to doctors and hospitals. And it will continue to try to minimize expensive hospital stays by reminding members with chronic ailments like asthma, diabetes and congestive heart failure to take their medication and closely follow their doctors' orders.
Mr. Hoehn, the analyst, said that managed care had succeeded in bringing health costs down. Fifteen years ago, he said, reviews like those being dropped by United played an important role in holding down costs. "Now quality and access to care are taking precedence," he said, as prior reviews could no longer show savings.
Dr. Lee Sacks, a family physician in Oak Brook Ill., said he was "encouraged that United is trying to figure out how to work with physicians and patients to provide the best care." Dr. Sacks, a senior executive of Advocate Health Care, a group of 2,700 doctors, said that previously United had approved the group's requests for prior approval of care "in 99 out of 100 cases."
Helen Darling, a senior health care consultant with the Watson Wyatt consulting group, said that "health plans, for the most part, are approving everything."

HEADLINE: Namesake as Spoils of War;
North vs. South, With a Battleship to the Victor

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Call it the battle for the battleship, or the north versus the south.
As the much-decorated and now decommissioned battleship New Jersey heads slowly toward that state, the Navy is trying to decide which of two cities will become its permanent home. 
 The contest is between two decidedly unglamorous places trying to transform themselves: Bayonne, an industrial city in the shadow of the Statue of Liberty, and Camden, an industrial city across the Delaware River from Philadelphia.
The ship, which had been berthed in Bremerton, Wash., since being decommissioned in 1991, was towed through the Panama Canal toward the East Coast. Long before its expected arrival on Thursday, it had become an object of intense attention, from veterans and military buffs eager to walk its teak decks and from the two cities eager to attract tourists. Each city is seeking to persuade the Navy that it is best suited to accommodate the ship and preserve it as a museum, and the competition has started to take on the undertones of the north-south rivalry that often defines New Jersey politics.
Bayonne supporters say that the battleship, the most decorated in the American fleet, should be where most New Jersey residents can have access to it. They reason that because two-thirds of the state's residents live north of Trenton, the ship is likely to attract more tourists if it is in the New York City metropolitan area, which would help support its expensive upkeep.
Camden backers say the battleship ought to be near its birthplace, the Philadelphia Naval Shipyards, where it was built in 1942. The battleship will be set up as a museum on the revitalized Camden waterfront, next to the New Jersey Aquarium and just across the Delaware from downtown Philadelphia and its historical attractions. The Delaware River, they also point out, will provide a freshwater port for the ship, an important consideration in preserving the battleship's aging steel hull.
Both sides cite a long list of pros and cons, and many who care about the ship's fate fear that a decision will come down to politics. If that is the case, some say, North Jersey could prevail, as it often has.
"They have more clout up in the north than we do here in the south," said John Horan of Cherry Hill, N.J., who was a signalman on the original crew for two and a half years during World War II. Mr. Horan, who said he would visit the ship no matter where it ended up, said he would rather see it in Camden, 10 minutes from his home, but expected the north to win. "In the state as a whole, North Jersey gets a lot more than South Jersey," he said.
But maybe not this time. A few days before the ship is to arrive in Philadelphia, its temporary home, the scales may be tipping in Camden's favor. While the Navy wouldn't say what it would do before a decision was announced, possibly in January, Camden's proposal has gained powerful support in Washington. Backers include senators and representatives and the Secretary for Housing and Urban Development, Andrew M. Cuomo. Meanwhile, the Bayonne plan has been garnering more critics, including several United States representatives from the New York City area, and the directors of the Intrepid, a similar floating museum at a Manhattan pier.
As the competition comes down to the last few months, the criticisms have become sharper. State Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina said that Camden, which is under state control because of fiscal mismanagement, was too intimidating for most tourists. Mr. Azzolina is chairman of the state-appointed U.S.S. New Jersey Battleship Commission, which favors Bayonne. While Camden's refurbished waterfront is attracting thousands of tourists weekly, he said, the city itself has one of the highest crime rates in the country.
"As soon as you walk off the parking lot, you're in the middle of the murder capital of the world," he said.
United States Representative James H. Saxton, whose district includes Camden, fired back with a shot of his own. "All I can say is, when Brendan Byrne was governor, he said he wanted to be buried in Bayonne so he could continue in politics," he said.
The return of the 45,000-ton ship to New Jersey, after serving in three wars -- World War II, The Korean War and Vietnam -- ends a 30-year sentimental journey by dozens of veterans who worked to persuade the Navy to donate it to its namesake state.
Chief among them is Mr. Azzolina, Republican of Middletown, a retired Navy captain who served on the New Jersey in the 1980's.
Mr. Azzolina, who has made a fortune in the grocery store business, was named chairman of the Battleship Commission when it was formed by Governor Byrne in 1981 and has held the job ever since. "It's probably my greatest achievement ever in my life, in my career, in politics, that the New Jersey is finally coming back home," Mr. Azzolina said recently. "It's a symbol of freedom. It will be a great teaching tool."
The commission was set up to pick a site for the ship and raise money for its return and upkeep. Most of the money is coming from the sale of auto license plates showing the battleship and from state income tax checkoffs allowing taxpayers to contribute to the ship's cause.
Few ports in the state could accommodate the ship. It is six stories high above the waterline, the length of three football fields and 108 feet wide at its beam. Only three cities applied: Bayonne, Camden and Jersey City. Eight commission members voted for Bayonne, saying the city could easily berth the ship at a dock on the Military Ocean Terminal, a 437-acre former naval base turned over to the city in September. Four members voted for Jersey City, which wanted to put the ship near the Liberty Science Center, next to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty. One voted for Camden.
But Camden backers did not take the defeat easily, surprising Mr. Azzolina, who had never envisioned the ship's being located anywhere but North Jersey.
Shortly after the commission's vote, Jersey City threw its support to Bayonne, and Camden County officials filed a lawsuit. Camden supporters complained that only one commission member was from that area. They also asserted that the commission's chairman was biased in favor of Bayonne because of his friendship with its mayor, Joseph Doria, who was then the Assembly's Democratic majority leader. Mr. Azzolina denied the allegations. Camden backers said that of the three choices, Bayonne had the least to offer tourists.
The lawsuit was withdrawn after Navy officials hinted to county officials that litigation would keep them from handing over the ship to either city. But by then, RepresentativeSaxton, who is on the House Armed Services Committee, which sets the Navy budget, met with top Navy officials and learned that they, and not the state commission, would have the last word on where the ship would go.
Since then, support for Camden has grown stronger, and Bayonne's getting the ship has become less of a given. Even Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who appointed some of the commission members, reversed her decision to support the commission's choice, and said in May that instead, she would support whichever city the Navy picked.
Camden's backers say it can support the ship because 22 million visitors come to the Philadelphia area every year. Camden's revitalized waterfront, with its neat brick-lined river walk, is a five-minute ferry ride or a short drive from Philadelphia's Penn's Landing, with its maritime attractions and restaurants. The city would have to spend $2.9 million to build a pier for the battleship, and Secretary Cuomo of HUD has pledged $1 million in federal empowerment zone money for the project.
Mr. Azzolina, as head of the battleship commission, feels confident that the Navy will take the commission's application more seriously, since it comes from an official state body.
Bayonne already has a 1,200-foot-long dock at the old Military Ocean Terminal that could take the ship, although refurbishing the site would be costly. But Mr. Azzolina said that redevelopment of the old base was about five years away, because the city of Bayonne, which only recently took control of the base, had yet to decide on a plan. If Bayonne did get the battleship, it would be the only reason for New York-area tourists to visit Hudson County's southernmost city.
With the confidence of someone from North Jersey, Mr. Azzolina said Bayonne just made more sense as a home for the ship. "It's on the Hudson waterfront," he said. "The population there is three times what it is in Camden. You've got to have at least 400,000 visitors a year to make this work, and Camden can't do that. It's not a north-south war. It's an economic war. You've got to go where it's best for the ship."

HEADLINE: Whitman and Forbes, Separated Now by Political Ideology

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Steve Forbes brought his Republican presidential campaign into New Jersey's capital today, speaking on the steps of a war memorial a block from the office of his childhood pal, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.
Mrs. Whitman made her own public appearance in a Revolutionary War barracks just a few hundred yards away. But Mr. Forbes and the governor did not visit with each other or speak during his daylong stop in Trenton, and that conspicuous silence was a stark reminder that their friendship of nearly a half century has become a casualty in the battle between the various factions of the Republican Party. 
 Once schoolmates, political allies and young Republican bluebloods in New Jersey's hunt country, Mr. Forbes and Mrs. Whitman now find themselves on opposing sides of the Republican Party divide.
Mrs. Whitman, who has been vilified by her party's right wing for her support of abortion rights, has publicly criticized Mr. Forbes's shift on social issues several times this year, accusing him of caving in to the conservative voters who dominate the party's primaries.
During the course of a conversation with reporters today, the governor offered a few kind words for Mr. Forbes. When she was asked whether she knew that campaign aides for her longtime friend had been trying to win votes by bluntly portraying him as the anti-Whitman, her expression made it clear that she was hardly heartened.
"Steve was certainly a Christie Whitman Republican when I first ran for governor," Mrs. Whitman said with a smile, "and I haven't changed on the issues that were important to me then and are important to me now. If he's changed, that's up to him. And that's fine."
Mr. Forbes came to Trenton to rally social conservatives supporting a proposal to make every student in New Jersey begin the school day by reciting part of the Declaration of Independence in addition to the Pledge of Allegiance.
He also took the occasion to brush aside any suggestion that he might abandon his presidential bid and seek the party's nomination for United States Senate next year. That race has been in turmoil since Governor Whitman dropped out of contention in September. Chuck Haytaian, chairman of the state Republican Party, said he had no indication that Mr. Forbes might be interested in the Senate race if his presidential bid is unsuccessful.
"He's running for the presidency; he still thinks he has a shot," Mr. Haytaian said. "Think about it. He spent $37 million to run for president last time; he's spent $15 million this time. After all that, why would he back away to run for the Senate?"
Other than their background and party affiliation, Mr. Forbes and Mrs. Whitman have little in common now. She will complete her final term as governor next year, and has traveled the country trying to raise money and support for Republican moderates. Mr. Forbes has spent much of the last four years courting conservatives, occasionally at the expense of Mrs. Whitman.
A former Republican governor, Tom Kean, who has known both Mr. Forbes and Mrs. Whitman for decades, said it was inevitable that they would go their separate ways once Mr. Forbes acted on his ambitions for national office.
"On the national stage, there's only room for one person from New Jersey," Mr. Kean said. "There's a rivalry that develops, quite naturally. So there's a certain wariness among supporters and friends."
Although both Mr. Forbes and Mrs. Whitman have tried to play down politely any conflict between them, they often display uncomfortable facial expressions when asked about each other.
In the minds of many New Jersey Republicans, young Christie and Steve were indelibly linked at the Republican presidential convention in 1956, which nominated Dwight D. Eisenhower to a second term in the White House. Christie Todd, age 9, and Steve Forbes, age 8, appeared on stage together to present ceremonial gifts to the children of the renominated vice president, Richard M. Nixon.
They attended Far Hills Country Day School in Somerset County together, and were raised in prominent and politically active Republican families in affluent Somerset County and grew up in estates about 10 minutes apart.
Mr. Forbes's father, Malcolm Forbes, was both a successful magazine publisher and an unsuccessful candidate for New Jersey governor. Mrs. Whitman's parents were paragons of Eastern establishment Republicanism, and had close ties to Wendell Wilkie, Dwight Eisenhower and Nelson Rockefeller.
Once they entered politics, their early careers also ran a parallel course. Mrs. Whitman first ran for freeholder of Somerset County in 1982, and worked closely with Mr. Forbes as parks commissioner on a variety of civic boards and community projects, said Ray Bateman, a state legislator and gubernatorial candidate from Somerset County at the time.
"Neither of them were really considered rising stars at the time," said Mr. Bateman, who is now chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, appointed by Mrs. Whitman. "They were participants, bright and enthusiastic, but I don't think anyone then figured that they'd be governor or a presidential candidate. There were other people who appeared far more likely to go places in the party." For an example, he mentioned her brother, Dan Todd.
Mrs. Whitman catapulted above the pack of ambitious Republicans by running for the Senate in 1990, when she came startlingly close to unseating Bill Bradley, a popular incumbent. When she ran for governor against Jim Florio in 1993, Mr. Forbes was one of a handful of advisers who saved her campaign six weeks before the election by persuading her to adopt a proposal to cut income tax rates by 30 percent. Mrs. Whitman reluctantly agreed, won the election and has since made tax cuts a cornerstone of her agenda and her national reputation as a fiscal conservative.
Mr. Forbes's surprise presidential run in 1996 focused largely on his call for a simplification of the income tax system, but some New Jersey analysts thought Governor Whitman stood to gain from his success because they appeared to share much the same ideology.
"Certainly in 1996, people thought they were coming out of the same wing of the party and that Steve Forbes could help her and the moderates outflank some of those conservative Republicans whom they considered fanatical," said David P. Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider University.
Instead, Mrs. Whitman delivered a crushing blow to Mr. Forbes's aspirations by choosing practicality over loyalty and endorsing Bob Dole in the weeks before the 1996 New Hampshire primary.
Relations between them have never quite been the same, party leaders said, even though Mr. Forbes endorsed her for re-election in 1997. He has used her strong support for abortion rights as a way of highlighting his own anti-abortion stand, and urged the Legislature to override her veto of the ban on a late-term abortion procedure opponents call partial birth abortion. Just last month, one of Mr. Forbes's campaign managers described him as a real "Reagan Republican, not some Christie Whitman Republican."
Even today, when Mr. Forbes heard that the governor was skeptical of the Declaration of Independence bill, he pounced on the opportunity to make a point about what he considers the differences in the way he and Ms. Whitman express their devotion to American values.
"If we can't spare a couple of minutes to understand the founding document of this country, then we're in very sorry shape," he said.
The governor has not yet endorsed anyone seeking her party's presidential nomination, but her past references to Mr. Forbes as a kind of moderate gone astray make it seem unlikely she will support him.
"I think he's an extraordinarily bright person when it comes to economic issues," she said. "Obviously, he seems to have changed a bit on social issues from where he was when we were working together."
Mr. Forbes said he fully expected Mrs. Whitman to endorse Gov. George W. Bush of Texas for the nomination, and he playfully promised that he would welcome support from both of them after he captures the Republican nomination himself.
Despite the different political paths Mr. Forbes and Mrs. Whitman have chosen, he said he hoped that they would manage to preserve their lifelong friendship. On issues like abortion, "We do disagree, but we have friendly and civil relations," he said. Then Mr. Forbes added, "We still have them as far as I know."

HEADLINE: At Berlin Wall: The Crumbling, Then and Now

SERIES: ONE EUROPE, 10 YEARS -- After the Wall

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Having guarded the ramparts of East German Communism for 28 years, Harald Jaeger knew his business at the Berlin Wall. So the statement by the Politburo member on television on that night -- Nov. 9, 1989 -- struck him as lunacy.
But the words were clear enough. Gunter Schabowski, representing the Communist state's highest authority, said that East Germans were free to travel "without meeting special provisions" and that the new rule would go into effect "immediately." 
 Mr. Jaeger, then a 46-year-old lieutenant colonel in the East German border guards, almost choked on his sandwich. "On the one hand, I knew what the party said was law," he said recently. "On the other, I was commanding a critical border post, and nobody had alerted us to any change of policy."
A decade later, it is clear that Mr. Jaeger's confusion was widely shared. Virtually nobody predicted the fall of the Berlin Wall, and apparently nobody planned it. At its most sensitive point, the Soviet empire imploded, undone by economic decay and by Mikhail S. Gorbachev's renunciation of the force ultimately needed to hold it together.
As a result, two German states with utterly divergent ideologies and cultures found themselves propelled toward union on the panicky reaction of a border guard, Mr. Jaeger, who opened the gate at Berlin's Bornholmer Strasse crossing, in the absence of instructions about what to do. Some of the effects of that precipitation are still evident today.
Most fundamentally, a united Germany is not quite sure of its identity. "Is Germany a great power?" the weekly magazine Der Spiegel asked this week on the cover of its issue commemorating the 10th anniversary of the wall's fall. The image above the question: a German eagle borne aloft by the Brandenburg Gate's winged goddess of Victory.
Chancellor Gerhard Schroder recently answered the question in the affirmative, calling Germany a "great European power." On one level, even though the country has no nuclear bomb, he is clearly right.
The German economy is one-third bigger than any other in Europe. And a German general now commands allied forces in Kosovo, something unthinkable even five years ago.
But the nature of that power, and of a new German patriotism, is less clear because German unity abruptly brought together in a single state zealous Communists like Mr. Jaeger, mild West Germans eager to escape German identity by calling themselves "Europeans" and some East Germans with strong nationalistic feelings for a united Germany.
What seems evident, a decade after the wall's fall, is that the postwar consensus around the "constitutional patriotism" proposed by the prominent intellectual Jurgen Habermas -- built on values like free speech and the rule of law -- has eroded.
In its place is a jumble. Hans-Peter Muller, a political scientist, said, "The reference point of 'never again' to the Holocaust still exists, but alongside it we have the patriotic nostalgia of those who feel they lost their state in the East, the right-wing radicalism of the frustrated and some conservative attempts to lift German taboos."
The project of the last decade has been the unification of a highly developed Western country that is ashamed of its past and rooted in NATO with a crumbling East German state raised to to see NATO as its mortal enemy. Given the dimensions of the task, difficulties were inevitable. But most Germans now agree that, however great the achievements of the last decade, there were also mistakes.
Among them were the headlong economic reforms that left about 20 percent of eastern Germans unemployed, a failure in the west to come up with gestures to soften the eastern sense of being taken over and the too-easy promises that suggested to eastern Germans that capitalism was a code word for get-rich-quick.
"We have paid for having no plan," said Willi Heidemann, the top administrative official in Jerxheim, a town that once stood just west of the border. "West Germany's Constitution made clear from 1949 that the aim was unification, but it was an aim without a project right up to the last moment. Nobody believed that border would disappear."
Least of all Mr. Jaeger, who became a border guard when the wall went up in 1961 to stanch the flow of 2,000 people a day fleeing to the West.
He believed in socialism; he believed that the people on the western side of the wall were his "class enemy." He considered it the state's right to protect its borders as it saw fit, even after the killing of more than 450 people who had tried to escape.
"I was lucky I was never placed in that situation, but believing what I believed then, I too would have shot anyone trying to flee," said Mr. Jaeger, who now runs a small newspaper store in Berlin. "At the same time, by that night in 1989, I could see that we were directionless, that the leadership had lost control."
Beginning in the summer of 1989, thousands of East Germans had been escaping through Hungary's newly opened borders with the West. In East Germany, on Oct. 18, Egon Krenz eased out Erich Honecker, who had governed since 1971.
Mr. Krenz visited Moscow on Oct. 31 and met Mr. Gorbachev, who made clear that the Soviet leadership opposed German unification, but also opposed any use of force. The people, Mr. Gorbachev said, should not be regarded as an enemy; on the contrary, policies should be found to bring them around.
Accordingly, Mr. Jaeger said, he received instructions several days before Nov. 9 that force should not be used on any account. In the early evening, shortly after Mr. Schabowski's televised news conference, 10 or 15 people gathered in front of Mr. Jaeger, shouting that the party had declared they were free to travel "immediately."
Mr. Jaeger was at a loss. So he called his superior, Col. Rudi Ziegenhorn, to ask what to do. The following conversation, as Mr. Jaeger recalled it, ensued.
"Did you hear that nonsense on television?" Colonel Ziegenhorn asked.
"Yes, that's why I'm calling."
"How many are there in front of you?"
"About 15."
"You know the law -- send them back," the colonel said.
The group of soldiers under Mr. Jaeger's command tried to do just that, but more people kept arriving, and the border guards had no means of coercion.
About a half-hour later, Colonel Ziegenhorn called back, saying the people he described as "provocateurs" -- essentially those shouting loudest -- should be allowed out with the understanding that they would not be allowed to return.
"The idea was to open the valve a little and relieve the tension through what amounted to selective expulsions," Mr. Jaeger said. "But the idea proved disastrous because people got the impression that if they shouted loudly enough, they would be allowed out."
So he called his superior again. Colonel Ziegenhorn had meanwhile spoken to his superior to see if anyone knew what should be done. Apparently no one did.
"Ziegenhorn told me that there were no more orders, nothing else to say," Mr. Jaeger said. "In effect, I was on my own."
By 10:30 p.m., thousands were in the street. The soldiers were urging him to make a decision. "But," Mr. Jaeger said, "that wall was my life. I'd defended it for 28 years. It was not like kicking over a bucket."
For about another 30 minutes, Mr. Jaeger wavered, torn between fear of a violent catastrophe and terror of opening up a wall he regarded as his. He gave the order, shortly after 11 p.m., to open the gates.
"I did not free Europe, or release my people, or any of that nonsense," Mr. Jaeger said. "It was that crowd in front of me, and the hopeless confusion of my leadership, that opened those gates."
Overwhelmed by what he had done, Mr. Jaeger hesitated to call Colonel Ziegenhorn back. But eventually he informed his superior of his decision. "Das ist gut, mein Junge," -- "You did right, young man" -- was the cursory reply.
So ended East Germany, the division of Europe, the cold war, and around the globe, much else that, for good or ill, had depended on the global struggle between capitalism and Communism. Mr. Jaeger's long career as a border guard also ended.
As for millions of eastern Germans, unemployment followed for him and for his wife, and a long struggle to adjust to the values of a society he had long opposed.
Hundreds of thousands of East Germans moved from the east to the west. But an increasing number of western Germans also move to the east. Last year, the Federal Statistics Office reported, 182,000 moved from east to west, 30,000 more than in the opposite direction.
Mr. Jaeger stayed in Berlin, and finally, in 1997, he was able to borrow the money so that he and his wife could start a newspaper store.
"I suppose I'm a capitalist," he said. "I exploit my wife, and she exploits me. That's our capitalism. But I listen to the people in the store worrying about jobs for their children, and I still have my doubts about this system."
He is not alone. "Wir sind das Volk" -- "We are the people" -- was the cry of East German protesters in 1989. Today, a large, sad banner hangs at the Alexanderplatz, the former center of East Berlin, saying: "Wir waren das Volk" -- "We were the people."
Nearby, stalls sell T-shirts emblazoned with the German eagle and the bold word: "Deutschland." Between the nostalgic disillusionment of that banner and the patriotism of that shirt, a united Germany struggles today to define itself.
This article is part of a series on Europe a decade after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Previous articles have looked at key players and at the aftermath for Germany and neighboring countries, and at the lives of Germans who fled and those who stayed behind.

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: Ignoring State Curriculum Caused Poor Scores, Experts Say

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
When New York State announced the poor results of its tough new fourth- and eighth-grade math tests on Friday, the dismay was not confined, as so often in the past, to New York City and other big cities. Many parents, teachers and administrators in the state's wealthiest areas -- where people buy expensive homes thinking that they are also buying outstanding public schools -- were in shock, too.
For decades, residents there had been lulled into a sense of complacency because the state had used a minimum competency test to measure student performance, a test on which children in places like Westchester County and Long Island routinely scored near 100 percent -- so high that there was no statistical room for improvement. 
 That complacency was rudely shattered last week when one out of five children in even the most exclusive suburbs, like Rye, Great Neck and Mamaroneck, failed to meet state standards in eighth-grade math.
What went wrong? parents throughout the state wondered. Was the test asking the wrong questions, or were schools failing to teach what children should know?
From Syracuse to New York City, educators said yesterday that they believed the test itself was not to blame. State officials said that the new test -- far from expecting children to demonstrate an unprecedented level of knowledge -- was actually based on elements of the state curriculum that have been in place for more than 30 years.
The problem, they said was that -- especially in the middle grades -- those standards had never before been tested. And since no one was watching, officials said, teachers felt free to ignore the state curriculum, relying on inadequate textbooks or their own judgment.
"I wasn't surprised," the state education commissioner, Richard Mills, who pushed the State Board of Regents to adopt the new tests, said yesterday.
Judith Rizzo, deputy chancellor for instruction in New York City, where 77 percent of eighth graders failed to meet the new math standards, agreed.
"I know everybody wants to blame the test," Ms. Rizzo said. "But you can't. There's nothing wrong with this test. It's that it measures standards that, across the state, people have not been preparing kids for. And it's that simple."
Stung as they were by the dismal results, some education officials said the test revealed problems that pervade eighth-grade math classes across the country, and not just in New York, including shortages of qualified teachers, early tracking of students and a focus on rote learning rather than understanding.
The lack of testing in middle school also explains why fourth graders did better than eighth graders on the new test, said Lynn Richbart, a mathematics specialist for the state Education Department. Fifty-four percent of eighth graders failed outside New York City, but just 23 percent of fourth graders did (it was 50 percent in New York City).
Since 1965, Mr. Richbart said, the state has tested heavily in third grade through sixth grade, forcing teachers to focus on state standards. But this is the first year that eighth graders have been required to take math tests, he said.
The new tests are in many ways a reaction to the freedom, experimentation and idiosyncratic curriculums that came to characterize American schools in the last generation, educators said. In New York City, curricular unorthodoxy was heightened by decentralization.
The tests, given during the last school year, grew out of a broader re-examination of how students across the nation were being taught math. In 1989, state officials said, the National Council of Mathematics recommended new math standards.
In 1993, New York State, influenced by the council, toughened its own math standards. Five years later, seeing a need to make those standards more concrete, the state put out a new math curriculum for kindergarten through eighth grade. These were the standards used for the latest tests.
Now that the results are out, the next step, Mr. Mills said, is to use those results as a force to improve the curriculum and teaching.
"This is not a pop quiz," Mr. Mills, the education commissioner, said. "We had standards, curriculum, test results. If you don't like the results, what do you do? First of all, you look at what is actually taught in every school in every classroom."
Echoing Mr. Mills, several math teachers said yesterday that the concepts used in the eighth-grade test are not particularly difficult and that the problem is they have too often been taught by rote, or not at all.
Many elementary school teachers, they said, suffer from a kind of math phobia, often brought on by lack of training, that limits them to teaching simple calculation and formulas, without giving students a richer understanding of the abstract concepts the calculations are based on.
Martin Davis, a math teacher in New York City, said that he began the last school year by trying to teach algebra to his ninth graders at Bayard Rustin High School for Humanities in Manhattan. As they asked questions, he said, it became clear that many of them did not know how to multiply two double-digit numbers, and he had to start over.
"Theoretical math, in essence, is really play, it's games," said Mr. Davis, who has since moved to a different school. "If kids don't start playing those games and thinking about them, and thinking about strategies, they miss out on a great opportunity to succeed in seventh- or eighth-grade math."
Dr. Rizzo said she expected scores to improve when the test was given a second time this year. But even if they do not, she said, the city will use the next scores as one factor in determining whether students move to the next grade.
"If the kids don't have the skills and they're not going to succeed at the next grade level, what's the point?" she said.
Like Dr. Rizzo, officials in District 2, one of the city's most successful districts, which runs from TriBeCa to the Upper East Side, believe that teacher training is the key to success on the new test. For the last three years, the district has assigned master teachers to work all year long in classrooms with individual teachers and with groups of teachers.
"You can't teach what you don't know," said Lucy West, director of mathematics for District 2. Fifty-two percent of the district's eighth graders met the math standards, more than double the citywide average.
In a suburban setting, Sherry King, superintendent of Mamaroneck schools, said she chalked up the first year's performance to unfamiliarity with the test and to the problems of children who are in special education or who do not speak English fluently.
The tests, Dr. King said, are just one measure of what schools are doing right. "They don't pay any attention to our rich focus on the arts, to what we're doing in creating community, in keeping our schools from becoming like Columbine; to the growing issues of economic and social diversity."
Mr. Mills said he had little patience with the argument that disadvantaged children could not be held to the same standards as more affluent ones who came to school with more learning from home. In the job market, he said, they would all face the same demands.
"People don't say before we have this job interview, would you please tell me did you come from a good school or a bad school, an advantaged community or a disadvantaged community?" he said.
Susan S. Lewen, the mother of two children in Mamaroneck schools, said that while she took the test scores "with a grain of salt," she could not help but use them to compare schools.
Her son, Michael, now in the fourth grade, is being taught much more sophisticated math than her daughter, now in seventh grade, was taught just three years ago, she said. Michael has become skilled at writing his own mathematical story problems, long the bane of schoolchildren everywhere. He keeps a journal of his thoughts and ideas for English and a similar journal for math.
The schools are teaching to the test, Mrs. Lewen admitted, but to her surprise, she doesn't object. "I thought I might feel badly about it, but I don't," Mrs. Lewen said. "I think to some extent, this test does reflect best practice in the classroom."

HEADLINE: After 40 Years, New York-Havana Flights Will Resume

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO

 BODY:
Almost 40 years after the last Havana-bound commercial airplane took off from a New York City airport, flights between the two cities will resume next month, fulfilling one of the key elements of the Clinton administration's more relaxed policy toward Cuba.
The direct flights are expected to start Dec. 3 from Kennedy International Airport. While it will remain illegal for American tourists to travel to Cuba, the flights will make it easier and faster for the thousands of Cuban-Americans in the New York-New Jersey region to legally visit relatives on the island. 
 It will also ease travel for an increasing number of United States citizens from the Northeast traveling as scholars, journalists or members of religious groups, who are exempt from a provision of the American trade embargo on Cuba that prohibits traveling there. Until now, flying to Havana has required traveling through Miami, the Bahamas or Mexico.
Marazul Charters has been approved by both governments to handle the flights. The company, which has begun selling tickets from its office in Weehawken, N.J., has scheduled one flight per week to Cuba that will leave Kennedy at 8:35 p.m. on Fridays, with a return flight scheduled for before dawn every Saturday.
United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, who called the direct flights "a giant step for America," said he believed the flights would help normalize relations between the two countries and might encourage his colleagues in Congress to move toward lifting the decades-old embargo.
"There is no reason today why we can't trade with Cuba," Mr. Rangel said yesterday at a breakfast sponsored by Marazul Charters. "The more people travel to Cuba and come back with stories that the Cuban people really love us, the better it is."
About 140,000 United States citizens travel to Cuba every year, said John S. Kavulich II, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a New York group that advocates the lifting of the embargo. About 25,000 travel illegally through third countries, he said.
Mr. Kavulich said 92 percent of the people who traveled to the island legally were Cuban-Americans with relatives there. He also said that American business people were increasingly traveling to the island in anticipation that the embargo would be lifted; by the end of this year, he said, 3,000 business people will have traveled to Cuba, 500 more than last year.
Francisco Aruca, president of Marazul Charters, said the bulk of his customers were among the 200,000 Cuban-Americans who live in the New York-New Jersey region, who now must travel to Miami to board a flight to Cuba. The direct flights from New York will be flown by Grupo Taca, an alliance of Central American airlines, and a round trip will cost $629; most of the 150 seats on the first flight have already been sold, Marazul officials said yesterday.
"With these flights we hope to provide needed services, but we are also creating a link between the financial capital of the world and Havana," said Mr. Aruca, who for years has been a loud anti-embargo voice among Cuban-Americans in Miami. "Within the law, we stand ready to facilitate communication between the two countries, in accordance with the new policy of the United States."
Earlier this year, President Clinton announced measures intended to increase contacts between people in the United States and the people of Cuba. They included expanding direct charter flights, allowing more Americans -- not just those with relatives on the island -- to send money to Cubans, establishing direct mail service and permitting the sale of food and agricultural supplies to nongovernmental entities.
The president's initiative was well received by those who oppose the embargo and by many who support it. Some supporters of the embargo, who fear that tourism would amount to economic support for Cuba's Communist leader, Fidel Castro, described the initiative as a sign that the president was committed to keep a tough policy toward Cuba while helping families. Opponents of sanctions said the president's announcement was an opening that could help unite the voices of people asking Congress to lift the embargo.
Armando Collazo, an official with the Cuban Interest Section in Washington, Cuba's only formal diplomatic presence in the United States, said yesterday that the direct flights would contribute to "normalcy in the communications and the relations between Cuban families, here and over there."
But Yvonne Conde, a free lance writer in Manhattan who left Cuba 38 years ago and has never been back, said she feared the flights would facilitate travel to Cuba for those who have no family there.
"Nowadays, anyone can be a scholar," she said. "Anybody can say they are doing research, when in fact it is tourism. I can't condemn anyone who goes to Cuba to see relatives, but I find tourism to Cuba appalling."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1999, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the resumption of direct flights from New York to Havana misstated the views of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council on the American trade embargo on Cuba. The council takes no position; it does not advocate lifting the embargo. The article also misstated the council's statistics on United States citizens who travel to Cuba. The council's president, John S. Kavulich II, estimated that 140,000 U.S. citizens would travel to Cuba this year; he did not say that 140,000 U.S. citizens travel there every year.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: THE BOSS;
Learning atMayor's Knee, Mayor La Guardia's Knee

BYLINE: By David Rockefeller with Richard A. Oppel Jr.; David Rockefeller, the patriarch of perhaps the most influential family business empire of this century, was an unpaid aide to Mayor Fiorello La Guardia in 1940 and 1941.

 BODY:
I was his aide for a year and a half. It was a $1-a-year proposition. I did a variety of things for him, like traveling with him in his big car when he visited a dedication of a big school or Department of Sanitation garages. He also gave me a number of special assignments, which included finding ways to get to La Guardia Airport and how they could increase their revenue by having shops and things like that.
He could change his manner very quickly. I would sit in his office while people would come in. An elderly lady would have a very sad story to report, and he would be extremely considerate and warm, and then some commissioner who had done something he didn't like would come in, and he'd fly into a rage and throw his glasses at him. 
 He could turn on whatever was needed in terms of attitude, depending on who it was. He was very versatile and very charismatic, but he could also be very angry and tough. But basically, I liked him very much. I remember when I got engaged to be married while I was with him, he took us out to Tavern on the Green. It was a nice thing for the mayor to do.
He taught me how to deal with many different people, even though one had no prior connection or background with them. He understood the role and importance of city government, and I think he helped me recognize the extraordinary diversity and complexity of the city and to realize that one was dealing with people of different backgrounds and needs and aspirations, and it was the responsibility of the mayor to be helpful to all those groups.
He was an extraordinarily colorful figure, and he had a sense of the audience he was talking to to a degree I've never seen. He would go to a school or some other gathering without having prepared anything and sense what the audience was interested in, and he'd always get loud applause.
He gave me a feel for the city I wouldn't have otherwise had. What I learned from him was an ability to deal with a broad variety of people. I realized one thing, that the city of New York was a great deal broader than Manhattan Island south of 96th Street.
The Chamber of Commerce for many years dealt mostly with the large businesses downtown; one who wanted to have organization really citywide had to include a large variety of people from many different ethnic and cultural groups and from many parts of the city and many economic levels, and the New York City Partnership a leading business advocacy group Mr. Rockefeller founded does. It was important that a private sector group that wanted to speak for the city was more inclusive. That had been my experience with the mayor.
This was a very good way to get a sense of city government and the relationship of the city to the private sector, and I feel very strongly that many activities should not be handled exclusively by either city government or the private sector.

HEADLINE: Scratching the Popular Itch to Switch Jobs

BYLINE: By CHARLES BUTLER 

 BODY:
Sally Poliak will never forget her political victories. She also never wants to relive them.
For nearly 14 years, starting shortly after graduating from college in 1983, Ms. Poliak was a top Republican Party consultant in Washington State. From her Seattle headquarters, she ran campaigns for offices ranging from county commissioner to member of Congress. She also organized fund-raising events, including several for former President George Bush. Her political high point came in November 1994 when she won $200 in the Hacks and Flacks pool, an election-day wager among political consultants and reporters in the Seattle area, even as more than two dozen state legislative candidates she represented won office. 
 It should have been a dream job. At a young age, Ms. Poliak was making her mark on Republican politics of a large state, quite an accomplishment considering that she had been born into a family of Democrats and that her father, Paul Poliak, was campaign treasurer for Brock Adams, who was a Democratic Senator from Washington. Between campaigns, she had time to ski and travel and once took three months off to go scuba diving in the South Pacific. Best of all, she was her own boss. In 1993, she and a partner started a consulting company, Polis Political Services, and it thrived.
But by the spring of 1996, the political passions that had burned since the early 1970's, when she and her family debated Richard M. Nixon's policies over dinner, began to wane. The repetitiveness of developing strategies, polling voters and tweaking campaign messages had become a grind. So, in April 1997, she left her business, took a pay cut and joined the legions of marketing professionals at the Microsoft Corporation, in suburban Redmond.
"I had burned out of politics," said Ms. Poliak, now 38. "There were no new challenges. It was like, 'I have been to the peak and I'm beginning to slide down the back slope.' I wanted to get out before I became like a lot of my friends who hated their jobs."
Ms. Poliak, join the crowd. As the baby-boom generation ages, the inclination of those in its ranks to strike out in different directions is finding fertile soil in the booming economy. As corporations downsized in the first half of the 1990's, managers and other professionals became used to the idea of switching jobs, albeit by way of the pink slip. Now, with labor shortages forcing employers to beg for help, people with marketable skills are discovering how easy it is to switch their working way of life. "Because the economy is good, people are more verbal about what stresses them and are willing to risk making a change," said Harold Weinstein, a consultant with Caliper Human Strategies Inc. in Princeton, N.J.
Sometimes the motive is to make more money; sometimes it is boredom, or a longing to fulfill a childhood ambition.
For Joe Benigno, it was a transport to his true calling. For 18 years, Mr. Benigno was a food distributor, most recently selling gourmet fare like French jams and British teas to Manhattan supermarkets. But sports was his love, and he was such a regular caller to WFAN-AM, the New York all-sports radio station, that the station's hosts dubbed him "Joe from Saddle River," his New Jersey town.
In 1994, WFAN invited him to come on air for an hour. It was a gimmick, but he was such a hit that eight months later, he was offered a job as host of the station's overnight show. He quit his sales job that day.
"When I was a salesman, all I ever thought about was sports," said Mr. Benigno, 46, who makes about as much as he did in his good years as a salesman. "I knew that some day I had to find my way into it."
Quitting a lifetime vocation for a new line of work was not unheard of a decade or even a century ago, of course. But until recently, lifetime loyalty to the employer was still the ideal, and switching professional gears was often prompted by incompetence or a desire to make more money.
In 1976, for example, Peter Rubolotta ended an eight-year stint as a high school teacher in New Jersey to become a stockbroker at Merrill Lynch. Even though he got an immediate 25 percent raise, to $15,000 from $12,000, friends thought he was making a mistake by giving up his job tenure. "Now everybody tells me I did the right thing," said Mr. Rubolotta, 53, who still works for Merrill Lynch in Florham Park, N.J.
Sometimes, the urge to move on to something new can be overpowering. Ms. Poliak says her lagging interest in political work had made her "lethargic." Her enthusiasm for playing tennis and soccer flagged, she said, and she stopped frequenting jazz clubs that she had haunted for years.
Then, over coffee at a Starbuck's cafe one day in April 1996, she informed her business partner, Stan Shore, that she was going to quit after the fall election, even though she had no idea what she would do next.
In the ensuing months, she rummaged through boxes of high school memorabilia looking for inspiration, and even jotted down lists of things she wanted to avoid in her next career. At the top was the anxiety of meeting payroll and the drudgery of keeping track of billable hours. "That ruled out working in an agency," she said.
Finally, in December, still with no grand aspirations, she took a friend up on a suggestion to seek an interview at Microsoft. A few months later, the company offered her a job, even though she had no experience in technology.
That very lack was almost a plus, to hear Microsoft tell it. "She is smart, likes to learn and is a risk-taker," said Lisa Kelley, her boss. "Changing your career in midlife is risky."
When she started her new job in April 1997, Ms. Poliak left behind her Rolodex of political contacts and photographs that showed her chatting with the likes of Dan Quayle and Barbara Bush. She did not want the relics of her old career to distract her from learning the software acronyms and marketing strategies of her new one.
She proved a quick study; soon, her colleagues were calling her Dr. Poliak, and she developed a new direct-mail program for her division. Eighteen months after she arrived, she was promoted to management.
She has also discovered something else about herself: She is not a morning person. "Politics has 7 a.m. meetings," Ms. Poliak said. "That just doesn't happen here. It is much more civilized."

HEADLINE: FOOTLIGHTS

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:

NEWS
 
Memories of Berlin
 
More than 250 paintings, sculptures, drawings, prints, books, poems, letters, posters and theater memorabilia will go on display beginning on Sunday at the Jewish Museum. Running through April 23, "Berlin Metropolis: Jews and the New Culture, 1890-1918" will focus on a city of rapid economic, social and physical growth at a time when Jews were central to the development of its modern culture. Among the artists represented are Wassily Kandinsky, Oskar Kokoschka, Robert Delaunay and Edvard Munch. 

Global Picture
 
Babar and Celeste will deliver greetings. So will Wallace and Gromit, and Blondie and Dagwood. They won't be alone. Tapping 22 countries, the Museum of Television and Radio in cooperation with the United Nations will present the Eighth International Children's Television Festival beginning on Saturday. On weekends through Dec. 5 in New York and through Nov. 28 in Los Angeles, where the series began last Saturday, the museum will screen outstanding children's programming in an effort to foster cross-cultural awareness.
 
Saving Adelia
 
A serious opera by Donizetti with a happy ending for its heroine will have what is described at its United States premiere when Eve Queler's Opera Orchestra of New York performs it in concert version at 8 tomorrow night in Carnegie Hall. The work is "Adelia," first performed at the Teatro Apollo in Rome in the 1840-41 season and, though well received, something of a rarity afterward. But the Italian lyric soprano Mariella Devia, who recently gave the first performance in modern times in Genoa, will sing the title role at Carnegie Hall in a cast including the bass Paul Plishka, the tenor Warren Mok and the baritone Stephan Pyatnychko. The original plot called for the heroine to leap to her doom from her balcony. But Roman censors forbade depiction of suicide, so Donizetti changed "Adelia" to allow his heroine and her true love to live happily ever after.
 
Hand and Foot
 
Throughout New York City, 41 artists including Christo and Jean-Claude, Andres Serrano, Dale Chihuly, Sandro Chia, Joel Shapiro, Cecily Brown and Damian Loeb will open their studios from 2 to 5 p.m. on Saturday for 13 walking tours that are part of the Fifth Annual Artwalk NY. The daylong event, presented by the Coalition for the Homeless, begins at 11 a.m. with a slide lecture in the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street in SoHo. It ends there with a 6:30 p.m. reception and auction of some 175 donated works of art to benefit the homeless.
 LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

SECTION: Section B; Page 15; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 796 words

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
Does Social Class Matter in School?

BYLINE: By Richard Rothstein 

 BODY:
A DANGEROUS myth was once conventional -- that disadvantaged children could not learn. So poor children were assigned to tracks and taught less challenging lessons. Educators took little responsibility for low achievement, blaming children's poverty and home lives.
Many schools still deliver diluted curriculums to poor and minority children, from whom teachers expect little. 
 Yet there has been a reaction. The New York Regents now insist that children of all backgrounds show similar achievement. Parents today, by a ratio of three to one, tell pollsters that all children should be held to identical standards. We have gone overboard. To counter the earlier myth, we have developed a new, equally dangerous one: that social class no longer matters in education and that all children, regardless of background, can achieve to the same high standards if only schools demand it. We term schools, regardless of who attends them, "successful" if average test scores are above the median (typically termed "grade level" performance), and "failing" if below.
We cannot seriously believe this. Consider how typical middle-class families raise children. Infants' first toys are "touch and feel" books. Toddlers soon "read" stories from memory. Magnetic letters decorate refrigerator doors. Sitting on parents' laps, children "help" compose on computers before they can talk.
These children then attend preschool with equally verbal toddlers. They adopt family assumptions that someday they too will become professionals. Expected to attend college, the only question is how selective it will be.
But other children's homes are without books, magnetic letters or computers. These children have day care, not preschool. Some enter kindergarten not knowing how to hold pencils. Their poorly paid parents are unlikely to have attended college. Television, not newspapers, dominates their homes. In economically and racially segregated neighborhoods, their play and schoolmates have similar experiences.
Do we really expect typical children in poor communities, even in good schools, to achieve just like typical children in schools where most had a middle-class "head start?" In truth, schools with privileged children should be termed failing if they test only at the 70th percentile. Though already well above grade level, they should do even better. A school with many poor children, scoring at the 35th percentile, could be highly successful, though it tests below average. Nothing could be more dangerous to education reform than schemes to reward the first and penalize the second. By labeling all schools in poor communities with below-norm achievement failing (and all suburban schools successful), we paralyze our ability to distinguish good schools from bad.
Demography is not destiny. Some poor children will, with effort, natural ability and good schooling, achieve more than most privileged children. "Rags to riches" stories abound -- some disadvantaged children excel in school and became leaders. But these stories are not universal. On average, with equal school quality, children with more academic support at home will have higher achievement. The power of social class will not disappear if we pretend it does not exist.
Can we avoid the defeatist myth, that schools make no difference, without bouncing to the other extreme, that they make all the difference? From taking too little responsibility, must schools now take too much?
In the 1980's, South Carolina sought a middle ground, holding all schools to higher standards -- but not the same standards. It categorized schools in five bands, based on average poverty, and gave bonuses to the best performers within each band. To win, the best schools serving children of textile-mill workers did not have to outscore schools serving children of urban professionals. Schools were rewarded when teachers evoked higher achievement than was typical in similar communities. The state later abandoned this daring but controversial program. But it was the right idea.
With similar insight, the advocacy group Education Trust this year identified schools where most children were poor, but where scores were higher than in other high-poverty schools. It described practices that might have caused this achievement -- more attention to standards, or better staff training, for example.
Better schools can narrow the gaps between typical achievement of poor and middle-class students. But significant gaps will remain. To figure out how these schools succeed, and to imitate them, we will have to understand the gaps we have closed, not focus only on those that remain. If we want schools to make a difference, we will need more sensible assessments of how much of a difference it can be.

LENGTH: 363 words

HEADLINE: How to Get Paid Not to Work

BYLINE: By Jerry Jasinowski; Jerry Jasinowski is president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Naturally government and employers want to help Americans balance their family lives and their jobs. But the Clinton administration's plan to let states use unemployment insurance money to pay employees on leave after the birth of children is shortsighted, misguided and politically motivated.
Unemployment insurance is a rainy day fund, and during periods of recession like the late 70's and early 80's, it has come perilously close to bankruptcy in some states. It's easy to forget those bad times as we enjoy an unprecedented economic expansion, but it is dangerously myopic to ignore the cyclical nature of our economy. 
 With the number of women eligible to take advantage of paid leave under the Clinton proposal as high as 1.9 million a year, the policy that Mr. Clinton recommends would seriously drain unemployment insurance funds, even without the inevitable economic downturn. And this number does not even consider the significant number of men who could be eligible to collect these benefits as well.
Unemployment insurance is supposed to help keep the unemployed afloat while they look for new jobs. Workers taking leave under the Family and Medical Leave Act are in a different situation altogether. They are voluntarily stepping out of the work force and are entitled to go back to their jobs after three months.
Most manufacturers have adopted programs to help their employees balance work and family life. They have found that flexible scheduling, expanded birth and adoption leave, on-site day care and other programs for parents help boost morale, productivity and retention of employees.
Undermining the unemployment safety net by dipping into what looks like a leftover pot of money during good times is the wrong way to help working parents.
By unilaterally moving forward with this proposal, despite objections from members of Congress, employers and -- most importantly -- state officials who administer the unemployment insurance system, President Clinton has shown that he is more interested in fulfilling old campaign promises to make the family leave law a government-run paid-leave program than in fiscally sound public policy. 
http://www.nytimes.com
