HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Longtime I.M.F. Director Resigns in Midterm

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9

 BODY:
Michel Camdessus resigned today in the middle of his third term as managing director of the International Monetary Fund, setting off a behind-the-scenes struggle involving the Clinton administration and European nations over who will head the agency that is in effect dictating national economic policy from Russia to Indonesia and Africa.
Mr. Camdessus, who has steered the I.M.F. for nearly 13 years through a succession of economic crises, said today that "entirely personal reasons" had prompted his resignation two years before the end of his term. Colleagues said constant travel and a succession of international crises had exhausted him. 
 But in a half-hour conversation in his office here this afternoon, the 66-year-old former French central banker appeared vigorous, telling tales of political intrigue, responding to attacks from conservatives in the United States Congress who had accused him of wasting billions in bailing out Russia, and arguing that his much-attacked prescriptions saved Asia from a far worse economic fate.
And in discussing the fund's growing political impact throughout the world, he acknowledged for the first time that its actions in Indonesia served as a catalyst in forcing out the man who led the nation, the world's fourth most populous.
"We created the conditions that obliged President Suharto to leave his job," Mr. Camdessus said. "That was not our intention," he said, but quickly added that soon after Mr. Suharto's resignation he traveled to Moscow to warn President Boris N. Yeltsin that the same forces could end his control of Russia unless he acted.
Because the I.M.F. has become such a far-reaching political force, the struggle over who will occupy Mr. Camdessus' spacious office, situated halfway between the White House and Federal Reserve headquarters, is likely to be a fierce one. Traditionally, the fund has been run by a European, and for 30 of its 51 years the top job has gone to a Frenchman. Washington has usually had only a bit role in selecting the monetary fund's director because it has sole discretion in choosing the head of the I.M.F.'s much-larger sister institution, the World Bank. The bank focuses on alleviating poverty and promoting development, while the I.M.F.'s mission is economic stabilization, particularly in times of crisis.
All that may change. Europeans appear divided on the question of who should succeed Mr. Camdessus when he steps down in February, and the Clinton administration has signaled that it intends to play a much bigger role in the selection.
"This is a very important decision for the fund at a very important time," a senior Treasury official said tonight. "The stakes are higher now because the fund's profile is so much higher." The official said the United States was looking for a candidate "who will have strong credibility in the markets," and was not necessarily ready to back a European.
Among the top candidates for the job are Caio Koch-Weser, a state secretary of finance in Germany and former managing director of the World Bank, and Andrew Crockett of Britain, who heads the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland. Other possible successors include the current governor of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet, who is scheduled to be the next head of the European Central Bank; Mervyn King, deputy governor of the Bank of England; Nigel Wicks, a top official in the British Treasury, and Horst Koehler, head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
In his nearly 13 years at the fund, Mr. Camdessus earned praise, particularly from American officials, as a knowledgeable political operator who could cajole, wheedle and threaten foreign leaders who were reluctant to enact economic changes.
"Damn right he can be tough," former Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen once said of him, though he added, "Sometimes you have to lean on him real hard to get things done."
But when Washington appealed for help, Mr. Camdessus was almost always there -- particularly in 1995, when an early-morning telephone call from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin with the news that Congress would not back a bailout of Mexico led him to take extraordinary action on his own.
He committed $18 billion without the usual round of negotiations with the board that directs the fund. He later told them, "Gentlemen, I don't ask your permission because you would have to speak with your ministers or governors, and you have no time for that." The bailout worked.
Mr. Camdessus' critics, and they were legion, had many complaints. They viewed him as arrogant -- "I am French," he once said in an interview during the Asian crisis, "and what Frenchmen is not accused of that" -- and far too quick to urge the devaluation of currencies and fiscal austerity. In fact, that is what the I.M.F. did when the Asian crisis started in Thailand and Indonesia, but within months it backed away, restoring subsidies for fuel and rice to contain widening street protests.
In Congress, conservatives complained that the fund wasted billions, particularly with a $17 billion bailout of Russia last year that collapsed in months -- and which has led to continuing investigations into where I.M.F. money went.
Mr. Camdessus repeated today that "the charges are completely unsubstantiated," and said "we must not loose sight of the fact that Russia is now a democracy and a market economy, even if it is blurred by corruption and cronyism, and mistakes in Chechnya."
What undercut some of Mr. Camdessus' credibility on Capitol Hill, where financing for the I.M.F. seems always under attack, was his tendency to act as a public cheerleader for countries in trouble. Speaking of the capital flight from Russia in the spring of 1998, for example, he said: "Contrary to what markets and commentators are imagining, this is not a crisis. This is not a major development." It became one quickly, leading to one of the fund's biggest and least successful stabilization efforts.
Today, Mr. Camdessus said he had become resigned to the idea that Europeans and Asians viewed him as a lackey for the United States -- "they call me a damn U.S. neo-liberal in Europe," he remarked -- while in Congress he is viewed as not doing enough to advance the United States agenda.
"The fact is that the American influence in the I.M.F. is strong, very strong, and for good reason," he said. "America has a systemic vision of the world. The problem is that America does not always put its money where its mouth is. When my countrymen in Europe complain about that, I say that if you had the guts to stand united, you would have more power than the U.S."
And then he ushered a visitor past his collection of sculptures, including one of an Indian goddess who "dances on ignorance and is the force of creative destruction," to a favorite painting. It shows a blur of hands reaching into the pockets of a pinstriped suit. The painting is titled "Sorry, no funds."

HEADLINE: Trump Proposes Clearing Nation's Debt at Expense of the Rich

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Preparing to embark on his first trip as a prospective candidate for president, Donald J. Trump yesterday presented a plan that he said would pay off the national debt, bolster Social Security and slash taxes by billions of dollars. Mr. Trump promised to accomplish all this at no cost to ordinary Americans, by forcing the rich to pay for it.
Mr. Trump, describing the first proposal of his exploratory presidential campaign, said the government should impose a one-time 14.25 percent tax on the net worth of individuals and trusts worth $10 million or more. That would raise $5.7 trillion, he said, enough to pay off the national debt in a single year. And eliminating the debt, Mr. Trump explained, would save the nation $200 billion in annual interest payments, money that he said could be used for tax cuts and ensuring the stability of the Social Security system. 
 The New York developer chose an unusual forum to unveil what he described as a policy cornerstone of his prospective campaign: a rolling series of radio and television interviews. The proposal comes a week before Mr. Trump is to fly to Florida for a series of campaign-style events in Miami, the first of three such trips planned for the next month.
"The phones are going off the hook," Mr. Trump reported, as he combined a discussion of his economic ideas with a description of what he called the public's giddy reaction to his foray into economic policy-making. "I've never seen anything like this. Do you make Page 1 with this one?"
As a matter of politics, Mr. Trump's proposal -- simple in its concept and framed in populist terms -- seems aimed directly at the people who have supported the Reform Party since Ross Perot first called it to arms with, among other things, a call to wipe out the national debt. Mr. Trump, should he run, said he would seek to become the Reform Party's candidate for president.
It also had the advantage of lessening any liability Mr. Trump might believe he could suffer because of his own reputation as a man of wealth. The developer put his own net worth at $5 billion, and said that under his plan, he would owe $750 million in taxes (though his estate would ultimately profit if another part of Mr. Trump's plan were enacted: the repeal of the estate tax, which can be as high as 55 percent).
Mr. Trump's plan met a response that ranged from incredulity to ridicule from a number of economists yesterday. They suggested that a 14.25 percent tax would be impossible to get through a Republican-controlled Congress that championed a $792 billion tax cut this year. Beyond that, they said that even if it passed it would be problematic to measure net worth and then to tax it.
"I don't think the plan makes much economic sense," said Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the libertarian Cato Institute. "The fact is that most people's wealth that has been built up over 10, 20 or 50 years is wealth that has already been taxed."
Mr. Trump's main opponent for the Reform Party nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan, offered a harsher assessment of Mr. Trump's plan. "This is serious wacko stuff," Mr. Buchanan said by telephone from Albany.
Mr. Buchanan predicted that Mr. Trump's plan would cause the wealthy to move their holdings beyond the reach of the Internal Revenue Service. "I can't think of a better idea to cause capital flight out of the United States," Mr. Buchanan said.
Mr. Trump said he had come up with the idea on his own and worked out its details with private economists. He declined to name them.
He rejected criticism of his idea, demanding: "Where is Gore's plan? Where is Bradley's plan? Where is Bush's plan? They don't exist."
Still, it was clear that some parts of Mr. Trump's proposal remained unformed. For example, of the $200 billion in interest costs that would be saved, he said he would apply half to the Social Security system and the rest to tax reduction.
Mr. Trump said that $20 billion of that would pay for eliminating the inheritance tax. Asked how he would allocate the rest, he responded: "All different taxes across the board. That would be determined and worked out."

HEADLINE: Investigation of State Development Agency Focuses on L.I. Land Deal

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Nearly two dozen developers eagerly set their sights on the old Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in 1997 when the state offered to sell the property -- the largest tract of undeveloped land on Long Island.
Companies from as close as Brentwood and as far as Montreal thought the tree-lined 560-acre parcel, which straddles the Long Island Expressway and the Sagtikos Parkway in Islip, was a potential gold mine, ideally suited for housing, retail space and office buildings. 
 In one instance, Miromar Development spent $1 million and more than two years developing a proposal. Jerry Wolkoff, who owns an industrial park adjacent to Pilgrim, worked for about a year on his proposal, while Mentmore Development put in a month on its bid.
But it was only 10 days before the bids were due last November that another, final entrant into the competition for the valuable chunk of land surfaced. Reckson Associates Realty, a large, publicly traded real estate investment trust based in Melville, joined the fray with an 11th-hour offer.
Barely a month later, Reckson was declared the winner, its $32 million package deemed the worthiest by the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency handling the sale.
The announcement, however, did not end the process so much as it began another: the losing bidders began to complain that Reckson had prevailed unfairly, and in recent months they have made their complaints to the Manhattan district attorney.
One losing participant has told the authorities that he believed that Reckson had obtained inside information about the rival offers, which enabled the company to produce a winning bid and suggested that the improper assistance resulted from Reckson's partner, Louis R. Cappelli, and his political ties and contributions to state Republicans.
Another prospective buyer, Miromar, has told prosecutors that the company found it unusual, given the state agency's wide latitude to reopen the bid process, that the economic development corporation had rejected its final $35 million offer because it had been submitted three days late.
Officials with Reckson, who maintained that their proposal won on its merits, said they were mystified by the complaints.
"It doesn't make any sense," Donald Rechler, the chairman of Reckson, said of the complaints. "We're not political animals."
For months, the Manhattan district attorney's office has been trying to determine whether political favoritism has played a role in the Empire State Development Corporation's awarding of a handful of economic incentive packages, and the sale of the Pilgrim hospital land is one of those deals.
Bidders and state officials have been interviewed; documents have been subpoenaed. The travel and business dealings of the agency's chairman, Charles A. Gargano, have also been examined as part of the broad investigation.
The state agency has refused to discuss the sale publicly other than to say it was entirely justified. And in an effort to close the deal with Reckson by the end of the year, two state officials said that the agency recently took the unusual step of hiring an outside law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, to review the bidding process.
Ordinarily, concerns about wrongdoing by state employees are referred to the state inspector general. But the inspector general, according to the state officials, has been working with the district attorney on his investigation of the economic development agency.
So far, both the inspector general and the district attorney have refused to discuss the inquiry in any detail.
"The privatization of Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center was right and proper in every way," Maura Gallucci, a spokeswoman for the state agency, said in a written statement, "and as a demonstration of our confidence, we have hired Skadden Arps to complete a thorough, objective and independent review of the transaction."
Neither Mr. Gargano, who oversaw the Pilgrim sale, nor John Buttarazzi, a senior vice president directly responsible for the bidding process, returned calls requesting comment.
But at least two other bidders say that the Pilgrim tract should be put up for sale again.
"They should just reopen the process and have open bidding," said Mr. Wolkoff, a Long Island developer and a finalist in the bidding.
Pilgrim State was not only the largest, but also the most valuable of the 12 former psychiatric centers that the state put up for sale. Unlike many of the other properties, Pilgrim State has good highway access and sits near several desirable communities in Suffolk County, where housing prices are high.
Built in 1930, Pilgrim State was part of a network of sprawling state psychiatric centers that Gov. George E. Pataki has sought to sell now that they are considered obsolete. About 84 dilapidated buildings would be demolished, although a small psychiatric center would continue to operate on a separate parcel.
But attempts to sell or redevelop the property over the last 20 years as a state prison, juvenile detention center or regional incinerator have met with fierce local resistance. This time, the state set up a task force, which eventually recommended a variety of sports and entertainment-related uses, as well as housing for the elderly and a small amount of light industry.
The recommendations were in no way binding on a potential buyer, although any developer would have to obtain zoning and environmental approval from the local towns.
"It's a very valuable parcel because it lends itself to multi-use development," said David Pannetta, a vice president with Oxford & Simpson, a real estate broker based on Long Island.
The state agency formally issued invitations to bid in July 1998 and required prospective buyers to submit their offers by Nov. 16. The bidding documents did not require the state to accept the highest bid, a condition that would allow the state to sell the property to a developer who offered a plan favored by local towns, but not necessarily the highest price. It did require that all proposals be cash-only bids.
Long aware of the pending sale, Margaret Miller, the president of Miromar, which is based in Montreal, said the company had spent nearly three years devising a proposal for the Pilgrim site and meeting with civic leaders and local and state officials, including Mr. Gargano. Miromar envisioned a combination of museums, hotels, a sports complex, golf course and an amusement park.
That is not to say that Miromar's plans had met with universal acceptance.
"It was way out of proportion, which would not have sat well with the communities," said Laura Mansi, a local civic leader and chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals in Huntington.
But in contrast with Miromar's protracted approach, Mr. Rechler said Reckson did not decide to bid on Pilgrim until Nov. 6. Since Reckson specializes in industrial and commercial buildings, he said he sought out a partner who was active in residential development. He ultimately turned to Mr. Cappelli, a developer and prominent Republican contributor who had sold his office portfolio in Westchester to Reckson last year for $183 million.
Mr. Rechler said he signed a two-page agreement with Mr. Cappelli, but it was Reckson that submitted the formal proposal to build a combination of housing, office and industrial projects. The plan has not been released by the state, but Reckson has promised to work with local communities.
"This all happened within a 10-day period," Mr. Rechler said. "We went to a number of residential and retail guys. Cappelli was the only one who stepped up and sent a deposit check."
Mr. Cappelli, whose companies and relatives have contributed more than $85,000 to Republicans since early 1995, is also involved in a state-subsidized project to redevelop downtown New Rochelle, a project that is also being scrutinized by the district attorney. Mr. Cappelli did not return calls requesting comment.
About 20 developers submitted bids in November and, according to the bidders, four of them -- Miromar, Reckson, Mr. Wolkoff and Mentmore Holdings in New York -- were selected as finalists and asked to make second, presumably higher, offers on Dec. 3.
One bidder has told investigators that he concluded the sale was being conducted improperly after he learned from another person involved in the bidding that Reckson knew the amount of his offer before the final deadline and while the offers were supposedly secret. He complained that Mr. Cappelli had secured the deal because of his political contributions to Republicans.
"Another bidder knew what I was offering," said the developer, who spoke only on the condition that he not be named. "It was disheartening."
Mr. Rechler insisted that his company did nothing wrong and was cooperating with investigators.
In the end, Mentmore, which had bid $52 million and proposed a combination of housing for the elderly, a regional shopping center, a golf course and entertainment complex, was disqualified because its offer contained a number of contingencies that did not conform to the state's bidding guidelines.
The company also submitted a $35 million offer, but it, too, had a number of contingencies.
Mr. Wolkoff, who proposed to build warehouses, office buildings and housing for the elderly, pushed his offer up to $25 million. That left Miromar, which raised its bid, to $28.1 million from $21.5 million, and Reckson, which came in at $32 million.
According to a person who has reviewed the bidding, Reckson offered to put up $16 million in cash, while Mr. Cappelli offered a $16 million letter of credit.
Three days after the December deadline, Ms. Miller said she sent a letter to the development corporation increasing her offer to $35.5 million, after reviewing her projected demolition costs, but still unaware of the opposing bids. Ms. Miller, who met with investigators in New York in July, said she had since given her letter and other documents to the district attorney.
Executives at the state agency told investigators that the new offer from Miromar ignited a debate among Mr. Gargano, Mr. Buttarazzi and others within the agency. Some executives said that it would be unfair to the other bidders to accept an offer that came in after the deadline, while others argued that it would be a mistake to leave the extra $3 million from Miromar on the auction block.
Ms. Miller contends that the agency had reopened the bidding in December, after initially setting a single deadline, Nov. 16. Indeed, the state's bidding documents specified only one round of bidding, but preserved the state's right to do just about anything in the disposition of the property.
"They could've reopened the bidding 10 times to get it right," Ms. Miller said. "There was no limit."
Mr. Rechler is as confident as the agency that the deal for Pilgrim will go forward. He said the state was finishing up several details relating to the sale, which he expects to complete soon. "It's all pretty much cleared up now," Mr. Rechler said.
Skadden Arps's review of the deal is expected to last four weeks.
David R. Binswanger, the president of Chesterton Blumenauer Binswanger, the Philadelphia real estate company hired by the state to market the Pilgrim property and 11 other parcels, said the state was merely being diligent.
"It's the largest parcel, and the one that people are squawking about the most," Mr. Binswanger said. "I think this is a very clean deal."

HEADLINE: Web Search Group Loses Grant

BYLINE: By GEORGE ROBINSON 

 BODY:
THE SCOUT REPORT, a highly regarded publication that monitors the Internet for new and useful research resources, is facing a loss of financing when its three-year grant from the National Science Foundation runs out next spring.
Not that the foundation is displeased with the report; it is "quite pleased," said George Strawn, acting executive officer of the foundation's directorate of computer and information sciences and engineering. "We typically fund a project for two to three years and, when it concludes, it is not extended," Dr. Strawn said. 
 Operating as a part of the computer science department at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, The Scout Report, which comes out weekly on Friday afternoons, highlights about 20 Web sites of interest to the research and education communities. In addition, the report also publishes editions twice a month for science and engineering, social sciences, business and economics, and sites for schoolchildren in kindergarten through 12th grade.
Unlike search engines, The Scout Report is highly selective in its choice of Internet resources, checking each for currentness, reliability and ease of access.
"There are currently 30,000 direct subscribers to the list," Susan Calcari, the report's creator and director, wrote in an e-mail. "But we know it is forwarded on many times and that some of the subscriptions are actually 'exploder' lists which include many individuals in various departments or organizations."
The subject-specific reports have a total of about 45,000 subscribers. And the Web site (scout.cs.wisc.edu), which archives all the reports and includes an easy-to-use database of all the covered Web sites (www .signpost.org/signpost), records more than 45,000 hits daily.
The loss of the science foundation money will result in an annual shortfall of about $400,000. To make up for the loss, The Scout Report editors and staff will pursue grants from nongovernment sources. They are also considering working with commercial organizations that may want to be sponsors in return for recognition in the reports.
On Oct. 6, the report sent a survey to subscribers, asking for suggestions on new sources of financing. Ms. Calcari said that there were 3,000 responses "filled with examples of how the filtered content of the Scout reports allow users of all ages and all walks of life to enjoy the best of the Internet."
Joseph J. Mattie, a library development specialist in the New York State Department of Education, forwards the report to 45 directors of school library systems. "We don't have the staff to spend the hours it takes to analyze Web sites and make recommendations," he said. "This material comes from a higher-education environment, so it's reliable."
The Scout Report has also proved helpful for a user with a more narrowly defined objective. Rita Jo Jordan edits and publishes Analytical Consumer, a monthly newsletter that evaluates instruments used by analytical chemistry laboratories. "I find the items on the environment, waterways and wetlands extremely useful," Dr. Jordan said. "With a search engine I have something specific in mind. The Scout Report tells me about things I wouldn't have thought to look for."
Ms. Calcari is concerned that the Report continue to be free.
"The focus of our project," she said, "has always been to improve resource discovery on the Internet and to reach as many educators, students, librarians and lifelong learners as possible. Attempting to charge for the publications would be counter to these goals."

HEADLINE: Getting Personal in Prime Time;
Creators of TV Shows Tap Their Lives

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Two years ago Betsy Thomas, a television writer, checked into the Chateau Marmont hotel in West Hollywood in the aftermath of a divorce. On her first evening there she called room service for a bottle of wine when friends visited. The waiter, an unemployed actor, arrived with the tray.
One thing led to another. Ms. Thomas not only married the actor, Adrian Wenner, but also turned the experience into a television comedy series, "Then Came You," creating it with Jeff Strauss. The show is scheduled to make its debut on ABC early next year. 
 "Writing about your own life keeps you honest," said Ms. Thomas. "And let's face it, truth is often stranger than fiction."
With the network television audience shrinking and network executives acknowledging that no one is quite sure anymore what viewers want, television writers have turned inward to create a surprising number of shows that reflect their personal lives, most of them funny, but some painful too.
At least 10 new shows that either began this fall or are set to be shown next year are based on the writers' experiences. The dramatic fodder includes being abandoned as a child by a father who returns years later; entering the dating game after a divorce; coping with a strong-willed mother; life as a high-school geek, and being a gay man living in a Brooklyn apartment with straight roommates.
And then there's Ms. Thomas, who is fully tapping into her often embarrassing experiences while dating Mr. Wenner. (The two were married in May.)
"He's seven years younger, and he looks really young," said Ms. Thomas, who is 33. "I've been asked if he's my son, my nephew, my little brother. And I don't look old! When we got our marriage license in Chicago, the woman asked our date of births. I told her mine, and he told her his -- which is 1973 and terrifying. She just stopped and raised an eyebrow at me and went back to her writing. My first reaction was, 'I'm not a cradle robber.' My second reaction was anger."
For years writers and creators have used television to mirror their lives. Two of television's most successful series, "I Love Lucy" and "Seinfeld," were based to some degree on the lives and idiosyncrasies of their creators. On the other hand, Steven Bochco ("N.Y.P.D. Blue") and Dick Wolf ("Law and Order") have never worked as police officers or prosecutors, and Norman Lear ("All in the Family") is hardly a working-class family man from Queens.
Yet this year shows based on personal experience are unusually abundant, and no one seems fully sure why, though many note that networks are searching for something -- anything -- to distract audiences from cable or the Internet.
"When writers are able to draw on their own life experiences and find comedy within those experiences, and the comedy rings true, that often creates a very compelling program," said Lloyd Braun, co-chairman of the ABC Entertainment Television Group.
Networks sometimes go out of their way to find writers whose lives reflect the ones they are creating, especially for shows about families. "An office show is one thing," said Garth Ancier, president of NBC Entertainment. "We've all worked in offices and you can observe the human dynamics, but it's difficult to do stories about parenting if you don't have kids."
Similarly, Alan Ball, the creator of "Oh Grow Up," a comedy series on ABC about a gay man and his straight roommates in Brooklyn, said writers have more empathy and passion for a show that springs from personal experience.
"What you're ultimately doing is creating a stylized version of life," said Mr. Ball, who also wrote the screenplay for the film "American Beauty." "We're definitely looking to base the arc of the show on very real things, some of which I've experienced," said Mr. Ball, who is gay and shared an apartment in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn from 1986 to 1994. "But the gay guy does not fully represent me; I don't look like him, I didn't get married like him, I'm not a lawyer like him and he's much more conservative than I am."
In "Sammy," an animated show with a serious spin, which is to have its premiere early next year on NBC, the comedian David Spade deals with "your textbook deadbeat dad," the character Sammy, who abandons his wife and three young sons and later moves back into the life of one of the sons, who has become a successful comedian.
"The core of the show is pretty true," said Mr. Spade, who also stars in the NBC comedy "Just Shoot Me." "It gets touchy for me. It's close to home. I keep thinking, 'Do I really want people to know about this?' It's a fine line."
One reason for doing "Sammy," Mr. Spade said, was that he wanted to create something semiserious about growing up without a father and about a mother burdened with two jobs and caring for three boys. The network and Mr. Spade are convinced that because divorce affects almost half of American children, the show could touch a large audience.
But Mr. Spade also made clear that he wants to exorcise some personal demons. At one point in the show Sammy is tossing a football with his grown son. "You got your arm from me," says Sammy. His son replies, "All I got from you is alcoholism and a fear of commitment."
There is NBC's "Freaks and Geeks," about two cliques of high school outcasts in the 1980's, created by Paul Feig, 37, and Judd Apatow. "I fell squarely in the geek category," said Mr. Feig, a longtime television comedy writer who attended Chippewa Valley High School in Mount Clemens, Mich. "I was a big, lanky, awkward kid. All my extremities developed before the rest of me. I was the kid who knew how to fix the movie projectors and get things in focus. I think I had one date in high school."
Mr. Feig said: "The only way I can make something 100 percent honest is taking from my own life. It's also more fun to write that way, more cathartic."
Other sitcoms and dramas based on personal lives include an ABC series about the aftermath of divorce, "Once and Again," which reflects the experiences of one of its creators, Marshall Herskovitz, and CBS's highly successful "Judging Amy," in which the actress Amy Brenneman plays a newly appointed judge in Hartford who tangles with her forceful mother, played by Tyne Daly.
Ms. Brenneman's mother, Frederica S. Brenneman, has been a judge for 30 years in courts in Connecticut and is a technical adviser to the show. "The relationship between my character and Tyne Daly was very much mirrored on my relationship to my mother," Ms. Brenneman said. "Sometimes it gets complicated. At the end of the day we're making a fictional piece, but there are moments that are tricky for both of us."
She said with a laugh, "I don't think any secrets have been told."
Ms. Brenneman, who was formerly on "N.Y.P.D. Blue," said that she grew up listening to her mother's stories about court cases. "When you write from your own story it's so much more quirky than any fiction can be," she said. "You have an endless supply from which to draw. It's so specific. It's just better stuff."
Another highly promoted show, NBC's "Third Watch," about police officers, paramedics and firefighters, is based on the experiences of Edward Allen Bernero, a former Chicago policeman who worked on the police show "Brooklyn South" and is the co-creator and co-producer of the new series with John Wells.
"The characters on the show are me and the people I know," Mr. Bernero said. "We haven't had to invent a lot. It's natural."
He said viewers no longer accept traditional police dramas on television because of the influence of reality-based shows like "Cops" and Mr. Bochco's shows like "N.Y.P.D. Blue." "If you tried to do a 'Starsky and Hutch' today people wouldn't accept it," said Mr. Bernero. "They've been on the inside too much."
The personal approach is hardly restricted to network television. There is also the successful half-hour series "Oh Baby" on the Lifetime cable network, which is about a single working woman who has a child through artificial insemination. The comedy is based on the experiences of Susan Beavers, its creator and executive producer. Ms. Beavers, a veteran television writer, said that after taking 18 months off to spend with her baby, returning to work was difficult.
"I knew that in order to get back to work I'd have to write something," she said. "I tried to deal with what I knew -- how to tell a boyfriend that you're artificially inseminated, the logistics of it, hiring a nanny, going back to work for the first time with the baby at home, getting a kid into a prenursery, which meant for me joining a church and getting baptized, which I did."
Ms. Beavers, whose son is 4, said that writing about what she knew was far more honest and artistically truthful than creating scripts involving issues about which she knew little. "I wrote a show for Tony Danza where he was a police officer in Hoboken," she said. "I don't know anything about Hoboken or police officers. Why was I on that show?"

LENGTH: 1530 words

HEADLINE: GUY DECOR;
. . . And Committing to His Decorator

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
ON the day that Jerry Seinfeld was announcing his engagement to Jessica Sklar, a Tommy Hilfiger publicist, her former husband, Eric Nederlander, was closing on his new Lafayette Street loft and contemplating his future -- with a decorator.
For Mr. Nederlander (whose friends are eager to fix him up with a woman to help him forget that Ms. Sklar left him for Mr. Seinfeld three weeks after their honeymoon in 1998), it's design first, dating later. 
 And that means at a safe geographic distance from his recent Upper West Side past. "I have to feel comfortable in my surroundings," said Mr. Nederlander, 34, a Broadway producer, whose 3,000-square-foot home boasts a giant wrap terrace and David Bowie as a neighbor. He wants a serious television system with surround sound. He wants artwork that's "nice," but beyond that? So he's talking to William Sofield, the designer of the SoHo Grand Hotel.
"I want to hire someone I trust," he said wistfully. "And let them do whatever they want."
That may be why someone like Todd Romano, a decorator on the Upper East Side, said: "I'm seeing younger and younger men decorating. They are not waiting to get married to do this stuff."
Mr. Romano has been decorating homes for more than seven years, from New York to Texas. In that time, as the economy soared and the pleasures of home design began to be touted in upstart magazines like Wallpaper, the tastes of the young men requesting his services became more sophisticated.
"Men want to have the best-looking girlfriends, the best-tailored duds, the shiniest cars," he said. "They may not say, 'I want a Louis XV period room,' but they know they want to live well."
Which means out with the futons and college sports trophies and in with what Mr. Romano called the "James Bond meets the Rat Pack lounge look." At the turn of the century, the ultimate arm candy is not a supermodel; it's a bachelor pad that is masculine but says, "I have style and taste."
So what do single men want? Gadgets like flat screen televisions, big pulsating shower heads, terraces full of greenery so their dogs will be comfortable. What they don't want is a girlfriend involved in the designing. "If you let girls buy sheets and towels or pick out furniture, that's letting them get their tentacles into you," said Andrew Feldman, 43, a sports doctor with a freshly decorated apartment.
So altar-shy men go for the vow-free alternative: a decorator. All the comforts of home (tasteful, too) without your girlfriend telling you what to do (or moving in). "Look, you never know if the girl will last through the 14-week delivery date on the couch," one bachelor said. "So why bring her?"
Though Dr. Feldman's apartment at the Eldorado was ill equipped, and furnished "with some of my grandmother's furniture and one towel," he shied from girlfriends' offers to upgrade his surroundings. That seemed too much involvement. Instead, he committed to a decorator, though he worried about things like "boopy" curtains. He ended with exactly what he wanted: sofas long enough to lounge on, a steam shower and a spot for a six-foot statue he dug up in Tanzania. It's in the entrance hall, warding off evil spirits (and perhaps girlfriends interested in improving his surroundings). If a woman buys sheets for a man, she may want to sleep between them, Heaven forbid, forever.
Single men decorating an apartment seem to come equipped with a built-in Tanzanian statue that wards off blithe spirits bearing copies of Elle Decor and visions of connubial bliss. Decorators and designers in New York are reaping the benefits of the male fear of commitment in an age of haut decor.
Pamela Sicher, a New York psychiatrist, blames the rise in divorce figures for a growing fear of commitment among her male patients. "The majority of today's 20-year-olds and 30-year-olds are coming out of families where at least one divorce took place, and there is not as much confidence in home and hearth," she said, adding that while some of her patients marry young or "prematurely nest," others "avoid dependence of any kind by seeking to acquire homes by paying for them."
Other men say they are waiting as long as possible before making a commitment, to assure themselves that something better won't come along, said Dr. Robert Welber, a couples therapist in Manhattan.
A single man will gladly hire a woman as a decorator, however, as long as her taste is nothing like his mother's. Brad Miller, 36, the chief operating officer of an entertainment and technology company, wanted his new 1,700-square-foot loft on Thompson Street to be comfortable. Friends suggested that he consider Nancy Pearson, a decorator he met last summer in a Hamptons share house.
"I never thought I'd be the type of guy to hire a decorator," Mr. Miller said. "I'm someone who likes to roll around in the mud playing rugby. Hiring a decorator sounds slighty pretentious and even a little feminine." (He equated it with men who watch polo.)
Ms. Pearson asked him, "What's your taste?" He looked around the share house, filled with English country furniture, and said, "This, I guess."
He was a dream client, she said. At least at first, because he didn't care. Then, warming to the design possibilities, he insisted on the emblem of swinging Manhattan bachelorhood, a black leather sofa, but "she had the clout to steer me in a different direction and let me see the light," he said, adding, "It's not like I had a taste."
Eventually, she persuaded him to embrace a white chenille sofa. Still, he did want functional furniture, so she got an old laundry table for a dining room table, wooden chairs and a bench. It is all very English country in effect, though Mr. Miller usually keeps the bench stuffed with in-line skates, instead of cricket bats. Emboldened, Mr. Miller went to an antiques fair, bought two French Art Deco chairs "and put them in my English country living room," Ms. Pearson fumed. "I was sick over it," she said.
Despite the intrusion, the apartment, which cost Mr. Miller more than $75,000 to finish, is surviving. "I've done a lot of single guys' apartments," Ms. Pearson said, plainly wary of leaving guys to their own devices. Men, it seems, do not know when to let well enough alone. Soon after finishing the job, Ms. Pearson stopped by to discover that Mr. Miller had installed an exercise area, complete with a Bowflex machine with power rods, next to the kitchen.
"Oh, nice," she said. "It reminds me of a torture chamber."
At least the exercise area was Mr. Miller's idea, not the result of an inamorata's meddling. Mary Meehan, an Upper East Side decorator, will not even take a job from a single man. She is certain that behind every seemingly independent guy is a girlfriend, serious or not. "See, if there is a woman involved, she should be involved, because you're going to be working against her without even knowing it," she said.
Consider one of her recent clients, a 40-something divorced doctor who hired Ms. Meehan to decorate a 4,000-square-foot house in Westchester County. Ms. Meehan, an Architectural Digest alumna whose average job costs about $500,000, shopped for comfortable furniture and picked bright colors for the walls.
Six months into the job, she asked the painter why the colors she had chosen were not being put on the walls. The painter said the doctor's girlfriend (that was the first Ms. Meehan had heard about a girlfriend) wanted different colors. A week later, the decorator was fired.
"Girls, you can't question their taste," said Jeff Burroughs, 33, the vice president of BadBoy Entertainment, a company founded by Sean (Puffy) Combs. "They take it personally." So Mr. Burroughs hired Shawna Chow to make his 2,000-square-foot loft on Nassau Street into "a sexy space." A spiritual one, too, with candles everywhere. ("She took my love for candles to another level," he said.) And a social place, where he could "have cool little dinner parties," befitting someone who made Manhattan File magazine's "100 Most-Wanted Bachelors" list. Mr. Burroughs said he had very strong feelings about one room in particular. "The bed was very important," he said.
A woman who was his house guest last weekend said of his four-poster: "It will change when you get married. Look, no woman wants to sleep where other women have been."
Mr. Burroughs quickly changed the subject to toys, specifically one he still didn't have in his arsenal of special effects: the remote control that Mr. Combs has, which will turn down the lights and fire up the CD player simultaneously. "I can't have everything that Puffy has," he said. "But I have to get that."
One young man on the Upper West Side who has hired a male decorator but asked not to be identified, spoke of the relationship nuances that can occur in bringing a date on decorating excursions. Not so much nuances, mind you, as potential threats.
"You wouldn't want a date you're taking out to see you buy a $20,000 rug," he said. "They'll think if you spend $20,000 on a rug you walk all over and will last you five years max, then you'll easily spend $100,000 on a ring she'll wear the rest of the life."

PUB-DATE: November 11, 1999

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 3; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1514 words

HEADLINE: GUY DECOR;
Iron John Is Buying Throw Pillows . . .

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IF you accept the rule of thumb that anything three inches above the floor constitutes furniture, then Charlie Himmelberg, who is single and lives in a four-room apartment on the Upper West Side, owns six pieces: a futon, a bookshelf, a television stand with a television, a coffee table, a folding canvas patio chair and a pressed-wood kitchen table that a girlfriend gave him.
"Does my electric keyboard count?" asked Mr. Himmelberg, 36, a professor of finance and economics at Columbia University. The keyboard has the dining room to itself. His mother sent him the patio chair after she visited the apartment, where he has lived for five years, because there was no place to sit. 
 Mr. Himmelberg is letting nature run its course.
"I'm still single," he said. "I could spend a ton of money, then get married to someone who doesn't like the stuff."
Until he married, had a baby and bought a six-bedroom house in New Jersey, Kevin Smith, 29, whose 1994 film "Clerks" chronicled the adulthood dilemmas of two single young men and whose new film, "Dogma," opens tomorrow, lived a similar life.
"The television was the most important piece of furniture in the house," Mr. Smith said.
But there are indications that men, notoriously resistant to the idea of buying furniture for themselves, are losing their fear of furnishing. And no, they're not buying it with beer-cap coupons.
New furniture shopping formats like the Internet, retail stores friendly to both sexes, like Pottery Barn and Restoration Hardware, and a changing social attitude are helping men get in touch with their furnishing side.
"The received wisdom has always been that women are the major purchasers," said Lee Brown, an analyst with Rosenthal & George, a market research company in Atlanta. Industry sources have put the figure as high as 95 percent. "We have discovered that this may be a thought that's 10 years old," she said.
In a September report, the company found that men have become an almost equal buying force. Single men accounted for 19 percent of the purchases, single women, 28 percent and couples making joint purchases, 53 percent. "Though 81 percent of the furniture purchases involved women, 72 percent involved men," Ms. Brown said. "It's now almost neck and neck." She explained that the men making the greatest impact were 25 to 34.
"They have opinions about style, they're marrying later and they're often at a higher discretionary income level at a younger age," Ms. Brown said. "So they have to feather the nest themselves."
The Internet, with a population of 97 million and a projected $92 million in furniture and housewares sales this year, may be the big icebreaker between men and furnishing. Edmund Wise, a design consultant available by an "800" number for Furniture.com, the Internet's most heavily visited furniture site, said of men who call, "They talk about how embarrassed they are about the way they live."
Roughly half of Furniture.com's 722,000 visitors in September were men; half of Mr. Wise's callers were also men.
"Single men used to be the rarest category in furniture retail," he said, speaking of seven years' experience as a furniture-store salesman. "On the Internet, they're typical."
Besides the convenience of shopping online, "men are saying, 'Help me,' " Mr. Wise said.
"I worked in a high-traffic store," he continued. "Two thousand people came through in a month. I never had one guy talk to me about color in seven years. Now, on the phone, they all want to talk about color." It's refreshing, he said: "It's like people who start painting in their 50's."
Ben Hansen, design service manager for Living.com, another large furniture site, said that half of its sales were to men. "They're going for the higher tickets, too," he said.
According to a September report published by NetSmartAmerica .com, which analyzes the e-commerce market, men represent 49 percent of the visitors to furniture sites. Eleven percent are single.
And retailers are playing to the figure, online and off.
"George, tell us about your first time," says the voice-over in a Furniture.com television advertisement. George, a single male, is also a cat. "I'll never forget it," he replies. "So inexpensive. So easy." Sounds like "a good date," the voice says, with male approval. No, George answers, he was shopping for furniture.
In Restoration Hardware's holiday catalog, the Morgan leather sofa sits with a glass of beer balanced on an open book, a Dagwood sandwich on the ottoman and a wall of sports trophies behind. Deconstructing the sales pitch wouldn't require Roland Barthes. Furniture now accounts for 30 percent of the baby-boomer hardware store's sales.
Men's Journal is introducing a monthly furnishings page with the intention of helping men find their "inner guy" at home. The September issue, which was devoted to design, was its best-selling newstand issue.
"Design is a tool for them, like suits," said Terry McDonell, the editor. "They now think where they live has to measure up."
Jay Tarrant, 32, an editor at Fortune Small Business magazine, bought his first apartment last year on West 57th Street, and suddenly found himself house proud.
In a month, Mr. Tarrant purchased a club chair and sofa at ABC Carpet and Home, a torchere floor lamp at Caldor and simple cotton drapes at Urban Outfitters. "Big warning for single men: window treatments," he said. "What the hell is a window treatment?"
Mr. Tarrant said he enjoyed the process: "For 10 years, I took whatever people gave me. I'm not going to put anything in this apartment I don't want." That includes a framed picture of dogs playing poker. "Can't get rid of that," he said.
Last Sunday at Crate & Barrel in New York, the furniture floor was crowded with young couples with babies strapped to their chests. The people shopping by themselves were an equal mix of men and women.
"About 40 percent of my customers are single men," said Robert Hedstrom, a salesman, who has noted an increase during five years at the store. "You get a lot who are a clean slate. They've got the style in mind. They start with the sofa and buy up around it, from the store display: end tables, chairs."
Do they kick the tires? "The construction question doesn't come up," Mr. Hedstrom said.
At Pottery Barn, single men are a benchmark for product introductions, said Celia Tejada, vice president of product design and development.
"If it works with this guy, it will work with couples and women," she added.
Both Mr. Hedstrom and Ms. Tejada said that price was not a priority for single men buying furniture. But sticker shock is very real.
"I was blown away at couches that cost $2,000, $3,000," said Mr. Tarrant, who picked a sofa he liked at ABC Carpet & Home in the sale-item room. He also bought his club chair without its $700 ottoman; he found one at an antiques store upstate.
Are men furnishing to impress women? In part, yes. But the motivations may be changing, from seduction to security.
"My men friends are pretty impressed," Mr. Tarrant said. "They see the stuff I've bought, and that it's nice, and it's like, 'Wow, it's a grown-up apartment.' Women are more impressed. They find out I did it myself, and they like that."
Michael Kimmel, a professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and the author of "The Gendered Society" (Oxford University Press), to be published in March, said that changing mores were changing how men live at home. Learning to have a life of their own, at home, which could include comforts like furniture, is, if not a rite of manhood, at least a passage into adulthood.
"Decorating your home, and nicely, is a positive image, that you're capable of taking care of a home," Mr. Kimmel said. "A woman walks in, and sees: 'Oh, I don't have to feed him. I'm going to have room for myself as well.' "
Then, what's taking so long? Why is the furnishing reflex frozen in many single men, like an attack of stage fright?
"They want to be the guy they knew and loved in college," said Stephen Gordon, the chief executive of Restoration Hardware. "They slowly become guys they don't know, and don't recognize. Furnishing reinforces it -- 'Who am I in the furniture realm?' "
Mr. Smith, the filmmaker, has survived the transition from condominium male to suburban husband. His Batman cel art collection is intact. The television is 40 inches wide.
Much else is as new as tomorrow.
"The transition is piece by piece, room by room," Mr. Smith said. "Wallpaper takes over. It starts in a small bathroom downstairs. Then it creeps into every bathroom in the house. Certain rooms get surrendered -- the bedroom." Mr. Smith said he suffered no resentment toward his wife, Jennifer Schwalbach-Smith. "I find it quite comforting that she thinks about stuff like that," he said. When single, Mr. Smith based his aethestic choices on where he had a department store credit card. "No style whatsoever," he explained. "That's the thing you learn quickly when you get a wife.
"You have no style whatsoever."

HEADLINE: Medical-Device Reuse

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The reuse of medical devices (front page, Nov. 10) is potentially wonderful news, despite the warning tone of your article. Industrial ecology teaches us to analyze what industry takes, what it makes and what it wastes. Routinely disposing of serviceable equipment, manufactured at high economic and environmental cost, is wasteful. 
 Moreover, incineration releases mercury, dioxins and other toxins into the environment, threatening public health. Once we have evidence of safety, we should promote the reuse of medical equipment for sound health, environmental and economic reasons.
 
HOWARD FRUMKIN, M.D.
Atlanta, Nov. 10, 1999
 
The writer is an associate professor of environmental health, Emory University.

HEADLINE: In America;
Dismantling Medicaid

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Ambivalence.
Bill Bradley is being praised for proposing a bold new plan to make health insurance available to nearly all Americans, and for putting the health care issue back on the national agenda in a major way. 
 But some of the strongest advocates of health care reform, especially those concerned about the health of poor children, are worried that Mr. Bradley's proposal is financially unrealistic and, in some ways, could do more harm than good.
Causing the most worry is Mr. Bradley's plan to do away with Medicaid, the federal and state program that provides health care for the poor. It would be replaced by a system of vouchers and tax credits designed to "mainstream" low-income people into the private insurance market.
Medicaid has been like a safe house for the poor. The thought of moving the poor out of Medicaid and into the health care marketplace with only a voucher for protection fills many advocates with dread.
The vouchers to purchase health insurance are, in fact, capped subsidies, and the caps have been set quite low. So poor people in many parts of the country may go into the private market only to find that their vouchers will not cover the full cost of health insurance. A big fear is that people now enrolled in Medicaid could end up with no coverage at all.
"I'm thrilled that health care is back on the agenda," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, president of the Children's Health Fund, which is based in New York and has become a national model for providing health care to poor children.
"I never expected to see this issue front and center like it is now, and that's a good thing. But I think Senator Bradley's proposal that Medicaid be eliminated is incredibly ill advised. Medicaid to me is a 30-year-old bedrock safety net program for children and poor pregnant women. For the life of me, I can't understand how that can be replaced by what amounts to a voucher program, which would both undermine the health care access that children have gotten under Medicaid and, second of all, put a new set of bureaucratic burdens on poor families that I think is just unreasonable."
Judy Feder, the dean of policy studies at Georgetown University, said there were aspects of Mr. Bradley's plan that she admired. But she, too, is concerned about the elimination of Medicaid, which provides not only health care but a range of related services to the very poor. Those services can include personal assistance and non-emergency transportation, as well as supplying beneficiaries with eyeglasses, hearing aids, wheelchairs and other medical equipment.
"It is important," said Ms. Feder, "to understand the special role of Medicaid. It treats a very disadvantaged population and provides a broad array of services that private health insurance has never touched."
There are other potential problems. Medicaid provides nursing home care for the elderly, which is a significant benefit for both low- and middle-class families. Under Mr. Bradley's plan, the responsibility for long-term care would be turned over to the states. What happens to long-term benefits and nursing home standards under that scenario is, at the moment, anybody's guess.
I asked David Cutler, a professor of economics at Harvard and a health care adviser to the Bradley campaign, about the financial hurdles faced by the plan. He said he expected the caps to be raised, that the proposed $1,800-a-year ceiling on the health insurance vouchers to be given to poor people would be increased to better reflect the market.
"The subsidy is not up to the most generous plan, not even the median plan, but a decent plan," said Mr. Cutler. His understanding, he said, is that it "is not fixed in stone."
Mr. Bradley proposes to pay for his initiative with money from the federal budget's non-Social Security surplus. Vice President Al Gore, who is touting his own, more modest health care proposal -- and who also plans to pay for it with the surplus -- has said Mr. Bradley's plan will devour the entire surplus.
"It doesn't eat up all of it," Mr. Cutler said, adding, "To me, the bigger issue is, before this gets enacted, or anything gets enacted, will Congress have already spent the money, either on silly tax cuts or something else."

HEADLINE: Share the Wealth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
You report (Week in Review, Nov. 7) that Americans are wondering if there is more to life than prosperity and that politicians are listening to the wondering. 
 For those who want to do more, here are a few ideas for fighting the poverty that persists despite the long economic boom: Overtip -- chronically and lavishly. Give your housekeeper a big raise. Instead of exchanging presents with well-heeled friends, each of you make a donation to a group serving the needy.
Take part in your shareholders' proxy statement vote. Proxies often present opportunities to vote on diversity, labor practices and other issues. It's rarely necessary to capture a majority of the votes to bring about a change.
 
PATRICIA O'TOOLE

HEADLINE: 2 Retailers Post Increases In Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Kmart and Federated Department Stores said yesterday that third-quarter profits rose as high consumer confidence and low unemployment helped increase sales, led by clothing and housewares.
Net income at Kmart, the No. 2 discount chain behind Wal-Mart Stores, rose 13 percent, meeting estimates. Federated, the owner of Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other chains, said net income gained 12 percent, beating forecasts. 
 Kmart's net income rose to $43 million, or 9 cents a diluted share, compared with $38 million, or 8 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended Oct. 27 rose 5.4 percent, to $8.06 billion from $7.64 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 3.2 percent.
The results for Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., met analysts' expectations, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks company earnings.
Federated's net income rose to $123 million, or 56 cents a share, compared with profit from operations of $110 million, or 50 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended Oct. 30 rose 16 percent, to $4.24 billion from $3.65 billion, while same-store sales rose 3.9 percent. A year earlier, a charge of $23 million, or 10 cents a share, for the early retirement of debt resulted in net income of $87 million, or 40 cents a share.
Analysts had expected Federated, based in Cincinnati, to earn 53 cents a share, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial.
Most retailers have had their strongest stretch of sales gains in at least a decade amid a robust economy. Consumer spending may ease as the holiday season nears, which would separate the industry leaders like Federated that sell popular brand names and keep inventory costs low from the laggards like Kmart.
"It's going to be very competitive," said Sally Wallick, an analyst at Legg Mason Wood Walker. "There's going to be a lot of promotional activity and a tremendous amount of advertising."
Shares of Kmart rose 18.75 cents, to $9.75, while Federated rose $1.4375, to $43.625.

HEADLINE: Clinton Optimistic About Year 2000

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
In his first detailed remarks on the subject since late last year, President Clinton predicted today that the Year 2000 computer problem would not disrupt the federal government or critical companies in the private sector, including those providing most of the nation's financial services, power, phones and transportation.
"America is well on its way to being Y2K ready," Mr. Clinton said at the White House, summarizing a progress report released later today by his Council on Year 2000 Conversion. 
 Advocates for Year 2000 preparedness said Mr. Clinton's assessment was too rosy and undercut his own council's recommendations that people prepare for possible disruptions as they would for a winter storm.
"This is an overly optimistic view," said Norman L. Dean, executive director of the Center for Y2K and Society, a nonprofit group based in Washington that is promoting local preparedness.
The disagreements turn on how to assess the risks suggested by the ever-changing preparedness data like that in the council's report. For instance, the council reported that several important services appeared to be far from ready, like 911 emergency phone centers. Just 50 percent have fully prepared their computers for the change to 2000 as of Oct. 1, according to the report.
But 911 experts say the centers will be able to receive and process all calls even without such enhancements as automatically pinpointing the origin of the calls. They argue that the problems with wireless phones were a bigger threat than Year 2000 glitches to such systems. Most major cities, including New York, have announced that their 911 systems are ready.
The council also noted that Year 2000 preparedness had been moving too slowly in schools, local governments, small businesses and developing countries, but in every case there are questions about how complete a picture can be derived from its data. Most of it comes from surveys in which data sources are unidentified and the responses are combined before the council sees them.
Mr. Clinton said he was confident that computer problems "will not put the savings or the safety of the American people at risk" and that government functions "from air traffic control systems to Social Security payment systems will continue to work exactly as they should."
But preparedness advocates complained that Mr. Clinton, who in his Internet chat on Monday told a questioner he saw no need to prepare for the millennium by bunkering down, should nonetheless have advised Americans to at least stockpile enough food, water and other vital supplies for several days of possible disruption.
At a news conference, John Koskinen, chairman of the Council on Year 2000 Conversion, took a more cautious stance than Mr. Clinton. While endorsing the bright national picture, Mr. Koskinen repeated the council's longstanding advice that each community had to look at its owns risks and that individuals should have the supplies on hand they would want if they were facing a natural disaster.
"We are urging people not only to prepare but to prepare early," Mr. Koskinen said.
The report was the fourth in a series of quarterly reviews the council began publishing in January. It is a compendium of data provided to the council through groups created to represent various sectors of the economy. But, Mr. Koskinen noted, such surveys have produced results consistent with federal regulators' reviews of some sectors like banks, energy and the drug industry.
Important information in the report, like data showing lagging preparations in small business and local governments, was gathered in the spring and is undoubtedly out of date. But Mr. Koskinen said anyone still taking a wait-and-see approach to the computer challenge is "asking for trouble."
The Year 2000 problem stems from the widespread use of just two digits to represent the year in electronic dates, like 99 for 1999. Some computers and other electronic equipment with embedded computers do not recognize 00 as 2000. As a result, they may shut down or generate faulty data.
Mr. Koskinen said that it might not seem irrational to a small business with little reliance on computers to count on fixing failures when they occur but that Year 2000 faults might also affect building security systems, office telephones and relationships with customers and suppliers in ways they might not expect. Moreover, repair support that would normally be quickly available might be delayed for weeks or months if problems are widespread.
Mr. Koskinen said there were continuing risks even for big computer users who thoughts their preparations were done, because computer vendors continue to discover flaws in their equipment and software.
Another concern, which Mr. Koskinen said he was briefed about on Tuesday at an Office of Management and Budget meeting with computer specialists, is that some computer systems that do not appear to track the date may nonetheless have date-sensitive microchips in them. Those systems also have to be tested, and plans must be made to handle breakdowns, Mr. Koskinen said.
Contingency plans have become a focus because it is widely recognized that some malfunctions are inevitable. Mr. Clinton noted that there were several glitches during the federal government's transition to its fiscal year 2000 on Oct. 1 and said the "overriding lesson of that experience was that alert organizations armed with good contingency plans can fix Y2K disruptions in short order."
Mr. Koskinen cautioned, however, that the experience with computers embedded in other equipment might not follow the fiscal year precedent. Such embedded system problems are expected to hit hardest in the first 10 days of next year. In some cases, they might not knock out a complex structure like a power grid but slowly degrade its performance, he said.
The lagging work on 911 systems raises similar concerns. In towns where 911 systems are plagued with Year 2000 problems, calls will still reach switchboards but it may take longer to handle them. Mr. Koskinen said the survey data provided no information on which communities had such problems.

HEADLINE: A French Paradox at Work;
35-Hour Week May Turn Out to Be Best for Employers

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PFASTATT, France

 BODY:
Last year, the Beyer family, which owns a small jam and fruit preserves plant here near the Swiss border, made a proposal to their 18 employees: Would they like a 35-hour workweek and continue to be paid for working 39 hours?
To no one's great surprise, the employees said yes. "An hour more for yourself is an hour more," said Christiane Grimm, whose job includes slapping labels on jars, sorting through crates of fruit and watching over bubbling vats of jam. "There's lots you can do with it." 
 Surprisingly, the Beyers ended up happy, too. The company, one of thousands of French enterprises that have reorganized their businesses because of a 16-month-old law creating one of the shortest workweeks in the world, believes that it is far better off than before.
In the reshuffle, Philippe Beyer split his 18 employees into two teams and staggered their shifts. His factory here in the Alsace region now operates 12 hours a day, up from 8. And it produces 30 percent more than it did last year with only two extra employees.
The promise of 39 hours of pay for 35 hours of work was a campaign plank that helped catapult Lionel Jospin's leftist coalition to power in the 1997 Parliament elections. And it remains the glue that keeps Socialists, Communists and Greens together. It was aimed at creating as many as a million jobs in a country that has struggled with a double-digit rate of unemployment for years.
But many experts think that this bold experiment -- which business leaders had warned would cripple France's economy -- is not going to be a cure-all for the nearly three million unemployed.
Instead, it could accomplish something the leftist governing coalition never aimed for: a kind of housecleaning in the French workplace that will tear the cobwebs from French industry and lead to a more productive and flexible work force, as it did at Beyer.
"The primary goal of this policy is very unlikely," said Emanuel Ferry, an economist at Banque National de Paris, who is studying the policy. "But it seems to be having a backdoor effect. It is providing a very good opportunity to renovate the workplace. And it is introducing these elements -- productivity, flexibility -- quietly without triggering social unrest. So even if the direct goal of job creation is not achieved, it may still not necessarily be a bad thing for the economy."
That may be, but there is hardly a policy that has caused as much argument in France as the 35-hour week. While labor was an early advocate of the idea, many unions have recently demonstrated against it, fearing that the way it is being carried out will freeze salary levels and reverse hard-fought gains in employee rights. Businesses have protested, too. Last month, some 30,000 industrialists and executives gathered in an empty Paris conference center to wave placards and chant slogans deploring the policy. They say it will cost too much and destroy France's competitiveness.
Average citizens also seem to be losing their appetite for it. Surveys show that the idea was very popular when first proposed, but resistance grew the more the French considered it. A recent poll found that less than 10 percent of France's citizens now believe that they are going to benefit from shorter workweeks. Most people suspect that one way or another, they will be inconvenienced. Either way, it is a subject almost sure to start a fight.
"People feel very strongly about it," Mr. Beyer said. "In this country we are a little retrograde, we live the way we lived 30 years ago, and this is forcing change and so people are uneasy with it."
So far, there is little proof that the 35-hour week has created many jobs. Labor Ministry officials said in Parliament recently that the plan had created or saved 120,000 jobs. But one legislator called the figures "thin air," and most economists say a more realistic number would probably be half that. Opponents also point out that the government has been subsidizing the transition with business tax cuts and other incentives.
France's economy grew at a healthy rate of 3.2 percent in 1998, and is expected to do nearly as well this year. The unemployment rate has dropped to 11.1 in August from a high of 12.6 percent in June 1997. But few see much connection between the new jobs and the 35-hour policy.
"The 35 hours was a political decision," a Finance Ministry official said, "but it may become a really positive thing. Nothing was moving before. Now suddenly everyone has to go back and look at the way we have been doing business. People are talking and thinking and being creative."
The process of carrying out this complicated law, passed in June 1998, is still in its early stages. This month, Parliament passed a tangle of more than 100 amendments spelling out exactly how and when the policy should be instituted. One rule: All companies with 20 employees or more must operate with a 35-hour workweek by the year 2002. So far, only a little more than 1 percent of eligible French employers have formally made plans for the conversion.
Economists say the brunt of the law will be felt unevenly. Some businesses like the Beyer factory will benefit. Others, including service industries, are likely to have a much harder time.
George Jallerat, who owns Le Grand Monarque Hotel and Restaurant in Chartres, says he cannot figure out how to reduce his employees' hours, pay them the same wages and not lose money. "In the end, we will have to raise prices," he said. "There is no other way."
Some entrepreneurs are already taking steps to protect themselves. Dr. Thierry Sandre employs 19 people in his medical lab on the outskirts of Paris. He says he will do all that he can to avoid hiring a 20th person and bring the 35-hour workweek into his business.
But he does not trust the government to leave him alone. So he has not raised the pay of any of his employees in two years, as a way of saving money for the day he has to give them a 35-hour workweek for 39 hours of pay. He says he is not alone.
While the 35-hour workweek was being debated, government officials began trying to enforce the 39-hour limit that now exists, even among managers. Agents prowled garages to see what time people were actually leaving. Thousands of fines were issued, and in one case, the director of a electronics factory owned by Thomson-RCM was hauled into court for working too hard and allowing his engineers and other managers to put in an average of 46 hours a week. In June, he received an $18,000 fine. The action prompted some businesses to install time clocks even for managers and made the government the butt of jokes.
Those who have jumped at the shortened workweek are often those who were already planning to expand their businesses. For instance, the Packard Bell factory in the western town of Angers, which makes computers, went to the 35-hour week this year precisely because it wanted to increase production by 30 percent. To do that, it needed to reorganize its 1,200 employees into more teams and more shifts. Offering a 35-hour week was a way of opening negotiations with its unions.
Jean-Luc Bayel, the director of human resources, said the plan had worked out even better than anyone expected. "We have far less absenteeism," Mr. Bayel said. "And we are seeing a better product. People have to stand to do the job, and standing for eight hours is hard. Now they stand for only seven and we are seeing a 5 percent reduction in problem computers. We are very happy with the changes."
Packard Bell did not take advantage of government subsidies because it did not want to follow government rules. But others like Mr. Beyer also saw in the new law a way of getting government aid to pay for expansion plans.
At Beyer, for instance, the government aid package will pay nearly 90 percent of the salary for the two employees he added this year. Next year, it will pay about 70 percent and 50 percent the year after that. But Mr. Beyer, who took over the business from his father two years ago, wanted to expand anyway. He says he might have gone ahead with his plans anyhow, but the law gave him a push.
Not far from Mr. Beyer's factory, Didier Thuet, who owns a small heating-installation business, adopted the 35-hour week for just the same reason. "It was an opportunity to try something," he said.
Mr. Thuet's business is seasonal. There is little work at all from March to May. So he offered his employees a shorter workweek during those months in exchange for a longer one during peak business periods. They also got an additional six to eight days off. All six of the employees agreed to a salary freeze until the year was over and the company could see how much money it made.
But both Mr. Thuet and Mr. Beyer have their doubts about whether the law will work everywhere.
And there are complaints from the supposed beneficiaries of the new jobs. At Beyer, Sarah Charro, who at 26 had a series of temporary jobs, was hired because of the reorganization, but she has little good to say about it, regarding the atmosphere in the factory as tense.
"I feel in some ways like we went backward," Ms. Charro said. "We are working only 35 hours, but they are trying to push a lot into those hours -- push, push, push. We are all stressed out."
Mr. Thuet's new employee, Christoffe Foulon, says the 35-hour week is great if he does not lose any money. But in truth, he would rather work more and earn more. He says few of his friends seem to envy him. Instead, most give him a hard time. "They treat me like I'm lazy," he said.
