HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Cites Harley-Davidson in Pushing His Trade Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: YORK, Pa., Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton today saluted a much-exported American icon, the Harley-Davidson motorcycle, in an effort to prepare the political ground for two high-stakes trade negotiations that are already touching off raucous debate in Washington and around the country.
As Mr. Clinton donned a leather Harley-Davidson jacket at the company's factory in York and mused about the possibility of becoming a biker at the end of his presidency, half of his economic team was in Beijing in a last-ditch effort to strike a deal with China that could vastly open the market for American producers. 
 While Mr. Clinton said nothing about the tense talks, Harley-Davidson was a fitting backdrop: It has had huge sales success in Japan, home ground for its archrival Honda, but it remains barred from the Chinese market.
In a small meeting with workers here, and then a campaign-style speech in front of the factory's 2,700 workers, Mr. Clinton spent much of the day trying to build support for America's position at the round of global trade negotiations that start in Seattle at the end of this month.
Already the administration is reeling from criticism that it has mismanaged the agenda, and that the streets will be dominated by environmentalists, economic nationalists and union members who all have their complaints about the World Trade Organization.
"I want y'all to watch Seattle when it rolls around," he said of the talks, which start Nov. 30 and will probably take years to complete. "I'll have more demonstrators against me than I've had in the whole seven years I've been president. I'm kind of looking forward to it."
He may be the only one who is. Mr. Clinton's aides fear that the global talks that they proposed are now out of hand. The United States wants to focus on agriculture and issues like keeping the Internet free of tariffs.
In a nod to labor and environmental groups, the United States has also proposed setting up a "working group on trade and labor" within the W.T.O. and to conduct an environmental review of the impact of trade talks. But that is not likely to satisfy opponents who fear that the trade group now has the power to override national environmental safety laws, or labor groups that want worldwide standards on minimum wages and employment conditions.
Developing nations oppose many of those proposals. Meanwhile, Japan and Europe want to use the talks to attack American antidumping laws, which they say are used as an American trade barrier to keep out foreign steel and other goods.
But Mr. Clinton went into none of that detail in his visit today. Instead, he offered a series of arguments about why trade helps American workers and consumers, and he cited Harley-Davidson, which exports 66,000 cycles a year. "In spite of all those numbers," Mr. Clinton said, "there's more debate on whether trade is good for us now than there was in 1992."
Mr. Clinton's critics on trade policy say that events like today's are too late, and that the president -- fearful of alienating Democrats and his traditional supporters -- has been too timid on trade issues.
"It's true we are in worse trouble on trade now than we were in '92," said Representative Jim Kolbe, an Arizona Republican who has often sided with Mr. Clinton on trade issues. "But I put a lot of blame for this at the feet of the President himself. Since NAFTA and the GATT agreementthere has been no leadership on this from the White House."
Mr. Clinton's response has mixed new arguments and old. He has made the case that few politicians dare to utter: That rising imports are a sign of the health of the American economy, and help keep inflation low and competition keen. But his conversation today with workers about the administration's effort to eliminate trade barriers could have taken place in the 1980's -- he even used the example of a Japanese restriction on imported skis that hurt American ski manufacturers. In fact, that problem was largely solved before he took office.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON with Joe Brescia 

 BODY:

A Swinger, a Miss And an Injury
JERRY SEINFELD was a no-show at an auction on Tuesday that raised money for an assisted-living wing for Alzheimer's patients at the Cobble Hill Health Center in Brooklyn. KEITH HERNANDEZ, the former first baseman for the Mets whose mother died of Alzheimer's disease in 1989, had invited Mr. Seinfeld, as well as a benchful of ballplayers who did attend: BUD HARRELSON, LEE MAZZILLI and RUSTY STAUB all former Mets, as well as DAVID CONE, who is now a free agent.
As for Mr. Seinfeld, "He was supposed to come, at least for the cocktail hour," said Mr. Hernandez, who appeared on the "Seinfeld" show and whose photograph occupied a place of honor on Mr. Seinfeld's living room wall on the set. "But he called me and said he couldn't make it." 
 With an incredulous look, as if he had swung and missed a hanging curveball during his playing days, Mr. Hernandez added: "He told me he had a stress fracture in his leg."
Could the stress involved have had anything to do with the torrent of publicity about his engagement to JESSICA SKLAR, who had been Mrs. Eric Nederlander for only three weeks when they met?
No, said Mr. Seinfeld's spokeswoman, ELIZABETH CLARK. "He's had it for a couple of weeks," she said. "He's been wearing a soft cast. What people have been asking is how he did it, but there wasn't one specific accident." Getting around was painful, she said, "and it turned out he had a broken foot."
 
Magazine Chief To TV Moderator
Suddenly, it is not enough for magazine types to have jobs on magazines. They seem to want to break into broadcasting, too.
Consider HAROLD EVANS, who is stepping down as the vice chairman and editorial director of U.S. News and World Report magazine at the end of the year but will remain a contributing editor and consultant. He will be the moderator of the magazine's new public-television panel discussion program, "World At Large." (And by the way, Mr. Evans noted during an interview arranged by U.S. News, "I'd much rather you said I was the author of 'The American Century.' That gives me the kind of authority to range over these profound issues." ("The American Century" was his 710-page book, published last year by Knopf.)
Mr. Evans said that the guests for the first episode would include ROBERT E. RUBIN, the former treasury secretary, who is now one of Citigroup's leaders; EUGENE MCCARTHY, whose dovish presidential campaign in 1968 helped end Lyndon B. Johnson's hopes of a second full term, and the author JOHN EDGAR WIDEMAN.
"World at Large" will be videotaped not in a television studio but at the Four Seasons restaurant, where Mr. Evans said the pool -- the bubbly centerpiece of Philip Johnson's smooth-surface design -- will be turned off and covered over for the day. "We're not in our bathing suits," he said. "It's a U.S. News special. U.S. News is heavily concentrated on politics and economic news. We don't go for show business."
Nor should "World at Large" be confused with the breakfast-time discussions that Mr. Evans moderated at Barneys when he was president and publisher of Random House.
"The difference, first of all, is that was held in a clothing store," he said. "Second, it was all literary. The last one, I think I did on James Joyce, and Frank McCourt and Malachy McCourt burst into song."
And then there is KURT ANDERSEN, who writes for The New Yorker magazine, was editor in chief of New York magazine and was a co-founder and editor of Spy magazine.
Now he has signed on as the host of a public-radio program, "Hot Ticket." Which is why he has also signed on with a voice coach.
"I'm spending a few hours with a woman who tells me how not to sound so Omahan, a person who trains actors and voice-over people in how to sound persuasive and warm, I guess," he said.
"You think, having been in the interviewee's seat on lots of radio and TV shows, that you know how to do it, but it's a different set of skills." JAMES BARRON with Joe Brescia

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall After Release of Price Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices fell yesterday for the second consecutive day after a report showed that the core rate of producer prices in October rose more than expected. The strong data raised speculation again that the Federal Reserve would increase short-term interest rates to keep inflation from accelerating.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 8/32, to 100 16/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.09 percent from 6.07 percent on Tuesday. 
 The government completed its quarterly refunding yesterday, with the sale of $10 billion of 10-year notes. It followed Tuesday's $15 billion sale of five-year notes. The 10-year notes, which were a reopening of an issue sold in August, had good demand and helped to buttress the market, which got off to a shaky start after the report that producer prices outside of food and energy rose three-tenths of a percent in October.
Some market participants are speculating that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates on Tuesday when the Federal Open Market Committee meets, but others are less certain. But most agree that the Fed's bias will have an equally important effect on the market.
While the producer prices report might have surprised the market a little, some economists, like Phil Hill of Briefing.com, a market analysis firm in Burlingame, Calif., still say rates will remain unchanged.
"Even though core prices, which exclude food and energy, came in larger than expected, it was still another benign month for producer prices," Mr. Hill said.
Kathleen M. Camilli, director of economic research at Tucker Anthony Inc., said Treasuries recovered from early losses after the producer prices report on the strength of market participants closing short positions. "It appears," she said, "that some people went into today's 10-year note auction expecting to buy notes at cheaper prices but instead wound up scrambling to cover short positions after the auction went better than expected."
The notes were awarded at a yield of 6.007 percent, with the bid-to-cover ratio a healthy 2.48 to 1 as traders were quick to remind people that the auction had been reduced to $10 billion from $12 billion. The result helped Treasuries close above their daily lows.
Market participants think the Fed's decision could hinge on productivity and retail sales data to be released tomorrow. Worries about the Fed, however, are expected to keep the market vulnerable.
Ms. Camilli said her firm was expecting a quarter-point increase in short-term rates. "The bond market is awaiting further confirming evidence that the economy is returning to a more sustainable rate of inflationary G.D.P. growth around 3 to 3.5 percent," she said.
Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, said: "Today's report is disappointing. The higher-than-expected core finished goods result, the surge in prices further down the production chain, and the recent recovery in oil prices all fuel the view that inflation pressures will continue to build, a negative for financial markets."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Shares Resume Surge as Demand for New Issues Offsets Inflation Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks resumed a mostly upward course yesterday as enthusiasm for technology issues overcame some early nervousness about the government's latest figures on inflation.
The Nasdaq composite index, its streak of seven straight records broken on Tuesday, scaled a new peak yesterday, gaining 30.92 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 3,155.96. 
 A surprisingly strong profit report from Cisco Systems set the tone, analysts said, helping to lift three initial offerings of Internet companies to huge gains. United Parcel Service, the biggest initial offering ever, also moved to a handsome premium. Cisco rose 5 1/4, to 79 7/16.
"Momentum still rules," said Byron R. Wien, chief United States strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The technology stocks are dominant, but a lot of other things are not participating."
More stocks fell than rose on the New York Stock Exchange, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was almost exactly balanced between winners and losers. The index advanced 8.18 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 1,373.46.
Among the 30 components of the Dow Jones industrial average, which rebounded from an 81-point decline to finish with a loss of 19.58 points, or two-tenths of a percent, at 10,597.74, 18 stocks fell while 11 rose and one was unchanged.
The Russell 2000 index of small-company stocks climbed for the 11th consecutive session, gaining 2.44 points, or 0.55 percent, to 448.72.
The Labor Department's report that core producer prices rose three-tenths of a percent in October, more than expected, weighed on stocks and contributed to a modest upturn in long-term interest rates, analysts said.
The report's impact, however, was diminished because much of the increase was in motor vehicles, an area of statistical difficulty because of varying introduction dates of new models.
"It doesn't really change the basic balance of the evidence" for the Federal Reserve when its policy committee meets on Tuesday, said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. Whether the central bank decides to raise short-term interest rates to slow the economy remains, he said, "a very close call."
Another analyst, Calvin Schnure of Chase Securities and until recently a Fed staff economist, called the inflation data "not friendly" but not a big negative, either.
Still, investors swarmed to the day's new issues, bidding up shares of Expedia, the online travel agent owned by Microsoft, to 53 1/2 from 14 after trading as high as 65 7/8. Next Level Communications, a maker of software for telephone companies that is majority-owned by General Instrument, soared to 51 from 20 after trading as high as 66. And iBasis, which operates a network for international phone calls, surged to 40 1/4 from 16. All three companies are currently losing money.
In the biggest initial offering on record, United Parcel jumped to 68 1/8 from 50, with 80.8 million shares changing hands, nearly twice as many as the day's second-most-active issue, Charter Communications, up 2 1/4, at 25.
Drug stocks, paced by 2-point gains for Warner-Lambert and American Home Products, were one of the strongest nontechnology sectors.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,644 issues fell while 1,420 rose and 118 hit new 52-week lows compared with 71 new highs. Volume swelled to 984.8 million shares.

HEADLINE: China and U.S. Resume Talks On Trade in a Hopeful Spirit

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 10

 BODY:
With both sides expressing cautious hope, senior American and Chinese trade officials met today in renewed negotiations over China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
After a year of on-and-off negotiations, including a near-miss in April, there is a wide sense that this week's talks may answer the key question: is China ready to make the major market-opening concessions demanded by the United States and Europe? 
 The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, along with the presidential economic adviser Gene Sperling and other officials, arrived last night for what is supposed to be two days of talks. Mr. Sperling said this morning that President Clinton had sent him along "to make clear his belief that we have a historical opportunity."
The Chinese were represented by Shi Guangsheng, the foreign trade minister, and officials from the central bank and affected ministries. Opening the session this morning, Mr. Shi said China was "positive and earnest."
Other countries are closely watching the Beijing talks, and not only because of the potentially huge economic effects if China is admitted to the organization that sets international trade rules and works for less fettered commerce.
China's willingness open up cherished industries to global competition will also signal its commitment to far-reaching domestic economic and social changes, economists say, and may also reveal the power of reformers in the government, especially Prime Minister Zhu Rongji.
Mr. Zhu was embarrassed in Washington in April when President Clinton rejected as inadequate what the Chinese felt were major concessions.
Since then, Chinese industries that would be threatened by a rapid market opening, like telecommunications and automobile production, have fought to preserve more protections. The leadership has become increasingly worried about a threat to social stability if unemployment worsens in the short term because of reductions in tariffs and investment barriers.
President Jiang Zemin badly wants the increased foreign investment that would follow membership in the trade organization. But he must also placate conservatives and threatened industries and workers, and it is unclear if the leadership has the political will to proceed with painful concessions right now.
The United States, for its part, will have to relax controls on textile imports from China for an agreement to be possible.
Mr. Clinton is said to regret his failure to reach agreement in April. He now sees securing China's admission to the World Trade Organization as an important foreign policy goal, but he cannot relent on the commercial terms, because he needs the support of business interests and Congress.
In the last year, American officials repeatedly said it was vital for China to join the trade group before Nov. 30, when a new round of global talks to revise trading rules will begin in Seattle.
Trade experts said that even if China and the United States reached substantial agreement this week, it appeared unlikely that China could cross all hurdles, including agreement with the European Union and other countries, in time for the start of the Seattle talks. But if it becomes apparent that China will succeed, the experts said, it will be easier to take its concerns into account in the global round.

HEADLINE: More Colombia Aid Urged

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he will ask Congress early next year to increase economic and anti-narcotics aid to Colombia, but officials said he would not seek money to fight leftist guerrillas.

 Separately, the Pentagon said Colombia wanted to buy outright 14 United States Black Hawk military helicopters for $221 million, but officials said no final decision had been made on whether to approve the sale.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A EuropeanTrade Compromise Is Rejected

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
The European Union proposed a compromise today aimed at altering the trade bloc's banana import policy to end a long-running trade dispute with the United States and Latin American producers, but the proposal was quickly rejected.
"There are certain elements in this proposal that would cause problems," a United States trade official said. "It's difficult to see how this is going to resolve the dispute." 
 Francisco de Soto, vice minister of trade for Panama, a leading banana producer, also rejected the basis of the European Union proposal, saying in a telephone interview that "none of the ideas that the Latin American producers presented have been taken into consideration."
The European Union's proposed compromise was intended to bring its banana-import policy into line with World Trade Organization rules and lead to the lifting of almost $200 million in sanctions imposed by the United States this year.
A W.T.O. dispute panel has said that the European Union's policy is illegal because it favors banana producers in former European colonies. Growers in Latin America and big American multinational growers like Dole Food and Chiquita Brands have said the policy denies them fair access to Europe's market.
The proposed compromise called for the European Union to phase out the preferential system by Jan. 1, 2006, after a transition involving a complex tariff rate quota system.
But the United States said that the proposals were not acceptable and that the sanctions would continue to be applied. "It's very likely to end up being W.T.O.-inconsistent," the United States trade official said. "The main point that we've made is it's likely to end up being discriminatory in its application."
The banana dispute is one of several marring American-European trade relations in the weeks before W.T.O. members gather in Seattle on Nov. 30 for a new round of global trade talks.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Shareholders, Mostly, SupportTheir Chairman

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: BELLEVUE, Wash., Nov. 10

 BODY:
He got a prolonged standing ovation on the way to the podium, and he was mobbed by autograph seekers on the way out.
But in between, William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, fielded some questions from his shareholders at the company's annual meeting today that he might not have faced a week ago, questions about whether his legal team had failed him and whether the company might even be broken up in the wake of its antitrust fight with the federal government. 
 In the main, the 44-year-old co-founder of the company was speaking to a friendly audience, composed of about 2,500 shareholders, and he reiterated his stance that Microsoft's "innovations and behavior were completely fair and brought tremendous benefits to millions of consumers." The meeting came five days after a federal judge issued a harsh denunciation of the company in the antitrust case, saying it had abused its monopoly power to bully and thwart the competition.
But during questions and answers with the shareholders, Mr. Gates did hear from one man who urged the company to "try your damnedest to see that this here suit is settled out of court." And another man spoke of "the feelings of disappointment at best that I have and humiliation at worst that I have at how the case against Microsoft was handled by our counsel."
With the company's general counsel and chief legal strategist, William H. Neukom, seated on the dais with Mr. Gates, the shareholder asked whether Mr. Gates might hire a new legal team so that "we are not outrun and outmaneuvered by the government," putting such a sarcastic emphasis on the word "government" that several in the audience laughed or applauded.
But Mr. Gates went into a defense of the company's legal approach and, by implication, of Mr. Neukom, who sat silently through the exchange.
"It's pretty important in a case like this not to look in a very superficial way for someone to blame," said Mr. Gates. "When the government decides they're going to block innovation, your own government decides they're going to take you to court and say you should not make those kinds of advances, it's not going to be a pleasant experience. It's not going to be something that anyone should have to go through."
And, he said: "The way we've put forth the story through our internal and external counsel about why our work is good for the economy, good for consumers, I'm quite proud of what's been done there. I'm really quite supportive of what's been done there. We're going to continue to tell that story." His remarks drew applause from the audience, and many shareholders said afterwards that they were fully behind Mr. Gates and his defense of the company.
"Of course they should fight this," said Don Benusa, a retired papermaker from Everett, Wash., who described himself as a "small shareholder" of the company. "Just because the company's a huge success, the government comes after them. I don't like government poking its nose into business."
Other Microsoft stockholders said they remained high on Mr. Gates, but agreed with the man who criticized the company's legal strategy.
"I'm appalled at the whole way the case has been mishandled," said Leonard Samuels, who owns a small printing business in Woodland Hills, Calif., and said he owned 4,200 shares of Microsoft stock. "They've made a mess of it. It should never have gotten to this point."
Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's findings, while not a final verdict, have already had a financial impact. Shares in Microsoft, the world's most highly valued company, fell for the third day today, to $87.0625, down $1.75 for the day and almost 5 percent below Friday's close. Still, even with the case pending, the company has continued to enrich its investors, with its stock rising more than 60 percent in the last year.
At today's meeting Mr. Gates and other company officials for the most part maintained a calm and often smiling demeanor, even when a loud fire alarm went off for a few moments in the convention hall. (A security official quickly cut in over the loudspeakers to announce that it was a false alarm.) But the company chairman did show a small flash of pique when he offered an acerbic characterization of the government's case against his company.
"Under this lawsuit," he said, "a software developer would end up having to focus on questions like: Is there anyone else doing something similar? If so, we can't improve this product in that way.
"Is our innovation going to force competitors to work harder?" he continued. "If so, we can't improve the product in that way. Someone might file a lawsuit! Are we providing any features at too low of a price? Are they too good? Then someone might complain. The net effect would be a chilling impact on innovation."
Again, his pledge not to compromise with the government on the company's "freedom to innovate" was met with widespread cheers from the audience at the Meydenbauer Center in Bellevue, just a few miles from the company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash.
Specifically, Mr. Gates and other company officials pledged not to agree to any settlement that would force the giant software maker to "unbundle" its Internet browser from its Windows operating system, which currently powers the vast majority of computers across the world.
"We're willing to go a long way to address the government's concerns," Mr. Gates said. "But if we can't get Internet support, we can't add any new features. No company should accept these kinds of limitations on their ability to innovate."
And, he said: "One of the most defensible things we've ever done is to support the Internet in our operating system. We cannot back off on that."
A question from another shareholder about whether the company was making any contingency plans for a breakup, along the lines of what was done in 1984 to the AT&T Corporation, was parried by Microsoft's chief operating officer, Bob Herbold. He said company officials firmly believed there was no justification for such an extreme step.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Nigerian Fraud Syndicates Set Up Shop in South Africa

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 9

 BODY:
The unsolved killing of one foreign businessman here and the mysterious disappearance of another has local and international law enforcement agents warning overseas executives and entrepreneurs to be wary of West African criminal syndicates that in recent years have made this, the continent's financial capital, their second home.
"Don't Be Fooled! Many Have Lost Money!" read a recent advertisement run by the Nigerian government in The International Herald Tribune. The ad describes one of the most common variations of a "4-1-9" fraud, so called for its statute number in the penal code of Nigeria, the birthplace of the scam. 
 Purporting to be Nigerian civil servants conspiring to inflate a government contract and pocket the difference, the schemers send letters to thousands of foreign businesspeople, seeking access to a clean, overseas bank account where embezzled money can be transferred.
Prospective accomplices are promised a cut of the multimillion-dollar sum. Once lured to Africa, they are often shown the supposed money, most or all of it actually fake.
Entangled in the ruse, the accomplices are duped into handing over money, usually when the scheme is said to encounter unforeseen problems that can be resolved only with five- or six-figure fees. Desperate to exploit what they perceive as a fleeting opportunity, the victims usually pay. By the time they realize the deception, they are out many thousands of dollars. In one case to come to light this year, a syndicate bilked a Japanese businessman of $7 million, according to South African police.
Simple as the scheme is, it results in tens of millions of dollars in losses each year, according to the United States Secret Service, which opened an office in South Africa several weeks ago to coordinate the agency's fight against commercial fraud in Africa.
"It continues to be a problem here in the United States and around the world," John Tomlinson, a spokesman for the Secret Service, said in a phone interview from Washington.
Indeed, even after a decade or so, the ruse continues to be a reliable moneymaker for the maturing network of organized crime that emanates from Nigeria.
The rise of Nigerian syndicates dates to the late 1970's and early 1980's when the West African country was hit hard by the global collapse in oil prices. Thousands of enterprising and well-educated Nigerian oil industry employees were left to look for jobs. Some took their acquired skills in trade and communications into organized crime, said Peter Gastrow, a researcher at the Institute for Security Studies in South Africa.
In the last two decades, the criminal networks have grown in number and sophistication. From their beginnings in credit card scams, they have widened their repertory of frauds.
It is no surprise, then, that the F.B.I. and the Secret Service have been in Lagos, Nigeria's biggest city, for years. The Secret Service has a crime-monitoring initiative known as Operation 4-1-9. With the West Africans' move into South Africa, it became clear to the Secret Service that it should be here, too, alongside the F.B.I., which already has an office in Pretoria.
"We recognized there was a need for a presence here," said Mitch Price, the special agent who heads the new office. "The bad guys know this is the economic hub of the region, and they have come here to operate."
Fighting this sort of fraud is made more difficult by the fact that victims are often too embarrassed or too scared to approach authorities; when they do come forward, what little information they have about their contacts is usually bogus.
Jean Pierre Tin Nok Il Shing Tat, a 42-year-old businessman from Mauritius, never had the chance to come forward. On June 4, he was kidnapped from an area hotel. Twelve days later, his body was found near an old mine along a highway in Heidelberg, southeast of here. He had been shot in the head.
Investigators are certain he was caught in a 4-1-9 scam. They now believe Kjetil Moe, an industrialist from Norway who was ensnared in a similar scam, is dead, too, Lawrence van der Westhuizen, a South African police superintendent, said.
Mr. Moe, a 65-year-old mechanical engineer, arrived here Sept. 24 and disappeared three days later, after contacting Nigerians who instructed him to hand over $5,000 to what turned out to be a fictitious company, said Mr. van der Westhuizen, who leads the Johannesburg commercial crimes unit.
Even before Mr. Moe disappeared, the unit had amassed considerable evidence of the criminal network's expanding influence in South Africa. At least three other foreign businessmen involved in the syndicate scams have been kidnapped this year. Unlike Mr. Tat, and apparently Mr. Moe, each escaped or was rescued.
"A year ago, this wasn't a big problem here," Mr. van der Westhuizen said. "Now it's an enormous problem."
Since the end of apartheid eased restrictions on immigration to South Africa, criminal operatives from Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, have migrated to Johannesburg, and the impact has begun to be felt, law enforcement agents here say.
With increasing frequency, the letters about 4-1-9 bear Johannesburg postmarks when they arrive in Britain, the Netherlands, Germany, the United States and other nations.
Home to Africa's biggest stock exchange, its biggest banks and many of its biggest companies, Johannesburg offers confidence men what Lagos cannot: a cloak of respectability and credibility. A businessman scared off by a letter from Nigeria and fearful of traveling there might not be as wary of a solicitation sent from South Africa.
But authorities here worry that South Africa's image will not remain untainted for long.
"If you receive a letter or a contract from South Africa, you will think twice about it," Mr. van der Westhuizen said. "Is this a real deal or is it a bogus one? People will be asking, 'Why should we go to South Africa? It's not safe to do business there.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Increase in Shares of U.P.S. Pushes Value to $81 Billion
In the biggest initial stock offering ever, investors drove up the price of United Parcel Service to $68.25 a share from an opening price of $50. In less than 24 hours, the public increased the company's market value to more than $81 billion, almost twice as much as General Motors and nearly six times as much as Federal Express.
Many of the company's shareholders are current or retired U.P.S. employees who are poised to cash in. Page A1. 

'Cybersquatting' Measure Revived
Hoping to fend off a threatened veto of a controversial bill to outlaw speculating in Internet addresses, or "cybersquatting," Congressional leaders have attached it to a satellite-television bill that has already been passed by the House and is awaiting a vote in the Senate. The revival of the legislation marks a key victory for the Motion Picture Association of America, led by Jack Valenti, and other groups that have sought to protect trademarks online. C2.
 
Stocks Mixed on Inflation Report
Stocks resumed a mostly upward course as enthusiasm for technology issues overcame some early market nervousness about a report that showed producer prices rose more than expected in October. The Nasdaq composite index gained 30.92 points, to 3,155.96, another closing high. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 8.18 points, to 1,373.46, but the Dow Jones industrial average declined 19.58 points, to 10,597.74. C16.
 
Treasury prices fell on concern that the Federal Reserve will increase short-term interest rates next week. The yield on the 30-year issue rose to 6.09 percent, from 6.07 percent. C16.
 
Allstate Plans to Sell on Internet
In a significant shift in sales strategy, Allstate insurance said it would begin selling auto and homeowners insurance and other coverage over the telephone and through the Internet. The company said it was not abandoning its force of 15,200 agents, but it is accelerating the trend toward converting its staff agents to independent contractors. C6.
 
Computer Associates to Appeal
Computer Associates said it would appeal a judge's ruling that its top three executives must return more than half a billion dollars worth of stock from a lavish executive payout that infuriated shareholders. C8.
 
Philip Morris Seeks Better Image
Philip Morris, which spends more than $2 billion a year on advertising, is undertaking an extensive multimedia campaign meant to help burnish its corporate image and counter the critics who object to the company's tobacco operations. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C12.
 
Psychiatric Centers to Be Sold
Charter Behavioral Health Systems, the largest operator of privately run psychiatric hospitals and clinics, said that it planned to sell 53 of the 96 centers it operates. Charter, a unit of Crescent Real Estate Equities, said that it was losing money at many of its psychiatric hospitals. But federal officials are continuing to investigate the hospital chain for patient abuse and Medicaid fraud. Shares of Crescent Real Estate rose 43.75 cents, to $16.875. C6.
 
Clinton Gives a Trade Pep Talk
President Clinton saluted a much-exported American icon, the Harley-Davidson motorcycle, in an effort to prepare the political ground for high-stakes trade negotiations that are already touching off raucous debate in Washington and across the country. C4.
 
Goldman Lifts Limits for Charity
In what may become an early holiday gift to schools, hospitals and other nonprofit groups, Goldman Sachs Group has lifted some restrictions on its stock to allow partners to donate as much as $500 million to charity. C14.
 
Bond Market Is Closed
Government offices, most banks, bond markets and commodity trading in financial contracts will be closed today in observance of Veterans Day. Stock exchanges will be open.

HEADLINE: Judge Halts Drug Tests of Welfare Applicants

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 10

 BODY:
A federal judge today temporarily halted Michigan's unusual program to test welfare applicants for drug use.
Under a pilot program that started last month, Michigan had been requiring welfare applicants at three sites, including one in Detroit, to pass a drug test or be denied benefits. Michigan is the first state with such a program. 
 The American Civil Liberties Union sued the state to stop the drug tests, arguing that they violated the privacy of welfare applicants and the constitutional protections against unreasonable search and seizure.
Today, Judge Victoria A. Roberts of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan, Northern Division, granted a temporary restraining order that stops the tests until at least Dec. 14, when another hearing has been scheduled. The judge said she granted the order because the drug tests were probably unconstitutional.
Kary L. Moss, executive director of the Michigan office of the A.C.L.U., said the ruling means "that for the time being, welfare applicants will not be forced to choose between their constitutional rights and providing for their families."
The state said it would comply with the court order but believes it will ultimately prevail.
"We look forward to returning to this program, which was allowed by federal legislation, enacted by the Michigan Legislature and supported by our customers and the general public," Douglas E. Howard, director of Michigan's welfare agency, the Family Independence Agency, said. "The drug testing pilot is an opportunity to help individuals find employment and to strengthen families. We believe it is the right thing to do."
Karen Smith, a spokeswoman for the agency, said 8.1 percent of the applicants tested positive for drug use. No one refused the test, Ms. Smith said. Of the 258 tests analyzed, 237 tested negative while 21 tested positive. Of the positive results, three were for cocaine, and the rest were for marijuana.
While the state had results for only 258 tests, a total of 379 applicants had been tested at the three sites. Tests were required in Alpena and Presque Isle Counties in northeastern Michigan, in Berrien County in southwestern Michigan and in one urban area, a part of western Detroit.
Michigan has been one of the early leaders in the effort to end traditional welfare, initiating programs intended to put recipients into the work force. The state's caseload has dropped about 60 percent since October 1992, when changes in welfare rules and the booming economy lowered the unemployment rate.
Michigan's caseload stands at slightly more 80,000, down from about 240,000 in the mid-1990's, said John Truscott, a spokesman for Gov. John Engler, a Republican who has championed the welfare changes.
"We know that drug abuse is a barrier to employment," Mr. Truscott said. "Our whole approach to welfare is helping people find a job and keep a job."
Those who tested positive under the pilot program were required to get drug treatment in order to receive a welfare check. Anyone who refused treatment would have been denied benefits. In the first month, none of those who tested positive refused treatment, Mr. Truscott said.
Other states have considered requiring drug tests but have backed away. Both Florida and Louisiana require applicants to answer questions about drug use and then use the answers to determine whether to administer a test. New York and Maryland had planned to require tests but found that other types of screening, like questionnaires, were cheaper. New Jersey, South Carolina, Wisconsin and Minnesota randomly test welfare recipients with felony drug convictions.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Drama At 301 Congress

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Every dramatist knows that before the plot can thicken, a mix of characters must be stirred in. In the roman a clef to be written about the Bush campaign, if it wins, here are the real people on whom to base the cast:
The cunning strategist: Karl Rove, professional pol, strives to be grandmaster of the political chessboard, honing themes, anticipating opponents' thrusts. 
 Will Steve Forbes ever launch a TV campaign to brand the Texas governor a heavy taxer? If he does, Rove's counter would measure increases in Texas against Ronald Reagan's record in California. No Bush litmus test on abortion for Supreme Court nominees? The answer that turneth away pro-life wrath: Such a prejudgment would have to be reported to the Senate at confirmation, and the nominee would then have to recuse himself when the issue comes before the court.
Campaign durability is the strategist's mantra; rather than "a thousand points of light," he thinks of a $5 million TV buy as "a thousand points of penetration" in California, ensuring that a viewer sees a Bush ad 10 times in the critical state.
The tough, take-charge campaign manager next bestrides the stage of "301 Congress Avenue," the address of the headquarters and likely title of the insiders' drama.
He is big, burly, bombastic Joe Allbaugh, with a Haldeman crew cut and an overpowering presence. The former Oklahoma farmer ran Bush's victory over Ann Richards in 1994 and enforces the candidate's will with Frank Nitti-like discipline.
In command of the Bush calendar, he gives the candidate weekends off; in December, Allbaugh schedules one joint TV appearance a week and has Bush at home nearly half the days before Christmas. Not overly taxing. If the nomination is decided by April, he'll send Bush overseas before the convention to gain gravitas.
The resident intellectual is the youthful but graying policy adviser and outside-advice conduit Joshua Bolten. He's the slot man, turning to a capable triumvirate of Stephen Goldsmith, Condoleezza Rice and Larry Lindsey for domestic, foreign and economic positions. (Espousing competition in education may augur resistance to monopoly in the marketplace.)
He doesn't run a "murder board" -- the panel of tough questioners that usually prepares candidates for debates and penetrating interviews. That's because Bush is not receptive to the scripting of quips, ripostes and zingers. This could be a mistake in a head-to-head with John McCain, gaining every day; an unrehearsed Bush failed to dominate a weak opponent in an El Paso debate last year.
The strong woman alter ego, now an indispensable public role, is played by Karen Hughes, his longtime spokeswoman. This dedicated, savvy media aide knows how he thinks and what he should say but also what he's likely to say, and is on a hair trigger to counter charges of lightweightedness. She brooks no interference with her access; nobody on the inside crosses her.
The idealistic speechwriter, an appealing stock character in political novels, is played by Michael Gerson, laboring behind a closed door and a pile of books and papers at 301 Congress. A theology student at Wheaton College, he wrote for Chuck Colson in the Prison Fellowship, was one of Bob Dole's junior writers in 1996, and had turned to journalism at U.S. News before his recruitment by Bush.
Gerson has adopted his principal's style, remembered from a Yale rhetoric course: three points and a peroration, elevated rather than homey, with declarative sentences, no oratorical run-ups, with topical organizers like "prosperity with a purpose," "responsibility society" and "empowering faith-based institutions."
He knows his boss is reading Pat Tyler's "The Great Wall" for China policy, just as the strategic guru Rove is rereading William Roepke's "The Humane Economy." But Gerson no longer has time to read; he must turn out a draft of a foreign policy address to be given next week at the Reagan Library. He's looking for Reagan quotes to advocate advancing freedom but husbanding military power -- without appearing to straddle.
In all, the cast at 301 Congress reflects well on Bush's organizing ability, but it has not yet taken a body blow. Lest overconfidence show, gruffs Allbaugh, the manager, "There'll be no measuring for White House drapes." But that's what the entire Bush cast must be secretly doing. Even pols are human.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plans a Kosovo Visit, And the Serbs Are Surprised

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton may add a brief stop in Kosovo to his trip this month through southern Europe to highlight the importance of the peacekeeping mission there and to address tensions between Serbs and Albanians, administration officials said today.
The stopover would also be a new slap at President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, since under the agreement that brought an end to the NATO bombing, Kosovo is administered by the United Nations but formally remains part of Serbia. 
 An official at the Yugoslav mission to the United Nations in New York said she had heard nothing about the president's plans but expected official notification from Washington. "Kosovo is not an independent state that anybody can just jump in," the official said, declining to give her name.
But that appeared to be what the president intended to do. "He's going into a U.N.-controlled and patrolled area," a State Department official said. "The authority in Kosovo is in the U.N."
Aides involved in planning the trip say the president will very likely visit the United States military base in south-central Kosovo known as Camp Bondsteel, a 775-acre site surrounded by barbed wire, concrete barriers and guard towers.
The aides said that security concerns remain about visiting the province, which just months ago was being pelted by NATO bombs and where incidents of ethnic violence continue. White House aides said it was premature to announce the trip officially.
Officials said the visit would include a face-to-face meeting between Serbs and Albanians during which Mr. Clinton would urge them to put violence and hatred aside.
The president will likely call for more financial support from foreign governments for reconstruction in Kosovo, officials said. "I think it's an important trip to show the American commitment to the progress in Kosovo," an administration official said.
A State Department official said the government of Mr. Milosevic is expected to object to the trip.
But international law experts said the agreement that ended the war left some ambiguity about Kosovo's status.
"It's true that there is still Serbian sovereignty over Kosovo," said Allan Gerson, a former counsel to the United States mission to the United Nations and now a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations. "In a formal way, that's true. But it's in contradiction with other provisions that call for an economically and politically self-sufficient entity."
The schedule of Mr. Clinton's coming trip has already been juggled because of safety fears. The White House announced today that Mr. Clinton would delay and shorten his state visit to Greece, which was to begin on Monday, because of the prospect of violent anti-American protests there.

HEADLINE: Deal Is Struck On Restoring Medicare Aid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators and Clinton administration officials announced tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on legislation to restore some of the money cut from Medicare in 1997.
The cuts provoked howls of protest from the health care industry, which sent dozens of lobbyists to Capitol Hill to campaign for more money. 
 Representative Bill Thomas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, and Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House, said the deal would increase Medicare payments to most hospitals, nursing homes, health maintenance organizations and home health care agencies.
Mr. Thomas, Republican of California, said the agreement would increase Medicare spending by $12 billion over the next five years. That represents 7 percent to 10 percent of the amount cut by the 1997 law.
The agreement would gradually reduce huge disparities in what Medicare pays to train doctors in different parts of the country. As a result, many teaching hospitals in New York City would lose money, though the losses would be smaller than under earlier proposals.
Emerging from negotiations tonight, Mr. Thomas said: "We and the administration were partners in the Balanced Budget Act two years ago. Now we are partners in knocking the rough edges off that law."
Mr. Jennings said: "This is an honorable compromise. It lays a foundation for more significant Medicare reforms next year."
Even as lawmakers reached agreement on Medicare, they found themselves stymied on another health care measure. A bill to provide health insurance to hundreds of thousands of disabled people, passed with overwhelming bipartisan support in the House and the Senate, became snarled today in a tangle of partisan disagreements, raising doubts about whether it would become law before Congress adjourns for the year.
Different versions of this bill sailed through the Senate, 99 to 0, and the House, 412 to 9, earlier this year. But negotiations bogged down on the question of how to pay the comparatively modest cost, less than $1 billion over five years.
Democrats complained today that Republicans would offset the cost of aid for the disabled by cutting housing and other programs for people with low and moderate incomes.
People with disabilities have strongly supported the bill, which would allow them to keep Medicaid and Medicare coverage after they return to work. Under current law, they often lose such coverage if they earn a significant amount of money.
Advocates for the disabled and Democratic senators, including Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said they might oppose the bill if Republicans financed it by cutting other social programs. "We cannot support any legislation that would advance the lives of people with disabilities on the backs of poor and middle-class Americans," said Pat Wright, a lawyer at the Disability Rights Education and Defense Fund.
Republicans said that President Clinton was free to suggest other ways of covering the cost, but that he had not done so.
In talks on Medicare, two powerful New Yorkers -- Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Finance Committee, and Representative Charles B. Rangel, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee -- tried to protect the Medicare payments that New York hospitals receive for training doctors. Hospitals like Beth Israel in Manhattan and Montefiore in the Bronx get three or four times as much for each trainee as hospitals in Los Angeles and Cleveland.
But ultimately Mr. Thomas prevailed in his insistence that such disparities must be reduced. Under the agreement reached tonight, Medicare will move toward a standard national payment to teaching hospitals for each doctor in training.
Medicare now pays a different amount for each hospital, based on its historic costs. Under tonight's agreement, the highest-paid hospitals -- those with payments more than 40 percent above the national average for each hospital resident -- will not get any allowance for inflation in 2001 or 2002. And in the next three years, their payments will rise two percentage points less than the Consumer Price Index, while other teaching hospitals get a full allowance for inflation.
Mr. Thomas praised Mr. Moynihan and Mr. Rangel, saying the two men had persuaded New York hospitals that they needed to be "part of the solution" this year. "In the past," Mr. Thomas said, "there had been a degree of stonewalling," as New Yorkers resisted any cuts in Medicare payments to teaching hospitals.
The issue is colored by the politics surrounding Hillary Rodham Clinton's expected run for the Senate next year. Republicans said they did not want to be too generous to New York hospitals because they feared that she might get political credit for securing such largess.
Mr. Thomas said that the likely Republican candidate for senator, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City, had "zeroed in on this issue to make sure New York hospitals would be protected."
Much as she might like to fight for New York hospitals, Mrs. Clinton could not openly do so on Capitol Hill. Lawmakers of both parties said she would have alienated Republicans if she had tried to intervene.
In an interview, Representative Eliot L. Engel, Democrat of New York, said he believed Republicans wanted to "embarrass Mrs. Clinton by getting the White House to go along with legislation that would be devastating" to New York hospitals.

Flight Recorder Data Rule Out Some Causes
Federal investigators said an analysis of the flight data recorder from EgyptAir 990 showed that the plane's autopilot disconnected about eight seconds before the Boeing 767 began what seemed to be a controlled descent. The information appeared to rule out a malfunctioning autopilot's throwing the plane into a dive or thrust reversers' deploying by accident. Searchers in the Atlantic off Nantucket were still trying to recover the cockpit voice recorder. A1

HEADLINE: New State Park of 153 Acres Is Created on L.I.

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: KINGS PARK, N.Y., Nov. 10

 BODY:
In a major victory for environmentalists, Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that more than 80 percent of a former psychiatric center near Long Island Sound would be preserved as a wooded nature sanctuary and a new state park.
The Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development arm, had been preparing to seek bids on nearly all 567 acres of the Kings Park Psychiatric Center, the largest piece of undeveloped property on the North Shore of Long Island. The sale, however, was opposed by environmentalists and local officials. 
 Their efforts bore fruit today when Mr. Pataki unveiled a large sign here declaring that nearly 153 acres, including 4 miles of waterfront, had become the latest addition to the state park system and would be called Nissequogue River State Park.
Old stands of oak and other mature woodland that surround most of the remaining acreage are to be preserved under a plan in which only 95 acres will be available for private housing development. Altogether, Governor Pataki said, the plan will protect 472 acres of what was once the largest psychiatric care center in the country.
"By protecting this valuable property, we are providing New Yorkers with more open space for their enjoyment and ensuring that the most important and environmentally sensitive lands will be preserved for generations to come," Mr. Pataki said.
The new park, which is expected to open to the public next spring, will include the waterfront where the Nissequogue River enters Long Island Sound. The park will have two marinas, wildlife habitats, tidal pools and estuaries for migratory birds, and a green strip connected to existing trails. Mr. Pataki noted that the park would also include "a very important freshwater wetland that contains an egret rookery."
The new park will be across the water from both Sunken Meadow State Park and a Smithtown park on Smithtown Bay.
The development corporation will be responsible for selling the property under rules requiring three open acres for every acre that is built on. The governor said the rules would also guarantee the preservation of mature-growth forests and the conservation of an existing green strip along the eastern edge.
Mr. Pataki said questions raised in an article in Wednesday's New York Times about the fairness of bidding for development rights at another former center for the mentally ill on Long Island, Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood, would have no effect on the Kings Park project. Mr. Pataki said the state had hired a law firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, to review the Pilgrim State bidding process, which some of the losing bidders said was skewed by insider information and political favoritism.
Environmentalists who attended today's announcement were jubilant about the new park and the promises that private development of the remaining property would be limited.
"This is sensational," said Richard L. Amper Jr., executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society, which fought for the creation of the 100,000-acre pine barrens preserve in eastern Suffolk County in 1993. "Only a few months ago there was a threat that most of this was going to get paved over. Now most of it's going to be preserved."

HEADLINE: Treason Charge For Pakistan's Ousted Premier

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Thursday, Nov. 11

 BODY:
Almost a month after he was ousted from power in a swift bloodless coup, Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, has been accused of hijacking and kidnapping for what military officials say was his treasonous refusal to allow a plane carrying the army chief to land at an airport in the port city of Karachi.
If convicted, Mr. Sharif and other officials accuse in the case could face the death penalty. 
 The charges against Mr. Sharif, which became known this morning, are at the heart of the armed forces' justification for the Oct. 12 coup and revolve around the still murky events that precipitated the military takeover. The charges were leveled by the military in a formal complaint to the police, who will now undertake an investigation.
In the weeks since the coup, the army chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, and other military officials, have maintained that Mr. Sharif endangered the life of the general and about 200 passengers on his commercial flight by refusing the jet aircraft permission to land.
That afternoon, the prime minister had announced through the state news agency that he had fired the army chief while General Musharraf was in the air returning from an official visit to Sri Lanka.
But Mr. Sharif's action immediately set off an apparently well-oiled coup. As the general's commercial flight approached the Karachi airport, military officials say that his commercial Pakistan International Airlines flight was denied permission to land. They have said the Pakistan International Airlines plane had only seven minutes of fuel left by the time the military seized control of the airport and allowed it to land.
Mr. Sharif has been under house arrest since the coup and has not been allowed to speak to reporters or visiting international dignitaries. The military has yet to offer its proof of the prime minister's personal involvement in the air traffic control decisions about the plane's landing.
The United States on Wednesday appealed to the new military rulers of Pakistan to guarantee Mr. Sharif's legal rights. "We have continued to raise our concerns with Pakistani authorities about former Prime Minister Sharif's well-being and our concern he be accorded due process," said a State Department spokesman, James B. Foley.
American officials have also called for a return to democracy in Pakistan, but General Musharraf has adamantly refused to give any timetable for new elections. And the general said in a recent news conference that Mr. Sharif would have his chance to defend himself when he went on trial, suggesting that he may not be allowed to speak beforehand.
In a major televised address to the nation on Oct. 17, General Musharraf, who declared himself Pakistan's chief executive, described himself as having taken over in highly unusual circumstances "not of my making" and thanked the armed forces for intervening to ensure the flight's safe arrival.
"Who would believe that the chief of the army staff, having represented Pakistan in Sri Lanka, upon his return was denied landing in his own country and instead circumstances were created which would have forced our plane either to land in India or crash?" he said.
Other officials were accused of conspiring with Mr. Sharif. They include G. Ali Shah, a former government adviser, Shahid Abbasi, former director of Pakistan's national airline; Rana Maqbool, former police official in Sind, and A. Chaudhry, former director general of the Civil Aviation Authority.
Just hours after the midair drama, Gen. Musharraf declared a state of emergency, suspended the constitution and the Parliament and assumed sweeping authority to run the country.
While there are no reliable polls to gauge public sentiment, there has been no outpouring of public support for the ousted prime minister, who had been tarnished by accusations of corruption and autocratic rule.
Gen. Musharraf has promised that he will go after all the high-level officials and business people who have stolen public money -- and has said the real crackdown will begin next week. And he has set an extraordinarily ambitious domestic agenda for himself, saying he will revive the country's ailing economy, restore harmony among the rivalrous provinces and clean up the pervasive corruption and incompetence in the bureaucracy.
Until he achieves his goals, he has said, he will not be ready to return the country to call new elections.
In Washington, the Clinton administration appealed to Pakistan's military leaders to observe Mr. Sharif's legal rights.
Mr. Sharif was a protege of the late Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. The prime minister the general deposed, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was charged with a political murder and hanged in 1979.

HEADLINE: Picking the Right Data Superhighway

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
THE key to happiness in the Internet age is bandwidth. Bandwidth, bandwidth, bandwidth. Fat pipes, capable of sucking down Web pages, music files, video clips, e-mail and other forms of digital information and entertainment from the Internet in the blink of an eye. A data spigot that is always open, without busy signals and without the kinds of delays and service interruptions that drive most computer users mad.
Bandwidth -- a measure of the flow of information, in bits, that moves over a given distance in a period of time -- is the most important factor in the development of new types of services on the Internet, more so than increases in personal computer processing power or new types of Internet communications devices. 
 Until recently, high-bandwidth connections to the Internet were available mainly to businesses and certain lucky people willing and able to pay hundreds or even thousands of dollars a month for so-called broadband Internet access. But with the development of cable modems, digital subscriber line (D.S.L.) modems and satellite data services, several million Americans now have access to high-speed, broadband data services.
You can tell who they are by the smug looks on their faces. I know, because I see the face of a bandwidth glutton in the mirror each morning. I am rich in bandwidth, wallowing in a broadband trough.
In recent months I have had the luxury of using not just one broadband connection in my home office but three: a cable modem, a D.S.L. modem and a satellite modem. I've been testing them to see which one to keep, a decision that sooner or later a lot of Net surfers are going to make.
Now, only a small percentage of Americans live in the right geographic or service area to get any one of these services, and even fewer -- perhaps 1 percent, according to market reseachers -- have a choice of two. But by the grace of whatever digital deities watch over the Internet, my house in Austin is in a rare sweet spot, where cable, D.S.L. and satellite coverage overlap. I also had I.S.D.N. (integrated services digital network, which essentially combines the capacity of two phones lines), but I had it ripped from my house when its cost and complexity far outstripped the modest speed improvements it offered over regular dial-up phone service.
My files are downloaded in a snap. Web pages pop onto my screen. I do not think twice about downloading video clips or MP3 music files. Multiplayer network games and home videoconferences suddenly become practical. But the thing that changes everything is the fact that the Internet is always on, whenever I want it.
My biggest nightmare is that I will wake up someday and have to connect to the Internet using -- the horror, the horror -- an old-fashioned 56K modem on a dial-up telephone line.
Here is an example: Earlier this year, the movie trailer for "Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace" was made available for downloading from the Internet, but it was a 25-megabyte file. The fastest conventional modems available today, at 56K, can download nearly 56,000 bits per second. There are 8 bits in a byte, and, because of way binary numbers are counted, 1,048,576 bytes, or 8,388,608 bits, in a megabyte and roughly 200 million bits in a 25-megabyte file.
In the time it takes to do the calculation of how long it would take a regular modem to download the file, it would already be done via a cable or D.S.L. modem.
Alas, I cannot put all three broadband services on my expense account indefinitely, so I have to choose. Following is a discussion of the three broadband options, and what went into my decision.
 
Cable
The black coaxial cable that carries cable television signals to tens of millions of households can also handle high-bandwidth data connections. Analysts expect cable to become the dominant method for high-speed Internet connections at home, in part because cable already passes by the majority of houses in the country. But older cable systems were designed to be only one-way, sending video to the home, so cable providers have to upgrade their systems to give them the two-way capabilities needed for Internet access.
The top speed of a cable modem, at least in theory, is about 30 million bits per second (30 mbps), but a more realistic expectation is around 1 mbps. It can be a bit faster, but considering that most of us connect a cable modem to a 10-mbps Ethernet card, 30 mbps is a pipe dream. Uploading is somewhat slower, but that is usually not a problem for most home users.
More important is that cable downloading can be even slower, depending on how many of your neighbors are also using the neighborhood cable pipe at the same time. It is a shared service.
If you have the local cable line all to yourself, you can easily top 1 mbps. But if all of your neighbors have cable modems, things can slow down so much that you might actually yearn to have your dial-up modem back. If one of your cable-using neighbors starts running a Web server out of the home, you can imagine neighbors marching with torches and pitchforks. The two leading cable data services, Time Warner's Roadrunner and AT&T Cable's @Home, forbid residential customers to run Web server computers on the network.
Remember, however, that the practical speed of any broadband network, no matter what its theoretical speed, is limited by the slowest link on the network. If you link to a popular site that is congested, or to an obscure site that may be attached to the Internet through the equivalent of a hand-cranked computer, your multimegabit broadband connection will slow down accordingly.
My monthly cable data fee is $44.95 because I also subscribe to the cable company's standard (as opposed to basic) television services. If I were not already a cable television customer, I would have to become one to get the data services, taking my monthly cost to a minimum of about $65 a month. With my extra television channels, I'm now paying Time Warner $85 a month, which includes the rental of the cable modem. Adding e-mail addresses for family members costs $5 a month each. If I want to have a home page on the Web, it is $5 extra per month.
There was a setup and installation charge of $130, but periodic promotional deals cut that price in half. It took several frustrating exchanges with the local company before technicians finally came to my house. Over all, the installation process was about what I had come to expect from my cable company: a logistical nightmare.
Besides the Jekyll and Hyde speed issues that affect cable modems, a big drawback is that cable customers have no choice of Internet service providers. America Online and other popular I.S.P.'s are challenging the cable companies in court to open cable services to competition, but for now, it's either Roadrunner or @Home. Time Warner is my local cable company, and Roadrunner is the only choice I have for cable I.S.P. service.
Another concern is data security. Because it is a shared network, any of your devious neighbors with the technical expertise to run a network sniffer can intercept data packets from your computer. That is highly unlikely, but it is a risk.
Try this: Lie to your neighbors, telling them that hackers came in over your cable modem and wiped out your bank accounts. Mention that you have heard that D.S.L. service is more secure. Then you will have the cable network all to yourself.
 
D.S.L.
D.S.L., which stands for digital subscriber line, enables high-speed Internet connections to houses and small businesses over the same copper telephone lines that handle voice and fax calls. It does not interfere with voice traffic on the line, however, so one person can make or receive calls while another is using the same line to connect to the Internet. A big advantage, therefore, is that D.S.L. does not require the installation of a second phone line or cable service.
Its big drawback is that the service degrades quickly as a function of distance, so customers are limited to a geographic radius of about 3 miles from a telephone company's central office (technically, about 17,500 feet). The phone company first checks to see if your nearest central office offers digital service, then checks to see if you live close enough to it and finally checks the actual line to see if it can handle D.S.L. bandwidth.
If everything checks out, the phone company will send out a crew to install a splitter, which splits voice and data traffic on the line. A splitterless form of the service is also in the works.
There are many kinds of D.S.L. The most common for residential service is the asynchronous kind, A.D.S.L., or A.D.S.L Lite, which offers slightly lower data speeds. On an A.D.S.L. line, information is uploaded to the Internet at one speed, typically 128 kilobits per second, but downloaded at much higher speeds, typically 384 kilobits per second (kbps) to 1.544 megabits per second (mbps).
The downloading speed is most important for most people, so it is fair to say that downloading with D.S.L. is anywhere from 7 to 25 times as fast as with the fastest dial-up analog modems.
Unlike cable modem users, who share a line, each D.S.L. subscriber has a dedicated line to the central office. Therefore, the speed is more constant and predictable.
The top speed of a D.S.L. modem is basically determined by how much money you are willing to spend and how close you live to the central telephone office. I live 200 yards from a central office, and my basic D.S.L. service regularly achieves more than the minimum speed of 384 kbps downstream and often hovers near the 1.5 mbps maximum; it is 128 kbps upstream.
It costs about $70 a month, which includes the telephone company line charge of $39 a month, the fee of the Internet service provider, three e-mail addresses and other services for which the cable company charges extra.
I also paid $212 for a cable modem and a network adapter card. I leased the modem instead of buying one outright because I wanted to make sure it worked with the D.S.L. equipment at the phone company.
My monthly fee is high compared with other D.S.L. offerings around the country. In general, you can expect to pay $30 to $50 a month for basic service.
While D.S.L. cannot compete with cable in terms of speed during the day, when most of my neighbors are at their offices and I have the cable line mostly to myself, it is routinely faster than cable in the evenings, when my neighbors are sharing my cable pipe.
I can increase my guaranteed D.S.L. performance to a minimum of 384 kbps upstream and 1.544 mbps downstream by paying $170 or more a month.
The performance at this level is almost comparable with the speeds of T-1 lines, which many companies use to operate Web-based businesses. T-1 service typically costs $1,000 a month or more. Other forms of D.S.L. service can promise speeds up to 50 mbps, but at monthly prices that would probably exceed your mortgage payment.
As with cable, my D.S.L. connection is always on.
 
Satellite
Satellite data service has so much promise, especially for people in areas not served by D.S.L. or cable. But satellite also has many challenges. The Web is an interactive medium, while satellite is intrinsically a one-way medium (most of us do not routinely communicate with satellites). To send mouse clicks and typed commands to the Internet, you have to have an open telephone line in addition to the satellite connection.
Satellite service requires the installation of a receiver dish antenna, which is about the size of a garbage can lid and costs $200 to $400. The dish has to have a clear line of sight to the satellite, which in the New York City area is typically in the southwestern sky.
The installation and alignment of the dish is not for technological sissies, and I highly recommend paying the extra $200 to $300 for professional installation. Once installed, moreover, the data signal can be knocked out of whack by high winds or other bad weather conditions.
I signed up for Hughes DirecPC satellite data services as part of a package with Compaq Computer. Compaq, like many other PC makers, is trying to make it as easy as possible for its customers to be ready for broadband access. Besides the dish and installation cost, monthly satellite data service costs $30 to $130 a month, depending on how many hours you spend on line.
The $30 plan is good for a measly 25 hours a month. The $130 plan allows up to 200 hours a month (versus unlimited time with cable or D.S.L. service).
Satellite data services may someday be ubiquitous and reach speeds of 45 mbps, but for now the maximum speed is a relatively pokey 400 kbps. More users can mean slower speeds and, occasionally, busy signals when you're trying to connect with the local satellite I.S.P.
So far, so bad. The guys who wired my satellite system were apparently receiving their orders directly from deep space. Despite my request that they mount the dish on the side of the house and not drill holes in my roof, I now have a dish bolted through my roof.
Satellite is a swell choice for people who cannot get cable or D.S.L. service, especially people who live in remote areas. But a satellite broadband connection requires a phone line, and that can be a major problem if you live in Whitefish, Mont., and the nearest satellite I.S.P. is a long-distance call away in Bozeman.
 
Decisions
If you spend only a few minutes on line every day, switching to a broadband modem may not make much financial sense. But if you find yourself spending more time connected to the Internet each day and becoming more impatient with busy signals and the time spent waiting for pages to load, a broadband connection may be the solution.
Satellite was scratched off my list first. If I lived in an area where satellite was my only choice, I could live with it. But since I have a choice, satellite isn't it.
I'm still going to use an analog modem because it is impossible to take my cable modem and D.S.L. modem with me on trips.
The choice, then, comes down to two contenders, cable and D.S.L. Either is vastly more satisfactory than a regular modem, and if I had no choice and had to take one or the other, I would still consider myself very fortunate, no matter which one I had.
The speed is nice, but more than that, I have come to rely on the always-on connection. There are no busy signals, no delays in getting online, no screeching, beep-boop modem sounds and no interruptions if I stay idle longer than the service provider thinks is necessary.
Despite cable's theoretical speed advantage, the actual performances of cable and D.S.L. are comparable. Therefore, the determinants come down to price and, to a lesser extent, to security, the choice of I.S.P. and reliability.
If I had to choose -- and economics dictate that I must -- I would keep D.S.L. Performance is steady and reliable. From the start, the phone company has been easier to deal with than my cable company, although both could improve their customer service skills.
Naturally, many people have drawn exactly the opposite conclusion. They found their local phone company impossible to deal with and had no trouble with cable. It all depends on the skills and temperament of the local service providers. The best tactic, as always, is to ask neighbors and friends who have local broadband access about their experiences.

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits on Thursday about services that offer fast Internet connections misstated the translation of A.D.S.L. It is an abbreviation for asymmetric digital subscriber line, not asynchronous.
The article also referred incompletely to the ownership of the @Home cable Internet service. AT&T is the largest shareholder, not the only one.

D.S.L.
 
ROUTE -- Signals travel over ordinary telephone lines without disturbing any voice traffic.
 
ADVANTAGE -- The speed of the data connection is guaranteed.
 
DISADVANTAGE -- You must live close enough to a phone switching station.
 
SATELLITE
 
ROUTE -- Satellite transmissions go to a dish antenna.
 
ADVANTAGE -- No wires are necessary.
 
DISADVANTAGE -- Also needs a phone connection for sending mouse clicks and commands to the satellite. Fast speeds apply only to downloading.
 
CABLE
 
ROUTE -- Television cable.
 
ADVANTAGE -- If you have cable television, you should eventually be able to get this service.
 
DISADVANTAGE -- The more neighbors who log on, the slower it is.
(Ellen Weinstein)

"Waiting for the Phantom"
Earlier this year the movie trailer for "Star Wars: Episode One -- The Phantom Menace" was released on the Web for downloading. The downloading times for this 25-megabyte file -- at the speeds you are most likely to achieve -- give an idea of how fast various high-bandwidth connections can be. The speeds below are neither advertised maximums nor averages, but the best speeds I could get with my connections. PETER H. LEWIS
 
INTERNET CONNECTION
 
CABLE MODEM
Speed depends on how many people are using the connection. I found one to two million bits per second was what I was able to achieve. The best download time: just under two minutes. 1 min. 40 sec.
 
D.S.L.
The guaranteed download rate was 384,000 bits per second, but it can be faster. I found I was able to get speeds of just over one million bits per second, making it comparable to cable. 3 min. 20 sec.
 
SATELLITE
The best is 400,000 bits per second and it can be a lot slower. 8 min. 20 sec.
 
56K MODEM
Top speed is 53,000 bits per second. Typical speed is slower. Download is bound to take at least an hour. 1 hour
