HEADLINE: Talks on China Trade Deal In Peril, the U.S. Side Says

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Friday, Nov. 12

 BODY:
American officials expressed a sudden pessimism today about the prospects for a long-sought deal to get China into the World Trade Organization.
In a curt statement issued to reporters this morning, Charlene Barshefsky, the chief trade negotiator for the United States, said: "We came hoping to make progress. We are discouraged that progress has not been made at this point. The clock has nearly run out." 
 The turn came the morning after Chinese officials had asked President Clinton's negotiators to remain in Beijing at least one more day to continue talks on how far China must open its markets to qualify for membership in the trade organization.
Only hours before they issued the statement, American officials had sounded upbeat about the previous two days of talks here. It was not immediately clear whether Ms. Barshefsky issued the severe statement as a last-minute pressure tactic or whether the talks were collapsing.
During the talks this week, which included detailed discussions of specific trade issues in working groups, the United States presented China with an overall package of proposals.
"So far, the Chinese haven't shown any willingness to make a deal," an American official said late this morning, describing the growing frustration of American negotiators here. "It's across the board."
Ms. Barshefsky's public statement came after the Chinese postponed a meeting scheduled for 9 a.m. today. The Americans now plan to leave on Saturday, they say, after a final effort to learn whether the Chinese will come around at the last minute, or whether their position has seriously slipped from where it was last April, when Prime Minister Zhu Rongji visited Washington.
The Chinese are reluctant to open markets as fast as the United States and other Western countries demand, fearing the short-term unemployment and dislocations that outside competition could bring.
In an interview on Thursday, a senior government economist, Ji Chongwei, said: "If the United States can lower its demands this time, then there is likely to be an agreement. I hope the United States can be patient and understand the reality in China."
But President Clinton is under pressure from Congress and American companies to hold China to stringent requirements for opening its markets, as well as to protect American textile producers from sudden increases in imports from China.
President Clinton, speaking at the White House on Thursday, said, "When I know we have got an agreement or whether we haven't, I'll let you know." Mr. Clinton was described by aides as deeply involved in the talks, which are being held here by Ms. Barshefsky and the director of the National Economic Council, Gene Sperling.
After years of fumbling efforts, China and the United States, for political as well as economic reasons, want to achieve China's entry into the W.T.O., which sets trade rules and adjudicates trade disputes among countries. A breakdown would cast a sour note in bilateral relations, as China accuses the United States of holding it to punitive standards.
A deal was nearly struck in April, but President Clinton decided that China's concessions were insufficient to pass Congressional scrutiny.
Now the negotiations appear to be centered on a handful of major issues, including the rights of American companies to take majority stakes in Chinese companies, American restrictions on the import of Chinese textiles and whether the United States could unilaterally ban some Chinese products if it concludes that China is violating its commitments.
On Wednesday, working groups met here on specific topics, such as the right of foreign businesses to invest in -- and take control of -- Chinese banking, telecommunications and other companies. Prime Minister Zhu offered such openings in April, but the Chinese government has been under pressure to back off on some of the concessions to protect local industries and workers.
China hopes to gain entry soon into the trade organization, which now has 134 members, so it can participate in a new round of global trade talks that begin Nov. 30 in Seattle. It must first reach bilateral accords with major trading partners.
At the time of the April negotiations, the American trade office released a description of Mr. Zhu's concessions, apparently hoping to build support among American businesses. The release did elicit such support, but in China it caused a firestorm, in part because some affected ministries had not signed off on Mr. Zhu's concessions.

HEADLINE: EX-INDONESIA CHIEF GETS PARDON VOW

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11

 BODY:
The new president of Indonesia said here tonight that he had decided to pardon the nation's former leader, President Suharto, if Mr. Suharto is convicted of crimes as a result of an investigation into whether he and his family stole billions of dollars from the government.
President Abdurrahman Wahid insisted, however, that the corruption investigation would go forward, that Mr. Suharto would be pardoned only after a trial, and that the former leader's children and his friends would not be treated with similar leniency. 
 "Once he is found guilty in a court, then we will pardon him, because he was our president," President Wahid told a group of American business leaders and diplomats. "But not the rest of his family. This is very important. Not the family and not the cronies."
Mr. Wahid, a respected Islamic cleric who was elected last month after the freest balloting in decades in the world's fourth most populous nation, said he would also pardon his immediate predecessor, B. J. Habibie, should Mr. Habibie be accused of any crime.
Mr. Wahid's comments came on the eve of a White House meeting with President Clinton.
Mr. Suharto, 78, ruled Indonesia for 32 years. He and his children have been accused of stashing billions of dollars overseas, a charge that Mr. Suharto has denied. Still, corruption by the Suharto family and its friends is widely believed to have distorted the Indonesian economy, and allegations of such large-scale diversions of riches contributed to a wave of public fury that drove him from office in May 1998.
While the decision to pardon Mr. Suharto seems almost certain to be criticized by human rights advocates and others who have urged that the former president be brought to justice, it could short-circuit threats posed to Mr. Wahid's democratically elected government by Mr. Suharto's remaining allies within the powerful military.
In characteristically blunt comments, President Wahid acknowledged that his relationship with the military was problematic. "The idea of the supremacy of the civilians -- this is very important," he said. "But please remember, we are in a difficult position."
President Wahid said he believed that Mr. Suharto had indeed hidden vast amounts of money abroad. "He is richer than the state even," Mr. Wahid said at a meeting organized by the U.S.-Indonesia Society and the U.S.-Asean Business Council.
But he said President Suharto had been clever to hide his assets abroad under the names of his children and his friends, suggesting that it might be difficult to convict him of corruption. "The problem is that he stashed all the money abroad in the names of his cronies, his family -- not himself," President Wahid said.
Mr. Wahid's government announced late last month that it would reopen the Suharto inquiry that had been dropped as one of the final acts of Mr. Habibie's government.
The assignment was given to the new Attorney General, Marzuki Darusman, a former human rights commissioner who was an opponent of Mr. Suharto. The investigation is expected to focus on a complex of purportedly charitable foundations controlled by the Suharto family. Critics of the former president have long charged that the foundations were used to launder billions of dollars in bribes and other money stolen from the treasury.
In an apparent slip of the tongue, Mr. Wahid said, "I have instructed the attorney general to convict him," but then amended that to say, "to determine whether he's guilty or not."
Mr. Wahid is one of the few prominent political figures in Indonesia who are not tainted by allegations of corruption.
While he did not say so explicitly, the new president seemed to suggest that he still hoped to recover much of the money that may have been stolen -- if not from Mr. Suharto directly, then through his many wealthy children.
"His children are so rich they can pay the budget," Mr. Wahid said.
During the meeting tonight with senior American diplomats and executives of prominent American companies doing business in Indonesia, Mr. Wahid said the Indonesian economy was in "shambles" as a result of the Asian economic crisis.
He said he would ask President Clinton for continuing economic assistance and for help in establishing the rule of law in Indonesia, a nation that has known corrupt authoritarianism for most of its modern history.
"We were controlled by a government that looked after its own interests, not the interests of the people," he said. "We want to say to the American people, please help us in obtaining a good government -- an open one, an honest one."

HEADLINE: City Unions Shift Strategy On Bargaining

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Unhappy with their current contracts, leaders of New York City's municipal unions said yesterday that they would use new bargaining tactics that they hoped would help them overcome the Giuliani administration's past success in holding down wage increases.
The unions hope to negotiate their contracts one by one, starting with the teachers and the police officers, two powerful unions that are expected to make the strongest cases for large pay increases. The strategy would break a practice known as pattern bargaining, under which each of the city's municipal unions have for the last quarter century agreed to accept the same annual wage increases. 
 In theory, the new approach -- developed by the Municipal Labor Committee, a coalition of 75 unions representing nearly 300,000 city workers -- would improve the bargaining position of both large and small unions. The teachers and the police would be able to argue that big wage increases were needed to stem a debilitating flight of their members to the suburbs, while the weaker unions would try to piggyback on the stronger unions' success.
In past years, the city often maneuvered to begin talks with a weak union or a political ally in the hope of granting only a low wage increase that then set the pattern for all other unions.
"The problem with pattern bargaining," said Norman Seabrook, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association, "is if the city grabs one union leader and that leader folds under pressure, it can possibly ruin it for hundreds of thousands of hard-working union people in this city."
City Hall officials said yesterday that they would reject the union's new approach, insisting that the traditional practice of pattern bargaining was fairest for the city and its unions.
Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine, who is the mayor's chief labor negotiator, asserted that a piecemeal approach could make it extremely difficult for the city to reach agreements with every union and could enrage unions that end up with smaller pay increases than their counterparts.
"We're going to engage in pattern bargaining -- that's the only way that makes sense," Mr. Levine said. "It's more fair."
The municipal unions are calling their new approach "coordinated bargaining." Under this strategy, while unions negotiate individually, they would keep in close touch with other union leaders, who would advise them on what is an acceptable wage increase.
"This coordinated approach is different from everybody going it alone and it's different from coalition bargaining," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers and chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee. "The city's unions need to represent their members in different ways. Their members have different needs. The teachers have competitiveness issues with the suburbs. The police have competitiveness issues with the suburbs."
Representatives of all 75 municipal unions are scheduled to hold a conference in Princeton, N.J., this weekend to flesh out the negotiating strategy and sketch out specific demands. One proposal on the agenda is levying a special assessment on union members to finance an advertising campaign that would seek to line up public support for the municipal workers.
In an unusual move, 20 municipal union leaders have signed what they are calling a compact in which they pledge that when negotiating individually, they will not accept certain unsatisfactory terms. Probably the most important pledge in the compact is to accept only contracts that contain a substantial increase in base pay, which would not be linked to any increase in productivity.
"Our people have suffered long enough, and their sacrifices helped create the city's budget surplus," said Lee Saunders, chief administrator of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents 125,000 city workers. "The city is flush with money right now. What we're trying to do is get a fair piece of the economic pot. And we want to do that without having to tie an increase in base pay to productivity."
But Mr. Levine said the mayor would demand, as he has in the past, that any wage increases be accompanied by union pledges to increase productivity. "The mayor," Mr. Levine said, "has said over and over again that our position going into these negotiations is raises will be funded by labor productivity."
The unions embraced the new strategy after many members felt widespread disgust with the last round of contract negotiations, which were led by Stanley Hill, a close ally of the mayor who was executive director of District Council 37.
Other unions criticized Mr. Hill for accepting a contract that contained an unpopular two-year wage freeze and for not having stopped widespread vote-rigging that clinched the ratification of the contract and set a pattern for other unions. Mr. Hill, who was ousted by his parent union, has denied participation in or knowledge of the vote fraud, to which two of his top aides have pleaded guilty.
The current five-year contract, which expires next year for most city workers, contains the two-year wage freeze initially and a 13 percent raise over the last three years.
Unlike New York, most American cities do not have pattern bargaining. Normally the teachers negotiate one contract, another is negotiated by the uniformed unions, including the police and firefighters, and the union representing nonuniformed workers, like social workers, negotiates still another.
While the unions might look to what the others get, the raises in their contracts are not in lock step with each other.
Union officials said the lack of pattern bargaining in other cities has not created major union frictions or political problems because unions there do not expect carbon-copy wage increases.
Ms. Weingarten said the new approach was intended to make sure that City Hall did not dictate how bargaining was conducted. It also aims, she said, to accommodate weaker unions while giving flexibility to larger unions that have fallen behind their suburban counterparts. "In the past," she said, "lock step rigidity has hurt recruitment and retention not just with teachers, but with police and librarians."
Several union leaders said they would not be surprised if the new strategy were to turn into pattern bargaining, especially if the first union to secure a contract obtained a hefty wage increase.
One question that leaders of several smaller unions had was what would happen if the city awarded the police a 16 percent raise over four years to help them catch up with salaries for officers in the suburbs while insisting on only an 8 percent increase over four years for weaker, smaller unions.
Arthur Cheliotes, president of a Communications Workers Local 1180, which represents city middle managers, said, "Then we'd say, 'You've established a pattern. You always said you wanted pattern bargaining, so why are you now wanting to break pattern bargaining?' We'd say, 'If you don't match it, let's take it to arbitration.' Historically, arbitrators have usually followed what other unions obtained."
But, several unions leaders acknowledged, if the first union to negotiate received a small wage increase, other city unions would reject pattern bargaining.

HEADLINE: While Mrs. Clinton Looks On, Palestinian Officials Criticize Israel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 11

 BODY:
In a return visit to Palestinian territory today, Hillary Rodham Clinton was acclaimed anew as a champion of Palestinian nationhood, and then listened with visible discomfort as her hosts at a health care function here excoriated Israel for its alleged toxic contamination of Palestinian air and water.
Going furthest of all was the other first lady in the room: Suha Arafat, the wife of the Palestinian Authority president, who in a rare public address contended that the Israeli military had routinely used carcinogenic crowd-control gases in Gaza and the West Bank, creating a severe public health problem. 
 "Our people have been subjected to the daily intensive use of poisonous gas by the Israeli forces, which have led to an increase in cancer cases among women and children," Mrs. Arafat asserted.
Her comment sparked an immediate uproar in Israel, with opposition legislators demanding a retaliatory halt to planned West Bank troop withdrawals. Prime Minister Ehud Barak issued his own swift denunciation.
"These comments have no connection to reality, and it would have been better if they would have never been said," the prime minister's office said.
"Poisoning the public atmosphere does not help in bringing about success in these negotiations," the statement added.
On the second day of her tour in the Middle East, Mrs. Clinton, the first lady and presumptive senatorial candidate, who has tried hard to avoid such controversy in her regional tour, was unavoidably in the middle of it all.
The day began peaceably enough, with a Jerusalem hotel breakfast with Nava Barak, the prime minister's wife, and Reuma Weizman, the Israeli president's wife. With her daughter, Chelsea, and the Baraks' daughter Michal, Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Barak spent 90 minutes viewing new exhibits and laying a wreath at Yad Vashem, the Holocaust memorial and museum.
And after her two-hour foray into Palestinian territory, she returned to a cordial but uneventful celebrity's welcome at the Western Wall in the Jewish quarter of Jerusalem's Old City. Chaim and Libby Friedman, a vacationing Orthodox couple from Rockland County, watched as Mrs. Clinton headed toward the segregated women's section of the wall with Mrs. Barak, their daughters and a sunglassed phalanx of Secret Service and Shin Bet bodyguards.
"I don't know what her politics are," mused Mr. Friedman as the entourage passed. Commenting on Mrs. Clinton's likely opponent in the Senate race, he said, "Giuliani is tough. You know what he stands for." But Mrs. Friedman followed Mrs. Clinton to the wall, chatted with the her and returned to pronounce her "a nice person." Mr. Friedman did not disagree: "She comes across very well," he said.
As Mrs. Clinton frequently noted during her 30-hour tour here, this was her fifth visit to Israel, and the fourth since she moved into the White House. But her intimate knowledge of Israeli and Palestinian politics did not make it any easier to bridge the short but sharp divide between Ramallah and Jerusalem.
Stopping in Ramallah to announce a $3.8 million U.S.-financed maternal care program, Mrs. Clinton was greeted with a consistent message: It takes an independent state to raise a healthy child, Palestinian officials insisted. Calling "the legacy of three decades of Israeli occupation" one of environmental despoliation and rampant disease, they argued that only sovereignty and Israeli withdrawal would allow Palestinians to remedy their medical problems.
Mrs. Clinton, in remarks at the opening of the program here, had herself stressed the acute health care needs in the West Bank and Gaza. Fewer than half of the area's expectant mothers receive any prenatal care, she said.
But she devoted most of her brief address to the peace negotiations that were renewed here in Ramallah this morning. "This visit is particularly meaningful to me because today the Palestinian and Israeli people are at a crossroads, ready to take the hard decisions necessary for a just and lasting peace," she said.
Then, in what turned into a hard-edged West Bank version of the "listening tours" she conducted as a prospective Senate candidate in New York, Mrs. Clinton sat mute as public health professionals alternated attacks on Israel with effusive praise for her 1998 remark favoring an eventual Palestinian state.
"I would like to remind you of the words that you said to Israeli and Palestinian children," said Jihad Mashal, the Palestinian health minister. "Words that are inscribed in the hearts of all Palestinians, when you told them that the path to a just and real peace is the establishment of a Palestinian state."
What Mrs. Clinton actually said regarding Palestinian statehood last year -- in a spontaneous comment she never retracted -- was a more nuanced call for Palestinians to assume responsibility for their destiny.
Speaking to an international gathering of teenagers in Europe, Mrs. Clinton had stated in response to a question that it was "in the longterm interests of the Middle East for Palestine to be a state and for it to be a state that is responsible for its citizens' well-being, a state that has responsibility for providing education and health care and economic opportunity to its citizens, a state that has to accept the responsibility of governing."
In Israel itself, most cabinet ministers acknowledge that they see Palestinian independence as an inevitability. The real statehood issues are ones of terms and timing.
But Mrs. Clinton's statement has been viewed as a political problem in New York. And it created a sensation among Palestinians.
The remarks made by Palestinian officials today touched off even more criticism hours later, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's aides in New York chiding Mrs. Clinton for not confronting Mrs. Arafat. The fallout prompted Mrs. Clinton's office to offer a written statement by the first lady: "What was said today in Ramallah is an example of why the president at Oslo urged the parties to refrain from making inflammatory charges or engaging in excessive rhetoric and to deal with any issues at the negotiating table."
Mrs. Clinton's other recent statement on local sovereignty controversies seemed unfamiliar to Palestinian officials in Ramallah today: her letter to Orthodox leaders in New York in July supporting Jerusalem's status as Israel's "eternal and indivisible" capital. Yet they pointedly reiterated the longstanding Palestinian demand for a state incorporating Israeli-annexed East Jerusalem, including all of the Old City. 
"The next time I hope we will host you in our homeland in our capital, Jerusalem," said Mr. Mashal.
Minutes later, Mrs. Clinton kissed Mrs. Arafat goodbye and departed for Jerusalem.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Financial Companies Lead in a Broad Advance of Prices

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday, led by financial shares including American Express and Citigroup, after a government report on productivity eased investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates for a third time this year when policy makers meet on Tuesday.
The Nasdaq composite index rose to its 10th record in 11 sessions. 
 "It's another bit of evidence that the Fed won't raise interest rates, and it's good for equities," said Guy Truicko, who helps manage $1 billion for Unity Management in Garden City, N.Y. "The financials are ready to make another move. It's happening today, and I suspect it will continue after the Fed gets out of the way."
The Nasdaq index, rebounding from a 72-point loss, rose 23.86 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to close at 3,221.15, as Qualcomm soared on a favorable report from a J. P. Morgan Securities analyst.
The Dow Jones industrial average rallied 174.02 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,769.32, its biggest gain in two weeks. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 14.60 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,396.06. Seventeen stocks rose for every 13 that fell on the New York Stock Exchange.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 26/32, to 101 10/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.03 percent from 6.09 percent on Thursday.
Financial companies rose after the Labor Department reported that worker productivity was up more than expected in the third quarter and labor costs grew at a slower rate. The report may persuade the Fed to keep interest rates steady at the meeting on Tuesday. Stable or falling interest rates increase the value of financial companies' bond portfolios and can increase business for lenders.
The central bank raised its target rate for overnight loans between banks by a quarter of a point in both June and August. The federal funds target is now 5.25 percent.
American Express climbed 8 1/2 yesterday, to 154 1/4. J. P. Morgan gained 6 9/16, to 139 5/16, and General Electric, whose GE Capital is the largest nonbank finance company, advanced 1 3/8, to 135 3/8. Citigroup, the largest financial services company, led the S.& P. 500 higher, rising 2 3/4, to 54 7/8.
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company jumped 7 11/16, to 120. The big underwriter for initial stock sales advised United Parcel Service Inc. on its $5.47 billion stock sale on Wednesday. U.P.S. fell 3 7/8, to 70 1/8, retreating from the 50 percent gain it had in the first two days of trading.
Merrill Lynch, the biggest United States brokerage firm, jumped 7 11/16, to 83 3/16.
The Finisar Corporation, which makes fiber optic systems that permit high-speed data communications over computer networks, more than quadrupled in its first day of trading after an initial stock sale. Shares of the company rose 67 7/8, to 86 7/8. The shares opened at 95, giving the company a market value of $4.76 billion.
Qualcomm, a developer of cellular-phone technology, jumped 32 13/32 to 377 7/8, after an analyst at J. P. Morgan Securities, Gregory Geiling, raised his forecast on the stock price.
Mr. Geiling said in a report that he expected Qualcomm to reach $460 in the next 12 months, an increase from his previous prediction of $315, because the future sale of Qualcomm's phone business will help the company increase profits from its cellular-phone technology.
The Nasdaq was lower for much of the day, depressed by Intel, the computer-chip maker. The stock fell 3 3/16, to 76 3/16, after a Merrill Lynch analyst, Joseph Osha, cut his rating on concern that Intel faces stiffer competition from Advanced Micro Devices Inc.
Mr. Osha lowered his near-term rating on Intel to "accumulate" from "buy" and said the stock could reach $90 in 12 months, down from his previous estimate of $100. Advanced Micro said yesterday that it might break even in the fourth quarter on increased demand for its new Athlon chip, which competes with Intel's Pentium III processor. Advanced Micro shares closed down 1 5/8, at 26 9/16, after jumping 5 1/4.
Other semiconductor makers fell with Intel. Texas Instruments lost 11/16, to 100 3/4, and Micron Technology dropped 2, to 73 1/2.
Dell Computer, the direct seller of personal computers, fell 1 11/16, to 41 13/16, after reporting revenue growth that fell short of analysts' expectations.

HEADLINE: Year 2000 Insurance Is Hot on Wall St., but Not as a Sign of Fear

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Year 2000 insurance has been the hottest-selling item on Wall Street recently. And its popularity is one reason investors are less concerned than they were a few months ago about possible disruptions in business and trading when computers make the internal change to the new year.
To help ensure that cash will be readily available even if the changeover disrupts the financial system, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has been holding weekly auctions of options that will guarantee the availability of billions of dollars from Dec. 23 to Jan 12. 
 In just four weeks, the Fed has sold $306 billion of the options and has at least three more auctions planned. The amount paid for the insurance so far is just $4.9 million, a small price in markets where trillions are traded.
Other barometers also indicate that institutional and individual investors have been somewhat reassured leading up to the Century Date Change -- the Federal Reserve's preferred nomenclature for what is commonly referred to as the Y2K problem. Because of a design problem that may render computers unable to recognize "00" as 2000 when the new year rolls in, patchwork efforts have been made across all types of business and government, but the real test will come on Jan. 1.
Many Fed analysts had suggested this summer that central bank policy makers would not even consider raising short-term interest rates in November because higher rates could intensify any problems at the end of the year. But that view has changed. "Fears have subsided," said Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist of Merrill Lynch, who is now expecting a rate increase when the Fed meets on Tuesday.
Though risky securities usually command a higher yield than Treasury securities, which are backed by the government, the differences in those yields grew earlier this year. Recently, however, those spreads have narrowed, indicating that investors are willing to take on more risk even as the year draws to a close.
Stock prices, meanwhile, have continued to rise. Consumers are still buying big-ticket items, like automobiles. Mutual fund flows hint of no significant Year 2000 concern. And the fund company T. Rowe Price found in a recent survey that only one in 10 of its fund customers expected to alter investment strategy because of such concerns.
There was a rush this summer to buy the first six-month Treasury bills that mature in January 2000, so that proceeds could be invested after Jan. 1, but no rush this fall when the first three-month Treasury bills maturing in 2000 became available.
Investors have also taken advantage of opportunities created by the heightened concern earlier this year. Paul DeRosa, a partner at Mount Lucas Management, an asset management company in Princeton, N.J., bought mortgage-backed securities in early August when the spread between these securities and Treasuries was abnormally wide. The wide spread reflected, in part, a preference for Treasury securities, which would be much easier to buy and sell than mortgage-backed securities in a crisis. The spread has since narrowed, bringing Mr. DeRosa a profit.
Even Edward J. Yardeni, the chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities who has long warned of a Year 2000 recession because of the date change, is moderating his view.
"It doesn't look as though Y2K will slow down consumer demand as much as I thought," Mr. Yardeni said, adding that he would have to revise upward his fourth-quarter United States growth forecast, which has been just one-half percent.
"I probably will be one of the happiest people on the planet if nothing happens, since I'm worrying so much about it," he said. Still, he added that he had been "quite surprised by the increasing complacency."
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, says that intense preparations for the Year 2000 are paying off. "The good news," he said in a speech last month, "is that evidence is becoming more persuasive that our electronic infrastructure will be ready for the Century Date Change. The public's understanding of the degree of our Y2K readiness also has grown, and fears of widespread disruptions around the C.D.C. appear to be waning, though we are not as yet home free."
Whether the additional money is needed or not, the Fed's insurance program, which was announced in October, is doing at least part of its job. "It adds a level of comfort to the environment," said Paul Scheufele, managing director for liability management at Credit Suisse First Boston.
The insurance, sold through primary dealers in the Treasury market, is intended to assure that cash is available to keep fixed-income markets working smoothly, even in case of computer problems.
Primary dealers are the center of the repo market, where securities, like Treasuries, are traded for cash to meet the short-term needs of Wall Street firms, banks, mutual funds, hedge funds and corporations. The cash can be borrowed for as short a period as overnight and is a major means of financing the bets made in the fixed-income market. If Year 2000 problems send repo interest rates soaring, this market could dry up, with damaging ripples through the entire fixed-income market.
Primary dealers say the option insurance costs $15,000 to $30,000 per billion dollars, depending on the week covered. The most expensive is for the week beginning Thursday, Dec. 30, which includes the turn of the year. Options are also available for the week before and the week after. An option gives the dealer access to its face value in cash in exchange for securities as collateral. The interest rate is 1.5 percentage points over the target rate then for federal funds, now 5.25 percent.
The insurance would help if mutual funds or corporations suddenly had trouble borrowing. A mutual fund might need money to cover withdrawals at the end of the year, while a corporation might need money to cover a dividend payment.
"It insures that if we need cash, we would have the ability to get it," said David Sylvester, who runs the Stagecoach and Norwest Advantage money market funds for Wells Capital Management, a unit of Wells Fargo.
If a settlement problem arose in the repo market, making it more difficult for cash to move through the system, Mr. Scheufele said, the insurance options could be exercised to provide the funds.
Fear of the unknown could also make primary dealers reluctant to lend at the end of the year. But with this insurance, primary dealers know their maximum cost of borrowing -- 1.5 percentage points over the federal funds rate target.
"I am more comfortable lending out over the year end to my customers," Mr. Scheufele said.
Most important, primary dealers, who borrow heavily themselves to make their bets, will have the cash they need. Without this source of cash they might be forced to sell holdings, from Treasuries to mortgage-backed securities, to meet their obligations. Such dumping could prompt a marketwide selloff, cause panic among many investors and lead to gridlock in the fixed-income markets. It happened in 1998 after Russia defaulted on its debt and a major hedge fund nearly collapsed. The Federal Reserve ultimately cut its short-term interest rate three-quarters of a percentage point to ease the strain on the virtually frozen bond market.
The idea of the program, said Joe Blauvelt, the managing director responsible for the finance desk at J. P. Morgan Securities, is for the Fed to "gauge what kind of trading volatility people expect and then alleviate some of that pressure by offering more of the insurance options to the dealers." This is why the Fed has expanded the program from five auctions to seven and why the amount offered has increased with each auction.
But the stampede for the options is not a sign of pervasive fear, just another relatively inexpensive precaution.
"This is a no-brainer," Mr. Blauvelt said. "We are buying insurance in case the repo market goes away."
It is also good for job security, added Paul Thomas, head of government securities sales and trading at Merrill Lynch. "Knowing that this insurance was available, an individual cannot afford to walk into his boss's office at the end of the year and say we can't get cash," he said.
Among the signs of continued concern is a buildup in business inventories. Manufacturing inventories shot up in October, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management, indicating that executives are worried about getting deliveries of products early in the new year. At 51.1, the index reading in October was the first over 50 since November 1988.
And while some Year 2000 fears from last summer are easing, some new ones are turning up.
Money market fund managers were worried last summer about having enough cash to meet withdrawals near the end of the year. Now, they may have too much cash.
Mr. Sylvester, the fund manager, said it was now possible that money would pour into the bigger funds in December from midsize companies and local governments with cash on hand. So he will need places to invest his extra cash. And he has already made arrangements with primary dealers, who are willing to do so because they expect the Fed insurance program to help keep the repo market working smoothly.

HEADLINE: Is the Dollar Leaving Canada Feeling Drained?;
Capital Is Fleeing to the South As U.S. Companies Look North

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, when an outside company tried to buy MacMillan Bloedel, British Columbia's largest timber company, the provincial premier reacted angrily, saying: "B.C. is not for sale."
But on Nov. 1, MacMillan, an 80-year-old Canadian company, disappeared into the corporate maw of Weyerhaeuser in a deal worth $2.4 billion. Approval of the takeover came this summer from the Provincial Forestry Minister, David Zirnhelt, who said, "Icons don't make jobs." 
 Taking advantage of a neighboring economy newly open to foreign investment and a Canadian dollar trading near historic lows, Americans are vacuuming up Canadian companies at a record pace. In the first nine months of this year, American companies bought 181 companies for $24 billion, double the amount spent during the corresponding period last year, according to a survey by KPMG Corporate Finance.
"Canada has a 'for sale' sign on the lawn, courtesy of a very cheap exchange rate," said David Rosenberg, a senior economist at Nesbitt Burns, a major securities firm in Toronto. Although the Canadian dollar has strengthened slightly this year to 68 American cents, Canadian companies still seem cheap to American executives who remember the days in the 1960's when North America's two dollars were equal in value.
Today, American investors are also plunging into Canadian stocks. In the first seven months of this year, Americans increased their Canadian stockholdings by $6.5 billion, a sevenfold increase over the corresponding period two years ago. More American investment is on the way, according to 23 American portfolio managers surveyed in October about the Canadian markets by Broadgate Consultants, a capital markets communications firm.
"All of the investors surveyed said they would increase or maintain their Canadian positions over the next 12 months," John Silver, a Broadgate managing director, said from New York. "What caught my eye was the incredible amount of good will that American portfolio managers had toward Canadian companies."
Oddly, while Americans are investing heavily in Canadian stocks and companies, Canadians are funneling their money across the border in volumes evocative of capital flight from Latin America.
As of August, Canadians had, for the first time on record, more money invested in foreign stock markets than in Canadian markets, according to data compiled by Statistics Canada, a government agency.
Investing largely in American shares, Canadians now own at least $57 billion of foreign stocks -- almost $2,000 for each Canadian citizen. This drain has taken place despite tax credits for owning local stocks and a government-mandated 20 percent cap on foreign investments for registered retirement plans.
And while Canada's economy is only 7 percent the size of its southern neighbor, Canada has become the fourth-largest direct foreign investor in the United States. Last year, Canada, with 30 million inhabitants, had $87 billion invested in real assets in the United States. The United States, with nine times Canada's population, had $99.3 billion invested directly in Canada. During much of the 1990's, Canadian investment abroad increased at twice the rate as foreign investment here.
"It's fair to call it capital flight," Mr. Rosenberg said. "The irony is that while Canadians have become net sellers of Canadian-based mutual funds, foreigners have been dramatically lifting their investments in Canada."
And now, with oil and gasoline prices rising sharply this year and an Asian recovery fueling demand for minerals and wood products, those bets are starting to pay off as prospects improve for Canada's economy, which is heavily dependent on natural resources. Compared with last year, when the Toronto Stock Exchange 300, the market's main index, dropped 3 percent, the index has outperformed the equivalent in the United States, the Standard & Poor's 500, so far this year, rising 16.04 percent, compared with 13.57 percent.
"Everyone is looking for undiscovered stocks, which the rest of the marketplace has not discovered," Mr. Silver said of American interest in Canadian companies.
Yet after watching the Canadian dollar shrink by a third in value, Canadians are leery of investing in their own country.
Canadians tend to dwell on their economic negatives, especially the $50 billion a year in taxes that goes every year to service federal and provincial debts. Largely because of these interest payments, Canada's tax revenue equals 37 percent of its gross domestic product, compared with 32 percent for federal, state and local taxes in the United States.
Partly because of this higher tax burden, Canada's unemployment rate is 7.2 percent, well above the 4.1 percent rate in the United States. And Canada, in contrast to the United States, has not registered growth in real personal income during the 1990's. As the "brain drain" becomes a national conversation topic, half of 1,850 senior Canadian executives agreed in a recent survey with the statement: "Talented people are leaving the country due to high income taxes."
But, after budget cutting, the federal government here recorded a $2 billion surplus last year, which is expected to rise to nearly $4 billion this year. After lagging behind the United States during much of the 1990's, Canada is expected to equal the forecast of a 4 percent American growth rate this year. With budget surpluses expected to grow in coming years, businesspeople are lobbying heavily to use them to cut taxes and to pay down the $392 billion national debt.
Although Canada increased its total take in personal and corporate income taxes by 39 percent over the last five years, Paul Martin, the Finance Minister, vowed in a policy speech earlier this month to cut taxes in coming years.
Meanwhile, to American investors, a growing economy, an undervalued market, and a currency that appears to have stabilized are signals to buy.
AT&T and Ameritech this year bought up to the 20 percent limit on foreign ownership of Canadian telecommunications companies.
"There is more and more U.S. investment," said Bruce McWilliam, a lawyer here specializing in foreign investment in such companies. Referring to the 20 percent limits on foreign investment in banking, telecommunications and transport, he said, "They always want to try to come up to the limits of what is allowed under foreign investment rules."
In the finance sector, the CIT Group, a Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank unit based in Livingston, N.J., agreed in late October to pay $2.7 billion for the Newcourt Credit Group, a growing commercial finance company based in Toronto.
In western Canada's oil patch, two Houston companies are making big purchases. Burlington Resources is paying $1.9 billion for Poco Petroleums of Calgary, and Apache is paying $531 million for most of Shell Canada Ltd.'s oil producing properties. Shell is a unit of Royal Dutch/ Shell.
As some see it, in the oil and gas business -- and many other industries as well -- the border between the United States and Canada is being erased.
"The 49th parallel is gone -- just look at the deals," said Rick Roberge, a petroleum analyst with PricewaterhouseCoopers. Mr. Roberge, an Albertan who now works in mergers and acquisitions in Houston, also noted that Canadian energy companies had made purchases of American companies.
Fueling the activity, he said, was a 50 percent jump in natural gas prices since spring and the expected opening next year of a gas pipeline from western Canada to Chicago.
Interest in Canada has extended to the aviation industry. AMR, the parent of American Airlines, and UAL, parent of United Airlines, marshaled rival bids of about half a billion dollars each in an effort help Canadian allies wrest control of Canada's two major airlines. United and its partner, Air Canada, emerged as the winners this month after an American-backed bid was disbanded.
All these American investments in Canada, like those Canadians are making in the United States, reflect North America's rapid economic integration.
In the biggest deal on the part of Canadians in the United States, Canadian National Railway paid $2.4 billion this summer for Illinois Central. Building on an explosion in north-south trade after a free trade pact was signed a decade ago, the expanded railroad will carry freight from Canada to Chicago and on to New Orleans. In another major deal, Nortel Networks of Toronto, a unit of Northern Telecom and Canada's largest supplier of telephone equipment, agreed in mid-October to pay $2.1 billion for Clarify, an e-commerce software company based in San Jose, Calif.
And in a deal that makes Quebecor Printing the world's largest commercial printer, the Montreal-based company paid $1.4 billion for a major American rival, World Color Press, of Greenwich, Conn.
Despite this evidence of a two-way street, many people here focus on what they call the threatened loss of their sports icons -- professional hockey, basketball and baseball teams coveted by wealthy American investors. Bill Laurie, a St. Louis billionaire, for example, has been negotiating to buy the Vancouver Grizzlies basketball team.
Some commentators fear that Canadian National Hockey League teams are next.
"The Ottawa Senators will be first," Jeffrey Simpson, a columnist at The Globe and Mail newspaper in Toronto, predicted recently. "Within a year or two, or perhaps even sooner, the Calgary Flames, Edmonton Oilers and Vancouver Canucks will follow, leaving Canada with only the Toronto Maple Leafs and Montreal Canadiens."
Although the percentage of Canada's economy controlled by foreign companies is actually lower today than during the nationalist days of the 1970's, Canadian newspapers carry laments about some of the high-profile purchases.
"The great sucking sound from the south is creating a storm of troubles," Eric Reguly, a columnist, warned in a recent Globe and Mail article titled "The devouring of corporate Canada."
"The trend is depressingly familiar," he wrote. "A Canadian company grows, often with the tender loving care of the provincial and federal governments, gets big enough to attract attention on the international stage and -- zap! -- vanishes like a bug into a frog's mouth."
Fearing that Canada is losing corporate headquarters, he noted that Alcan Aluminium was merging with two rivals and setting up a head office in New York. The big American buyout was the topic of a speech delivered in September by David P. O'Brien, president of Canadian Pacific Ltd., before the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, the nation's largest business association.
"Canadian icons are falling like tenpins," said Mr. O'Brien, who is also chairman of the Business Council on National Issues, a private policy group. "The great Canadian fire sale is under way. Because of the low Canadian dollar, corporate Canada is easy pickings for countries with stronger currencies."
But few people predict a return to the restrictive investment policies of the 1970's.
"I don't necessarily like each and every one of those transactions, but this is part and parcel of the integration of North America," Raymond Chretien, Canada's ambassador to the United States, said in an interview in Washington. "It worries some people," the ambassador, a nephew of Prime Minister Jean Chretien, said, "but again if you look at the experience of the last 10 years, it usually balances out. We Canadians buy a lot in the U.S."

HEADLINE: Harlem's Pathmark Anchors a Commercial Revival on 125th Street

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
When a Pathmark store opened on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue in April, becoming the first full-service supermarket in Harlem in three decades, a few things needed to be adjusted. In response to feedback from customers, products from local bakeries were added, for example, and steps were taken to ease the delivery truck traffic that was clogging 124th Street.
But over all, the new supermarket has been a huge success, drawing 30,000 customers a week, said Harvey Gutman, a Pathmark spokesman. Only about 10 percent of the customers arrive by car, Mr. Gutman said, suggesting to the company that most come from Harlem or the Bronx. 
 Financed with private and public money, the Pathmark took years to build, in part because of the strong opposition from owners of independent supermarkets, who feared that they would be put out of business. And, in fact, some of the local stores have found it hard to compete. One of them, a Bravo market on 126th Street and Fifth Avenue, which was having a tough time even before the Pathmark opened, has closed.
Others are remodeling or adjusting. Juana Marte, the owner of the Park Avenue Supermarket on 126th Street and Park, said her sales were down to $5,000 a week from $18,000, forcing her to close off half of her store in the hope of finding a subtenant and to dismiss four of her six employees.
But while some grocers may be struggling, the Pathmark's popularity is having a big impact on the neighborhood. Not only has it altered the fortunes of the unsightly intersection where it is located, it is also helping to spur development across 125th Street.
Karen A. Phillips, the chief executive of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, the nonprofit organization that developed the Pathmark, said the store is expected to become the eastern anchor of a shopping strip extending along 125th Street.
The Pathmark has "done what it was supposed to do -- inspire new commercial development," Ms. Phillips said.
The western anchor will be Harlem U.S.A., a shopping center with a nine-screen multiplex between St. Nicholas Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard that is nearing completion. (The first tenant, an Old Navy store, is expected to open on Feb. 2.) On Nov. 3, plans were announced for the Harlem Center, an $85 million retail, office and hotel complex on state-owned land two blocks east of the new shopping center. The Abyssinian Development Corporation will develop the Harlem Center with Forest City Ratner, a private real estate development company.
Nearby, a new Metropolitan Life Insurance Financial Services Center with a high-tech meeting room opened in September on the site of Copeland's, a restaurant that went out of business a couple of years ago. In March, European American Bank, known as E.A.B., plans to open its first Harlem branch next to the new Met Life center, on the corner of Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard.
On the opposite end of the shopping strip, on 125th Street east of Lexington, just across from the Pathmark, there are plans to build a smaller shopping center with 10-screen multiplex.
Originally, the multiplex was a joint venture of the Blumenfeld Development Group, of Syosset, N.Y., and United Artists Cinema Theater. But David Blumenfeld, a vice president of the development company, said he was talking to other theater operators because United Artists was having financial problems. According to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, United Artists recently defaulted on a loan payment.
In August, the company, which has been closing unprofitable theaters, won a reprieve and more time to repay its lender. Officials of United Artists in Englewood, Colo., failed to return several telephone call seeking information about the company's plans.
"If U.A. hits financial trouble, we'll find a replacement," Mr. Blumenfeld said.
Cater-corner to the Pathmark, on the northwest corner of 125th Street and Lexington, plans are under way to replace a city-owned parking lot with an $8.8 million, two-story retail building with a Duane Reade and a Seaman Furniture store. The development team includes DDM Development and Services, a company with extensive experience in residential and commercial rehabilitation in East Harlem.
Last month, the New York Empowerment Zone Corporation, which administers a federal, state and city program aimed at stimulating economic development in Harlem, awarded the developers a $2.5 million loan for some of the construction costs, which will be higher than usual because the site is above a two-story subway station, said Nina De Martini-Day, one of the principals of DDM.
So far, the developers have not been able to make a deal with George Tsolekas, the owner of the Bus Stop Luncheonette, which is housed in a one-story building that is standing in the way of their project. Mr. Tsolekas, who has run the luncheonette for nearly three decades, said he had no plans to budge. Ms. De Martini-Day said she would prefer to build a new luncheonette for Mr. Tsolekas in her new building, but that she assumed she would have to build around him.
Anthony J. Cuti, the chairman and chief executive of Duane Reade, said he was drawn to the East Harlem location because of the success of Pathmark. It would be the chain's second store along 125th Street. "We're always influenced by the fact that a retail area is being elevated by recognized trademarks," he said. "Every time that happens, it brings a crowd."
The Harlem Center is expected to house a CVS store, bringing the neighborhood a taste of the drugstore wars that are occurring throughout the city. The Pathmark store also has a pharmacy.
As development increases, rents are also going up, making it hard for some smaller businesses to survive. Barbara Askins, the president of the 125th Street Business Improvement District, estimated that about a half-dozen stores would go out of business this year. Ideally, she said, some sort of a balance would be struck so that small stores on 125th Street, like those offering African-inspired products, would be able to co-exist with the national chain stores.
"It shouldn't become a commercial strip that looks like every other place," she said.
Despite all the new projects, however, there is little chance that 125th Street will soon be mistaken for a gentrified shopping strip. In June, the city auctioned off the Corn Exchange Building, a 19th-century landmark on the corner of Park Avenue, to Elie Hirschfeld, the son of Abe Hirschfeld, the real estate developer. When he bought the property, Mr. Hirschfeld said his group had not decided what to do with it. The building has been abandoned for so long that small trees are growing out its cornices.
Farther west, between Madison and Fifth Avenues, developers had hoped to demolish several buildings and replace them with a three-story retail and office building. But the proposal was abandoned after the principal developer, Nikos Kefalidis, died in last year's crash of Swissair Flight 111 off Nova Scotia.
One real estate broker who follows Harlem closely but did not want to be quoted by name said it was important to keep the neighborhood's revival in perspective, remembering that deals made there must still get government subsidies.
"We've got to be careful that we don't make of this market more than it is," he said.

HEADLINE: BELIEFS;
Three men, with three styles, in three venues, deliver three messages. Just perhaps, there is one very important common thread.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
On the surface, the three events were completely different -- and even more so the three individuals at the center of them. A small lunch, a private interview, a public lecture. An Italian Roman Catholic cardinal steeped in years of Vatican diplomacy; a Jordanian prince claiming direct descent, over 42 generations, from the prophet Muhammad; a Canadian philosopher known for his explorations of liberalism, ethics and the nature of modernity.
But jammed up one after another a few days back, the three encounters left the sense that beyond all the differences, some common thread wove them into a larger pattern. 
 The lunch was with Cardinal Achille Silvestrini. For many years he was papal under secretary of state, the Vatican's equivalent of foreign minister. Now he heads the Vatican's office for Eastern churches -- that is, for the churches originating in the Middle East and Eastern Europe that recognize the pope's authority but follow ancient, non-Western rites and practices.
Cardinal Silvestrini has just edited a collection of excerpts from talks that John Paul II has given in the course of 85 journeys all over the world. So strictly speaking, it was a publisher's lunch, a small gathering of journalists and churchmen to greet "A Pilgrim Pope" (K. S. Giniger/Andrews McMeel Universal).
But Cardinal Silvestrini was not in the United States to publicize a book. He was here to meet with the bishops from the Western Hemisphere who oversee non-Latin-rite Catholic churches founded by immigrants from Ukraine, Hungary, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and other countries.
One lunchtime topic, therefore, became the strained relations between the Catholic Church and Eastern Orthodox Christianity, strains that leave many of these Eastern-rite Catholics caught in the middle. Are they part of the solution, a bridge between divided parts of Christianity? Or are they part of the problem, a papal bridgehead that threatens Eastern Orthodoxy?
The other topic was the plight of Arab Christians, whose presence in the Middle East has fallen victim to the region's religious rivalries and economic disruption.
At the center of the conversation was, of course, the cardinal himself, always a diplomat in the best sense. His evenhanded assessments of the fears, fault lines and failures of different religious groups radiated sympathy and not blame. One could understand why a few years ago he was often listed among possible successors to John Paul II.
By now, his age, 76, might tell against him as a papal candidate. But one could imagine him still a "great elector," a man so respected by other cardinals that his support for a candidate would be extremely persuasive.
From His Eminence to His Royal Highness was a jolt. Prince El Hassan bin Talal of Jordan, the younger brother of the late King Hussein, is a compact, thickset man who bristles with energy, physical and intellectual. He is a veteran of international commissions and a serious patron of interfaith dialogue, but it is not surprising to learn he is also a black belt in martial arts.
On Monday, he had come from a meeting at the Council on Foreign Relations to the offices of the World Conference on Religion and Peace near the United Nations. In two weeks he will preside as chairman ofthe conference's Seventh World Assembly, which will bring more than 600 senior religious leaders together in Amman, Jordan, to discuss ways of resolving violent conflicts and building peaceful institutions.
Tossed a standard query about religion and violence, Prince Hassan was off and running. He quoted Pascal and Kierkegaard, Yehudi Menuhin, Vaclav Havel and the archbishop of Canterbury. He mentioned personal encounters in Bosnia, Prague, Ulster, Albania, Geneva, at the Wiesenthal Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles. No words recurred more than "universal," "pluralism," "code of ethics." World leaders and institutions had to pursue a "spiritual agenda" alongside the political and economic ones; humankind needed a universal morality developed on the basis of a genuine pluralism.
Charles Taylor was yet another contrast. On Monday evening, this Canadian scholar of Hegel and exacting analyst of modern identity in the magisterial work "Sources of the Self" (Harvard University Press, 1989) was lecturing on "Democracy and Exclusion" to a crowded auditorium at the New School for Social Research.
Where Prince Hassan had spilled his ideas out in a cascade, Professor Taylor unwrapped his carefully, step by step. Why, he asked, had the last two centuries of expanding democracy also been an era of unprecedented ethnic cleansing?
He cautioned against the complacent assumption that such conduct was merely atavistic "tribalism," destined to disappear with the progress of modernity. Exclusion, in one form or another, is also the child of popular sovereignty, he said: democracy, no less than authoritarian regimes, poses the question, Who is this "we" of "we the people"? And modern conditions make it increasingly unlikely that minorities will even allow themselves to be assimilated into the "we" of the majority. The problem, he said, is not going away but has somehow to be accommodated.
Were these three events anything more than fascinating but unconnected moments in an overheated New York schedule? Was it fanciful to think that they had suddenly lit up a window into the global web of people and projects, thinking, talking, organizing, that keep a deeply divided humanity from tearing itself apart, that might even, someday, stitch by stitch, bind it together?

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Speech on Security Concerns in Asia

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech that Steve Forbes made yesterday on United States policy toward China. The address was given at the Richard Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif.
It is time to set a new course for American foreign policy in Asia. We need a principled president who will deal with China from a position of strength. We need a president willing to say to Beijing in no uncertain terms: No more business as usual. 
 No more shutting our ears to the cries of Christians, Buddhists and others suffering religious persecution in Chinese gulags. No more turning a blind eye to Chinese spies in our nuclear labs. No more keeping silent about Chinese slave labor camps, forced abortions and death-factory orphanages. No more doing business with Chinese military-owned companies trafficking in weapons of mass destruction. No more leaving our children and our allies vulnerable to Chinese nuclear missiles. And no more sweetheart trade deals.
I share the American people's sense of frustration that our security and our values are constantly being trampled by Beijing, and the Clinton-Gore administration does nothing. It is weak. It is reactive. It is rudderless -- and it is wrong. . . .
Some believe the right course of action is to immediately revoke most-favored-nation trade status -- a form of "shock therapy" -- to force China to stop its egregious military and human rights abuses.
And that is an entirely understandable point of view, especially given the White House's approach of "hear no evil, see no evil, speak no evil" towards Beijing. Indeed, we may very well need to revoke M.F.N.
But first we need a real China policy, a tough China policy. We need Beijing to understand the rules of engagement.
And we need to begin using the economic and diplomatic tools at our disposal to effect real change in China: tough sanctions on Chinese military-owned companies; tough sanctions on Chinese companies using slave labor; tough sanctions on Chinese companies trafficking in weapons of mass destruction, and continuous, high-profile condemnations of Chinese human rights abuses in every international forum possible. . . .
The Forbes administration will rebuild -- not run down -- our national defenses. We will strengthen our alliances with key countries in the region to counterbalance the Chinese threat.
We will make it clear that we will defend Taiwan from a Chinese attack. As president, I will sign the bipartisan "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" offered by Senator Jesse Helms and Senator Robert Torricelli. This will lift restrictions on the sale of defensive weapons to Taiwan, including missile defense systems.
We will also deploy state-of-the-art missile defense systems, such as the sea-based Aegis system, to protect our allies and ourselves. Indeed, we must dramatically step up our research and development to reopen the technology gap and pull away from our adversaries.
When a Chinese general made a not-so-veiled threat to "nuke" Los Angeles over the Taiwan crisis several years ago, he made one thing abundantly clear: We must not allow China's growing nuclear arsenal to continue to threaten American cities and decouple the United States from our allies. . . .

HEADLINE: Big Increases In Productivity By Workers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The most debated economics issue in America today is whether workers are becoming ever more efficient, thanks to computers and the Internet. And the Labor Department, in the most comprehensive review of the data to date, says there has indeed been an improvement in this decade, mainly in the last four years.
The review, stretching back to 1959, came attached to the department's announcement yesterday that productivity -- the key measure of labor efficiency -- had shot up in the third quarter at an annual rate of 4.2 percent. Workers manufactured that much more on average for each hour on the job, or sold that much more or increased a huge variety of services. It was the biggest quarterly jump in nearly two years. 
 But quarterly productivity numbers bounce around. The third-quarter jump, for example, followed a rise of only six-tenths of a percent in the second quarter. What counts are long-term trends, and the Labor Department, using new information about the economy, revised its productivity data back 40 years. The new set of figures showed the 1990's to be unmistakably better than the 1970's and 1980's -- pulled up by four powerful years.
Four-year spurts occur from time to time. There was one in the 1980's, but it was not strong enough to raise the average for the whole decade as the last four years have done for the 1990's.
"There is no one point where we can say that we are on a new upward trend line," said Michael Harper, chief of the division of productivity research at the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Labor Department. "But in each of the last four years we have seen a little more evidence that we may be."
The latest productivity numbers seem likely to work against an increase in interest rates when the Federal Reserve's policy makers meet on Tuesday. More output per worker, at a moment of full employment in the United States, reduces the odds of shortages and rising prices, two big concerns of the Fed. Furthermore, retail sales leveled off in October, remaining unchanged from September, the Commerce Department said in a separate report yesterday.
Productivity gets much less public attention than inflation or economic growth or employment. The concept is more arcane. But no measure is more important. A nation's standard of living rises with productivity. Given limited population growth, a nation can acquire more goods and services only if the existing workers produce more in a given workday.
But the Labor Department's new numbers, for all the improvement they display, were not enough to settle a national debate over whether a "new economy" has really emerged.
They fail to answer these questions: Does the recent jump in productivity simply mean that companies and their workers are stretching themselves for a while to satisfy the strong demand of a booming economy, and when the economy cools so will their productivity? Or is there a permanent change in which computers and the Internet are generating the long-term efficiencies that in the past came with the spread of railroads, the invention of electricity and the proliferation of cars and trucks?
Optimists like Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, say the new economy has indeed arrived and if the revised numbers fail to capture the arrival, then they are still undermeasuring productivity. "We are on an accelerating productivity trend," he said.
But for the skeptics, the revisions leave too much unsaid. Productivity is calculated by adding up all the output of an economy, expressed in dollars, and then dividing by the number of labor hours spent to produce that output. The revisions increased the output side of the calculation, but failed to correct a mismeasurement of hours, says Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"The Government has done a terrible job in uncovering the labor effort required to produce all the new output," he said, noting that in his own case, Morgan Stanley tells the Labor Department that he has a 40-hour-a-week schedule, which is true. But in fact Mr. Roach works 70 or 80 hours, common practice on Wall Street and in other industries, too.
With hours rising only slowly in the official data, unit labor costs -- the amount spent on wages and benefits to produce each piece of merchandise or each service -- rose a very mild six-tenths of a percent in the third quarter. The increases remained similarly low in the revised data. Economists cite these numbers in trying to explain the low inflation rate in recent years.
The productivity revisions announced yesterday resulted in changes only for the years after 1973. From 1959 until 1973, productivity rose at an annual rate of 2.9 percent, the same as the old, unrevised average. Between 1973 and 1995, however, the rate of growth was a fairly steady 1.4 percent to 1.6 percent a year, Mr. Harper said. That was slower, of course, than the pre-1973 number, but a considerable improvement over the unrevised average of about 1 percent a year for the 1973 to 1995 period.
And then in 1995 a boom kicked in. Economic growth soared and productivity jumped to an annual growth rate of 2.6 percent from the third quarter of 1995 through this year's third quarter, far better than the 1.9 percent figure before the revision. For the decade as a whole, the new productivity growth rate was 2 percent a year, much better than the unrevised 1.3 percent.
The productivity revisions reflect new ways of measuring the nation's output announced recently by the Commerce Department. One major change has been in the calculation of inflation, which has been revised downward for the years since 1978. That raises the dollar value of the nation's output of goods and services. The dollar total is adjusted for inflation.
Another big change involves computer software, a huge item, particularly in recent years. For the first time, software is being counted as a lasting investment and therefore must be listed separately in the national accounts, adding greatly to the nation's total output. Under the old system, the tens of billions of dollars spent on software were considered an expense, lost in the value of other items.
Software, in effect, has become a capital investment, and the rise in the productivity growth rate in the late 1990's reflects a sharp increase in capital spending, not only for software but for new machinery and equipment, particularly computers.
Capital spending has contributed in the past to temporary surges in productivity. "What is not clear," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, "is what would happen if we pulled out the accelerating contribution of capital investment. How much would be left that reflects a fundamental change brought about by new technology analogous to the invention of the electric motor."

HEADLINE: In Expanding Platform, Forbes Attacks China

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: YORBA LINDA, Calif., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Steve Forbes, the wealthy magazine publisher and candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, came to the shrine dedicated to the president who opened modern diplomatic relations with China today and launched a bitter attack on the Chinese government, saying he would militarily contain the country and deny it trade relations if it did not moderate its behavior.
A day after delivering a speech on domestic issues at the Reagan Library north of Los Angeles, Mr. Forbes went to the Richard Nixon Library and Birthplace in this suburb of strip malls and tract homes 50 miles southeast of Los Angeles to offer what his staff had described as a major foreign policy address. But the speech included almost no mention of Europe or the rest of the globe and instead involved a series of angry denunciations of China, which he described as militarily and politically aggressive. 
The speech appeared to be part of Mr. Forbes's effort to transform himself from a candidate focused largely on one issue, tax reform, as had been the case in 1996, to the most conservative candidate in the presidential race on a range of issues, such as abortion, which he vigorously opposes, and military expansion, which he supports. Many conservatives criticize the Communist government of China as a major peril, and today Mr. Forbes embraced that position enthusiastically.
Mr. Forbes declared, in stark cold-war terms, "The rise of China as a new power is one of the greatest challenges we face as a nation as we enter the 21st century," and he compared the country to Germany and Japan in the years leading to World War II.
He insisted that if he were elected, there would be "no more leaving our children and our allies vulnerable to Chinese nuclear missiles."
"And no more sweetheart trade deals," he continued. He said he was opposed to China's entry into the World Trade Organization and said he would revoke China's most-favored-nation trade status if it did not open up politically and end its military threat to its neighbors, especially Taiwan.
In comments after his speech here, Mr. Forbes also attacked the International Monetary Fund, the body formed after World War II to foster financial stability, and another target of conservative ire.
"They have done enormous harm around the globe," he said of the fund, promising to close it down if elected. The speech today was in keeping with the overall tone of Mr. Forbes's campaign, in which he has generally described imminent threats he says America faces and the ways in which he would confront those threats. Mr. Forbes characterized China as America's greatest rival, and he suggested that even while the country was on the verge of what he described as a political implosion it was pursuing expansionist designs.
"In short, China is an immensely important yet intensely unstable country," Mr. Forbes said, and he quoted a Chinese dissident predicting that the Communist government would fall within 10 years.
He also said that he wanted to strengthen America's military involvement in Asia, where the country already maintains huge bases in Japan and South Korea. "America must be absolutely committed to remain the premier military power in the Pacific," he said.
Mr. Forbes was scornful of the Clinton administration's China policy, saying that in the president's first term it "had all the predictability of a drunk driving on the road." He added, "I call it a study in confusion and mixed signals, often degenerating into appeasement."
He said that he would put in place tough sanctions against any company owned by the Chinese military, companies that use prison labor and companies that traffic in weapons of mass destruction. If their behavior does not change, and if China does not halt its pattern of human rights abuses, particularly what he said is religious persecution, Mr. Forbes promised to cut back on China's access to American markets.
Mr. Forbes described the decade since the protests and killings at Tiananmen Square as a time "of drift, indecision and plain bad judgment" in which the country has been suffering increasing instability and a spiritual malaise.
But economists describe it as a time of unparalleled growth and increasing openness. Nicholas Lardy, a China scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C., said that while China has made clear threats to Taiwan, "the economic reforms have continued after Tiananmen."
China's total trade with other countries has nearly tripled, to about $325 billion last year from $112 billion in 1989. In fact, China's trade surplus with the United States has ballooned to more than $50 billion this year, as American consumers have become increasingly dependent on the inexpensive products shipped here from China.
In addition, foreign investment in China, welcomed by the Chinese government, has shot up from about $3 billion a year in the late 1980's to close to $45 billion a year now. And the country's economic growth rate has averaged 8 percent to 10 percent over the past decade, Mr. Lardy said, bringing prosperity to millions of people in China.
Mr. Forbes said there was "a great spiritual awakening going on behind the Great Wall today," and that he would support those movements and battle the government's religious persecution by beefing up Radio Free Asia and attempting to create a Web site focused on China.
"Now is the time to intensify our efforts to communicate the good news of freedom and faith in God to a people living in great darkness," Mr. Forbes said.
