HEADLINE: Clinton Signs Legislation Overhauling Banking Laws

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12

 BODY:
President Clinton signed into law today a sweeping overhaul of Depression-era banking laws. The measure lifts barriers in the industry and allows banks, securities firms and insurance companies to merge and to sell each other's products.
"This legislation is truly historic," President Clinton told a packed audience of lawmakers and top financial regulators. "We have done right by the American people." 
 The bill repeals parts of the 1933 Glass-Steagall Act and the 1956 Bank Holding Company Act to level the domestic playing field for United States financial companies and allow them to compete better in the evolving global financial marketplace.
Analysts and industry leaders say the measure will probably fuel a wave of mergers as companies compete to build financial supermarkets offering all the services customers need under one roof.
Financial stocks were winners on Wall Street today, with J. P. Morgan & Company, Citigroup, American Express and Merrill Lynch all posting big gains. That helped the Dow Jones industrial average end up 174.02 points, at 10,769.32.
The Senate approved the final bill by 90 to 8 on Nov. 4 and the House followed suit by a vote of 362 to 57. Congress had previously made almost a dozen unsuccessful attempts over the last 25 years to revise the statutes, which had increasingly come to be viewed as anachronisms.
"The world changes, and Congress and the laws have to change with it," said Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the Banking Committee and one of the bill's prime sponsors.
Supporters of the legislation say it will also benefit consumers, providing them with greater choice and convenience and spurring competition that will lead to lower prices.
"With this bill," Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said, "the American financial system takes a major step forward toward the 21st Century -- one that will benefit American consumers, business and the national economy." Opponents said it would have the opposite effect, creating behemoths that will raise fees, violate customers' privacy by sharing and selling their personal data, and put the stability of the financial system at risk.
The privacy issue was a key focus in the long and often heated negotiations that produced a compromise bill, and President Clinton made clear he still wanted to see more done to safeguard consumers' personal financial information.
President Clinton said the Treasury and White House would put together a legislative proposal to take to Congress next year that would extend the privacy provisions of the legislation.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Global Trade Harmony? Yeah, Right

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 13

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization was meant to usher in a glorious new era of global trade harmony, but in the five years since its creation, the trade body increasingly has become more of an international agreement to disagree.
That has been amply illustrated in the current gridlock on the agenda for negotiations at the rapidly approaching summit meeting of the organization, which makes the rules of global commerce and negotiates disputes among trading partners.
Despite more than two months of effort, countries have made little progress on figuring out a framework for negotiation. The ministers, due to meet in two weeks in Seattle, could be facing a big wish list from member countries that will be difficult, if not impossible, to tackle in the four-day meeting designed to help dismantle resilient barriers to international trade. 
 The seeds of the divisiveness were sown earlier this year with the bitter contest to select the first non-European head of the trade group. Emerging-market economies, which comprise most of the trade group's 135 members -- Estonia joined today -- flexed their numerical muscle and stuck to demands for a developing country choice.
The fissures that appeared during the selection fight continue to trouble the trade organization. In the run-up to Seattle, countries are dodging compromise and instead setting out their positions and refusing to budge to a degree that has imperiled a new round of global trade talks.
"There will be a meeting in Seattle, but I am seriously worried that there might not be a trade round," one trade envoy said. "The chances are getting slimmer every day," agreed Japan's trade diplomat, Yo ichi Suzuki.
Negotiators are meeting days and some nights to thrash out an agenda, which right now is a rambling 32-page document. Despite high-level efforts two weeks ago in Lausanne, Switzerland, to kick-start talks, not much has happened.
"Actually, we really haven't agreed on anything," one European envoy said. "Even on the motherhood paragraphs dealing with developing countries and technical cooperation, there are two or three points of divergence."
Despite two public warnings by Mike Moore, the director general of the organization, that the impasse threatens to torpedo the coming talks, countries continue "to lay out their positions and stick to them," according to one participant in the private negotiation meetings at the organization's Geneva headquarters.
"We're trying to work out what the playing field will be," said Australia's trade envoy, Geoffrey Raby. "But this is an extremely complex exercise that involves real national interests so, of course, countries want to try to tilt the playing field in their favor."
Mr. Moore has been convening small groups in his Green Room, a conference room near his office, in attempts to negotiate compromises. This week, some movement was apparently achieved in the thorniest area -- agriculture. Although the topic is part of the built-in agenda, meaning it has to be negotiated, delegates are laboring to figure just what the negotiations will encompass.
The European Union and Japan, which have strong farming sectors, are battling the United States, Australia and other agriculture exporting countries over the issue. The exporters want agricultural goods to be treated just like any other goods, with subsidies and other protections eliminated.
Earlier this week, several large farming groups said in Geneva that they opposed giving in to exporting countries on the issue. Australia's Trade Minister, Mark Vaile, accused the European Union and its allies of thwarting preparations for Seattle by refusing to give any concessions on the issue.
A few days ago, a new two-page text on agriculture emerged informally from Green Room discussions. It dropped the reference to multifunctionality -- allowing reasons such as farming's role in maintaining rural life -- to be used to justify agricultural support.
Japan, however, does not agree. "The issue is too politically sensitive to be decided here," Mr. Suzuki said.
Efforts to open to the public the trade organization's mostly closed proceedings also seem to have fallen flat, with most countries sticking to the idea that they belong to a government-to-government organization. Underlining this stubbornness is a failed attempt by Canada to introduce a new preamble to the agenda that explains in everyday English the mission and goals of the trade body. Canada's delegation had hoped such an approach would deflect criticism from labor and environmental organizations, which have protested that the trade group has enormous power and little accountability.
With a short time left before hundreds of officials gather, Mr. Moore has indicated he plans to come up with two more drafts in the hope of reducing the document to a manageable negotiating size. However, it is unclear that any new draft would look much different from the current version -- which is the second draft -- although basic editing would slim it down.
The key, diplomats agreed, is the political will to get it done. No one country is to blame, most said, but the enormous differences between the United States and the European Union have impeded progress.
 The accepted wisdom is that despite foot-dragging on agriculture, the Europeans want a wide-ranging set of trade talks to open markets and bolster the Continent's economies. The Clinton administration, enjoying a booming economy, wants a more limited agenda, especially on the verge of an election year when there is no point in antagonizing voting constituencies.
"There is no talk of boycotting Seattle, but there is talk of putting off the round for a couple of years," a European negotiator said. "But that would be dangerous indeed because a lot of momentum would go out of the trade liberalization process."

LENGTH: 473 words

HEADLINE: 'A Sand County Almanac' at 50

 BODY:
Fifty years ago, Aldo Leopold's ecological testament, "A Sand County Almanac," was published. It was a posthumous book, appearing a year and a half after Leopold died of a heart attack in April 1948 at the age of 61. A graduate of the Yale Forestry School and a 17-year veteran of the United States Forest Service, Leopold had his greatest influence, during his lifetime, as a professor of game management at the University of Wisconsin. But it is the "Almanac," his meditations on a Wisconsin River farm and an unequivocal statement of conscience, that will carry his influence and his good name down the generations.
Leopold's principal and extraordinary contribution to our world was to articulate the idea of a land ethic. The human relation to land, he wrote, "is still strictly economic, entailing privileges but not obligations." Leopold believed that the basis of successful conservation was to extend to nature the ethical sense of responsibility that humans extend to each other. This idea has acquired tremendous force since "A Sand County Almanac" first appeared. The fact that the idea now seems unexceptionable is a measure of its widespread influence. 
 Fifty years is both a very short and a very long time in the life of a good idea. The power of Leopold's argument -- buttressed as it is by his clear, vigorous prose -- has not been blunted in the least. In fact, his argument seems more urgently true now than ever. In the past 50 years Leopold's work has helped drive the environmental movement. Yet the tendencies he lamented, summed up in the phrase "despoliation of land," have accelerated almost out of control.
Leopold will last not because he captured a moment or a feeling, though he does both in the first sections of "A Sand County Almanac." He will last because we have scarcely begun to work out the implications of his ideas. He suggested an "ecological interpretation of history," which has only recently begun to be written. He recognized that the "ability to see the cultural value of wilderness boils down . . . to a question of intellectual humility." He described a dynamic that still threatens wildness: "the very scarcity of wild places, reacting with the mores of advertising and promotion, tends to defeat any deliberate effort to prevent their growing still more scarce."
These are formidable ideas. But none are more challenging than Leopold's land ethic. It requires a re-rooting in nature, a forsaking of the hope that we can save wild or even open land on the basis of its economic value. We are busy, Leopold says, "inventing subterfuges to give nature economic importance." They will not work. There is a risk involved in creating a truly ethical relation to the land. But Leopold believed in risk. "Too much safety," he wrote, "seems to yield only danger in the long run." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Church Council Meets Amid Financial Crisis

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Nov. 12

 BODY:
In the 49 years since its founding, the National Council of Churches has distinguished itself by strongly supporting civil rights legislation, helping resettle many thousands of refugees in the United States and sponsoring two influential Bible translations that have sold nearly 70 million copies.
But this week, with the organization's leaders meeting here to celebrate the upcoming golden anniversary, the council faced a financial crisis and the question of what role it should play in an ecumenical movement it once helped lead but which has moved far beyond it. 
 Signaling a desire to begin a new chapter, the council turned to new leadership, under two men as well known in the secular world as they are in religious life.
In the final session of its conference this morning, the council's governing General Assembly elected a new general secretary, or top officer, the Rev. Robert W. Edgar, 56, a United Methodist minister who served in Congress from 1975 to 1987 as a Democratic Representative from Pennsylvania's historically Republican Seventh District. Mr. Edgar, who was named to a four-year term, was selected by a search committee formed a year ago. Mr. Edgar, who spent the past decade as president of Claremont School of Theology in Claremont, Calif., will assume the job on Jan. 1, succeeding the Rev. Joan B. Campbell, who stepped down after two terms.
The previous evening, the council held a worship service to install Andrew Young, the former United States representative to the United Nations and an ordained United Church of Christ minister, as the council's new president. The service took place in Cleveland's Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. John the Evangelist, with the call to worship led by Bishop Anthony M. Pilla, and it offered a tantalizing vision of how broad the ecumenical movement might be in the United States.
The council represents only a partial vision of American Christianity, with 35 member denominations -- mainline Protestant, predominately African-American and Eastern Orthodox. It does not include Roman Catholics, among other churches.
In an interview, Mr. Edgar said the council had a "fairly clear vision" of itself in its first three decades, especially in the 1960's, when the struggle for civil rights for black Americans was at its height. Since then, he said, the council has "done good work, but has been invisible at the local level."
Mr. Edgar said he would like to help the council offer greater support and encouragement in cooperation to local councils of churches. He also said he wanted to ask the member denominations what they thought the ecumenical movement could be and "then shape the N.C.C. to meet that need."
Mr. Edgar arrived at Claremont in 1990, when he said the school's endowment had been reduced to less than $4 million, from more than $7 million. He will leave the school, he said, with the endowment at $22 million, several buildings renovated and the budget balanced.
Such experience would seem vital in taking charge of the council. The organization is facing a deficit estimated at $3.5 million in an annual budget of nearly $70 million, a shortage that officials say resulted largely from the expense of an examination by outside consultants and a recommended overhaul of the council's financial operations.
Concern among denominations over the council's financial management peaked this fall when the United Methodist Church, a major contributor, said it would withhold a payment of more than $300,000 until the council had its fiscal house in order. The money is still being withheld.
Council officials say the staff will be reduced through elimination of vacant positions, attrition through retirements and layoffs. It is a course that would echo cuts made earlier this decade by several major Protestant churches at their national headquarters, as they struggled with their own financial crises.
Ms. Campbell, general secretary since 1991, said she thought part of the council's problem, shared by many national denominations, resulted from a trend within organized religion, as Americans increasingly prefer to see their donations go to causes at a local level or to a specific need, such as help for victims of a natural disaster. "In our system, we have very modest -- and less and less -- unrestricted money" for general operations, she said.
The Rev. Wes Granberg-Michelson, general secretary of the Reformed Church in America and a chairman of a committee formed to help the council restructure itself financially, said that while no one should underestimate "the sense of crisis" within the organization, the council's leaders had nontheless reached a consensus this week on steps to turn this around. They should put the council on a sound financial basis, he said.
Part of the council's difficulties might also lie in the very success of promoting understanding and cooperation among the different faiths. Rather than a single, centralized organization like the council leading the movement, important ecumenical work is now being carried on by churches at the local level, and by denominations that forge formal ties with each other. There is also a wider cast of potential partners for ecumenical efforts than there was 50 years ago, particularly among Catholics, evangelical Protestants and Pentecostals.
Another ecumenical organization attempting a transition to a new era, the World Council of Churches, is further along in the process. It is also a half-century old and now represents nearly 340 denominations. Both the national and world councils were founded largely by Protestants in a bygone era when their churches were dominant religious forces in their societies.
The Rev. Konrad Raiser, the world council's general secretary, said in an interview this week that that organization had been trying to shift its center of gravity and adopt a broader vision, so that its member churches -- not the organization's own agencies -- set the agenda, while it reaches out to other Christians.
"What really matters is to look at the council as a fellowship of churches," he said, referring to the World Council. "Our earlier understanding was very much focused around the council as an advocate of issues, an initiator of programs that were in some ways seen as a challenge to the churches."

HEADLINE: South Carolina Argues Future of a Rebel Flag

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 12

 BODY:
Carrying the battle flag of the Confederacy through this birthplace of the Civil War, the hundreds of men parading in their gray uniforms and the women in their black widow's weeds knew exactly what was at stake in their struggle over the memory of an earlier era.
Their immediate journey was to rebury the remains of 22 Confederate sailors and a 3-year-old boy whose first resting place had mistakenly been covered by the football stadium at the Citadel, the military college here. 
 More important, the marchers and the 2,500 others who joined them at Magnolia Cemetery today were there to invest the history and the symbols of the region with tangible meaning, which at that moment were under attack by many who see them in far less glorious terms.
Just a few hours earlier, the governor of South Carolina, Jim Hodges, had spent the morning asking business leaders to help him find an honorable way to remove the battle flag from atop the State Capitol. It has flown there, usually in the face of many offended people, since 1962. The Legislature, which has debated bills to remove the flag, has resisted efforts to take down the flag, even after South Carolina became the last state flying it.
The most serious of those efforts began this summer, when the national and local branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People gave up trying to negotiate the removal of the flag and announced an economic boycott of South Carolina.
Fearing the effects of the boycott and the growing damage to the state's reputation, an increasing number of organizations have called for the flag's removal, including the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce, the state Baptist Convention and Bob Jones University, a bastion of the religious right.
But even some legislators who might be inclined to compromise say they will not do so while an economic musket is pointed at their heads, and much of that traditional, prideful stubbornness was on display today at Magnolia Cemetery.
The crowd, entirely white, was hardly representative of the state, but many of those present said they had felt a twinge of resentment when a national organization tried to tell them what symbols their state was allowed to display.
"The people of South Carolina have the right to choose what flags they want to fly," said George Bragdon, a warehouse supervisor from Lancaster, S.C., who was dressed in the gray flannel of the 12th South Carolina Brigade, Company I, in which his great-grandfather had served. "No one from any other state can tell us what to do. I would remind the N.A.A.C.P. that the South was willing to go to war to protect its states rights, and we are still stubborn enough not to give in to this boycott."
Governor Hodges, though he is eager to have the flag removed, essentially had the same message in the speeches he has given all week, including one this morning to the state Chamber of Commerce.
"The N.A.A.C.P. boycott has drawn attention to the problem, which has been helpful in trying to move it towards closure," Governor Hodges said.
"But it is clear that in my discussions with legislators who hold the cards in whether or not this bill will pass, that the boycott now stands as an obstacle," he added. "Clearly the only way to show progress on this issue, I believe, is for the N.A.A.C.P. to suspend its boycott as the first step towards resolution."
If the N.A.A.C.P. agrees to do so, the governor said, he will not only press the Legislature to move the flag elsewhere on the statehouse grounds, but will work to enact a state holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr. and to build a museum in Columbia that would reflect the heritage of both blacks and whites in South Carolina.
But the N.A.A.C.P. has rejected the proposal and intends to continue its boycott.
Dwight C. James, executive director of the South Carolina Conference of Branches of the N.A.A.C.P., said today that it was ludicrous to try to appease blacks with the offer of a King holiday and questioned whether an end to the boycott would lead to negotiations.
"There were no discussions or negotiations before we called for these sanctions, and there wouldn't be any if we withdrew," Mr. James said. "We are committed to standing firm to the end, and it is up to the leadership of the state to change."
The N.A.A.C.P.'s effort is the latest attempt to remove the flag since it was put up in 1962 as a gesture of defiance to the civil rights movement. Most recently, then-Gov. David Beasley led a vocal campaign in 1997 but the Legislature rejected his proposal to take down the flag.
Mr. James and other proponents of removing the flag see it as a symbol of slavery, and say the flag's presence over the seat of government is indicative of the racial climate in the state. Many Southerners, while acknowledging that the flag has been appropriated by white hate groups, insist that it is not a racist symbol, but rather a banner under which many of their relatives fought and died.
"This was a soldier's flag, and that's why it's wrapped around those caskets right there," said Randy Burbage, president of the Confederate Heritage Trust, the group that dug up the sailors' remains from under the stadium and organized the reinterment. "This is our heritage, and if the flag comes down, then next the monuments will come down, and then the street names, and then we will forget our history. We can't forget that this was America's greatest tragedy."
Mr. Burbage wept as he helped lower the pine caskets into a long trench grave at Magnolia Cemetery, which was full of 135-year-old monuments to fallen rebels. The remains were discovered in June after the Heritage Trust, working with a state archaeologist, realized that a cemetery from the 1860's was beneath the stadium, which was built in 1948.
At today's ceremony, each of the flags over the coffins was carefully folded by re-enactors in Confederate uniforms, and each was handed to a woman dressed in the black hoop skirt and veil.
Then, the crowd sang "Dixie," the soldiers let loose a rebel yell, and there was a barrage of gunpowder salutes from rifles and artillery pieces.
One state official looking on let loose a barrage of his own, his mocking voice a reminder of the deep trench that still divides the state.
"The N.A.A.C.P. doesn't care about the flag, they're just doing this to raise money," said State Senator Arthur Ravenel, a Republican who represents the Charleston area.
"I would say that not only will the state not negotiate under threat of a boycott," Mr. Ravenel said, "but we'll never vote to take down that flag at all."

HEADLINE: U.S. Negotiators Extend Trade Talks in Beijing for 4th Day

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Saturday, Nov. 13

 BODY:
In a last-ditch effort to reach an agreement on China's entry into the World Trade Organization, American negotiators decided overnight to stay here a fourth day for at least one more meeting.
On Friday night, the Americans, practicing high-stakes brinkmanship, had said that the talks so far had been fruitless and announced that they were heading home. 
 But after an exchange of messages during the night, the two sides agreed to meet again today to make another try.
So far, the Chinese have balked at demands for the thorough opening of domestic industries to foreign ownership, which the United States insists is a condition for China's entry into the global trade body.
Early today, Tom Tripp, the spokesman for the American team, said, "Although progress has been slow in the talks so far, because of the importance of the issues, both sides thought it would be useful to have an additional day of meetings."
During the night, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, was for the first time this week asked to meet Prime Minister Zhu Rongji. They met this morning inside the government's leadership compound, Zhongnanhai.
In private, American officials expressed pessimism and disappointment that, up to now, the Chinese had been unable to match the market-opening concessions Mr. Zhu made in Washington last April.
One American official here said this morning, "There's been very little progress at all toward anything that could be considered a commercially satisfactory agreement in the United States."
While the Clinton administration desperately wants to secure China's entry into the trade body as a calming force in stormy Chinese-American relations, it is under pressure from Congress and American business interests to gain sweeping concessions.
The Chinese, while proceeding slowly toward a market economy, fear the short-term social dislocations of opening industries to outside competition and have pressed for more lenient terms of entry.
This week's talks, which follow more than a decade of fitful negotiations and a near-agreement in April, have been widely seen as make-or-break, and the administration is anxious to pursue all possibilities.
In Washington on Friday President Clinton said differences remained on a "finite and limited number of issues" and added, "I have not given up."
Bringing China soon into the world organization has been a prime goal of Mr. Clinton, and failure would be a setback for his strategy of engagement with the world's most populous country.
The Chinese have been publicly silent about this week's negotiations, and the Americans have not publicly described the remaining areas of disagreement. One American diplomat said major points of contention included the American demand that China allow majority foreign ownership in the telecommunications and financial services industries.
Other American officials said the negotiators had particularly pressed China, without success, to open its securities industry to outsiders. Securing a foothold in China for Wall Street companies, they said, could broaden the political support for a deal even if majority foreign ownership in telecommunications and other sensitive sectors was blocked.
In a visit to Washington in April, Prime Minister Zhu agreed to open up most industries to majority ownership by foreigners. But this week the Chinese delegation, led by Foreign Trade Minister Shi Guangsheng, has so far refused to match the April offer in important respects, American officials said.
China's backsliding may reflect not only Mr. Zhu's apparently diminished power but a broader shift in the political atmosphere here, toward a more conservative and nationalistic stance. This change gathered force during the Kosovo war last spring, when China vehemently opposed the NATO bombing campaign, and it accelerated after the bombing of its embassy in Belgrade, in which three Chinese were killed.
A failure to join the trade organization now would not mean that China's gradual opening to outside competition, and its efforts to overhaul hidebound state enterprises would come to a stop, economists here and abroad said.
China and the United States had both hoped that an agreement could be reached by Nov. 30, when a new round of global trade talks are to begin in Seattle. China needs to conclude bilateral accords with major partners before it can enter the global body.
In recent days, administration officials privately said an agreement would be possible if China could match the terms it offered in April.
But in the intervening months, Chinese industrial and bureaucratic interests began to lobby against such deep concessions. Even military officers joined the fray, describing control over the telecommunications sector, for example, as a national security issue, said Joseph Few smith, a Chinese politics specialist at Boston University.
Mr. Zhu, an impatient, straight-talking reformer who is popular abroad and with ordinary Chinese, came under attack from conservative politicians and ministers who want to preserve national control of key industries. According to many reports, he no longer has control over the trade talks or the overhaul of state enterprises.

HEADLINE: Pilgrims' Progress

BYLINE: By William A. Christian Jr.; William A. Christian Jr. is the author of "Visionaries: The Spanish Republic and the Reign of Christ."

 BODY:

LOURDES
 Body and Spirit in the Secular Age.
 By Ruth Harris.
 Illustrated. 474 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95. 
 Many Americans who are not Roman Catholics have only a vague idea of what happened at Lourdes. This ignorance is something like not knowing what happened at Mecca in a country whose biggest single religion is Islam. Bernadette Soubirous, a very poor 14-year-old, had a series of 18 visions at a riverside grotto from February to July 1858. Now about four million pilgrims go there every year. The nightly candlelight procession of tens of thousands of devotees constitutes one of the world's great religious spectacles, and the pilgrimages with the sick are remarkable for their caring and inclusiveness. For many Catholics the cures there have been a sign of the truth and the power of their faith. For others Lourdes is a troubling anomaly, a warm childhood memory but also a mark of difference. Lourdes became the matrix for subsequent apparitions, shrines and devotions. It changed the environment of world Catholicism. Yet this great spiritual center has been invisible for much of the general public and scholars alike, as if they had a blind spot for religious wonder and mystery when they occur in the Western world.
With her fascinating and sensitive book "Lourdes: Body and Spirit in the Secular Age," Ruth Harris, who teaches history at Oxford University, has made Lourdes visible, almost unavoidable. Harris, self-described as a secular Jew, herself overcame an initial aversion to the subject. On a pilgrimage she helped care for the sick, and at Lourdes she took the ritual bath. Male and female religious who opened their archives to her further kindled her sympathy. Her study, "neither a Catholic apology nor an anticlerical tirade," attempts "to provide an historical context for believers and give nonbelievers a sense of where the appeal of Lourdes lies."
It covers the polemical and formative period of the pilgrimage, from 1858 to 1914. First it places the apparitions in context, beginning with the religious culture of the Pyrenees and the economic crisis in its towns in 1858. After an account of Bernadette's visions, Harris describes those of other seers, children and adults, at the grotto. Some of them were at first credible competitors to Bernadette and even seemed to have the power to heal. But the clerical authorities stuck with Bernadette, and Lourdes swiftly became national news. Bernadette herself ("omnipresent in the story but astonishingly absent from the place") eventually entered a convent. Harris then takes us behind the scenes as the shrine prospers. We learn about the writer Henri Lasserre, whose melodramatic report of the visions was "probably the greatest best seller of the 19th century"; the organization of an annual national pilgrimage by dynamic Assumptionist priests and devoted female organizers, whose mutual relations were highly intense and productive; the accretion of the particular ritual prayers, baths and processions; the pilgrim experience of miraculous cures; and the effective defeat of critics like Zola and Charcot, who challenged these cures.
A number of themes run through the account. One is about a series of "tamings" by the authorities and by people's expectations. After her visions Bernadette, whom Harris obviously respects and admires, was constantly humiliated in public so she would not become proud and was taken from her home when there were complaints "she was running about with other children." The Virgin, whom Bernadette saw as a young girl, was recast as a woman. Originally in the wild, the grotto was girdled with masonry and capped with a basilica. Pilgrims were fenced out and ushered in. And reports of cures were made less subjective and more medical.
Harris follows the Lourdes story as an evolving narrative with a changing iconography. A chapter on the bitter struggle between the populist Lasserre and clerical historians points up the public's role in selecting the version it wanted. With a sophisticated eye, Harris examines photographs, engravings and cartoons, pointing out, for instance, the resonance between photos of Bernadette and Millet's paintings of devout peasants, or juxtaposing doctors at the Lourdes Medical Bureau questioning a cured woman and doctors in Paris observing a "hysteric."
A third theme follows "a story about France . . . the capacity of the Second Empire to adjust to, and even profit from, religious movements, and the inability of the Third Republic to suppress them." In 19th-century France, Harris finds not relentless progress toward a secular world, as is often assumed, but a coexistence, and eventually a kind of convergence, between positivism and a robust Catholic culture. She shows a France "normally hidden from view" that Lourdes made manifest. At the shrine the pilgrims of France's disparate regions recognized "the deep similarity of religious feeling that united them."
She pays special attention to women. Lourdes "valued and gave status to women, acknowledging many of the tasks that they did in private, as they consoled, fed and nursed." She identifies the emergence of active, engaged selves in the people healed and the female helpers. While forthright about the anti-Socialism, anti-Republicanism, anti-Masonism and the "hateful, racial anti-Semitism" of the Assumptionist organizers, she never loses sight of the compassionate and tender side of the pilgrimages, in which women became spiritual by helping and created community in the process. They dreamed of "a world in which personal connection was paramount" and "insisted on the organic links between men and women, between rich and poor." They were part of a trend; more than 100,000 women became active religious -- teachers, nurses, missionaries -- in 19th-century France.
The phenomenon of Lourdes has manifold ramifications, and Harris does not explore them all. One could write a history of Lourdes devotion from the point of view of a family, a community or a diocese. And while Catholic France was coming to know itself at Lourdes, so by 1900 was Catholic Europe, with Spanish, Italian, Belgian, Dutch, English and Irish Catholics converging there. The shrine's story was already going around the world, along with its water, images and replicas of its grotto. Lourdes's global impact is all the more reason to welcome this well-written, engaging and innovative history, open-ended and openhearted. Ruth Harris helps move religious history away from trench warfare to the shared exploration of fact and experience. Both those who love Lourdes and those curious at a distance will find deep pleasure in this book.

HEADLINE: Scorched Earth

BYLINE: By Bernard Knox; Bernard Knox's most recent books are "The Oldest Dead White European Males" and "Backing Into the Future."

 BODY:

THE SOUL OF BATTLE
 From Ancient Times to the Present Day, How Three Great Liberators Vanquished Tyranny.
 By Victor Davis Hanson.
 Illustrated. 480 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $30. 
 VICTOR DAVIS HansON is an ancient historian who teaches at California State University, Fresno. He is also a farmer, working a vineyard that has been in his family for generations. He has written groundbreaking, indispensable books on ancient Greek farmers ("The Other Greeks") who lived in the countryside, not the city, and on the legacy of the Greek insistence on the decisive battle, the clash of armored foot soldiers, embattled farmers whose dependence on their crops left them no time for long-range expeditions or protracted campaigns ("The Western Way of War"). In "The Soul of Battle" he widens the scope of his inquiry to discuss, in rich and fascinating detail, three campaigns in which idiosyncratic, uncompromising generals commanding soldiers of egalitarian societies led armies on what he calls "great marches" into the heart of enemy territory and, while avoiding pitched battles, destroyed the economic and political base of tyrannical and aggressive states. Their names are Epaminondas, Sherman and Patton.
To many readers of this brilliant and engrossing book the first name will be unfamiliar. He was a citizen of Thebes, which in the fifth and fourth centuries B.C. was the leading partner of a confederation of city-states in Boeotia, the land northwest of Athens. Unlike much of the rest of Greece, it was fertile, well-watered farmland, a tempting target for aggressive neighbors, especially for the Spartans, who had become by the beginning of the fourth century the dominant power in Greece. For centuries Spartan infantry had been invincible in the head-on collision of lines of armored men, wielding spear and sword, that was the normal pattern of Greek battle. They were full-time professionals, living and eating together, training and fighting in the same formation from boyhood on -- a life that produced a discipline and cohesion without parallel. They were a ruling class, supported by the forced labor of a whole conquered Greek population, the neighboring Messenians, who had been reduced to serfdom in the eighth century B.C. The Spartans were flanked in the battle line by the troops of their so-called allies to the north of them, who were allies only because they had no choice in the matter.
When, in 370 B.C., an army led by one of Sparta's two kings invaded Theban territory, at the city of Leuctra, Epaminondas faced it at the head of the Boeotian army. The Thebans were on the left wing of the line facing the Spartan elite force, but Epaminondas had massed his men in much greater depth than usual, so that when he led them at a run against the Spartans, who were already extending their line in order to outflank him, the impact of his contact broke their ranks; their king was killed and the survivors eventually asked for a truce to bury their dead and withdraw.
It was the first time Spartan troops had admitted defeat in all their long history. But Epaminondas was not finished with them. Their allies had begun to assert their independence and in the late summer of the next year asked for Theban help. Epaminondas did something unprecedented in Greek warfare. He led his army of 70,000 men all the way into the heart of Spartan territory and, while avoiding the pitched battle that would have resulted from an attack on the city of Sparta itself, marched through the countryside leaving behind him a trail of destruction. He then helped the allies to the north to fortify their cities and, more important still, freed 200,000 land-bonded serfs, called Helots, and helped them build a base, the city of Messene, from which they could defend their newly won freedom. It was the end of Spartan military supremacy, achieved with only minor losses by a general who had far exceeded the terms of his original commission, and who was in fact impeached, unsuccessfully, on his return to Thebes. Hanson sums up his importance: "Epaminondas . . . was the real modern military thinker of the ancient world, the sole constitutional general who realized that a democratic nation in arms must make the entire society of the enemy pay for the aggression of its army, must convince his own democratic army that they are morally superior to the enemy."
Many of the salient features of Epaminondas' extraordinary campaign recur in Gen. William T. Sherman's march from Atlanta to the sea. Like Epaminondas, he took his dangerous decisions without the wholehearted support of his colleagues at home. "His venture," according to the British war historian B. H. Liddell Hart, "was to be made under the cloud of the dubious permission of his military superior, the anxious fears of his president and the positive objections of their advisers." Like Epaminondas, Sherman led an army that admired and trusted him, an army inspired by his sense of mission. Both men struck deep into the enemy's heartland, wrecking its economy and liberating the slaves on which that economy depended. Both avoided the head-on battle and its huge casualty list, preferring deceptive feints and outflanking marches. Both left a trail of destruction behind them, though there was much more to destroy in Georgia than in the region around Sparta; Atlanta was burned to the ground, and railroads were systematically ruined. Lastly, both generals were difficult men, mavericks who puzzled and dismayed their fellow generals and their political controllers.
Epaminondas was a Pythagorean, an adherent of a philosophical sect that advocated vegetarianism and believed in metempsychosis; he set a dismaying example of ascetic living and self-control. As for Sherman, who graduated from West Point sixth in his class of 233, his 148 demerits in conduct placed him 216th in "personal behavior." In 1861, while he was the general in charge of Union troops in Kentucky, his pessimistic (and exact) predictions of a long and costly war caused such a furor in the newspapers that he was temporarily relieved of command on the basis that he was insane. Yet later, at Shiloh, he won the admiration of Gen. U. S. Grant and, in the campaigns that preceded the great march, the confidence and affection of his army.
So did Gen. George Patton, but he too had trouble with higher headquarters. Like Sherman, he was widely and deeply learned in military history, but he expressed himself in public in a violent and flamboyant way that shocked much of the public and alienated or even enraged many of his superiors. Yet he was not only a soldier who had been wounded on the Western Front in 1918; he had also, in North Africa and especially in Sicily in 1943, shown what could be done with a mobile force led by a daring commander. Because he twice slapped battle-stressed soldiers in Sicily who, he thought, were merely malingering, he was denied a major command in the Normandy landings, even though the Germans recognized him as their most formidable opponent. When his Third Army was finally committed to battle, he took off, plunging eastward into France and also turning north to make contact with the Canadians and trap the retreating German Army. But he was ordered by Gen. Omar Bradley to stop at Argentan, and the Germans escaped to fight again.
Unlike Epaminondas and Sherman, he was not a free agent. Later, poised at Metz after a spectacular dash through France and ready to push on into Germany, he was denied the gasoline for his move; the supplies went instead to Field Marshal Montgomery for his ill-fated thrust into Germany from Belgium. But after his extraordinary feat of switching the direction of his army in 48 hours from east to north to hit the German bulge from below -- when he proposed it Eisenhower said, "Don't be fatuous, George" -- he finally, in March 1945, took off on his 1,000-mile dash that took him to the gates of Prague, leaving behind him German dead and other German soldiers who had surrendered and been told to walk westward, as well as prisoners freed from the camps and the factories in which thousands of foreign workers had slaved for the Nazi war.
Both Sherman and Patton spoke of the "soul" of their army, and the Pythagorean Epaminondas would surely have agreed. In the case of these three great armies there was, as Hanson puts it, "a real moral difference" between the invaders and their enemies. His book, he says, "is more an essay on the ethical nature of democracies at war than a purely military history of three epic marches for freedom, for it claims that on rare occasions throughout the ages there can be a soul, not merely a spirit, in the way men battle."

HEADLINE: Is the Party Over?

BYLINE: By Robert J. Samuelson; Robert J. Samuelson, a columnist for Newsweek and The Washington Post Writers Group, is also the author of "The Good Life and Its Discontents: The American Dream in the Age of Entitlement."

 BODY:

MONEY, GREED, AND RISK
 Why Financial Crises and Crashes Happen.
 By Charles R. Morris.
 297 pp. New York:
 Times Business/Random House. $25. 
 A CENTRAL question of economics concerns the relationship between what we call the "real economy" and financial markets. The real economy is production, wages, profits, incomes, employment and living standards. Financial markets run the gamut from stocks, bonds and banks to more obscure investment instruments like mortgage-backed securities and options. The two worlds intersect, but until recently the consensus among economists was that financial markets were a sideshow. We could explain economic cycles mainly through shifts in purchasing power, technology and management methods. Well, maybe not.
Almost everywhere you look, financial markets seem crucial to economic fortune and misfortune. Japan's economic stagnation in the 1990's is intertwined with a banking crisis that may involve up to $1 trillion in bad loans. Asia's banking and currency collapses -- beginning in mid-1997 -- plunged many of the region's countries into deep slumps from which they are just beginning to recover. On a cheerier note (so far), the United States' boom has drawn strength from a headstrong stock market that has left people feeling richer and consuming more.
"The financial sector," Charles R. Morris writes, "is the economy's plumbing system. A company's failure, even a big one like I.B.M.'s, is like a broken sink, but a failure in the financial sector threatens the entire water supply." Just so, and in "Money, Greed, and Risk" Morris seeks to demystify the murky relationship between finance and the real economy. To this task he brings rare qualifications. He's both a market player and a first-rate writer. In the 1980's, he advised several LBO funds (for "leveraged buyout," meaning the funds bought companies with borrowed money). His previous books have covered subjects as varied as American Catholicism and computers.
Finance's main contribution to economic progress, Morris shows, has been to permit specialization and investment. Money itself (usually precious metals like silver and gold) represented an enormous advance because it liberated people from barter. The creation of "bills of exchange" -- used by the 15th-century Italians and further perfected by the 18th-century Dutch -- did the same for trade, sparing merchants from carting scarce coin around the world. Trade flourished.
In time, finance underwrote investments -- roads, canals, railroads, ships and factories -- that could presumably repay the original sums and then some. Accumulated wealth could be employed, not hoarded. At its best, this process confers huge social benefits. Thirty years ago, for example, most home mortgage loans were made by local savings associations and banks. Since then, mortgages have been widely "securitized," meaning they're bundled together in bonds and sold to institutional investors (pension funds, insurance companies, investment houses). The investors receive homeowners' principal and interest payments, a development that has cut interest rates on home loans relative to other investments and saved homeowners billions in monthly payments.
The rub, of course, is that the process doesn't always work well. Financial markets traffic in risk. Dutch banking houses that issued bills of exchange had to know whether merchants could cover the credits. If too many bills were issued, they might finance a shaky boom that would collapse. Not surprisingly, this happened. Similarly, savings channeled into unproductive investments can create losses for individual investors, and -- if the amounts are great enough -- destabilize entire economies. The crises in Japan and Asia exemplify this. Banks overlent for unneeded projects, from office buildings to factories. As more borrowers couldn't repay, lending (and the associated spending and jobs) imploded.
The paradox of finance is that a usually farsighted and constructive process routinely descends into frenzied, shortsighted and self-destructive binges. Greed, fear, hope and ignorance reign. Almost everyone plays for a quick killing -- or aims to escape a slaughter. To explain the paradox, Morris argues that finance regularly follows a cycle of "innovation, crisis and consolidation." Greater trade required paper credits; expanding railroads needed to sell more public stocks and bonds. The financial innovation meets the need, but its novelty also "triggers a period of greatly increased risk and instability, until institutions catch up."
Up to a point, this is convincing. Financial innovations initially involve huge profits that attract imitators until too many investors are chasing too few good opportunities. Crashes and losses ensue. Sooner or later, institutions adapt. Governments impose regulations, markets evaluate risk better -- or both. Morris provides much evidence for his theory, from British bond investments in American railroads in the 19th century to junk bonds in the 1980's. But in the end, the theory is not completely satisfying. Many financial crises stem from plain old excess. Markets go to extremes. Investors and traders get caught in fits of excitement or gloom. Morris ignores episodes that don't fit his theory. Except for passing references, for instance, he doesn't discuss Japan's banking crisis. After banks overlent, government regulators turned a blind eye to weak loans in the (vain) hope that prosperity would transform bad credits into good.
And while the financial breakdowns that he does explore -- from the collapse of the Bank of the United States in the 1830's to the savings and loan crisis of the 1980's -- are well told, the whole is less than the sum of the parts. What really concerns us is the world's financial plumbing. Are we dealing only with some leaky faucets? Or is the whole system in jeopardy? Some big crises -- take the savings and loan debacle -- haven't derailed prosperity. But there are ominous trends. Financial markets increasingly deal in instruments -- options, derivatives -- that can confuse even professionals. Moreover, financial markets have gone global. Morris argues that regulation can provide safeguards. Financial institutions can have ample capital to protect against losses; disclosure requirements may prevent some stupid investments. All this is true. But bad regulation also worsened some crises -- the S.&L. and Japanese banking meltdowns, for instance.
So, is the plumbing safe? Morris never says. Perhaps no one can.

HEADLINE: Who Am I?

BYLINE: By Abby Ellin and Degen Pener 

 BODY:
With the streets of New York as our laboratory, we decided to conduct an experiment. We assembled six experts: Jane Rinzler Buckingham, president of Youth Intelligence, a trend-spotting firm; Ginny Hilfiger, a senior vice president of Tommy Hilfiger; Kal Ruttenstein, a senior vice president of Bloomingdale's; Valerie Steele, chief curator at the Fashion Institute of Technology; Cathy Horyn, a fashion reporter for The Times; and Bill Blass, the designer. Then we asked them to decipher 15 human Rorschach blots: people photographed in whatever they happened to be wearing. Finally, we provide the real answers. The results begin here.
 
The Experts' Guesses
 
Buckingham: He is just Mr. Dapper. He strikes me as a student.
Hilfiger: He's definitely a student from the books and umbrella. He looks as if he's very holy and goes to church a lot. He probably would shop at Brooks Brothers if he was going to buy a suit.
Ruttenstein: He teaches at Columbia, in the English department.
Horyn: He's a junior-high or high-school teacher or a librarian. He doesn't take a lot of guff from his students.
Blass: He's probably a preacher's son.
Buckingham: She looks good. What she wears and being up on trends is definitely important to her. It's that casual "I don't care about trends, but I have them all" look. She's single.
Hilfiger: She lives on the Upper East Side. Whatever the trend is, she's able to go out and buy it because her parents have money. She's too young to have a lot of money on her own.
Ruttenstein: This girl is very hip. She has the pony-skin bag, which is the look of the season. She has the Adidas running pants. She lives downtown, and I think she's an actress or a dancer.
Steele: It's not an Upper East Side look, but it's not like a SoHo look, either. It looks more trendy than arty.
Horyn: She's on the go. She's kind of the bohemian hip mom. She lives in New Jersey and her husband works in Manhattan.
Blass: She is going to be successful. I like everything about her.
Buckingham: She probably volunteers at the museum. She's very practical; she's got everything she needs in her bag.
Hilfiger: She seems like the type of grandmother who has constantly tried to stay up with the trends. That outfit is probably something she bought not too long ago. She probably has grandkids and kids and a house out on Long Island.
Ruttenstein: She lives on the Upper West Side. She's retired. She's very active in city politics, like she would go to meetings.
Steele: She looks as if she has set out on her day and is prepared for everything. She's probably retired, but with this lady it doesn't mean she doesn't have a lot of things to do.
Horyn: Something tells me she did something during the Second World War. She was a nurse and she married her husband then.
 
The Answers
 
1. Jean Pierre Lorelus, 38, is a taxi driver who divides his time between New York and Florida, where he has family; he has never shopped at Brooks Brothers. "I was leaving church," he says. "My outfit says dignity and self-esteem."
 
2. Maggie Biller, 24, is single and has lived in NoLIta since moving to Manhattan from San Francisco a year ago; she is a freelance fashion writer, stylist and health consultant. "My outfit says I've got a lot of color, that I do yoga, that I'm kind of weird," she says. "I mix everything I have," a look consistent with "my lifestyle and what it's always been."
 
3. Esta Gildwarg was born in Williamsburg and lives in Brooklyn Heights; now retired, she was an assistant principal. She did do local work for the Army during World War II, but never married. "I haven't been shopping in a while because I have so many clothes," she says. "I am a self-sufficient person. If it wasn't for this bum leg, I would be playing golf."
 
Who Am I?

SECTION: Section 6; Page 130; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: The Axis Of Austerity

BYLINE: By Ginia Bellafante; Ginia Bellafante is a fashion reporter for The Times. This is her first article for the magazine.

 BODY:
In 1899, the economist Thorstein Veblen proffered a theory about high fashion that would hold true for most of the next century. In fact, it would provide an answer to the question so often asked by ordinary people when they come into contact with clothes that cost more than sofas: "Why would anyone ever buy that?" The point of stylish outfits, Veblen maintained, was not simply to show the world that you were rich but to prove, in the most envy-making sense, that you had little to do but get dressed. A neat, expensive garment carries with it "an exemption from personal contact with industrial processes of any kind," he wrote. It argues that the person wearing it "consumes without producing."
When the Italian label Prada came to the world's attention in the early 1990's, it explored the notion that the taint of industry could actually be quite desirable. Prada trafficked in darkly colored clothes with clean lines and sedate hemlines -- not stuff for languishing about on yachts in Portofino. Early on, much of the Prada uniform -- including the all-important knapsack big enough to contain a Filofax and other vitals of urban life -- was forged out of seemingly stainproof black nylon. Today Prada Sport, ostensibly the company's leisure line, is so steeped in the language of technology that women and men wearing it can look as if they spend all their time in clean rooms assembling microchips. Here are expensive clothes that make you appear productive. 
 The virtue of productivity, as it turns out, is something that Miuccia Prada, the label's head designer, and her husband, Patrizio Bertelli, its C.E.O., understand a bit about. In less than two decades they have turned an ailing luggage enterprise into not only the ultimate signifier of urbane good taste but also a $1 billion business.
In recent months, the company has grown from a fashion house into a budding luxury-goods empire along the lines of Bernard Arnault's giant Louis Vuitton Mot Hennessy (LVMH). This year, Bertelli purchased majority stakes in the design houses of Helmut Lang and Jil Sander. Like Prada, Lang, an Austrian based in New York, and Sander, a German based in Hamburg, have built reputations as purveyors of an austere elegance. Their clothes are pricey and simply cut, and with the exception of truck shows or Mob weddings, there are few occasions at which you'd seem out of place wearing them. When Jil Sander sent a cotton skirt with a muted floral motif down the runway in Milan last month, it caused a buzz because she'd actually done something in a print.
Last month, Bertelli purchased nearly 83 percent of the British shoe company Church, known for its traditional men's footwear. At the same time, he announced that the Prada Group had formed a partnership with LVMH to purchase a 51 percent interest in the rival Milanese house of Fendi. Known for decades for its furs, Fendi has revived its accessories business with a series of small shoulder bags -- Baguettes" -- which cost, on average, $1,500 apiece.
By associating itself with other luxury brands, particularly those that share the Prada aesthetic, the company has managed to grow without reverting to licensing deals -- the sale of a designer name to manufacturers of hose, underwear and the like -- which can demystify and dilute a brand's image. Prada makes its own underwear -- a bra can cost $180. Even the company's youth-oriented Miu Miu line for women, meant to cost less than its collection, doesn't cost that much less at all. Go to a Miu Miu shop and you will find yourself stumbling across shoes for $350, a mere $50 saving over an actual pair of Pradas.
Although Miuccia Prada took over her family's luggage business in 1978, much of Prada's growth has come about in the past few years. In the 70's, Prada had a single shop in Milan, which sold about $400,000 worth of merchandise each year. In 1980, Prada, who had completed a doctorate in political science, formed an alliance with Bertelli, a leather manufacturer she'd met at a trade show. "He has a lot of energy, and she is more tranquil," explains Christina Ortiz, who ran the women's wear division until 1997. "She is always looking for something strange and eccentric to do, and he is always looking toward the commercial. He is earth, she is air." Bertelli began distributing a line of leather goods she designed, and in 1988 Prada started her clothing line for women. Miu Miu, Prada Sport and a men's wear line followed. By 1994, the company had a well-established store on East 57th Street in Manhattan and 12 in Japan. (The Japanese stores were franchises that the company took control of three years later.) Prada now has 132 stores around the world.
Building the department-store business, though, initially proved difficult. In 1993, the earth-minded Bertelli dispatched Patrizio di Marco, who had been working for Prada in Asia, to expand the company's business in the United States. While scouting locations for Prada stores, di Marco also worked to get Prada knapsacks and handbags the kind of attention -- that is, the same prime real estate -- other expensive accessories received in big department stores. "Everyone laughed at me," says di Marco, now the acting president of Celine. "I sounded like a nut case. Prominent people working in department stores told me Prada was too avant-garde."
Barneys New York, with its tradition of embracing the avant-garde, had actually been stocking Prada bags since the late 1980's, but it wasn't until 1992, as Marin Hopper of Elle magazine recalls, that they wound up on the wish lists of influential fashion editors like herself, without whose unabashed enthusiasm few up-market trends would ever gain momentum. Soon the lust spread. Judy Collinson, the store's general merchandise manager for women, remembers witnessing a fight outside Barneys' defunct downtown location, confirming for her the bags' fetish appeal. A man was challenging his mate to explain the purchase of a $200-plus knapsack.
Prada was bursting onto the scene in the midst of a recession, which led fashion observers to determine that the label appealed because it stood in stark opposition to status. In 1992, no one anticipated that this decade would turn out as wealth-obsessed as the mocked, maligned decade before it. People were searching for a quiet antidote to the excesses of the loud, Lacroix 1980's, the thinking went. But of course no one spends hundreds of dollars on a skirt or a tote in order to feel penitent and go unnoticed.
What came to be thought of as the functional Prada look -- quickly knocked off at J. Crew, at department stores, at Club Monaco -- wasn't anti-status; it was simply tapping into what status would ultimately become: work, so much cooler in the Palm Pilot, high-tech, I.P.O. 90's than in the Charlie Sheen "Wall Street" era before. If fashion takes its cues from idleness and fantasy, then Prada speaks to the chic dream of putting in 100-hour weeks at a new-media start-up.
But Prada has also pulled off a brilliant sleight of hand, selling itself as fashion's antithesis while at the same time achieving what fashion at its core must: the creation of a relentless desire for something new. Prada derived nearly 70 percent of its sales in 1998 -- and maintains its brand identity as the embodiment of the utilitarian -- from its unfussy accessories. Its high-end women's line, however, the one lusted after by fashion editors, is constantly being reconceived, sometimes in ways that have little to do with the public's image of Prada.
While Prada's clothes are always wearable, her ready-to-wear collections may allude to vastly different things from one season to the next. Since her early and influential "techno" collection, Miuccia Prada has made reference to Mongolian outerwear, military dress and all things ladylike, only to follow up with collections that reinterpreted the work-is-good ethos. In 1996, Prada turned out prints inspired by the workaday imagery of 60's Formica kitchen tops and polyester suits that looked like stewardess uniforms -- which served to remind the world, with a wink, what the brand was about.
In Milan last month, Prada shifted gears again, delighting buyers and press people with a feminine spring collection of skirts, silk blouses and cardigans that bore little resemblance to the gypsyish mustard woolens she had unveiled for this fall. The clothes were shown with practical handbags of black and white. No more than a dozen hours after the presentation, they could be seen on the arms of fashion editors all over the city. The hype mechanism was at work. Prada's accessories are so closely linked with the colors and patterns of its collections that its bags and shoes often seem glaringly out of date the minute new clothes are sent down the runway. It is safe to assume that Prada devotees will queue up for those purses, cavalierly tossing into the closet last year's must-haves.
Speaking on the subject of her evolution, Prada says simply: "I always believe in doing new things and using new materials that I have never used or that I didn't like for a long time. Black nylon is part of my passion for industrial things. However, right from the start I tried to combine industrial materials with completely opposite materials, such as trimmings and embroidery."
To understand Prada's design philosophy, you must understand a few things about Prada herself, explains Franca Sozzani, the editor in chief of Italian Vogue. "She was dressed in Saint Laurent since she was 20 years old," says Sozzani. "She's from a very wealthy family, but she's not bourgeois in her head. She's always found a way to get out of the predictable idea of the moment. She becomes bored with an idea almost immediately. She never wants to repeat herself." Repeat she doesn't, but reinvent she does, exploiting the possibilities of fashion under the aegis of a seemingly indomitable brand.

But the sponsors thought pants were too suggestive and asked if I would stop wearing them; I said I'd rather not. A lot of women through the years have said I was their inspiration to take that dangerous step and sometimes even wear jeans while cleaning the house!" (Photofest)

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS: CITYSCAPES;
When the Charisma of the City Steals the Limelight

BYLINE: By GRAHAM FULLER; Graham Fuller is the executive editor of Interview magazine and editor of "Loach on Loach," about the director Ken Loach.

 BODY:
IT'S home sweet home this movie season for some, but not all, directors who have their eyes fixed on city life. In "Bringing Out the Dead," Martin Scorsese depicts Manhattan as an update on Pandaemonium -- the capital of hell in Milton's "Paradise Lost" -- as he did in "Taxi Driver." In one bravura nighttime shot, filmed from the perspective of an ambulance driver (Nicolas Cage) losing his grip on reality, Mr. Scorsese turned the camera over to give the impression of what it's like to career sideways down Ninth Avenue, "unbalanced" being the requisite point of view.
In "Liberty Heights," Barry Levinson peers back with bittersweet nostalgia at the Baltimore of the 1950's, as he did in his first feature, "Diner." Even as it says good riddance to racial segregation, the new film laments the passing of a world in which burlesque shows were havens for lonely men and a Jewish paterfamilias might slip out of the synagogue on Rosh Hashana for a private showing of the latest Cadillac. 
 These directors are on safe territory, even if Mr. Scorsese's Manhattan is more luridly dystopic than ever. Woody Allen, until recently that least movable of Manhattanites, has meanwhile taken a road trip. Having allowed himself to be filmed touring Europe with his jazz combo in the 1998 documentary "Wild Man Blues," Mr. Allen has now made the shaggy-dog story "Sweet and Lowdown," which gads about America in the company of a self-deluding jazz guitarist (Sean Penn). The movie visits New York briefly, but the city is not the centripetal force it has been in a majority of Mr. Allen's pictures since "Annie Hall" (1977).
The directorial profession is wide enough to encompass wanderers and regionalists, pastoralists and city rats. "We're all gypsies," the nomadic David Lean said in a 1985 interview, but some directors repeatedly gravitate toward their old metropolitan haunts, even if most eventually range beyond them. Spike Lee, Hal Hartley and Abel Ferrara are other directors proffering radically opposed visions of New York. John Waters presents a camp alternative to Mr. Levinson's Baltimore and Gus Van Sant a poetic Portland, Ore., Further afield, there is Pedro Almodovar's melodramatic Madrid, Terence Davies's working-class Liverpool and Wong-kar Wai's kinetic Hong Kong. In the past, there was Rene Clair's studio-rendered Paris; Marcel Pagnol's Marseilles of boule, pastis and the waterfront; Federico Fellini's circuslike Rome and Yasujiro Ozu's middle-class Tokyo.
Some film cities are best represented by one or two indelible visions: Carol Reed's labyrinthine postwar Vienna in "The Third Man"; Alfred Hitchcock's dreamy, deceptively manicured San Francisco in "Vertigo"; Francis Ford Coppola's illusory Las Vegas in "One From the Heart" and Mike Figgis's Stygian equivalent in "Leaving Las Vegas"; Volker Schlondorff's Beirut of political and sexual treachery in "Circle of Deceit" and Ziad Doueri's version of the same wartorn city in the recent "West Beirut"; Goran Paskaljevic's necropolitan Belgrade in "The Powder Keg," and Wim Wenders's celestially perceived Berlin in "Wings of Desire."
Mr. Wenders is modern cinema's ultimate global citizen, as promiscuously cosmopolitan as Woody Allen is supposedly a one-city guy. Defying the conventional wisdom that a film should be set in a single arena, Mr. Wenders originally planned to shoot his 1991 science-fiction road movie "Until the End of the World" in 28 cities in 17 countries. (He eventually settled for seven cities and the Australian outback.) His films consistently grapple with how the here-and-now of cities like Berlin, Tokyo, Lisbon and Los Angeles interact with their pasts, and how that confluence affects their denizens. "In many respects, cities have their own character," he said in 1989, "so for me they become like having another star actor in a film."
"Wings of Desire" (1988), which represented a spiritual homecoming for Mr. Wenders after seven years of voluntary exile in America, is his quest for the soul of Berlin and, by extension, what remained of the German soul four decades after the war. It follows the fortunes of two unemployed guardian angels as they glide down to Berlin's autobahns and subways, its apartments and the wastelands by the wall, where they tune in to the innermost anxieties of the city's fretting populace.
As bound up as we are in the angels' desire to become mortal, they are primarily conduits for a metaphysical meditation on the film's mutating central character: Berlin itself. There is the sense that the city is itself telling the story and, as Mr. Wenders has suggested, that the citizens observed by the angels do not live in Berlin as much as Berlin lives in them. By the end of this remarkable film and its weaker 1993 sequel, "Faraway, So Close," even the angels have been absorbed into the city.
Mr. Wenders has spoken tenderly of the several stretches of wasteland he showed in "Wings of Desire," some of which the film memorialized before they were turned into formal gardens. He was acknowledging that a city's history is told as much by the gaps between buildings as by its architecture.
Mike Leigh has also made significant use of forgotten tracts of land, as well as the gaps between buildings, to staggering effect. Although Mr. Leigh is celebrated for his anthropologically based satires with their acid and compassionate observations of British manners, the visual fabric of his films is frequently neglected. Yet no one else has done as much to put contemporary London and its class divisions on the screen in the last 20 years, and certainly not with his deep understanding of how its physical and emotional topography are one and the same.
A grandchild of Jules Dassin's "Night and the City" (1950), Mr. Leigh's "Naked" follows the rake's progress of Johnny (David Thewlis), an overly articulate 30-ish Northerner burdened with existential angst, who rambles nocturnally through London's labyrinths in a doomed attempt to penetrate his own addled psyche. Like film noir heroes, he is guided by women, the usual crop of deadly Circes and benevolent Beatrices. He treats them cruelly or kindly, according to his whim. He buys one of them, a homeless Scottish lass separated from her boyfriend, a consoling cup of tea. But then the boyfriend turns up and begins kicking her. Instead of protecting her, Johnny wheels away in a single forlorn movement on the piece of empty ground on which he is standing. Where is he? Surely there are no bomb sites left in London. The empty space Johnny is occupying is, of course, the void between people, their failure to connect.
In Mr. Leigh's latest film, "Topsy- Turvy," set in London in 1884 and shot mostly in interiors, the librettist W. S. Gilbert (Jim Broadbent) leaves the theater where his and Arthur Sullivan's "Mikado" is about to open. Lurching down an alley, he is clawed at and propositioned by several wretched women. Whatever this nightmarish interlude tells us about Gilbert's inner turmoil, this dab of Dickens puts into a social context the rarefied world of theatrical artifice in which the film is unfolding; it is Mr. Leigh's reminder to the audience that there is a grim reality beyond the world of make-believe.
The sequence mirrors the opening of "Naked," in which Johnny angrily copulates with a woman in a Manchester alleyway. But the film remains there only for the time it takes him to abandon her and set off for London. Mr. Leigh, who has not made an entire film outside London since he went to Belfast, Northern Ireland, for "Four Days in July" (1984), exults in London's places -- dark and light -- and its people, and he relishes probing (and sometimes filling) the gaps between them. It is hard to imagine London, dour and sluggish though it is beyond its center, getting to him in the same way Manhattan's supercaffeinated energy appears to have done recently -- superficially, at least -- to its cinematic champion.
Woody Allen has been escaping New York a lot lately. "Mighty Aphrodite" took flights of fancy to ancient Greece and "Everyone Says I Love You" to Venice and Paris. "Deconstructing Harry" culminated in a desperate flight upstate, making a quick detour to hell en route. Mr. Allen's "Celebrity" sent its main character on a humiliating side trip to Atlantic City, and the Manhattan it showed was a treacherous black-and-white film noir city, its slick, shimmering streets redolent of those in Alexander Mackendrick's "Sweet Smell of Success," the most baleful image of Manhattan on film.
Eighteen years before "Celebrity," Mr. Allen filmed "Manhattan," in black and white. Its evocative opening sequence is a montage of lambently photographed vistas, galvanizingly scored to "Rhapsody in Blue" with Mr. Allen contributing a voice-over paean to the city. Although that film, like "Celebrity," was the story of a self-deceiving writer led astray by the wrong woman , it revealed Mr. Allen's inviolable love of New York at that time.
Now, we're not sure what the artist in him thinks of the city. But New York is a habit he can't break. Not one scene of "Sweet and Lowdown" was shot more than an hour outside Manhattan. And when he learned I was writing this article, he passed on the message that he one day hopes to shoot an out-and-out Western without leaving Manhattan at all.
It's almost a relief to find Mr. Allen exploring what passes for Chicago, Los Angeles and the American hinterland in "Sweet and Lowdown," which has delightful scenes in provincial speak-easies, at a rural gas station, on a Hollywood set, and on a New Jersey boardwalk where you can feel the breeze. The film is more relaxed than anything else Mr. Allen has made in the 90's. He should get out of New York more often -- maybe go on a safari to Pennsylvania.
Mr. Scorsese exhibits a less ambiguous relationship with New York. Ever since he recreated Lower East Side street life in "Who's That Knocking at My Door?" (1968), he has reveled in depicting the most depraved, squalid and dehumanizing aspects of the city. Mr. Scorsese's city of earthly degradations embraces the infested 42nd Street of "Taxi Driver," the fetid animal pen that is the Bronx of "Raging Bull," the claustrophobic SoHo loft world of "After Hours," the nouveau riche Mafia enclaves of East Brooklyn in "Goodfellas," the mansions of malice in the 19th-century Upper East Side of "The Age of Innocence" and now Hell's Kitchen in "Bringing Out the Dead."
This is a New York that throbs with physical and emotional violence yet is never less than beautiful -- in the same way that nightmares can be beautiful, and Goya's paintings and Edgar Allan Poe's short stories. In the most startling image in "Bringing Out the Dead," a drug dealer impaled on a railing hangs off a balcony hundreds of feet above the city. It's an atrocity, but we cannot help admiring the view, a field of black velvet studded with jewels. The shot grows intrinsically out of the story being told, just one image in a phantasmagoria that provokes Mr. Cage's character to rescue a comatose patient's daughter as he travels through the bloody, garbage-heaped canyons.
The Manhattan of "Eyes Wide Shut," that other recent fable of a medical man seeking women to save or seduce on the island of lost souls, was, by contrast, passive. Stanley Kubrick's direction never transcended the distinct Old Europeanness of the source novella, as was evident in the film's sets of a Greenwich Village that resembles the real place but lacks its Eurotrashy bohemianism. Irrespective of its flora and fauna, the dramatic milieu Kubrick created was tangential to the film's forward action.
In all these movies, the city is more than mere backdrop; it is the hero's adversary, of which the siren, the damsel in distress, the opponent (pimp, crime lord, drug dealer, socialite), even the mother who appears as a hectoring giantess on the Manhattan skyline in Woody Allen's segment of "New York Stories," are mere operatives. They -- the people, whether flesh or fantasy -- embody the cities that issue them like genies. And perhaps the most authentic film city of all is the most genielike: the mirage of Las Vegas in "One From the Heart," which in its sublime studio artifice replicates the real Vegas better than any documentary could.
In the end, though, all film cities, made not of concrete and steel and blood and bone but of moments of time that have already passed, are phantoms -- projections of those fears and desires that each of us carries onto the real mean streets every day.
