HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS: SCREEN GEMS;
It Happened With One Movie: A Studio Transformed

BYLINE: By LEAH ROZEN; Leah Rozen is an associate editor and movie critic at People magazine.

 BODY:
"IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT" almost didn't. Only days before shooting was to begin, this 1934 screwball comedy, now a classic, lacked a leading lady. Established draws like Myrna Loy, Margaret Sullavan, Miriam Hopkins and Constance Bennett had all passed on playing the role of the runaway heiress who falls for a newspaperman during a cross-country bus trip. Hopkins reportedly sniffed, "Not if I never play another part."
Fortunately for both moviegoers and Columbia Pictures, "It Happened One Night" did happen. The movie, directed by Frank Capra and written by Robert Riskin, played a pivotal role in elevating Columbia from Hollywood's minor leagues to the majors. How fitting, then, that it is one of 75 movies unspooling at the Film Forum in Manhattan during the theater's wide-ranging eight-week celebration of Columbia's 75th anniversary, Friday to Jan. 13. 
 "Columbia was the scrappy little studio that could," said Michael Schlesinger, the studio's vice president for repertory sales, who sifted through 3,000 titles in its film library with Bruce Goldstein, Film Forum's director for repertory programming.
Part of the problem in lining up a top female star for "It Happened One Night" was Columbia itself. Because it specialized in cranking out low-budget films, the studio barely registered on Hollywood's prestige meters in the early 1930's. Big-name stars toiled at Columbia before they became big or when their careers were headed down. For stars still in their prime, doing a picture there often meant they were being lent to scruffy Columbia as punishment by their home studios.
That was the case with Clark Gable, who was lent to Columbia for the male lead in "It Happened One Night" by Louis B. Mayer, his boss at MGM, after a minor infraction. Gable considered going to Columbia akin to being banished to Siberia. According to Capra's 1971 autobiography, "The Name Above the Title," Gable showed up drunk for their first meeting, slurringly shared his Columbia-as-Siberia theory with Capra, then bellowed at workers in Columbia's courtyard, "Why ain't you wearing parkas?"
It was Harry Cohn, the penny-pinching, plain-speaking head of production at Columbia, who solved the leading lady problem. "I gotta brainstorm -- Claudette Colbert," he told Capra. The director, who had clashed with the feisty Colbert while steering her movie debut back in 1927, a flop called "For the Love of Mike," protested that she was already under contract to Paramount Pictures.
"Yeah, yeah, but she's taking a four-week vacation," Cohn said."And I heard the French broad likes money." (Colbert was born in Paris but immigrated to the United States as a child.) "Why don't you and Riskin go see her personal?"
Capra dropped by Colbert's house on Nov. 21, 1933, and found her packing for a holiday trip to Sun Valley, Idaho. Colbert told Capra that she would make his movie only if Columbia doubled her usual pay -- $50,000 instead of $25,000 -- and if Capra promised that she would finish shooting by Dec. 23 so she could celebrate Christmas with pals in Sun Valley. Deal, Capra said.
Working with a budget of $325,000 (high by Columbia standards, but puny when one considers that glitzy MGM was routinely lavishing $1 million on its A pictures) and a four-week shooting schedule, Capra and his cast had to scramble. "We slammed through the film clowning, laughing, ad-libbing," Capra wrote. Colbert made it to Sun Valley for the holidays, where, Capra said, she told friends, "I just finished the worst picture in the world."
QUITE the opposite. Viewing "It Happened One Night" today, one reacts the same way audiences did in 1934, guffawing loudly throughout and sighing with contentment at the happy ending. The Depression-era movie is funny and full of hope. And the justly famous hitchhiking scene, in which Colbert proves to Gable that a shapely gam is mightier than a north-pointing thumb, is still a model of comic economy and character development. Colbert's uptight heiress learns to loosen up, and Gable's know-it-all newspaper man realizes that he can still learn a few tricks.
The movie made tubs of money for Columbia, and at the Academy Awards ceremony in 1935, "It Happened One Night" become the first film to nab the top five Oscars, for best picture, director, actor, actress and screenplay. (Its quintuple sweep went unmatched for more than 40 years, duplicated only in 1976 by "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and in 1992 by "The Silence of the Lambs.") For Columbia, winning that clutch of Oscars was as if the lady with a torch in the studio's familiar logo had gone from holding aloft a single wooden match to a klieg light. The studio was now in the big time.
Which is just where Harry Cohn had always thought he and his studio belonged. The son of an immigrant tailor, Cohn grew up in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, quit school at 14 and worked as a singer, a streetcar conductor and a song peddler before going into the movie business. With his older brother Jack and a buddy named Joel Brandt, Harry founded Cohn-Brandt-Cohn Film Sales, the forerunner to Columbia Pictures, in 1919.
While his brother and Brandt minded business in New York, Cohn moved to Los Angeles, where he set up shop alongside other fly-by-night film companies on Gower Street, a shabby stretch dismissed as Poverty Row by the movie industry's power elite. The same elite soon dubbed ragged C.B.C. Corned Beef and Cabbage, which may explain why C.B.C. incorporated itself as the classier-sounding Columbia Pictures in 1924. Hence this year's celebration of its 75th anniversary.
As Columbia grew, cheap remained its byword. "Cohn was willing to pay money where it counted: for scripts and directors, sometimes even stars, but not elsewhere," Mr. Schlesinger said. Cohn especially scrimped on sets and costumes, which explains why the studio turned out comparatively few epics, costume dramas (except westerns) and elaborate musicals, and why it excelled at contemporary comedies and hard-edged film noir, genres that rarely required large casts or massive, specially constructed sets.
Cohn's parsimony meant Columbia had few superstars to call its own. Whereas MGM, whose official slogan boasted that it had "more stars than there are in heaven," could claim Gable, Greta Garbo, Joan Crawford, Spencer Tracy, Judy Garland and dozens more, Cohn's biggest stars were Jean Arthur, Rita Hayworth and Kim Novak. Each was queen of the Columbia lot during her era: Arthur in the 1930's, Hayworth in the 40's and Ms. Novak in the 50's. Those three actresses account for 13 of the movies on the Film Forum's Columbia salute, offering fans ample opportunity to compare and contrast their varying styles and talent.
If you have never seen (or heard) Arthur, don't miss this chance. A piquant blond, she possessed a voice like gurgling water spiked with a splash of whiskey. Although she had appeared in films since the 20's, Arthur did not become popular until Cohn cast her opposite Edward G. Robinson in John Ford's delightful comedy "The Whole Town's Talking" (1935). At Columbia, Arthur excelled at playing smart, wisecracking big-city career women, often newspaper reporters, who started out cynical but turned meltingly gooey once they fell for the hero. Off screen, the reticent Arthur chafed at Cohn's blowhard style and dictatorial ways; boss and star were constantly involved in fractious disputes. When Arthur finally won release from her contract in 1944, she ran through the streets of Columbia's lot howling: "I'm free! I'm free!"
THE Brooklyn-born Hayworth (originally Margarita Carmen Cansino) began dancing professionally when she was 12. In 1937, after Hayworth had spent two years doing bit parts at other studios, Cohn signed her to a long-term contract and dyed her naturally black hair auburn. But not until Life magazine ran its famous pinup photo of Hayworth kneeling on a bed in 1941 did Cohn fully realize her worth to Columbia. He stopped lending Hayworth out to other studios and instead put the radiant actress into a series of mindless but successful musicals, including "Cover Girl" (1944), with Gene Kelly. Hayworth became a full-fledged Love Goddess when she peeled off her gloves while purring "Put the Blame on Mame" in "Gilda" (1946). Her steamy turn is double-billed at the Film Forum with her other most significant performance, as a femme fatale in "The Lady From Shanghai" (1948), a quirky thriller directed by and co-starring Orson Welles, who was married to her at the time.
Ms. Novak supplanted Hayworth at Columbia. With show-business training that consisted of traveling the country as Miss Deepfreeze and demonstrating refrigerators, she got her first break in Hollywood in 1954 as an extra in "French Line," a musical most notable for showcasing in 3-D Jane Russell's hefty chest. Cohn decided he could transform Ms. Novak into Columbia's own version of Marilyn Monroe after inexplicably letting the real Marilyn slip through his grasp. (In 1949, he had opted against picking up Columbia's option on Monroe's six-month contract after casting her in a single cheapie musical, "Ladies of the Chorus." He told associates, "The girl can't act.") Cohn gave the inexperienced Ms. Novak, whose pale blonde beauty and shapely figure always outshone her acting, a big publicity buildup and succeeded in turning her into a major star for a few years in such heavy-breathing pictures as "Picnic" (1955) and "Bell, Book and Candle" (1958).
If Arthur, Hayworth and Novak were Columbia's three leading ladies, their male counterparts were Moe, Curly and Larry. The Three Stooges wreaked their special brand of violent comic havoc at Columbia from 1934 to 1958, turning out a steady stream of shorts. "They should be the studio logo, if you ask me," joked Mr. Goldstein of Film Forum, who selected two of the Stooges' best two-reelers for the series. "Men in Black" (1934) is the Stooges' antic, Oscar-nominated short -- yes, you read that right -- spoof of "Men in White," a somber doctor drama MGM had released earlier that year, and "In the Sweet Pie and Pie" (1941) is a comic confection that Stooges aficionados consider the trio's "Citizen Kane."
Other gems from Columbia to be seen during the series include "His Girl Friday" (1940), "Born Yesterday" (1950), "Dr. Strangelove" (1964), "Cat Ballou" (1965) and "Taxi Driver" (1977), as well as such overlooked but worthy titles as "3:10 to Yuma" (1957), a western based on a story by Elmore Leonard, and "Fail-Safe" (1965), Sidney Lumet's cold-war thriller. "We came up with a lot of oddball choices, movies that aren't seen too often but are good," Mr. Goldstein said. "I really can't wait to see a lot of this stuff."

HEADLINE: ART;
Precision Marks Show of Mostly Black and White Drawings

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
IN these days of ever-splashier exhibitions, an austere one is sure to stand out. At the Gallery on the Hudson here, a show of mostly black and white drawings with some purposeful hints of color is absorbing because it has layers. A wealth of possible visual experiences emerges if the viewer spends time with the drawings.
The show is "A Fine Line Between . . . " a reference to the precision that is the hallmark of most of the work. Nine artists are represented. Most of them live in New York City, but Kumi Korf lives in Ithaca, Creighton Michael in Mount Kisco and Patricia Wright in Irvington. In selecting works for the exhibition, Leslie Scheiblberg, the gallery director, and Carol Edelson, an artist who is on the gallery's board of advisers, visited a number of studios, and Ms. Scheiblberg said they they found themselves drifting toward work where line itself carries the day; this means going away from representation and toward abstraction, but the real world, especially nature, is implied everywhere. 
 Ms. Korf's drawings are inspired by a tree outside a window in Vermont. She uses mainly charcoal and oil stick, and one of her two works here, "MM XI" (the title probably comes from her method of cataloguing her work) is presented like a painting. Although the marks are made on paper, the paper is fixed to canvas. An area of light ocher imparts a feeling of autumn. Her second all-charcoal drawing, presented under glass, is hazier overall, and more specifically, describes the tree, a willow, which is her model.
Jimbo Blachly is primarily a sculptor, and Ms. Scheiblberg notes that artists who invest heavily in drawing are more likely to be sculptors than painters. Drawing is how sculptors work out their big ideas. Mr. Blachly's untitled drawings, however, give little hint of coming from a sculptor. One of them, on what is listed as a Chinese paper, is full of little ink marks organized roughly in rows; they plunge the viewer into what seems to be an environment like a Chinese landscape, but it is landscape seen especially close-up.
Objects from the real, mundane world make an appearance in Stephen Antonson's drawings, which are based on apartment house facades. He eliminates the structure of the facade though, and concentrates only on the rows of windows. Patricia Wright's works are essentially contours filled in and has the most hedonistic drift in the show. She presents two flowers in exuberant beginning stages of life, "First Bud and "Hollow Bud," and the buds have almost the heft of boulders. Her third, more intensely black drawing is called "Fallen Tulip" and of course it evokes the end of life. But reassuringly, this downcast shape is close to the shapes of the buds.
James Bohary's drawings are organizations of rather thick, bar-like charcoal lines. The placement of the lines and their relationship to one another is done to give the drawing maximum energy, and the one called "Orchid," evokes something similar in feeling yet very different from Ms. Wright's whole flowers.
The way in which the elements in a thicket of lines relate to one another is also a concern of Katherin Hilten, who works in graphite of different types applied with different pressures. The contrast of dominating bold lines and softer, lighter ones is essential. It works to make ideas of surface and recession in depth as central to her concerns as the lines play across the paper. Her compositions are thickets of such lines, and if a viewer pays close attention to this massing, the marks seem to dance. This sensation is redoubled in Ms. Hilten's largest piece done on heavier paper. Here a third kind of line is introduced in addition to the bold and light ones: she makes slashes in the paper with a sharp knife.
Mr. Michael and Elise D'Arrigo have strong reputations as abstract sculptors and their drawings here, though they do not look very much like their three-dimensional works, recall their effects. Mr. Michael works primarily in steel but has incorporated other disparate elements like plywood and fiberglass in his sculptures. That sense of disparateness characterizes his drawings here. The series is titled "Split" and the paper is divided in two horizontally. The upper half, coated with shellac, is strewn with thick graphite spirals, while the untreated bottom half contains fine, elegant pencil lines that make streamlined shapes. The two halves work together to produce a rare, but purposely choreographed harmony.
Ms. D'Arrigo's two drawings are both called "Chiaroscuro," the traditional name for a bold contrast of light and dark. She effects this contrast, which implies volume, carefully, by building a shape out of pieces of Japanese rice paper and then drawing on it with ink. The shapes in the two drawings here, essentially a cascade and a vessel, have a certain sculptural-relief quality because of the collaged paper, and Ms. D'Arrigo creates a haunting sensation by drawing numerous circles on her shapes, some of which are like wheels but others are riveting, like eyes.
Exhibitions that create sensations are, of course, very in right now, and this show has a couple of incidents of discreet disturbance. Ms. D'Arrigo's probing circles are one instance and Charles Spurrier's choice of materials is another. One of his untitled drawings is a grid of tangled lines, but the lines are reddish human hair, affixed to tape which is then applied to paper. His other work, which conjures up a brick wall, is composed of his red-tinted fingerprints applied to strips of tape.
"A Fine Line Between . . . " is at the Gallery on the Hudson through Nov. 28. For information, the number to call is 591-1378.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Y2K Concerns Help Slow Year-End Office Sales

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THESE are roller-coaster times for the sale of office buildings in New Jersey. After six months of steady rises, sales eased in October and are expected to continue to slow in the waning weeks of 1999, then rebound in the new year.
Industry professionals said several factors took much of the zip out of year-end office sales in New Jersey. Interest rates crept up last month, as did fears that lenders would not originate loans amid worries they would be unable to sell them on Wall Street because of Y2K computer date-related concerns, which, in turn, caused many sellers not to market their buildings. So far, the retreat of lenders has been less significant than expected. 
 Still, Michael Tepedino, a senior managing director at the Manhattan office of Holliday Fenoglio Fowler, a commercial mortgage banking company, said there were fewer than usual lenders making loans through the end of the year. Moreover, he said, many intend to stop lending from Dec. 15 to Jan. 15 as a defense against possible computer glitches, making it difficult for investors to consummate deals. And those buyers looking to do last-minute deals may end up paying 5 to 10 percent higher interest rates, he said.
As a result of those possible rate increases, said Gary Gabriel, associate director of the Financial Services Group at Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage, investors either will try to renegotiate a lower purchase price or settle for a lower return on their investment.
Brokers say some buyers will delay closings. Charles Kushner, president of the Kushner Companies, a developer in Florham Park, said that while he was committed to buying a 100,000-square-foot secondary office building for $40 million he would not close the deal until January. "The overriding sentiment from lenders is to wait," he said, adding, however, that if a solid year-end deal came along "we will close despite the higher rates."
But other developers who locked in financing early say they intend to close by the end of the year. Among them is Denholtz Associates of Rahway, which will close on two buildings, in Middlesex and Bergen Counties, with a total of 400,000 square feet and valued at $40 million. Another is the Advance Group of Bedminster, which will also close on two buildings, in Somerset and Ocean Counties, valued at $30 million with a total of over 500,000 square feet.
This is the second year in a row in which fourth-quarter sales have slowed. The 1998 slump was due to difficulties in the capital markets last fall and winter set off by the financial crises in Asia and Russia. This year it is the perceived risk in the market because of Y2K worries.
The worries are "more perception than reality," said Robert Entin, president of Integrated Business Systems, a software company in Fairfield that provides accounting systems to real estate owners and developers. "The problem is simple to fix," he said. "It's the volume of programs that have to be changed that's the concern." He added that the computer failures that might happen would be "spotty, not massive."
Steve Kohn, managing director of the capital markets group at Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real estate investment banking company in Manhattan, added: "Most of the Y2K jitters occurred in the third quarter and the panic has waned." There will be an impact, but it will be temporary, he said.
In the fourth quarter 12 buildings with a total of 6 million square feet have been or will be sold in the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market, for a total value of $799 million, reported Cushman & Wakefield. Though those figures are greater than the 12 buildings that sold for $600 million in the last quarter of 1998, the two final-quarter tallies do not equal the 22 buildings that sold for $1.5 billion in the last quarter of 1997.
DESPITE sluggish fourth-quarter sales the state will probably end 1999 on an even keel, said Mr. Gabriel. And since many deals are being held off the market until January the pace will pick up again in the first quarter of the new year, he said.
Moreover, he said, capital for purchases will again be flowing as concerns over Y2K and interest rates lessen. The fundamentals of the office market remain strong as tenants continue to lease space, causing vacancy rates to remain stable and rents to creep up.
The overall vacancy rate in the third quarter was 12.4 percent, which while slightly higher than the 11.3 percent recorded in 1998 is expected to drop by year's end as available space is absorbed. At the same time average asking rents rose to an annual rate of $22.62 a square foot from $20.85.
The state's strong economy and job market are also expected to help. New Jersey is expected to add 60,000 to 65,000 more jobs by year's end, according to state figures.
But the dynamics of the investment market next year will be different, said Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, a commercial brokerage and advisory firm in Woodbridge. "Investors will not be able to obtain the same fast and high returns they have in the past," Mr. Schultz said. "They will have to hold properties, which have stabilized, for the long term, which is how real estate has traditionally been transacted."
The quick returns, he said, will not be as available as in the past because rents have increased in most submarkets to a high enough level to support new construction. Moreover, the price to acquire an existing building is at or close to the cost of constructing a new one, he added, noting that while financing for new construction is tougher to secure, it is available for projects in good locations with substantial preleasing. There are also fewer buyers. Real estate investment trusts, with their appetite for large deals, have diminished as a force in the market, replaced by pension funds, foreign buyers and private entrepreneurs, among others.
Mr. Gabriel of Cushman & Wakefield said that in 2000 his brokerage projects an increase in stabilized properties coming on the market, most of them Class B buildings.
Investors who in the past bought on the theory that rents could be improved say they recognize that much of the upside has been taken out of buildings. Still, they say, they will continue to search out deals.
Denholtz Associates, for instance, purchased 16 buildings, with a total of 600,000 square feet of mostly industrial space, with some office space, off Route 46 in Fairfield at a total cost of $28 million from the GE Credit Corporation, which provided the financing. The company's partner in the deal is the Zaro Group, an investment group in Ocean City.
Denholtz is investing $3 million to upgrade the buildings, renamed Fairfield 46 Business Center, has increased their occupancy from 75 to 90 percent and has raised rents by an average of 10 percent. The office space rents for $15.50 to $20 a square foot annually, while the industrial space rents for $4.75 to $7.75 a square foot.
"It's our typical value-added play," said Steven J. Denholtz, the company's managing partner, noting that such opportunities were becoming more difficult to find. "We know we can no longer make a killing and need to be more careful in selecting properties," he said, "because you just can't assume there will be the same rent increases of the past."
He said his company also had turned its attention to development. On a 127-acre former industrial site off Route 35 in Holmdel Denholtz is seeking approvals to develop a mixed-use complex that will contain 300,000 square feet of office and retail space and 150 assisted-living residences.
The same strategy is being pursued by the Advance Group and the Kushner Companies, each of which has office projects under way or planned. On Columbia Turnpike in Florham Park, Kushner has started construction on a 135,000-square-foot speculative office building that is to be completed by late next year.
And the Advance Group is developing three speculative buildings -- each with 44,000 to 88,000 square feet in Somerset and Hunterdon counties -- that it expects to complete by the middle of next year. It also plans to start a 100,000-square-foot building next year once 30 percent of the space has been preleased, said Gregory N. Senkevitch, the company's chief financial officer.
"The opportunities to buy buildings next year will not be as great as in the recent past and they will have a less dramatic upside," he said, but added: "We still think it will be a decent year for acquisitions."

HEADLINE: Riders Sitting High in the Saddle

BYLINE: By SYDNEY LADENSOHN STERN 

 BODY:
SOME of Westchester County's finest riders and horses jumped to the head of their classes last weekend when they joined the country's top equestrian competitors at Madison Square Garden for the 116th National Horse Show. Even to qualify for the premier equestrian event in the United States is an honor -- the show includes Olympic and world championship competitors -- and Westchester riders and horses not only participated. In many cases they also won.
Madison Square Garden was transformed for the occasion. At a cost of more than $60,000, the arena floor was covered with specially blended dirt instead of wood or ice, and where tall young men frequently leap to stuff balls through baskets, large horses, often ridden by small teenage girls, strained to surmount high hurdles. Horse shows may not draw the same numbers as the Knicks but, according to National Horse Show representatives, 27 million people older than 12 ride every year, 14.6 million of them regularly. The female to male ratio is 2.5 to 1. 
 The ratio among the top riders is not quite as lopsided. Eric Hasbrouck, a Bedford resident and one of the country's top Grand Prix jumping competitors, placed second in a $10,000 jumper event Nov. 4 and first in another last Sunday. On Monday he boarded a plane for Europe to shop for horses.
Besides riding competitively, Mr. Hasbrouck, 39, works as a professional trainer, a job that goes far beyond giving riding lessons. Trainers are paid to find horses for their students, to ride and school horses as well as riders, to accompany students to horse shows, to coach them there, to oversee the horses' well being (grooms usually do the actual caretaking) and to decide when their riders should move on to another horse. Mr. Hasbrouck, who hopes to make the Olympic 2000 team, said he loves his work as a trainer. "What gives me the most enjoyment is training young horses and kids and bringing them along," he said. "And the victories are not always in the ribbons."
Georgina Bloomberg, 16, whom the judges chose as best child rider in this year's show, has been riding since she was 3 1/2 and entered her first show at 6. Georgina lives in Manhattan but rides at Old Salem Farm in North Salem two or three days a week after school, plus any weekend that she is not away at shows. Her hunter Diplomacy was the top winning junior hunter of the year last year, although when she rode him in the 1998 show he performed disappointingly. This year they worked so well together that Diplomacy was the show's champion large junior hunter (meaning a large hunter ridden by a junior rider). Furthermore, the grand champion hunter of the show was Dialog L, another horse Georgina owns.
Although she rides him at the stable, Georgina is not allowed to ride Dialog L competitively until he is gelded -- he is a stallion and juniors are not allowed to compete on them. He was ridden by Georgina's trainer, Scott Stewart, who trains all the horses and students at Old Salem.
The difference between hunters and jumpers is like the difference between figure skaters and speed skaters. Both jump difficult courses, but the hunters are judged on the elegance of their performance while jumpers compete on speed.
Like Mr. Hasbrouck, Kate Levy, 19, of Katonah, prefers jumping events. "Hunter classes are judged on the horse and are completely subjective, versus the jumpers, which are 100 percent objective," Ms. Levy explained. "It is based on time against the clock, versus the judges' opinions. Jumpers have to jump high, fast and clear, and the courses ask a lot of the riders."
Ms. Levy, a 1999 John Jay High School graduate, postponed entering Georgetown University for a year to work at Heritage Farm in Somers and compete as an adult with her horse Opus in the amateur-owner jumper classes. This was Ms. Levy's third year to qualify for the show, but her first as an adult.
Actually, Ms. Levy did not qualify this year; Opus did. In hunter and jumper events, the horses, not the riders, are judged; the horses qualify for the national show and anyone can ride them. In equitation events (which also include jumping) the riders rather than the horses are judged and the qualifying riders can ride any horse.
Before she became an adult rider Ms. Levy rode in the Garden for two years in the Maclay Championship finals , the most prestigious contest for junior riders in the country (qualifying junior riders are younger than 18 on the previous Dec. 1). This year Cullen Latimer, 18, of Pound Ridge, and Beth Honig, 17, of Bronxville, rode in the Maclay; Ms. Latimer for the fourth year and Beth for the second. Ms. Latimer did not know until a week before the show what horse she would ride -- the horse she had planned to use had become lame. Her trainer arranged to borrow the same horse Ms. Latimer also had to borrow to ride in the previous year's competition. Such last minute arrangements are not unusual -- horses get sick or injured and people help one another out.
Even so, in borrowing her mount, Ms. Latimer was in the minority. Most of the riders who qualify for the National Horse Show not only own their own horses, but many of them also own several. Mr. Stewart, the trainer, said many of the riders at this show own both a hunter and a jumper. Show-quality horses start at $20,000 and more, and most of the horses in the national show cost hundreds of thousands of dollars. Grand Prix jumpers, which take part in the most demanding courses and compete for the largest purses, may cost more than $1 million or $2 million.
Mr. Hasbrouck said, "There are more good riders than good horses," which means the competition for the good ones pushes the prices up. Furthermore, buying a horse is only the beginning. Simply boarding a horse in Westchester typically costs at least $1,500 a month, and that must be supplemented by veterinary bills, shoeing fees, riding lessons, show entry fees, transportation fees to shows, grooming expenses, mane and tail braiding for hunter events, and more.
At a cost of tens of thousands of dollars a year, showing horses at this level is clearly not for the impecunious, but several longtime riders insisted that the sport was not completely elitist. Mr. Hasbrouck bought his first horse for $100 and worked his way up by training horses and riders, as have many of the professional riders. Ms. Latimer's mother, Brooke, also contended that while money is an important factor, "You don't need to be incredibly wealthy -- you can ride other people's horses and pay lease fees.
"If someone wants to sell a horse and wants to showcase it, they may lend it, for example."
Ms. Latimer had an advantage some riders do not have. "I had ridden as a child and knew the horse world," Brooke Latimer said, "so I could guide her through it and do things in the most economical way -- I could find horses that weren't outrageously expensive."
As Brooke Hodgson, Cullen's mother was the 1968 Maclay champion, making her a member of a very select group, and horses would not be lent for showcasing were not Cullen such an outstanding rider and the Maclay such a prestigious showcase.
The top level in the horse show world is a contrast-filled universe, and perhaps it is those very contrasts that give it such individuality. There is affluence but there is also danger -- even the best rounds can be one stumble away from disaster. The actor Christopher Reeve was a skilled and safety-conscious rider, but when he severed his spinal cord he was jumping a much lower hurdle than the junior riders routinely surmount. There is world-class competition but there are also touches of adolescence.
Georgina rides some of the top horses in the world but her fingernails are covered with frosted lavender nail polish. And always, there are the horses. "The horses are humbling," Brooke Latimer said. "Even the best horses can have a bad day. You never know what they'll do."

HEADLINE: Putting Tax-Delinquent Properties Into New Hands

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AT some point in the not too distant future 47 tax-delinquent properties in the Bronx, 20 of them parcels of vacant land, will complete a transfer to new ownership that has been initiated by city government -- even though city government itself will never take title.
The technique goes by the name of third-party transfers, and it is the most inventive of all the anti-abandonment strategies that the Giuliani administration has devised. Avoiding owner abandonment and ultimate city takeover of distressed property has been one of the administration's principal housing themes from the start. 
 Third-party transfers are intended as a way to get properties that owners have shown no interest in retaining efficiently into the hands of capable nonprofit or for-profit owner-managers, without intervening city ownership or management. It is being done via a newly formed nonprofit intermediary entity that is to hold title during a transitional period.
This procedure is bringing a fundamental change to the historic "in rem" foreclosure process for real estate under which the city itself has owned and in most cases managed thousands of units of housing, usually for a period of many years, after a court proceeding. After costly and not always effective management, the buildings are rehabilitated and transferred to private or some form of nonprofit ownership.
To this day, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development holds 28,600 units of housing in 3,100 buildings in its portfolio of tax-foreclosed properties, even though there has been no new taking of tax-delinquent residential property since 1995.
That was the year the Giuliani administration suspended the takings while its new policies emerged. An early step was the enactment of Local Law 37 by the City Council in 1996. Under the law, once multifamily properties have been delinquent in taxes for a year, the city may begin a foreclosure action. When a court judgment is obtained, the housing agency has eight months in which to transfer title to itself or to a third party.
In the first four months the law assures owners the right to pay off the debt, or enter into an installment agreement to pay it. In the next four months, the redemption agreement may still be obtained, but it is discretionary on the city's part.
With the intention of testing the third-party transfer approach, the city began a foreclosure action last year against 174 properties in a single tax district of the South Bronx. The area includes parts of Hunts Point, Longwood, Melrose, Morrisania, Mott Haven and Port Morris. It turned out that 128 of the 174 ownerships, or 73 percent, showed up to enter into installment agreements, said Robin Weinstein, acting deputy commissioner in charge of the Office of Housing Intervention and Resources. The office was formed last year to run the anti-abandonment program.
THE remaining 46 properties were assembled in packages for which for-profit and nonprofit housing operators were invited to bid. At the same time, the housing agency signed an agreement with a new nonprofit entity called Neighborhood Restore, whose role is to take title temporarily and see the properties through a transition period. It took title to the 46 properties last August.
Neighborhood Restore has a nine-member board of directors that includes bankers and community development leaders and is headed by Lewis P. Jones, vice chairman of Chase Community Development Corporation, the community development arm of Chase Manhattan Bank.
Thomas Ciano, its executive director and a former deputy commissioner of the Department of Homeless Services, said that the operation is on schedule to complete title transfers by the end of May, about two months ahead of the one-year deadline. Efforts are under way to line up the financing that the owners will need for further rehabilitation when they take title, he said.
All these properties are considered "distressed," and the tax liens are therefore not considered salable in the private market. Under another 1996 law, Local Law 26, the city has been selling tax liens of properties with greater economic viability to a trust, which then securitizes the liens. In six sales of packages of properties so far, the process has produced initial cash advances to the city that average 81 percent of the value of the liens, according to the Department of Finance, with the prospect of additional income once purchasers of the securities have been paid.
Local Law 37 defines a distressed property as one in which the tax lien is at least 15 percent of a property's market value. In addition, the distressed property has to have at least five Class B (hazardous) or Class C (immediately hazardous) building code violations, or at least $1,000 in liens for unpaid city emergency-repair work.
These conditions have not discouraged applicants from seeking to take over the owner-management role. A total of 120 nonprofit or for-profit companies submitted their qualifications to become possible future owners. Five were chosen by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development in May for the properties in the round-one cycle.
Three of them are nonprofits: the Belmont/Arthur Avenue Local Development Corporation, a 20-year-old organization that operates 45 buildings in the Bronx, with 1,300 apartments; Community Assisted Tenant Controlled Housing Inc., known as Catch, a foundation-supported citywide mutual housing association in which the Parodneck Foundation is the lead agency, and Neighborhood Housing Services, a nonprofit organization that offers various types of housing programs and services.
THE two private sector organizations are Jerome Associates, the ownership arm of a family-owned plumbing business, Crescent Contracting, on Webster Avenue; and Metropolitan Resources Group, a joint venture of principals of L.& M. Equity Participants, of Larchmont, N.Y., a longtime owner/developer of housing rehabilitated under city programs, and Lemle & Wolff Inc., which manages 5,400 apartments in the Bronx and Manhattan.
The specific causes that led past owners to abandon these 47 properties are by now shrouded in the mists of history. But there are clues. Joseph Cicciu, for 20 years the executive director of the Belmont/Arthur Avenue local development corporation, noted that it was difficult for owners with a small portfolio of buildings to achieve economies in costs, and if rents are too low or uncollectible, a building may soon fail.
In some cases the tenants themselves may have become the owners under a city disposition program, and ultimately, as early leaders depart or die, rent collections may weaken. In round one, three of the seven buildings with 20 apartments or more were formerly owned by the tenants themselves. Tenant ownership may take either the rental or limited-equity co-op form.
"There can be a turnover in leadership, an unexpected rise in costs, a reluctance to raise maintenance charges or rents, or a reluctance to take neighbors to housing court -- any number of reasons," said Harold de Rienzo, president of Catch, whose three-building package includes the 53-unit formerly tenant-owned co-op at 865 East 167th Street, off Intervale Avenue. "When that happens the tenants may just stop paying municipal charges," he said.
Other distressed buildings for which third-party owners have been selected have already been functioning under court-appointed management because of unsatisfactory housing conditions. Hale G. Rickman, a principal of Jerome Associates, was the court-appointed manager at 232 Cypress Avenue, with 20 apartments and a store, on the corner of East 138th Street. It was one of the buildings in a package of five, with 90 apartments, that Jerome Associates is now managing and expects to get from Neighborhood Restore. Mr. Rickman said that the deplorable conditions he found at the building are already being corrected with the help of a $150,000 loan from the housing agency.
When the properties are transferred to third-party owners, rehabilitation loans will be in place to upgrade all the properties. The Jerome Associates buildings include two vacant walk-ups at 613 and 627 East 141st Street and the occupied 25-unit building at 1071 Franklin Avenue.
"We intend to keep the existing tenants in place at the same rent they're aleady at, but the vacant apartments will go for about $550 for a one-bedroom and $650 for a two-bedroom," Mr. Rickman said.
But the road to a successful outcome is not necessarily smooth. Tenant hostility is one of the possible obstructions. Tenants at the eight-unit building at 839 East 156th Street, one of the six buildings that Metropolitan Resources Group is to get, have not even allowed the new managers inside.
"We've written them four letters and we're trying to assuage their fears," said Frank Anelante, a principal in the company. "But we have to have access to determine the scope of rehabilitation that's needed and we've started legal action to get it."

HEADLINE: ART;
In Stamford, Art and Artifacts That Tell a Story of Women

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
THE exhibition "Of Significant Influence: Women of Stamford, Past and Present," which is on view at the Stamford Historical Society through Saturday, began with the idea of focusing on seven Stamford women who became well known locally or nationally for their accomplishments: the comedian Gilda Radner, the singer Libby Holman, the philanthropist Helen Altschul, the political activist Louise Seeley, the urban renewal proponent Edith Sherman, the educator Sarah Francis Smith and the physician Dr. Joyce Yerwood.
The husband and wife curators of the exhibition -- Joshua Lane, the historical society's new curator, and Karen Suchenski, director of education -- said they realized there was an opportunity to expand the original premise, and make it more inclusive. 
 They invited the public to contribute to what is now an archive of women who are achievers in Stamford. (The discovery of a 1991 commemorative publication listing 350 notable people -- with only 2 women among them -- helped fire the search.)
Pushing beyond seven notable examples is the heart of the show in a time-line gallery that includes important documents and artifacts, telling the story of women's history nationally.
The exhibition explores the contributions women have made from the 17th century to the present, from the home, religious institutions, organizations and schools, and then from less likely places including the state legislature, corporate boardrooms and laboratories.
Among finds, for example, is the memoir of Louisa Zwart -- "which walked in the door with her daughter-in-law the other day," said Mr. Lane.
Louisa Zwart, who was born in Holland in 1871 and came to the United States in 1901, established a dry goods store in Glenbrook. "She was a businesswoman in an environment where few ran their own enterprises," Mr. Lane said.
Visitors can learn that among other hard-fought rights granted piecemeal to women was the right to vote in school board elections in 1893. (Not until 1920 did the Constitution of the United States give women the right to vote in elections for all offices.)
In the exhibition there is also evidence that early independence-minded women expanded the definition of home with weaving, dying, candle making, cheese making and open-hearth cooking, enabling Stamford residents to forego costly imports and develop economic independence from Britain.
The time-line gallery shows objects from 1640 to 1821, from cradles to hearthside pots and utensils to flax wheels, flax and the finished product, linen.
Women who worked to contribute to their households -- along the way gaining political power -- were referred to belonging to "the cult of the homespun," said Mr. Lane.
The few women who had businesses frequently owned dressmaking and millinery shops.
"The show places women in local history where they have always been, but largely invisible," Mr. Lane said.
"The purpose of the show is to recognize the accomplishments of Stamford women from all walks of life, creating a more inclusive history."
The Stamford Historical Society (1508 High Ridge Road, Stamford; 203-329-1183) is open Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 4 p.m.

HEADLINE: The Struggle to Stay on the Trail;
Kicked Off Land by New Owners, Hiking Routes Are Redrawn, Sometimes Onto Roads

BYLINE: By NANCY DONIGER 

 BODY:
FOR those who have taken to the woods this season to see the fall foliage, a walk along the 700-mile Blue-Blazed Hiking Trail System may seem like a peaceful respite.
But the negotiations required to preserve the well-maintained trails system, snaking throughout the four corners of the state, spanning private property, state parks and forests, municipal land, and water and utility company property, belies the serenity of the hiking system. In an era of economic prosperity and intensive development in most sections of the state, the hiking system's continuity and continuance are at risk. 
 Since the 1950's, the Connecticut Forest and Parks Association, which maintains the system, has lost 100 miles of trails in Fairfield County and other highly developed areas of the state, often causing a fracture in the systems' continuity.
During the same time period, the group also gained about 100 miles of trails in the eastern, less-developed section of the state. That has resulted in the same overall trail mileage, but presented considerable continuity and access issues, all of which have had to be solved through negotiations with property owners.
These negotiations can be intense and time-consuming, according to John Hibbard, the executive director of the association who has led the group for 37 years.
"I spend at least 50 percent of my time engaged in negotiations," he said. "Sprawl is an ongoing challenge. Over all, our goal is to maintain and protect the existing trail system and fill missing links to segments that have closed."
Accomplishing that goal is not easy, he said. In addition to himself, Ann Colson, the group's director of volunteers and trails coordinator, devotes about half her time to negotiations, particularly with new property owners when a parcel that has a trail on it changes hands. Negotiations are a top priority for other association principals as well, Mr. Hibbard said.
The association on Oct. 29 was forced to close a .83-mile section of the Mattabesett Trail in Haddam and relocate it onto the road because of a change in the ownership of the land. "This section of the trail was on someone's driveway who sold the property, and the new owner doesn't want it on his driveway," Mr. Hibbard said.
William R. Bowles, a Haddam lawyer who represented the buyer of the property, Wayland Hall, said the new owners aren't against trail conservation; they simply do not want to deal with the uncertainty of having an unknown number of people traipsing through their yard.
"The seller was an estate, and didn't realize the trail was there because the original agreement was oral, not written," he said. "Not only was the trail there, but it went up the driveway and across the backyard. In buying a home you don't want to be sitting in the backyard, sunbathing, and have some Boy Scouts come hiking through the yard."
At the same time, the association expects to be able to extend the Shenipsit Trail an additional mile in Tolland where an existing property has been subdivided, and the new property owner, Michael Cole, has agreed to allow the trail on an undeveloped portion of the parcel, Mr. Hibbard said.
"I bought 240 acres and subdivided it," Mr. Cole said. "I'll be developing 68 acres into 18 lots. The rest will be vacant land, through which the trial will pass. It's part of my open-space agreement with the town. Town Planner Ron Blake asked for the trail, but I was thinking of doing it anyway."
In this instance, the association is gaining a mile, thereby balancing the loss of .83 mile on the Mattabesett Trail, even though the two trails are not in the same area. Although seemingly small in size, it's an important accomplishment for the association because it will help fill one mile of a four-mile missing link in the Snenipsit Trial from the Cobalt Village section of East Hampton to Somers, 'but there is still much more to be done," Mr. Hibbard said.
Since 1895, the association has been working to conserve Connecticut's woodlands and encourage stewardship of the state's natural resources. The association drafts an annual agenda for state action and said it has been instrumental in enacting major environmental laws and programs. The association added trail development and maintenance to its duties in 1929. Over the years, it has enlisted an all-volunteer work force to maintain its statewide system.
Intense development in Fairfield County, and changing land ownership in other parts of the state, present a threat to the continuity of the trails. The breaking up of large tracts of land into smaller pieces is particularly troublesome because it requires the association to deal with multiple land owners on tracts that used to be owned by a few owners who allowed their land to be open to the public.
"As the blocks have become smaller and smaller, we have many more landowners to deal with," Mr. Hibbard said.
Association officials and volunteers attempt to relocate trails, or negotiate use of the land whenever property changes hands and problems ensue. One of the biggest threats is when the association had not had formal agreements with the previous owners, Mr. Hibbard said. The heirs may decide to selland developers who purchase the land may not want to retain the trails on them, he said.
Property transference and development has forced closure of some sections of the Mattabesett Trail in Middletown and Meriden. The association was also forced to close a portion of the Metacomet Trial in Meriden in the early 1990's, but successful negotiations with the Meriden Water Company will allow a one-mile portion of the trail to reopen later this fall. Restoration work has already begun, Mr. Hibbard said.
In another instance, Durham officials have negotiated with the owner of a site called Mount Pisgah. Mr. Hibbard said the owner didn't want the trail on his property, which forced the closure of a portion of the Mattabesett Trail there. Durham is applying for a grant under the new state act and will hold a referendum later this fall to let taxpayers decide whether the town should buy the site as open space.
One of the association's major successes was the relocation of the historic eastern route of the Appalachian Trail in Cornwall to a route west of the Housatonic River because of property owners who wanted the trail off their land, he said. The eastern route was subsequently re-established as a Blue-Blazed trail, named after the blue blazes, painted on tree trunks, that mark the trails, and renamed the Mohawk Trail.
Another success involved extending the Shenipsit Trail in Vernon over the Belding Wildlife Management area, given to the state by Maxwell Belding, a Connecticut conservationist, he said.
In 1998, the General Assembly approved an act concerning open space and watershed land, with lobbying by the association and other conservation groups. The program has provided $32 million in land grants to communities over the past two years to buy open space, which is part of Gov. John Rowland's plan to spend $166 million over five years to preserve forests and farmlands. Many of the parcels in the grant program contain trails that will be permanently protected from development.
Early in the association's history, members pooled their resources and purchased prime properties until the state could buy them as state forests and parks. Rocky Neck State Park in East Lyme, Hammonasset State Park in Madison, Sherwood Island State Park in Westport, and People's State Forest in Barkhamsted were purchased through such pooling of resources, according to Richard Whitehouse of Glastonbury, association president.
"The spirit and the giving is still out there," Mr. Whitehouse said. "That's one of the enjoyable parts about working with C.F.P.A. People really do care about open space, and they're willing to do something about it."
Russell Brenneman of Westport, a past association president, described the group as "the quiet conservation organization. We're not the government, but all the things we do is for public benefit. Unlike other organizations that make a lot of noise and get in the headlines, we do our work less flamboyantly, but people respect us and turn to us for our thoughtful response."
The association's quiet productivity and commitment attracted Ms. Colson to the organization.
"So many of the people who use the blue trails are unaware of our role in keeping them open," she said. "We work with unit managers at each state park where we have trails to maintain them. It's likely we built them as well."
Daniel Casey of Bristol became involved with the association as a youth volunteer in 1973. He is one of the association's 92 trail managers who carry their chain saws and rakes out onto the trails and direct more than 400 volunteers. His long-standing contributions led to his nomination as Connecticut Volunteer of the Year for 1999.
Maura Allaire, 15, of Bristol, one of the young volunteers who works with Mr. Casey, has been doing trail work since she was 9. She continues to volunteer despite the pressures of homework and sports, she said.
"I've always loved the outdoors," she said. "Trail work is a way to go hiking every weekend. The trail crew goes out every weekend, spring and fall. There are quite a few other young people who work with Mr. Casey."
Mr. Casey urges first-time hikers to start with an easy, well-marked trail, such as Sessions Woods in Burlington, a three-mile gravel road. He also recommends going with a guide or someone who has hiked the area before.
Hikers need to be aware of hunting season, from Oct. 1 to New Year's Day, and wear fluorescent orange while hiking in state forests and private land where hunting is allowed. Hunting is not allowed in state parks and forests on Sunday, he said.
"The trails are beautiful anytime, but especially during the peak foliage season in mid-October," said Patricia Barkman of Newtown, an avid hiker of the Blue-Blazed system. "The combination of rock ledges, foliage and the Housatonic River provide spectacular vistas. An abundant waterfall cascades into Lake Lillinonah," she said. "Preserving the continuity of trails is so important because they provide a place to exercise and regain a feeling of being spiritually restored."
 "The Connecticut Walk Book," published by the association and available at most library and book stores, includes comprehensive maps and information for hikers. For information about group, call the association office at (860) 346-TREE, or visit its website at www.ctwoodlands.org.

HEADLINE: For the Few, a Breathtaking View;
The Island Has Largely Resisted High-Rise Creep. But, Oh, the Scenery...

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: EAST MEADOW

 BODY:
NASSAU COUNTY MEDICAL CENTER opened here in 1974 as the tallest occupied structure in all of Nassau and Suffolk. The 19-floor tower commands a 360-degree view that on a clear day extends to the North Shore, Jones Beach and the distant New York City skyline.
So what was put on that top floor? A revolving restaurant? An observation deck with coin-operated binoculars? The executive offices? The directors' board room? Private suites for V.I.P. patients? 
 None of the above. The floor was designated for storage.
Today that top floor still reigns as Long Island's tallest overlook. It also remains a giant cellar in the sky. Makeshift walkways of old plywood panels wend their way across the rough, uneven concrete floor. Here is a cluster of dented desks and filing cabinets, there shelves are piled with stacks of dusty dinner plates and -- what's that? -- an obsolete iron lung. Much of the space is simply open.
Of the top five floors of the medical center, in fact, one is devoted to mechanical equipment and three are vacant, built for patient demand that never materialized. The exception is the 18th floor, where pediatric patients and staff enjoy a grand vista.
"Oh, yeah, definitely, the view is beautiful," said Lisa Fechtig, who said she had never tired of it in 15 years as a nursing station clerk.
"You can see the New York City skyline that way," she said, pointing west. "You can see the marathon runners on the parkway. We could see the brush fires in Suffolk. The Fourth of July is a major good. You can see all the fireworks."
Various work shifts bring sunsets and sunrises, day views and nighttime sparkle, including lights blinking atop other tall buildings to warn errant low-flying planes. Scenes change with the season: "It's pretty when it snows."
Why the medical center largely ignored its sweeping views is uncertain. Whether intentional or not, the tower stands as a monument to the conflicted feelings that many Long Islanders harbor about tall buildings. When people fled New York City's skyscrapers to become pioneers in the nation's new suburban culture, they adopted a distinctly low profile.
Although the skyline is gradually changing, tall buildings remain an anomaly on the Island. The very idea of constructing them provokes political, social, economic and aesthetic debate.
"In New York City, being in a tall building signifies you're at the top of the mountain, but on Long Island, a certain placelessness sets in," said Paul L. Bentel an architect in Locust Valley who has written about local architecture. "You wonder why a tower, and why here. Are the high rises displaced urban building types, or do they fulfill the modernist image of an tower in a park?"
To many Long Islanders, "high rise" are fighting words. A zoning proposal for three-floor garden apartments can provoke fierce opposition from civic groups. Neighbors rail against such "high rises," a description that may amuse those city folk who live in five-floor walkups. "They don't like tall buildings out here," said a county planner in Suffolk, Roy Fedelem. An architect of tall buildings, Michael H. Spector of New Hyde Park, said: "Some people will fight anything over one story. But we're not a farmland out here any more."
Opposition is receding, however, and tall buildings are growing in height and number. "You can make a beautiful building out of a high rise," said Jonathan B. Friedman, dean of architecture at New York Institute of Technology. High-rise economics can preserve surrounding land, he said. "In a way, it's a way of saving Long Island."
Mr. Bentel is not so sure. "In a flat landscape, a man-made building becomes monumental," he said. "The question is what should that profile be, and how should it be seen against the skyline."
The next major addition on the horizon will be the $240 million federal courthouse opening in the spring in Central Islip. It will have 11 floors, but lofty ceilings will inflate the total height to 240 feet, equal to a typical 22-floor building. As the architect, Mr. Spector said he was conscious about blending the structure into the setting. "We spent as much time solving the roofscape as we spent solving the rest of the space, because we knew people would be flying by it, driving by it and walking by it every day," he said. Capitalizing on the view was also a priority. "On every floor, the judges see the bay, and the public sees the sound."
Tall buildings fetch top dollar in real estate rentals, and rents escalate with the floors. "We're the top of the market, literally and figuratively," said Steven D. Mezick, assistant controller of The DeMatteis Organization, which is ensconced on the 15th floor atop EAB Plaza, which it built from another Spector design.
"It's in effect a Manhattan building in a suburban setting; it makes that statement," he said. "When I came for here for my interview, it made quite an impression." EAB Plaza, whose 1.1 million square feet make it the Island's largest office building, fosters its city image. With a conscious nod to Rockefeller Center, it has an indoor arcade, an outdoor ice skating rink and giant Christmas tree -- some years taller than its city cousin -- whose annual lighting draws thousands.
Views from the tall buildings offer a surprise: a verdant blanket of treetops that conceals the vast network of streets and rows of houses on the ground below. The only things protruding above the tree cover are spindly water towers and the few other tall buildings.
"For eight months of the year, it looks like we're in the middle of a thick forest," said Dr. Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, sitting in his seventh-floor office at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "That's because the maximum height of a house is 30 feet, if you have a two-story colonial, and the trees have grown to 70 feet. It's only when you fly over in a helicopter and look directly down that you see the sea of houses and swimming pools in almost every backyard."
For decades politicians have fought over high rises. "It was not just an aesthetic question but a major political issue," said Dr. Koppelman, recalling the reaction to proposals for modest to luxury apartments at Mitchel Field. "Margiotta, then the Republican leader, mounted a major campaign. They didn't want to bring New York City to Nassau, they wanted to keep the Tammany tentacles out. The real thing was that to him, tall buildings represented Democrats. But then when DeMatteis wanted to build EAB, all of a sudden it was acceptable. And when Hofstra built residential towers, they said, 'That's not high rise, that's university.' It's a slight bit of hypocrisy."
There may be something to the notion of apartment-dwelling Democrats. The biggest concentration of midrise apartments is in Long Beach -- a Democratic bastion. But even there, resentment of what critics called a "Chinese wall" of 6- to 10-story buildings once forced a moratorium on such projects.
In fundamental ways, the suburbs developed as the city's diametric opposite, with lawns replacing pavement, automobiles replacing mass transit, single-family homes replacing apartments -- and low-rise replacing skyscrapers. Homeowners feared that apartment renters would not have the same commitment to their buildings and community, said the curator of Long Island Studies Institute at Hofstra, Dr. Barbara M. Kelly. Racial prejudice was another factor, based on a stereotype of high-rise public housing.
At the peak of resistance, Republican campaign literature portrayed North Shore Towers looming ominously at Nassau's border. Part of the site is in Nassau; the towers are in Queens. True enough, they soar 32 floors, their shadow falling across the county line. But the landscaped complex seems peaceful and inviting, with a golf course, tennis, pools, underground shopping, a movie theater and a restaurant. The views include a lake, Long Island Sound and the Manhattan skyline. The security director, Kris Debysingh, said: "It's like a city in the country."
Personal preferences also come into play. Years ago when Suffolk opened its 12-floor Dennison building, County Executive John V. N. Klein shunned the top-floor office, moving instead to the first floor. Dr. Koppelman was delighted to get the high office but was puzzled by Mr. Klein's choice -- until the county executive pointed out the absence of sprinklers, hoses and fire escapes.
As a group, the island's tall buildings are architecturally undistinguished, critics say. The Nassau Medical Center is a hulking megalith. EAB Plaza's mirrored exterior reflects the here-but-not-here school. Peter A. Bentel, brother and partner of Paul, says the black tower at Stony Brook "makes me nervous, like the obelisk in Space Odyssey 2001." The adjoining tower, however, is a diverting stack of giant cubes. "They have problems with its concrete exterior," said Dr. Koppelman. "The gag on campus is that they'll never remove the scaffolding because the building might fall down."
The father of our country, George Washington, is also the father of the island's first tall building. As president, he ordered the construction of the Montauk Lighthouse, built in 1796. It stands 110 feet high and is boosted by its hilltop perch.
The Montauk tower was eclipsed in 1858 by the erection of the new Fire Island Lighthouse. At 164 feet, it was the king of the hill more for than a century and remains among the island's tallest buildings. It is also the only one open to the public. Reserved tours are available, $4 for adults and $3 for children and the elderly. A visit requires a hike and a climb. The parking lot is a half mile away, then inside the lighthouse await 182 steps on the original iron spiral staircase, with rope railings.
It is worth the effort. At the top, a circular outdoor catwalk offers what may be the most scenic high view of Long Island, overlooking the endless Atlantic, the slender barrier beaches and the Great South Bay. Below are little clamming boats, big party fishing boats and fast-moving craft whose wakes cut long white arcs across the water. The western view is graced by the Robert Moses Causeway and its bridges at Captree, and the sentinel-like water tower.
"On a clear day, as Barbra Streisand says, you can see the twin towers" of the World Trade Center, said the lighthouse's administrator, Daniel McDonnell.
Some high structures are not occupied by people and instead serve utilitarian functions: power transmission rigs, broadcast antennae and water towers. From Connecticut, the most prominent landmark across Long Island Sound is Keyspan's power plant at Northport. Its distinctive red and white smokestacks stand 600 feet, equal to 60 floors. Another big stack, the 390-foot chimney of the American Ref-Fuel recycling plan, is the only outside structure that pokes above the tree line at the otherwise idyllic Old Westbury Gardens.
The island's biggest cluster of sizable buildings -- a spread-out cluster, to be sure -- is around the Nassau Coliseum: Hofstra's six dormitory towers and library, Nassau Community College's triangular tower, the Omni office building, the Marriott hotel and EAB Plaza.
At Stony Brook, the surgery department's administrator, Roger Bogenshutz, said, "The view never fails to impress." Autumn is the best because of the patchwork of yellow, orange, red, brown and green foliage. He was excited about the annual turning back of the clock, because "that means the sky will be fuchsia before I go home," he said. "It's really spectacular."
It may become easier for regular Long Islanders to see such views. The Nassau Medical Center, recently taken over by a public benefit corporation, is considering installing a restaurant on the 19th floor. "I love views -- I remember when Windows on the World opened," said the executive vice president, Michael M. DeLuca. The menu will have to be something other than bland commissary food, and Windows on Hempstead Turnpike does not quite work for a name. "We're thinking of calling it the Top of Nassau," he said.
 
The Top of the Island
What does it mean to get high on Long Island? Here are the vital architectural statistics.

DESCRIPTION -- Y-shaped beige hospital.

ACCESS -- Four of the top five floors are closed, but the 19th is being considered for a restaurant. The 18th is for pediatrics staff, patients and authorized guests.

DESCRIPTION -- Adjacent towers, one with shiny black panels, the other shaped like giant tan cubes. WHEN OPENED: 1980. COST: $67 million VIEWS: North Shore, Long Island Sound.
ACCESS -- Limited to employees, patients and authorized visitors.

WHERE -- Uniondale.

COST -- $100 million.
VIEWS -- Coliseum, Hofstra University, Eisenhower Park.

WHERE -- Fire Island.

DESCRIPTION -- Brick tower, painted white and black for visibility.

VIEWS -- Lake Success, Long Island Sound and bridges, the Bronx, Manhattan skyline.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 8; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1672 words

HEADLINE: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year.
During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars. 
 They also lose out on other goodies, like $100 gift certificates on their birthdays, health club memberships and a cash bonus equal to 25 percent of their annual salary on the fifth anniversary of their employment.
About once a month, Mr. Galdi says, he asks his employees if they would rather have cash. The answer is always no.
"They seem to really like the programs," he said, "because it helps with their quality of life."
You could probably count on one hand, and perhaps even one finger, the number of employers in the New York metro area who are handing out keys to BMW's. But with the economy booming and unemployment at record lows, many employers are trying to come up with new and interesting perquisites.
"It's not so much about rewarding, but retaining," said Michael A. Keane, managing consultant at Watson Worldwide, a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. "When it comes to employees, it's basically a seller's market, and many companies are having to make extraordinary efforts."
A recent survey by the outplacement firm Lee Hecht Harrison found that the top two perks on employees' wish lists were health club memberships (58 percent) and flextime (57 percent). That's not what most employers are providing: A.T.M.'s on premises (25 percent) and travel services (15 percent), according to a survey of more than 1,000 employers conducted by Hewitt Associates, a compensation consulting firm.
"Employers need to ask themselves how they can make themselves different from everyone else," said Ray Baumruk, who helped conduct the study for Hewitt.
Perks vary widely from company to company and within particular industries. High-tech firms tend to have the most innovative offerings, like on-site massages, concierge services, even quiet rooms where workers can nap. Blue-chip companies, particularly those on suburban campuses, tend to focus more heavily on time-saving perks like on-site dry-cleaning and film drop-off.
For example, the 500 employees at Xerox's corporate headquarters at Stamford, Conn., are able to work out at an on-site fitness center, order meals from the company cafeteria for dinner and drop off dry-cleaning when they get to work in the morning; it's usually ready to be picked up the next day. On-site massage therapy -- a perk offered at other Xerox locations, but not in Stamford -- is in the works, said Christa Carone, a spokeswoman.
One difference from several years ago is that the perks are for a larger pool of workers. At Arcnet, even the receptionist qualified for a BMW. Last month, Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer that has stores in Hicksville, N.Y., and Elizabeth, N.J., pledged cash bonuses amounting to a day's worth of sales, $80 million worldwide, to its employees, from the snack bar staff and stock clerks to the president. Each employee will end up with $2,435 when checks are distributed this month, said Marty Marston, a spokeswoman for Ikea North America. Retailing tends to be among the lowest-paying type of employment, so the one-time bonus could equal a month's pay for some.
But even companies that can't afford to provide a car or a day's sales have plenty of options. Many perks being offered today cost the employer virtually nothing, but still create plenty of good will. Men's Wearhouse, a large California retailer that operates about 20 stores in the New York metro area, has signed up 120 local employers, including Citibank and New York University, for its V.I.P. program, which gives a company's employees 10 percent off on Men's Wearhouse purchases.
Transitchek, a program that allows employees of enrolled companies to set aside up to $65 a month before taxes for public transportation commuting costs, also provides savings on corporate taxes. Each month 7,000 to 8,000 employers in the New York area participate in the program, said George Serventi, Transitchek director.
"A lot of these things are in the interest of the employers who are doing them," said Helen Darling, a consultant at Watson Worldwide's Stamford office.
Even costly perks often pay off in the end. Lipton Child Care Centers, a Washington company that operates backup child care centers in Manhattan, White Plains and Jersey City, says that employers still save money because parents don't need to miss work when their regular child care provider isn't available. The service has attracted employers like the National Hockey League, the National Basketball Association, Philip Morris, Pepsico and Texaco, as well as newer, smaller companies like Knight Securities of Jersey City.
Stephanie Bernstein, director of human resources for Knight, a Nasdaq market maker, said she and several other parents were able to sell Knight's chief executive on the idea of backup care, even though Knight, like many other brokerage firms, mostly employs single men.
"There were a couple of people here, myself included, who would get into a situation and be jammed," Ms. Bernstein said. Now, for an annual fee of $50, she and other Knight parents have access to the Lipton center in the lobby at Newport Center.
At Dialogic Corporation, a Parsippany technology company recently bought by Intel, the company's 1,000 employees have access to a corporate concierge, who is able to arrange things like dinner reservations, family vacations and oil changes for cars. Dialogic pays LesConcierges of San Francisco for the service, but employees have to pay for individual requests. Other Dialogic perks include an on-site fitness center, a free coffee and juice bar, and heavily discounted soda.
"This is all aimed at making it comfortable for people to be here longer than 40 hours a week," said Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits. Though Mr. Cardinal said the company hadn't tried to figure out whether the concierge service and other perks were paying off for the company, he said that turnover had been lower than expected.
Still, at most companies, benefits are limited to items like health and life insurance and a retirement plan. Mr. Keane, the consultant at Watson Worldwide, estimated that only 15 to 20 percent of all companies offer what he described as nontraditional perks. That could grow if the economy continued to prosper.
"A lot of companies are being pretty cautious, because once you add it, it becomes hard to take it away," said Alan M. Johnson, managing director at Johnson Associates, a Wall Street compensation consulting firm.
Many consultants and even the companies that provide the perks wonder what will happen to the programs when the economy takes a turn for the worse. Employees who have grown used to the perks may be unwilling to give them up.
"We all know it's going to be difficult to take these things away," Mr. Cardinal said. Given the choice of layoffs or reducing perks, most employers would probably reduce the perks, consultants say.
But not Mr. Galdi. When business slowed down a few months ago, he said he had to lay off several employees. But he has no plans to stop handing out BMW's or cut back on any of the other benefits Arcnet employees receive.
"I'm in the service business," Mr. Galdi said, "and having employees that are happy and hard-working is good business for me."
 
Like a Front Desk at the Office
SO what exactly does a corporate concierge do? Just about anything, as long as it's legal.
"I never know what each day will bring," said Pam Wildrick, a corporate concierge at Dialogic Corporation, a technology company that was recently acquired by Intel Corporation. "People come in and they drop their problems on my desk."
In the year and a half since Ms. Wildrick began working at Dialogic's Parsippany headquarters, she's done everything from picking up gifts for spouses who have forgotten a birthday or anniversary to locating a clock that ticks backward to finding a guide to take an engineer through dense jungle in Costa Rica. In a typical month, she fields 230 to 250 requests from Dialogic's 1,000 employees.
Though Ms. Wildrick works in Parsippany, she's actually an employee of Les Concierges, a 13-year-old San Francisco company that provides concierge services to companies. (In the past, she had worked for several nonprofit groups in Morris County, including a stint as president of the Junior League and director of communications and special events for the Arts Council of the Morristown Area.)
Though the concierge concept is popular in California, particularly in the Silicon Valley, corporate concierges are still relatively new in the New York area.
"There's a lot of potential in the New York area," said Phil Wexler, Les Concierges' executive vice president. The company recently reached an agreement with Goldman Sachs to begin providing concierge services to its employees early next year.
Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits, said the service was popular. One part of Ms. Wildrick's job involves arranging for oil changes and other routine maintenance on employees' personal cars while they are working, saving the employees valuable time on the weekends.
So is there anything Ms. Wildrick won't do?
Yes. She won't hire strippers, though she has been asked to.
Though that's not illegal, Ms. Wildrick said she just didn't feel comfortable arranging that kind of entertainment for Dialogic employees, even if it took place off-site.
"That one just crosses the line," Ms. Wildrick said. MICHELLE LEDER
