HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Holocaust and Hiroshima
A link between the Holocaust and the American bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, as perceived by the Japanese author Kinue Tokudome, will be the subject of her talk on Friday at noon at the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains. The program, "Holocaust and Hiroshima: Facing Our Past," is being presented by the Westchester chapter of the American Jewish Committee as one of a series designed to promote positive relations among the county's ethnic, racial and religious groups. 
 Ms. Tokudome's "Courage to Remember" was the first book on the Holocaust written specifically for Japanese readers. It was published this year by Paragon House of St. Paul. Ms. Tokudome does extensive research and conducts countless interviews with key figures and individual survivors before embarking on her projects. She is working on a book about America's use of the atomic bomb in Japan in World War II, and the bomb's long-term effect on the survivors and society.
Raised in Japan, Ms. Tokudome has lived in the United States for 21 years, during which time she received degrees in political science and international relations from the University of Chicago. She has reported extensively on American life, to Japanese readers. Admission, including lunch, is $18. Reservations by 5 p.m. tomorrow at 948-5585.
 
Cat Show Contenders
Socks Clinton will be one of three nominees vying for the title of Cat of the Year at the 24th Westchester Cat Show next weekend. It is scheduled next Saturday and Sunday from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. at the County Center, Bronx River Parkway and Central Avenue in White Plains.
The award is based on uniqueness, courage, altruism and other characteristics more common to cats than most people realize. Last year's winner was actually a dog named Ginny that rescues cats. In the previous year, the winner was Scarlett, a cat that made all the local papers by rescuing her kittens from a burning building and suffering near-fatal burns.
A Japanese bobtail, the second current nominee, left his comfortable home after several visits to a neighbor's child, who, it turned out, had terminal cancer. The cat stayed with the child like a caring friend until the end, then remained with the grieving father.
A 12-year-old short-hair named Mary Paige has earned many thousands of dollars for animal rescue organizations by modeling and acting in print and television advertisements. She is apparently happy to do so in return for being rescued from the streets with her mother, pregnant with Mary at the time.
More than 250 domestic, exotic, and champion cats representing more than 30 breeds will compete for ribbons and the prestigious Best in Show Award. A Meow Market of cat-related merchandise, informal chats with veterinarians, sales of purebred cats and adoptions of cats from shelters are among the many features at the show. Admission is $8, $6 for people older than 61 and $3 for children younger than 12. Call 739-5408 for more information.
 
A Look at European Union
For the last 25 years Wouter L. Wilton of the Netherlands has served in diplomatic posts connected to European politics and economics. In his current role as Minister Counselor of the European Delegation in New York of the European Union, he will give a free talk on Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. at Concordia College in Bronxville.
His subject, "The European Union: Changing the Face of a Continent," will range widely over internal trade disputes in Bosnia, to NATO, and the European Union itself as it expands its influence in global affairs.
The college is at 171 White Plains Road and the number for more information is 337-9300, extension 2135.
 
Choreographers' Works
The Dance in Education Fund and Steffi Nossen School of Dance of Purchase College will present an afternoon of new works by Westchester choreographers next Saturday at 2 in the Dance Theater Laboratory at Purchase College. Admission is free and part of the program will be devoted to a discussion between the choreographers and audience. Children will be encouraged to take part.
Among the choreographer-performers are Rachel Berman, a former principal dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company; Deborah Damast, a master's degree candidate at the Tisch School of the Arts of New York University; Ara Fitzgerald, associate director of dance and theater at Manhattanville College; and Leslie Farlow, dance-theater faculty member at Trinity College in Hartford.
Reservations are suggested by calling 251-7855.
 
Penguin Rep Performance
Warren Leight, author of "Sideman," winner of the 1999 Tony Award for Best Play, has a new play called "Glimmer, Glimmer and Shine" at the Penguin Rep in Stony Point, Rockland County, through Dec. 5.
The play, initially presented as "Glimmer Brothers" last summer at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts, has been revised for this engagement. The story, described as funny and poignant, revolves around attempts to reconcile estranged twin brothers and their children.
Mr. Leight wrote and directed "The Night We Never Met," a film starring Matthew Broderick, and several additional screenplays, nightclub acts and plays.
The theater, a converted 1880's hay barn, is on Crickettown Road, accessible from the Palisades Interstate Parkway Exit 15 and Route 9W. Penguin Rep, established in 1977 as a professional theater, has produced more than 100 shows seen by more than 150,000 people. Performances are on Thursday and Friday at 8:30 p.m.; Saturday at 5 and 8:30 p.m., and Sunday at 2:30 p.m. Tickets priced at $22, or $19 for people older than 61 and students younger than 22, can be reserved by calling 786-2873. HEADLINE: Remnants of a War Hidden in the Soil

BYLINE: By DARICE BAILER 

 BODY:
AN archaeology teacher at Joel Barlow High School in Redding is leading a group of students and volunteers on an excavation of Israel Putnam Memorial State Park, work that is proving a hunch he and other historians have had for years: What was believed to be a cemetery for 25 Continental Army soldiers is actually the site of a field officer's quarters during the 1778-79 army encampment in Connecticut.
The teacher, Daniel Cruson of Newtown and an anthropology and archaeology teacher at Joel Barlow since 1968, said he has been fascinated with the site since he was a boy and would accompany his father, Dr. Daniel Cruson, on archaeology digs around Connecticut. Dr. Cruson was a dentist in Bridgeport, but on weekends he pursued his passion -- archaeology. The younger Mr. Cruson said he always wanted to dig around the two parallel rows of crumbled chimneys of the enlisted men's barracks beside Company Street and the cemetery up on a crag. 
 "I wanted to know what was down there, what was left from the Revolution," Mr. Cruson said.
The park is named after General Israel Putnam, a senior major general of the Continental Army, who, with General Enoch Poor, commanded three New Hampshire regiments and one Canadian unit that camped in Redding. That winter, the Continental Army did not camp together in one place as it did at Valley Forge. Instead, the army was spread throughout the tristate region.
Historians have said that the army camped in Redding because it was a sheltered valley with plenty of water and forest cover, and from there the troops could prevent the British from moving up the Hudson River or invading Connecticut through the shore.
The park is a memorial to the soldiers who suffered through one of the longest and severest winters in Connecticut. Twenty-five men died. Many soldiers didn't have clothing or shoes. There were not enough blankets, and the men sometimes went a few days without food because the heavy snowfall made it impossible to gather supplies from the Danbury supply station.
The "cemetery" was thought to be burial grounds because of the two piles of rock -- possibly burial mounds -- that were found on the hill about 24 feet apart. So, in 1902 the area up on the hill was designated as a cemetery, and granite posts were hammered into the dirt, forming a crude square.
But, even as a boy, Mr. Cruson didn't think the soldiers who died were buried in that square.
"I can't put my finger on it, but it just didn't seem right that they were burying in the encampment," he said. "The site didn't feel right. The land didn't feel right."
For one thing, it was pretty rocky and there wasn't much topsoil. "You don't bury someone when there's no topsoil," Mr. Cruson said.
Last spring, to test his hunch, Mr. Cruson asked permission of the State Department of Environmental Protection to excavate. Now, he is giving his students hands-on archaeological experience in a dig that began in September and is expected to end this Saturday.
"This is really bringing back a bit of the past," said Jeanine Herman, president of the Friends and Neighbors of Putnam Memorial State Park.
David Poirier, the staff archaeologist at the Connecticut Historical Commission, said that Mr. Cruson's excavation is giving his department a better understanding of how to manage park resources.
"We'll be better able to make decisions about what should and should not happen regarding future development," he said. "It allows us to better understand what areas are sensitive and how sensitive they are."
Mr. Cruson wasn't the first to excavate Putnam Park. In 1973-74, Mr. Poirier excavated around some of the chimneys, or firebacks, along Company Street.
Then, in 1990-91, Ricardo J. Elia, a professor at Boston University, did an archaeological survey of the park at the request of the state. Prof. Elia was the first person to publicly say that he thought the cemetery up on the hill was actually the site of an officer's barracks.
"That was what had been running through my mind," Mr. Cruson said, "and that's what gave me the courage to go up there and investigate."
Mr. Cruson, president of the Archaeological Society of Connecticut, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford with a bachelor of arts in economics and a master's in education. His archaeology training comes from apprenticeships with a number of state archaeologists. Last year, Mr. Cruson led students and volunteers on a dig of one of the enlisted men's barracks.
Mr. Cruson believes the soldiers who died passed away at hospitals in Danbury and Norwalk. As for what were thought to be the two burial mounds, Mr. Cruson thinks they're two crumbled chimneys that stood at the ends of the 12- or 14-feet-wide by 24-feet-long quarters. The dormitory was a two-room hut for the officer and an orderly.
An inch or two beneath the topsoil, Mr. Cruson and his rookie archaeologists are discovering what the officer and his orderly ate or did before razing the hut to the ground in the spring of 1779 when the group moved on to fight the British throughout the Hudson valley.
Left behind were a musket ball, a pewter button the size of a dime, a piece of a clay pipe, hand-hewn nails, lead casting drippings from pistol bullets, animal bone from a meal and what he said he thinks are peas.
The archaeological findings belong to the state and will be curated by Nicholas Bellantoni, the state archaeologist.
The peas will be taken to a lab to be analyzed by a botanical expert. The bones will be analyzed as well. They are so small as to be unidentifiable.
Eventually, all artifacts will be displayed in the park museum, near the current display of artifacts Mr. Cruson's group found during the excavation last year. Mr. Cruson's excavation report will be published next year in the Bulletin of the Archaeology Society of Connecticut.
About 50 to 60 percent of his students have participated in the dig.
"A soldier was living here 200 years ago and I get to see what he did and the remnants he left," said Neil Davidson, a senior at Barlow.
Kathleen von Jena of Redding, who is helping Mr. Cruson at the site, found the pewter button. She said the dig was fascinating.
"You get underneath the surface of the earth and you're handling a button that was attached to somebody's coat," Ms. von Jena said. "That kind of human connection across time is what really gets me."
Melissa Borko, a senior at Barlow, said she hopes to pursue a career in anthropology after participating in the dig.
"If someone had said to me three or four years ago, 'Why don't you go into anthropology?' I would have said, 'Why do I want to go into anything like that? It's just digging in dirt,' " she said. "But now I see that it's not just digging in dirt. It's finding out about how people lived and what their lives were like."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Abbey Gardner and Patrick Dolan

 BODY:
Abbey Marks Gardner and Patrick Sean Dolan were married yesterday at the Bath Club in Miami Beach by Judge Ursula Ungaro-Benages of Federal District Court in Miami.
Ms. Gardner, 32, is keeping her name. She is the executive director of the Baltic-American Partnership Fund, a New York-based civic development organization financed by the Agency for International Development and the Open Society Institute of George Soros. She graduated from Amherst College and received a master's degree in Russian area studies from Georgetown University. 
 She is a daughter of Behna Marks Gardner and Dr. Laurence B. Gardner of Miami. Her father is the chairman of medicine at the University of Miami School of Medicine. Her mother is a freelance photographer.
Mr. Dolan, 37, directs business operations for DoubleClick Inc., an Internet advertising company in New York. He graduated from the University of Virgina and received an M.B.A. from Virginia Commonwealth University. He is a son of Dr. Robert Dolan of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Patricia Dolan. His father is a professor of environmental sciences at the University of Virgina.
The couple met in 1995 in New York at an office of the Open Society Institute, for which Ms. Gardner was then the regional director for Russia and Mr. Dolan was the finance director in Budapest for the organization's European operations.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
How a Pair of Plays Gain Longer Lives

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
FOR everybody's good, not to mention the whole world of theater, Doug Hughes and David Saint not only believe that regional theaters should work together, but also are making it happen, once again, with two new works: "Syncopation," by Allan Knee, and "Down the Garden Paths," by Anne Meara.
Mr. Hughes, the artistic director of Long Wharf in New Haven, and Mr. Saint, artistic director of George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., are co-producing, collaborating, pooling resources, dividing expenses, lengthening the life of plays and the employment of actors, and all manner of other good things. 
 "We do our work so often to tear it down," said Mr. Hughes during rehearsals of "Syncopation" at Long Wharf. That often means, he said, "taking stuff to the Dumpster, and I've always been unhappy about that."
There are two pathways to be taken by a regional theater production: to have its run of, say, four to five weeks or to fulfill the wish if not the mission of nonprofit theater, "to go on to an extended commercial afterlife," Mr. Hughes said. He added that he is delighted there is "something in the middle."
That something in the middle -- an alliance between two important regional theaters -- happened recently between Hartford Stage and the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J. ("Cymbeline" staged by Mark Lamos) and between Long Wharf and the McCarter (John Henry Redwood's work, "The Old Settler").
It helps that Mr. Saint and Mr. Hughes -- "old friends for 20 years" -- have had a professional affiliation in tandem and overlappingly. Mr. Saint assisted Mr. Hughes when the latter was associate artistic director at Manhattan Theater Club from 1980 to 1982 and began directing at Seattle Repertory in 1990 when Mr. Hughes was associate artistic director there. Mr. Saint wound up succeeding him when Mr. Hughes went on to the Tyrone Guthrie in Minneapolis as head of the creative department.
First, both Mr. Knee's and Ms. Meara's plays came to Mr. Saint but Mr. Hughes said, "Anne Meara shows all her plays as she's working on them to John Guare, who told me this one was remarkable. And then David showed it to me."
"I was stunned," Mr. Saint said. "It is remarkable," Mr. Hughes added.
Critically speaking, the audience at the second theater is the beneficiary of a more seasoned performance, of a play refined by time.
"We continue to wave the flag for the new American play," Mr. Hughes said. And he cheered "this sort of shared responsibility for producing one and extending its life -- providing the luxury of a longer run -- especially when we have compatible tastes and the flexibility of dovetailing our schedules with crisscrossing productions."
"A co-production gives the play a chance to be worked on in two venues -- both outside New York," Mr. Saint said. "Working in New York is an invitation to excruciating pressure. You're constantly under the gun by theaters that want to make sure the first audience sees a finished product, or else the word will get out there and we're finished. 'Give us a chance to create something here, folks,' you want to say. Here we have that great opportunity."
Obviously, both theaters reap economic advantages. "We can stretch our money across the season," Mr. Hughes said. "This deal allowed Long Wharf to lavish more on cast size in other productions, to make sure the population of our stage doesn't dwindle."
And, Mr. Saint added, "we share costs without compromising artistic merit."
David Chandler and Lorca Simons are in "Syncopation," to be staged by Greg Leaming, Long Wharf's director of artistic programming. The play is set in 1911 when ballroom dancing was all the rage. Such dancing was still popular in the 1950's when Mr. Knee was growing up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and being taken to dance contests at the old Madison Square Garden.
David Chandler plays Henry, who is 42, Jewish and a butcher. For $7 a week, he rents a Lower East Side sixth floor walk-up, where he dreams of dancing. He also dreams of a partner. He places classified advertisements in the Morning Telegraph. After six weeks of waiting, he receives a reply from Anna (Lorca Simons), an Italian-American woman who is 23.
In the two-character play, which is being staged at Long Wharf after a series of readings in New York, dance is a metaphor for partnering and the struggles inherent in all relationships, Mr. Knee said.
It is also the playwright's response to the dullness ("except for dance," he said) of his teenage years. "I didn't fit in, I was not in tune with my environment," said Mr. Knee, who has also written the book for a musical version of "Little Women" and adapted "The Scarlet Letter" for television. "I lived in the past -- of charm, effortlessness and romance."
Even now, Mr. Knee said, "History tells me more about today than today does."
 "Syncopation," Tuesday through Dec. 19. "Down the Garden Paths," Jan. 19 through Feb. 20. Long Wharf Theater, 229 Sargent Drive, New Haven. (203) 787-4282.

HEADLINE: AILING THEATER;
Best of Three Worlds?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Regarding Steven Drukman's panel discussion with nine American playwrights "Prescriptions for a Troubled Patient: The Theater," Oct. 31 : I work in television, motion pictures and the theater, both as a writer and a producer. 
 I am one of those writers who started on Broadway and who was immediately spirited away to Hollywood to become a very well-paid television comedy writer.
 I currently have a television series going on the air, a second in development at a network, a feature film in pre-production and a new musical opening at the Pasadena Playhouse. What does all that mean?
My television series will stand or fall on the availability of stations and time slots, program lead-ins and shows on other channels at the same time.
My movie depends on the availability of stars, director and financing, finding good distribution and strong marketing support.
But my musical is definitely happening. It will play as part of a subscription series and will have the marketing support of the theater.
Despite the perils of the theater, it is only in the theater that the writer enjoys any kind of meaningful creative control. Producers can, of course, coerce the writer by threatening to pull the financial plug. In television, however, whoever pays the bills dictates every aspect of the show, including the cast, your script and who rewrites your script.
The theater is hard, mainly because you don't get your money up front; you make money only if the show does. Obviously, it's more attractive to get paid a ton of money whether or not your show is a hit.
The theater must deal with the harsh economic realities -- just like the rest of us. Producers need to select the right properties, budget them in a practical way, and go out and compete for the audience's attention and time.
As for being a playwright, I remind myself: nobody asked you to be a writer. Society does not owe it to you. You only owe it to yourself.
 
ERNEST CHAMBERS
Los Angeles

HEADLINE: Private Sector;
Seeing the Corporation's Demise

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
PETER F. DRUCKER, revered as the father of modern management, has a new message for corporate executives: Find another line of work.
"The unique 20th-century creation, the corporation, is not going to survive in the 21st century," he said, almost nonchalantly, in an interview. 
 Big companies, he said, don't seem to be able to thrive for more than 30 years, not even those like General Motors and Sears, Roebuck that have received advice from management gurus like himself. But another reason is seemingly contradictory: management skills have advanced so far that business has lost some of its challenge.
"In business, you are becoming bored, because we know so much," he said. "When I came in, nobody knew the routine and that made it exciting."
Few people in business today can remember when Dr. Drucker appeared as a management visionary in the 1940's. Dr. Drucker turns 90 this Friday, and that is prompting celebrations and reflections on his life and work.
Last Sunday, 400 people, many from nonprofit organizations he has advised, held a birthday party at the Getty Center here. On Friday, Dr. Drucker, a native of Austria, received that country's Cross of Honor for Science and Art. And at least two books have appeared in the last few years assessing his life and work.
Dr. Drucker wears hearing aids in both ears and walks with the help of a cane. But his mind seems as fertile and his pen as fluid as ever. He teaches a course for midcareer executives at the Claremont Graduate School, east of Los Angeles, where he has been based since 1971. He spouts facts, figures and historical tidbits from memory. The author of 31 books, he has recently written major articles for magazines like The Atlantic Monthly and The Economist.
"Writing is a compulsive neurosis," he said.
Dr. Drucker made his mark by viewing management as a subject in its own right, rather than as a collection of specific skills like finance and accounting. "He was the first person to formulate management as a professional discipline," said D. Quinn Mills, a professor at Harvard Business School.
Dr. Drucker recognized early on that a key to corporate success was to motivate employees. He also stressed marketing and innovation over finance.
His books, a mix of pungent generalizations and historical trivia, have been criticized as lacking academic rigor. Some business leaders consider his ideas dated. But his fans have included John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric and Andrew S. Grove of Intel. He also has a huge following among industrialists who rebuilt Japan after World War II.
"We owe him very, very much," said Masatoshi Ito, the founder of Ito-Yokado -- a large Japanese retailer that controls the 7-Eleven chain -- who came to the birthday party at the Getty Center and helped organize one in Tokyo.
Dr. Drucker does not like to be typecast as a management guru. He has written nearly as many books about economics, society and politics as about management. He has even penned two novels. He is an expert on Japanese art and once taught a course in it. Early in his career, he worked as a banker and a journalist.
Born and raised in Vienna, Dr. Drucker received his doctorate in international law from Frankfurt University before he was 22 and then remained in Germany. In 1933, after one of his essays was banned and burned by the the Nazi government, Dr. Drucker moved to London and then, in 1937, to the United States.
In 1944, after publishing a book about business and society, he received an invitation from General Motors to study its inner workings. That led to his first management book, "The Concept of the Corporation," in 1946.
He now does his consulting and writing at home, in the modest house in Claremont where he has lived for 29 years. He reads voraciously, both fiction and history, and does much of his writing on legal pads or a typewriter rather than on a computer, which he says makes him write too fast. Doris Drucker, his wife of 62 years, is a writer and physicist who has designed and manufactured a device to aid in speech therapy. The couple have four children and six grandchildren.
As for his view on the demise of corporations, Dr. Drucker says people will still work for a living but will not cast their lives with a single company. What Dr. Drucker calls the knowledge workers of today will save their best efforts for nonprofit social service organizations, where they can make a bigger difference. "The 20th century was the century of business," he said. "The next century is going to be the century of the social sector."
Dr. Drucker, spending an increasing portion of his time with such service groups, is the honorary chairman of the New York-based Peter F. Drucker Foundation for Nonprofit Management, founded by leaders of other nonprofit organizations that he advised.
Although he is fascinated by the Internet, Dr. Drucker says his choice for the growth industry of the next 30 years is not e-commerce. "It's going to be fish farming," he said, explaining that on the oceans, "we are still hunters and gatherers."
Claremont, which named its business school after Dr. Drucker, is now establishing his archives under the direction of Nan Stone, a former editor of Harvard Business Review. The archives will be largely available online, so Dr. Drucker's insights will be available to corporate managers well into the next century, even if the corporations themselves don't survive.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Young Professionals Group Wants Not Just Jobs, but Room at the Top

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Thomas Lopez-Pierre sounds a bit like a neophyte matchmaker when he describes his group: everyone involved, he says, is younger than 39 and earns more than $50,000 a year.
But Mr. Lopez-Pierre, 31, doesn't run a singles agency. He is the chairman of the Upper Manhattan Emerging Leadership Round-Table, a group of black and Hispanic professionals who want to promote minority entrepreneurs in Harlem, East Harlem and Washington Heights. 
 On Tuesday night, Mr. Lopez-Pierre had a dinner for about 40 at the Sugar Shack, a homey restaurant on Frederick Douglass Boulevard at 139th Street.
The group's bankers, real estate executives, brokers and public servants have been holding meet-and-greets like this one for about two years. But Mr. Lopez-Pierre said he wanted the group to meet more frequently to prepare for an ambitious campaign it hoped to begin early next year. It is not likely to win universal approbation: the Round-Table wants to encourage all large corporations doing business in Upper Manhattan to have a business partner who is either black or Hispanic.
Mr. Lopez-Pierre said too many fast-food chains and other corporations have opened franchises in the neighborhood and hired managers who did not represent the area's ethnic makeup.
"I don't feel that in a neighborhood that is mostly black and Hispanic, businesses and real estate should be owned by people of other races," he said. "Arabs and Indians are not from Harlem."
Terry C. Lane, president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which has helped many corporations set up shop above 96th Street, said that supporting local job creation and local ownership is vital to economic development.
But, he added: "I don't see race as a formula. What does it really mean? What I see is you want local participation and good corporate citizenship, and if you partner with people in the community it makes better business sense. But that has nothing to do with race."
Mr. Lopez-Pierre recently entered a joint venture with Arthur Treacher's, the seafood restaurant chain, to open a minimum of eight franchises north of 96th Street. With the deal, Mr. Lopez-Pierre becomes the kind of minority entrepreneur who his Round-Table hopes will multiply.
Thomas K. Hoffman, chief operating officer for Arthur Treacher's of Jacksonville, Fla., said the restaurants, which will each contain a Nathan's Famous, should open in a few months.
"When corporations want to appease a community, they give the neighborhood some jobs or come up here for a photo op," Mr. Lopez-Pierre said. "We're not interested in that. We just want access to ownership." NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Hefty History at Reasonable Prices

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
THE autumn has brought a wonderfully rich harvest of affordable and accessible paperback books for fans of business history, a genre whose volumes usually cost a bundle and weigh a ton.
To be sure, one of the new paperbacks -- "Titan: The Life of John D. Rockefeller Sr.," by Ron Chernow (Vintage Books, $16) -- is still pretty hefty, even without a hard cover. But it is a rich and enlightening tale, especially with the future of Microsoft in the air. And its length only looks daunting: the story of Rockefeller, the man who built the Standard Oil monopoly, races along with all the ease and grace of a well-constructed novel. 
 Graceful storytelling is also abundantly on display in two additions to the splendid Wiley Investment Classics series from John Wiley & Sons -- "Once in Golconda: A True Drama of Wall Street 1920-1938" ($19.95) and "The Go-Go Years: The Drama and Crashing Finale of Wall Street's Bullish 60's" ($19.95). Both are by John Brooks, a financial journalist and novelist who produced a small shelf of delightful books before a stroke brought on his death in 1993 at the age of 72.
"Once in Golconda" opens with an explanation of its title: "Golconda, now a ruin, was a city in southeastern India where, according to legend, everyone who passed through got rich. A similar legend attached to Wall Street between the wars." Of course, a similar legend has attached to Wall Street today, an excellent reason to absorb the gently told lessons drawn from the frenzied prelude and agonized aftermath of the 1929 crash.
The book opens on Sept. 16, 1920, when a bomb exploded in front of the Manhattan offices of J. P. Morgan & Company, then ground zero in the nation's financial landscape. The story closes in 1938 with Richard Whitney, once the unassailable president of the New York Stock Exchange, installed in a prison cell. It is a remarkable span of time, well worth recalling amid today's stock market party.
In "The Go-Go Years," Mr. Brooks sketches the psychedelic 1960's on Wall Street. Colorful crooks, celebrity fund managers, corrupt stock exchange officials and audacious corporate raiders added to the surreal atmosphere as stock promoters extolled an atomic-fueled future while back-office clerks labored in Dickensian conditions against a rising tide of unprocessed paperwork.
Mr. Brooks, with shrewd foresight, notices by the end of his tale that technology is wiping out the traditions of the Street. "Already in the early 1970's," he writes, "a significant proportion of stock trading is being conducted not face-to-face on a floor under a skylight but between men sitting in front of closed-circuit television screens in offices hundreds or thousands of miles apart." We must forgive him for failing to see that those television screens, soon to be replaced by computer monitors, were simply the latest manifestation of the stock ticker that had transformed trading nearly a century before.
IT was 1867 when E. A. Callahan harnessed the new technology of the telegraph to produce the first stock ticker. Improvements to Callahan's model by Thomas Edison yielded the financial windfall that paid for the workshop where he invented the phonograph and the electric light bulb.
That is just one of the nuggets tucked between the slim covers of "The Victorian Internet: The Remarkable Story of the Telegraph and the 19th Century's Online Pioneers," by Tom Standage, a science writer at The Economist in London. Now available in paperback from the Berkley Publishing Group ($12), "The Victorian Internet" puts a cool hand on the feverish face of the Internet.
Mr. Standage writes: "In the 19th century there were no televisions, airplanes, computers, or spacecraft; nor were there antibiotics, credit cards, microwave ovens, compact discs or mobile phones. There was, however, an Internet."
The telegraph, he writes, "revolutionized business practice, gave rise to new forms of crime and inundated its users with a deluge of information."
"Romances blossomed over the wires," he adds. "Secret codes were devised by some users and cracked by others. The benefits of the network were relentlessly hyped by its advocates and dismissed by the skeptics. Governments and regulators tried and failed to control the new medium. Attitudes toward everything from news gathering to diplomacy had to be completely rethought. Meanwhile, out on the wires, a technological subculture with its own customs and vocabulary was establishing itself."
Mr. Standage asks: "Does all this sound familiar?"
ONE emerges from this delightful book both humbled and heartened. The Victorians traveled, in a few short years, from a world in which it took 10 weeks to communicate between London and Bombay to a world in which it took 10 minutes. By comparison, the adjustments that the Internet requires of us -- a generation born with a telephone in our hands, with children who can scarcely remember the purpose of a postage stamp -- seem almost comically trivial.
On the other hand, all the grim predictions about the telegraph's catastrophic effects did not come to pass, and perhaps the same will be true this time as well. In any case, "The Victorian Internet" provides a much-needed perspective on how new technologies shape human society.

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS;
Sights Unseen From a Bus Top: Marilyn's Grate And Gay Harlem

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
"I DON'T give tours," said the man in the blue Giants cap and sunglasses. "I live 'em."
With that, Marvin Gelfand folded his white cane and pulled a cigarette from a worn metal case on Thursday morning. Grasping a friend's elbow, he continued down Broadway on his free-association tour of the Bloomingdale district, the area of Broadway around 96th Street. 
 Dressed in tennis shoes, slacks and a blue windbreaker, Mr. Gelfand, who is legally blind, bears little resemblance to the traditional tour guide who points out the postcard city from atop a double-decker bus. Instead of rattling off a litany of facts, Mr. Gelfand conducts "walking essays on the unpredictable human concourse of the city."
His tour subjects are out of the ordinary, too. They range from simple themes like Jewish Harlem, to daylong tours about crime in New York, to private tours on the city's economy given in the back of foreign bankers' limousines.
About 34 million people visit New York City each year. And 1,426 licensed tour guides -- and many more unlicensed ones -- can tell them that the Bronx is up, the Battery's down, and the diner from "Seinfeld" is somewhere in between. (O.K., it's Tom's Diner, at Broadway and 112th Street.) Many tour companies are expanding their mainstream offerings. But more and more offbeat tours, like Mr. Gelfand's, are springing up, too.
If the glimmer of Midtown Manhattan does not grab some visitors, for example, maybe the Wildman will. Steve Brill earned that nickname for his tours finding and cooking edible plants that grow wild in city parks. He leads groups of gatherers wielding clippers and shovels into the underbrush, foraging for vegetables, herbs, mushrooms and berries.
November is harvest time for wild greens like dandelions and chickweed, said Mr. Brill, who is now leading tours in Queens. There, mountain watercress grows in Kissena Park, wintercress in Alley Pond Park and oyster mushrooms on street trees in Kew Gardens.
Mr. Brill leads searches for medicinal herbs and roots, whether it is St. John's wort in Alley Pond Park or gingko nuts near the Central Park Reservoir. But the Wildman strongly recommends identifying any flora before eating.
"You shouldn't eat anything without trying it on the in-laws," he suggests. The edible wild carrots in Kissena Park, for example, resemble a poisonous hemlock growing along the Saw Mill River Parkway.
Michael Henry Adams is a wild life expert of another sort. Mr. Adams, a Harlem historian, runs offbeat tours uptown, including the Hi-Dee-Ho Harlem nightlife tour. It includes dinner and swing dancing at Wells Restaurant on Seventh Avenue near 135th Street, as well as late-night jam sessions at St. Nick's Pub on St. Nicholas Avenue near 149th Street. Diehards can eat a chicken and waffles breakfast at the historic M&G Diner at 125th Street and Morningside Drive.
In another tour, Mr. Adams visits haunts of famous gay Harlem residents, including Langston Hughes and James Baldwin. They stop at a legendary male brothel and then hit the dance floor at after-hours clubs.
Peter Salwen, a Mark Twain scholar, gives annual tours on Mark Twain's birthday. He peppers them with Twain quotations and visits sites in SoHo and Greenwich Village where Twain lived and socialized.
Mr. Salwen shows how Twain used his New York connections to rise from a promising reporter to a national literary figure. The oldest surviving scrap of his actual writing is a note he wrote to his parents while he was visiting New York as a teenager: "I've taken a liking to this abominable place," he confessed. (This year's Twain tour is on Saturday, the 164th anniversary of the author's birth. Call 212-242-5546. Most tour operators are listed in the phone book under their name or their company's.)
Some tour guides cut quite a figure. Arthur Marks is a show-tune aficionado who says he never quite made it on the stage, so he became a flamboyant tour guide who dresses in dapper suits and sings and dances his way through presentations.
"I still get to perform and get paid for it," said Mr. Marks, who takes groups to the Silk Stocking district on the Upper East Side and belts out "Money Makes the World Go Round" on an expensive stretch of Park Avenue.
"I'm more of a personality than a tour operator," said Mr. Marks, who offers 26 tours of Greenwich Village and tours for every major Manhattan neighborhood except Chinatown. "It's too touristy," he said.
Passers-by are also likely to notice Stan O'Connor, another tour guide. He dresses as Abraham Lincoln and conducts his tours of Manhattan from a 19th-century perspective.
"I've been stopped by many people who say, 'Thank you for freeing my relatives,' " Mr. O'Connor said.
Some offbeat tours focus on entertainment. NYC Discovery Tours gives one tour about the Beatles in New York and another about Marilyn Monroe -- including a visit to that naughty subway grating.
There's more. Century Walking Tours gives a tour on Ayn Rand's New York. Joyce Gold gives walking tours of macabre Greenwich Village and gangland Hell's Kitchen, and twice a year sails to New York on the Queen Elizabeth 2 to give slide shows to "prepare" visitors for New York. Philip Schoenberg, an eccentric guide from New York Talks and Walks, shows the sites of landmark New York legal cases. The tour's name is Let's Kiss All the Lawyers.
Howard Goldberg, who runs a tour group called Adventure on a Shoestring, has a special architectural focus. He takes groups to visit city bridges on the anniversary of their opening. "We sing 'Happy Birthday' to them," he said "Bridges have feelings too."
Bruce Kayton, yet another offbeat-tour operator, gives 15 different tours of famous Manhattan sites of radicalism, like the Harlem funeral home where Malcolm X lay after his assassination in 1965.
Mr. Kayton also points out Abbie Hoffman's favorite place for egg creams: the Gem Spa soda fountain, still on the corner of St. Marks Place and Second Avenue.
On New Year's Eve in 1967, Mr. Hoffman created the radical political party known as the Yippies at his apartment at 30 St. Marks Place. According to Mr. Kayton, he bragged for $101 a month in rent, he had "a front-row seat to the counterculture."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Gordon Grender;
GAMerica Capital Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
AS a fund manager, Gordon Grender doesn't seem to mind doing things that might be regarded as a little odd. For example, he runs a United States stock fund, the $58.5 million GAMerica Capital fund, from an office overlooking Westminster Cathedral in London.
The geography gives him an edge, he said. "I can read The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times on the Web and check Bloomberg before anybody in New York gets up," he said in an English accent. 
 Mr. Grender, who has been managing American money from across the Atlantic since 1974, has built an enviable record. GAMerica Capital returned 27.2 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Nov. 5, compared with 10.1 percent for its peer group of small blend funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher, and 33.8 percent for the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks.
Mr. Grender, 55, searches the markets for value among American companies of all sizes, although the fund is now heavily weighted in small-capitalization stocks -- the category where he is finding the best bargains. He looks for businesses with annual earnings growth of 15 percent or more and is adamant about not overpaying; he aims to pay less than the market's price-to-earnings multiple, currently 31. "I can't bring myself to buy glamour stocks with capitalizations in the billions but revenues in the millions," he said.
Still, if a stock performs strongly "I tend to run with it," he said, holding on as it rises in price. The turnover rate for his fund, which holds just 40 to 50 stocks, averages 29 percent, versus 96 percent for a typical fund. But its class A shares carry a 5 percent front-end load and an expense ratio of 2.46 percent, versus 1.49 percent for its average peer.
Mr. Grender reads many American business publications and gathers valuable information on the road, he said, attending investment conferences and visiting companies. He tours the United States at least four times a year; each trip lasts at least two weeks.
Unlike many other managers, he ignores quarterly earnings forecasts, which he calls a "futile exercise."
"Analysts tend to report what management tells them," he said. "They don't do their own independent work."
In looking at a company, Mr. Grender wants to see sales growth of at least 5 percent a year above inflation, and relatively substantial free cash flow, although the amount depends on the type of business.
He is particularly drawn to companies with very depressed stock prices -- those that are down 25 percent to 50 percent from their most recent highs. Here, he shows his contrarian streak: "I don't worry about companies whose share prices take big falls when they report disappointing earnings if I think the fundamental story is sound."
Another plus, he said, is inside ownership. "I want top management to own shares in the company, not just stock options," he said.
He is not afraid to carry cash -- the fund's cash position grew to 50 percent by October, as new money flowed in. In the last few weeks, he has reduced it to about 40 percent. "I've been nervous about the level of the stock market," he said. "But I've been buying lately because so many stocks have been taking such big falls."
MR. GRENDER owns stock in Power-One, a company in Camarilla, Calif., that makes power supply equipment for commercial electronic devices like CAT scanners. He bought more shares after a conference call in October in which company management expressed caution about meeting fourth-quarter earnings estimates, driving down the price from over $30 a share to $15. He paid $20. The company, he said, is "a lower-risk way to play the growth in electronics."
The fund initially bought Power-One stock in October 1998 at $6 a share. Earnings have grown about 25 percent a year since the company went public in 1997, helped by acquisitions. Insiders own about 15 percent of the shares, which closed on Friday at $19.625, or 29.5 times consensus earnings estimates of 66.5 cents a share for 1999.
Another choice is Policy Management Systems of Blythewood, S.C., which makes software used by insurers. Mr. Grender bought shares in October for $21, down from $55 in February, after the company said it would miss its third-quarter earnings forecasts because of delays caused by Year 2000 computer issues and other problems. "But because customers tend to rely on them heavily," Mr. Grender said, "the fact that their earnings are poor and their stock price is down doesn't mean that their business will go away."
He estimates three-year earnings growth of 15 to 20 percent a year, on average. And he thinks sales should grow above 10 percent a year over that time. Management owns just under 1 percent of shares, but that is enough for Mr. Grender because of the company's large market capitalization. The stock now trades at $20.875, or 13.9 times 1999 consensus earnings estimates of $1.51 a share.
In September, he paid $47 a share for Sprint, shortly before the company announced its merger deal with MCI WorldCom. The stock price had fallen to the mid-$40's, from $55 in June, because of worries about increased competition from other long-distance carriers. He jumped in, he said, "because I thought the company was a likely acquisition target as the industry consolidated." Moreover, he said, it was "reasonably priced" relative to other companies in the industry.
Mr. Grender is bullish on the merger, and thinks the combined company will grow 30 percent a year, on average, over three years.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Baby Steps Toward Accord On Social Security

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE country learned one main lesson this year from the inability of President Clinton and Congress to make headway in dealing with the long-term financial shortfall in Social Security: that making even modest changes to the retirement system requires far more political trust than is present in Washington today.
Despite solemn promises from the White House and from Democrats and Republicans in Congress not to use Social Security as a club to batter the opposition, each side whacked away with abandon, contending that it alone could be trusted to save retirees from financial ruin. 
 Lost in the partisan spectacle, however, were some promising developments and even some enlightened debate on various issues.
 
DEBT REDUCTION -- About the only big fiscal agreement between the two parties was that the bulk of the projected federal budget surplus -- the $2 trillion in excess revenue that Social Security will generate over the next decade -- should go toward reducing the $3.6 trillion in national debt held by the public.
The agreement was largely a result of a well-founded fear that using the Social Security surplus for anything else, like tax cuts or government spending, would be painted as a wholesale betrayal of Social Security.
That the outcome had beneficial economic effects, like lower interest rates, was a happy byproduct of gridlock, not the goal.
Still, using Social Security revenues to reduce the debt does nothing to address the underlying long-term shortfall in the retirement system's finances.
 
STOCK INVESTMENTS -- The most divisive issue was whether individuals should have the right and the responsibility to invest a portion of their tax dollars in private accounts. Nearly all Republicans and a few influential Democrats said yes. The vast majority of Democrats said no.
But that divide obscured a somewhat remarkable agreement among almost all voices in the debate. From the most liberal to the most conservative, they concluded that the power of the stock market to generate substantial returns over the long run should be used to help close the gap between the benefits that Social Security has promised to today's workers and the system's ability to pay them.
Mr. Clinton and Democrats in Congress said the Social Security system itself, not individuals, should do the investing, so that everyone would benefit or bear the risks equally. Advocates of private accounts said individuals should have more control over their financial futures, and that collective investment would result in de facto government ownership of private industry.
One way or another, Wall Street seems destined to play a role in dealing with the problem.
 
THE TRUST FUND -- Since its establishment during the New Deal, Social Security has worked in the same way: Today's workers pay a levy on their earnings; the revenue goes toward paying current retirees. Any excess -- payroll tax revenue beyond what is immediately needed to pay benefits -- is theoretically parked in a trust fund that can be used down the road to pay benefits when needed.
Only in the last year has it become clear to people other than policy types and actuaries that the trust fund is basically an accounting fiction. Excess Social Security revenue is not tucked away in the sense that the phrase "trust fund" suggests. Because of the way the government keeps its books, that excess can be used in only three ways: for general government spending, as was done each year until 1998; for a tax cut; or to reduce the national debt, as is being done now.
No matter how the excess is used, the government still deposits an i.o.u. in that amount with the Social Security system. The i.o.u. is nothing more than a promise to pay back the money, almost certainly out of general tax receipts or through increased government borrowing. The i.o.u.'s are not real assets like stocks or bonds, and they do not even represent cash, since the government cannot deposit cash with itself as if it were a bank.
The trust fund now contains i.o.u.'s totaling $865 billion. The amount is projected to peak at $4.5 trillion in 2022, when the system will have to begin redeeming them to pay benefits to retiring baby boomers.
In other words, if benefits are to be maintained after 2022, the government will either have to dip into general revenue or borrow from the public to make good on the $4.5 trillion. And even so, after the i.o.u.'s run out sometime around 2034, Social Security will be able to pay only 75 percent of promised benefits unless changes are made.
 
GENERATIONAL EQUITY -- Finally, there was a dawning recognition that solving Social Security's problems would require tradeoffs between the needs of today's workers -- overwhelmingly the baby boomers, who are at a peak of political and economic influence -- and later generations.
If the boomers cannot rally themselves to find a consensus and make sacrifices and compromises now, the bill will be dumped into the laps of their children and grandchildren.
And who is to say that they'll be in any mood to pay it?

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Construction Stocks Poised for Resurgence

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER 

 BODY:
WALL STREET is never wrong, according to the common wisdom, just early in making its investment recommendations. Analysts were wildly ahead of themselves in 1998, when Congress passed a giant transportation spending bill; many decided to recommend the shares of engineering and heavy-construction companies.
Now, with shares down 38 percent, on average, from their 1998 peaks, it may just be time to take the analysts up on their picks. 
 The bill, the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century, earmarked $217 billion for federal spending on highways, a 44 percent increase over the bill it replaced. In the first quarter of 1998, the Standard & Poor's SuperCap Engineering and Construction Index rose 21 percent, partly in anticipation of the bill's signing.
"People ran it up because they saw huge amounts of funding," said Charles D. Brady, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, referring to the construction sector.
But the government's future largess would be overshadowed by more immediate concerns. Shares of construction and engineering stocks eased as petrochemical-related projects were canceled because of declining oil prices. The stocks' retreat became a rout amid fears of a global recession.
As appropriations failed to materialize, disappointing earnings reports hurt the industry further. "Over the past year, just about every one of these companies has blown up," Mr. Brady said.
More recently, two construction companies have failed to meet third-quarter earnings forecasts, leading to selloffs. On Nov. 3, Granite Construction of Watsonville, Calif., reported profits of 77 cents a share, versus analysts' estimates of 83 cents as reported by First Call/ Thomson Financial. The stock fell 6 percent over two days, and is now at $20.375.
On Oct. 27, Stone & Webster of Boston announced that it was in violation of its credit agreements and posted a loss of 52 cents a share instead of the profit of 65 cents a share that analysts had expected. The stock fell 40 percent in a day; it is now at $15.625.
But 18 months after the transportation legislation was passed, money is beginning to trickle into the coffers of construction and engineering concerns. Between $25 billion and $28 billion of government funds are guaranteed next year, so analysts say the stocks should begin to recover.
Aside from Granite Construction, which despite its weaker-than-expected quarterly results said it would meet 1999 earnings estimates, analysts' favorites include Jacobs Engineering Group of Pasadena, Calif.; Morrison Knudsen of Boise, Idaho; and the URS Corporation of San Francisco, an engineering company. All are trading sharply below their 52-week highs, most near their 52-week lows.
"The first quarter of next year is when you're going to see the benefit in a major way," said David N. Allen, director of research for the Granite Financial Group, a San Diego brokerage firm not affiliated with Granite Construction. Mr. Allen has buys on Granite, Morrison Knudsen and URS.
Already, about a quarter of the $2 billion order backlog at URS is related to the transportation law. URS is now at $21.5625, 27 percent below its 52-week high. Mr. Allen, who rates URS a buy, has a 52-week price target of $26. He also has a buy on Granite, with a target of $25.
The stocks are trading for under 12 times analysts' consensus estimates for this year's earnings. One of Mr. Brady's picks is Jacobs, now trading at $32.50; his 52-week price target is $45. (Mr. Brady also likes Morrison Knudsen, trading at $8.9375, on which he has a 12-month price target of $14.)
Mark Dyer, an analyst at Strong Capital Management, says the industry is attractive at current prices. The Strong Common Stock fund recently increased its position in Jacobs, bringing it up to 1.2 percent of the fund's assets. Separate accounts managed by Richard T. Weiss, manager of the fund, hold a 1.2 percent stake in Morrison Knudsen.

HEADLINE: After the Fire

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
FOR most of her 20 years at the Manhasset, an ornate century-old building at Broadway and 109th Street, Hilary Schlessiger worked at home, writing children's books in the study of her spacious two-bedroom apartment. When her work lagged or her thoughts grew stale, the lanky, wiry-haired writer would reinspire herself by strolling the hallways and listening.
"I'd hear musicians practicing the piano," Mrs. Schlessiger said. "I'd hear opera singing, voice lessons. Before computers, I'd hear typewriters clacking: the energy of freelancers." 
 Six-year-old Sadie Bergen, the towheaded daughter of Andrew and Cynthia Bergen, had playmates upstairs and a best friend down the hall.
"We'd open the door," her father said, "and from 3 on, the girls would be running back and forth. We would have dinner with neighbors and their kids spontaneously. There was a nice feeling, a home larger than a home."
But a few moments of absent-mindedness all but destroyed this world.
As a result of an accidental fire in a ground-floor restaurant, all 300 residents of the 73 apartments at the landmark building at 300 West 109th Street were driven from their homes by a fire on March 11. They have already been displaced for eight months, and it will be at least six more before anyone can return. Meanwhile, residents are in temporary housing; adequate at best, oppressive at worst. Some have been wandering from place to place every few weeks. A few have given up and left the city for good. Many endured heavy financial losses; a few face bankruptcy. Some suffer from nightmares and insomnia.
In some ways it is easier to handle the initial drama of a disaster. But, as with the diagnosis of a life-threatening illness, the most exhausting and demoralizing part comes much later, in the months after the television cameras have departed. And in the case of the Manhasset, the impact was especially devastating because the building's community was so diverse and yet so cohesive.
The fire started in Fiesta Mexicana shortly after lunchtime. A chef accidentally left a pan on a burner, and in less than 20 minutes, flames from an out-of-control blaze leaped up the greasy ducts to the building's 11th floor, setting fire to the roof.
Word spread almost as rapidly as the flames, and residents converged from workplaces around the city. For hours they waited in the drizzle, desperately hoping the destruction would be less severe than it looked.
Instead, it was worse. After reaching the roof, the blaze flashed down the exterior on scaffolding from a just-completed renovation, exploded through windows and incinerated dozens of apartments. In some spots, the ash was two feet deep. The destruction was uneven, sparing some apartments and cremating others, reducing belongings to heaps of char and melted plastic. Everybody was displaced, on the street, with nothing but the clothes they had on and whatever they had in their pockets and purses.
After a few days of dramatic reports, the disaster disappeared from the evening news, just as the victims began to grasp the extent of their troubles. It was months before the amount of damage became clear. At first, residents thought they would be able to return to their apartments within weeks. Later, they realized they had to find temporary housing through the summer and perhaps even into the fall.
But almost certainly, none imagined they would still be homeless eight months later, still waiting to return.
In addition to personal losses, residents are mourning the loss of the rare, uninsurable treasure they shared: a closely knit community as economically and professionally varied as the Upper West Side itself. Living side by side were high-income co-op owners who bought their spacious, high-ceilinged apartments at market rates of $200,000 to $350,000, and 40-year tenants in equally large regulated apartments paying as little as $400 a month. There were also transient subletters, people with market-rate leases, and former renters who had bought their apartments years earlier for a fraction of their worth.
The population included professional musicians, artists and investment bankers; graduate students, caterers, lawyers and nurses; retirees, stay-at-home parents, a man who makes handmade violins, and a curator and a security guard, both of whom work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It was a sociable place, one in which residents passing through the dim, roomy lobby exchanged greetings that occasionally mushroomed into long conversations. Retirees and younger couples with children mixed easily, and both groups looked out for the elderly and the disabled.
"I had conversations with one person -- he just seemed like a little old guy -- about bird-watching," said Debrah Gilbert, a labor organizer. "It turned out he knew the Latin names for birds and knew a lot about anthropology. He told me about the Alan Lomax tapes of the blues in the South."
Ms. Schlessiger's husband, Charles, a literary agent, added: "There was an amazing feeling that went through that building. There was a feeling of kinship."
 
The Crisis Is Over; Now Comes the Hard Part
Fires have been decreasing steadily in New York City for more than a decade. In the last four years, the number was down by one-third, and the number of fire-related fatalities is the lowest in 50 years. But that is scant comfort to the victims of the 61,400 fires last year, most of which occurred in poor neighborhoods and relatively few of which were serious enough to displace people from their homes. What makes the Manhasset fire unusual is the large and diverse number of people affected and the extensiveness of the damage, leading to an exceptionally long time of displacement.
Ellen Stoller, president of the co-op board, said residents would start trickling back in the spring, and that everybody should be back by July if there are no delays with construction or insurance. A rough estimate of the restoration cost is $30 million, Ms. Stoller said. Though the building had adequate insurance, the relationship with Liberty Mutual, the insurer, has been rocky. The company declined to comment on the situation.
For the victims, the costs are considerably higher, measurable in emotional suffering as well as material and financial losses. Most of the residents of the 39 rental units and even some of the 34 co-op owners were uninsured, and many co-op owners were underinsured, Ms. Stoller said. The blizzard of paperwork that began within hours of the blaze continues unabated, not only insurance claims and loan applications to cover alternate housing, but also numerous lawsuits by nearly everyone involved against nearly every imaginable party.
There has been the enormous inconvenience of trudging from one temporary roof to another. Most people moved several times before finding a spot, and some are still changing addresses every few weeks.
"My suitcase lid is always open," said a pianist who has stayed with eight friends and who is constantly searching for a piano to practice on. "My question is not, where am I going to sleep? It's, where am I going to practice?"
The weeks right after the fire were chaotic. Like war refugees, residents were preoccupied with finding shelter and clothes. Though there were no fatalities or serious injuries, largely because most people were not home when the fire started, many were traumatized.
Ms. Gilbert organized a group of residents to help the most vulnerable among them. In the midst of salvaging their own belongings, they took time to move elderly people's boxes to storage and help tenants of rent-regulated apartments fill out government forms required to protect their leases. A resident who works for psychologists arranged for counseling sessions for children who were in the building when the fire started.
 
A Mother Works Overtime To Make Things Seem Normal
With more than adequate income and insurance coverage, Denise Pelligrini and Laddie de Paur could afford a one-year lease on a temporary apartment near the Manhasset, big enough for themselves and their three children, 4, 3 and 18 months.
But the fire has saddled them with chores and robbed them of time with their children, just when they needed extra attention. In the initial weeks, they had to spend hours in their apartment, "that toxic waste dump" as Ms. Pelligrini described it, salvaging and making inventories of their belongings. They are still deluged with insurance paperwork and shopping for replacement items.
Ms. Pelligrini, a business journalist, and Mr. de Paur, who cares for the children, also had to spend time reassuring their children. They took them to the city fire museum and encouraged them to talk about what had happened. But the effects of the disaster showed in unexpected ways. When the family moved from one hotel room to another while vacationing in Maine, Dashielle, 4, asked, "Was there a fire in the other room?"
"It has been very tense," Ms. Pelligrini said. "Laddie and I are mean to each other. Lately, Laddie is awake until 2 or 3 in the morning. With the kids, we have had to work really hard to make things seem at all normal."
 
'What's Taking So Long?' Homeless at Age 105
Louise Stern, 105, was probably the Manhasset's best-known resident. For 50 years, she lived in a two-bedroom rent-controlled apartment crammed with fading photos of her parents, her sister and her brother. Frail but gracious, she apologized to the firefighters for not offering them tea before letting them carry her to safety on a stretcher.
Every day, Mrs. Stern's caretaker, Rose Moody, pushed her in her wheelchair across the lobby and out to the sidewalk, to a bagel shop on 107th Street and to a park to watch the children. Mothers encountering her in the lobby lifted up their youngsters for her to see. The bagel shop employees fussed over the tiny white-haired figure covered in a blanket, her alert eyes peering out of in her deeply lined face.
Mrs. Stern, whose only income is Social Security and a small pension, was relocated to a low-rent hotel on 77th Street and Broadway. She has been there ever since, at the city's expense. Her room is tiny and dingy. She and Mrs. Moody sleep side by side on single beds, with only a few feet between them. There is a bureau, a closet, side tables and a bathroom, but no kitchen. Mrs. Moody boils eggs and heats soup on a hot plate, and makes peanut-butter-and-jelly sandwiches.
"I hate to see her spending her last few years in that situation," Mrs. Stiller said. "It breaks my heart." Not that Mrs. Stern is complaining. That is not her way. But she is noticeably frailer, and has lost interest in reading or watching television. Instead, she sleeps much more than she used to. "There is nothing else for her to do," Mrs. Stiller said.
"She has no visitors," her friend continued. "I think she feels terribly isolated. The room is so small, she and Rose are on top of each other. She just constantly keeps saying: 'When am I going to get back in my apartment? What's taking them so long to fix it?' "
 
A Family Cast Out From a Haven
After 20 years of seeing tenants come and go, Hilary Schlessiger has a keen sense of the Manhasset's history and evolution.
During the 1930's, she said as she sat by her husband in the one-room apartment that is their temporary home, the Manhasset was filled with Jewish refugees from Europe. After World War II, they were joined by other Jews, Holocaust survivors.
By the mid-70's, nearly all the refugees had died, and the building became popular with writers and musicians, including many opera singers and performers at the New York Philharmonic. Many babies were born. "Every time there was a baby, there was a party," she said. "It was a warm, loving building. It was very familial, gemutlich. A community."
As the children, including the Schlessigers', who were young in the 70's, left for college, they were replaced by another generation of babies and toddlers.
"I knew them when they were born," Mrs. Schlessiger said. "I knew them when they got older. I miss them, I miss them. There's a lot of emotion invested in this building."
The Schlessigers' rent-regulated apartment and possessions were not badly damaged, but they had no insurance. Even after discarding hundreds of their thousands of books, they are paying $320 a month for storage. In the summer they moved every few weeks, from a brother's pied-a-terre to a friend's office and back again. They used a shopping cart to schlep their belongings, a motley assortment they grabbed when they were allowed back in their apartment for 20 minutes: manuscripts, books, a small silver box, underwear, passports.
Finally, they found a studio near Lincoln Center, where they pay twice as much for a fifth of the space. The place is so small that when Mr. Schlessiger reads manuscripts on the couch, his head is only a few feet from the bed and his feet almost touch his wife's desk. It is so snug he once sought privacy by working in the tiny bathroom.
"It's not bad," Mrs. Schlessiger said, "if you don't mind staring at your mate all day long."
"We can't get out of each other's sight," Mr. Schlessiger elaborated. "We're both big people, too big for one room. I'm 6-3."
"We got through the summer riding on adrenaline," his wife chimed in. "But four months later, I was hideously depressed. Adrenaline is very sexy. You can go on that for a few months. But then the sadness came. What happened was incomprehensible. I'm homesick. I want my home."
 
'If I'm Going to Have to Move to Jersey, I Might as Well Move to California.'
"I MISS so much about New York," said Toni Boyd, a former resident of the Manhasset who left the city and moved to Northern California after being displaced by the fire. "We had made a nice life for ourselves. The Indian restaurant one block up: divine. Tacci's, where there's opera Saturday nights. Cleopatra's, for jazz."
Ms. Boyd, 51, who grew up in Marin County, Calif., and moved to New York 20 years ago, was the kind of diehard Manhattanite who thought Queens might as well be Ohio. She could not imagine leaving the borough until the fire forced her to.
 In Manhattan, her job as a nurse-anesthetist at Memorial Sloan-Kettering paid well. Her two adult daughters and her former husband lived nearby. And because of the Manhasset's elevators and wheelchair-accessible public buses, her partner, Kevin Cowlthorpe, who is a paraplegic, could get out of their co-op and around the city independently.
After the fire, Ms. Boyd hunted for weeks for a Manhattan apartment in an elevator building she could afford. Her lack of insurance made the search especially difficult. Mr. Cowlthorpe went to stay with his parents in Oregon.
After three months, Ms. Boyd gave up. During the summer, she and Mr. Cowlthorpe moved to an apartment complex in her hometown, Novato, among whose advantages are that he can get around in his own car.
"I thought, 'If I'm going to have to move to Jersey, I might as well move to California,' " she said. BARBARA STEWART
 
'We'd Move Back in a Second. We're Even Considering It.'
AT the time of the fire at the Manhasset, Michael and Cynthia Simpson were living their dream life.
Mrs. Simpson, a volleyball coach, was six months pregnant. She and her husband, Michael, a management consultant, also had a 2-year-old son, Zachary.
After the evacuation, Mrs. Simpson went to stay with her parents in Salt Lake City while her husband remained at his job in New York and commuted to Utah on weekends.
Despite the exhaustion and expense of long-distance commuting and the low cost and convenience of life in Utah, the Simpsons did not give up the city easily. They loved New York. But largely because they had no insurance, they could not afford to remain. So they moved to a condominium they owned in Park City, Utah., a ski resort.
"We were very happy," said Mr. Simpson, speaking from his new home. "I was happy with my job. Our apartment was absolutely gorgeous. We were within walking distance of a dozen friends. We'd meet friends from church and go down to the Village for dinner."
The Simpsons can list many practical advantages of life in the West. Most things are less expensive. Their parents and siblings live nearby. Instead of frequenting museums, they ski and hike in mountains that are minutes away.
"You have to find a way to try to be happy wherever you are," Mr. Simpson said. "But we'd move back in a second. We're even considering it." BARBARA STEWART
