SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3095 words

HEADLINE: A Grand Idea That Went Badly Awry

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN a way, Ernest Garcia and George Akers are flip sides of the same badly tarnished policy coin, the battle against raging unemployment in the inner cities. Both have operated small businesses and received loans from the Los Angeles Community Development Bank, an unusually ambitious, federally financed effort to bring a measure of prosperity to depressed areas of this city.
Several years ago, after his metal-plating business burned to the ground, Mr. Garcia ran out of capital and hope. He had been rejected by every commercial bank he approached, and finally turned to the Community Development Bank for a $500,000 loan to rebuild in his old neighborhood, East Los Angeles. The bank came through and today his thriving company, West Coast Metal Finishing, has increased its payroll from 7 workers to 42, and hums with the sounds of heavy machinery and a salsa beat. 
 The bank now celebrates his success with words it once reserved for Mr. Akers's company, Trinity Knitworks, a garment maker. Mr. Akers and a partner received the Community Development Bank's very first loan, for $700,000 in 1996, when they sought to save Trinity and its roughly 150 jobs. But Mr. Akers now says acidly that the loan was so badly botched by the bank that he was effectively in default from its first day. The company, overwhelmed by debt, has been shuttered and Mr. Akers is mired in litigation with the bank.
Mr. Garcia says the bank saved his life; Mr. Akers says it just about ruined his. In fact, the bank has produced a mix of such personal tales, despite the confident assertions of backers like Vice President Al Gore, who has endorsed the enterprise during visits here and once proclaimed, "This is an example of how an economic empowerment program should work."
But the harsh reality is that, over all, this grand, $435 million government experiment has had negligible impact on depressed areas of Los Angeles, even during an economic boom, and the bank has been a crushing disappointment to many.
Its loan default rate is a towering 32 percent, largely because of one huge failure, and it has created a tiny fraction of the jobs it promised. The Department of Housing and Urban Development, which financed the bank, says the fault lies at least partly with lax oversight by the city, while the city complains that the federal money came with too many strings.
"The past year at the bank has not been enjoyable," said Peter Taylor, an investment banker at Lehman Brothers and a member of the development bank's board. "It's time to catch our breath and narrow our mission and make the implementation of the idea work properly." Both the city and the federal government want to keep trying.
To salvage the idea, the troubled development bank is being reorganized. It is searching for a new chief executive, adding staff and loosening some operating methods as it struggles to learn from its mistakes and land on the right formula for stimulating growth in areas that have been left further and further behind in the current expansion. The bank has written a new business plan that the City Council is scheduled to debate soon.
Many people here remain deeply wary, but hopeful. So far, the lending "has not made a meaningful difference in my district," said Rita Walters, who represents South-Central Los Angeles, a focus of the bank's lending, on the City Council. "This is a whole different world in here, and we cannot give up on it. The execution needs to be better."
Marva Smith Battle-Bey, executive director of the Vermont-Slauson Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit group that invests in poor areas, added: "That was a hard-fought battle to get that bank and get it located in that neighborhood. It would negatively affect investment there if this went south now. I feel strongly that we need to make it a more viable instrument."
The interim chief executive of the bank, Linda Griego, acknowledges the problems and argues that the Community Development Bank can become more viable. "A lot rides on this experiment," she said. "A lot of people went out on the line for this. Some of what's happened is just unbelievable, but it can be fixed in my view."
IN the giddily prosperous era of the so-called new economy, talking about high unemployment in depressed urban neighborhoods may seem an anachronism, like discussing rust-prevention methods at an Internet company. But even as the rates of teenage pregancy and crime are dropping, joblessness in many cities remains disturbingly intractable.
Watts, for instance, which was convulsed by civil disturbances twice in the last 31 years, has shifted from a mostly black to a mostly Hispanic neighborhood, and it has been the target of many government job programs. But the unemployment rate still hovers near 20 percent, compared with 4.1 percent nationally.
The Los Angeles Community Development Bank represents one of the most expensive efforts to try a new philosophy in job creation. These efforts are often described as partnerships, since the view is that the government can merely help foster the growth of businesses that must be able to survive on their own. The theory was summed up in 1995 in an article in The Harvard Business Review by Michael E. Porter, a professor at Harvard Business School.
In it, Mr. Porter said job creation would come only "through private, for-profit initiatives and investment based on economic self-interest and genuine competitive advantage -- not through artificial inducements, charity or government mandates."
Andrew M. Cuomo, secretary of HUD, agrees: "Government is the facilitator for the private sector. You have to promote private-sector growth in there."
THE Los Angeles Community Development Bank was set up by the Clinton administration in the aftermath of the 1992 riots here. Los Angeles had failed to qualify for designation as an Empowerment Zone, a status that gives businesses an array of incentives to operate in depressed neighborhoods and employ local people. Furious, the city argued that it deserved some assistance, and the administration eventually offered the development bank as a sort of consolation prize. (Parts of the city have since received the Empowerment Zone designation.)
The bank was supposed to use public financing merely to water the seeds of the private sector -- to help entrepreneurs help themselves and then to get out of their way. In return, the entrepreneurs were obliged to locate in the depressed areas -- a patchwork of sites totaling 19 square miles, mostly to the south and the east of downtown -- and hire at least half their new employees from the neighborhoods.
There are several other community development banks around the country, in cities like Cleveland and Washington, but none are as large, as political in their origins or as dependent on federal funds as the Los Angeles bank. By the end of 2004, it is supposed to have lent out all $435 million -- and then see that it is all paid back.
But that is becoming problematic at best. Of the $97 million in loans it had extended as of Sept. 30, nearly a third have gone bad. The bank's largest loan, $24.1 million to a dairy operation called the Copeland Beverage Group, exceeded the bank's own loan limit of $20 million to a single borrower, and it has been written off. The company has been shut down. An additional $7.2 million of loans are now listed as very high risk if not actual losses.
The bank says it has fostered the creation or retention of 1,258 jobs, only 41 percent of the 3,039 required under the terms of the loans it has made. (Companies are obliged to create at least one job for every $35,000 borrowed.) And just 249 of those jobs went to people living in the Empowerment Zone, fewer than a third of the number required. The bank points out that since the companies have two years to meet the standards, there is still time for some of them to hire more people.
But the figures are actually worse than they look. The bank's employment statistics include nonexistent jobs -- positions created or retained by companies that later failed, like Copeland and Trinity. (The bank counts jobs created by its borrowers as well as jobs retained by companies that would have closed without the loans.) About 276 such jobs have vanished.
THE bank's proponents say that, at least in part, some of the difficulties are built into its charter. It can now lend only to companies
that have been rejected by commercial banks, yet it places a heavy burden on these companies.
"Let's look at the reality," said Caron Caines, a member of the Empowerment Zone Oversight Committee, a watchdog group appointed by the City Council. "You're going to lend money to businesses that no one wants to lend money to, and then you're going to saddle them with the responsibility of creating all these jobs. I don't get it. What this policy does is to transfer the very important policy goal of creating jobs to some of the weakest members of the business community. These businesses have a hard enough time just surviving."
Ms. Caines added: "It's a grand experiment. But with that you have to constantly monitor and evaluate and adjust the program to make it work. None of that happened."
Ms. Griego, a former deputy mayor, was brought in this summer after the first chief executive, C. Robert Kemp, resigned because of illness. She is leading the reorganization and helping to find a permanent chief executive -- with luck, by the end of the year. She said that every candidate who was approached initially had turned the job down cold, but that some people were now interested. Even the bank's sponsors -- HUD and the city -- have distanced themselves.
"I would beg you not to use the bank as a platform to talk about the bigger issues here," said Rockard J. Delgadillo, Los Angeles's deputy mayor for economic development. "It is one element of what I would say is a large number for attacking this issue. It's not a silver bullet. In fact, we've had more success with other products."
The city has a new program, Genesis L.A., focusing on encouraging businesses to locate in 15 old industrial sites. The Community Development Bank is a bit player in the plan, well down the list of incentives that include discounts on utility rates and accelerated city permits.
Mr. Cuomo said in an interview that the bank's problems were the city's, not the federal government's.
"I can count on one hand the number of conversations I've had with them," said Mr. Cuomo, emphasizing that Washington had not meddled. "The prevailing winds are devolution. The new ideas are coming from the new breed of mayor. We do not come in and micromanage."
He added, "I don't know that there's necessarily a lesson" in the bank's well-publicized problems.
But many experts do see lessons, if not in the politics then in a better understanding of what small businesses here really need. Even some critics of the development bank, and there are many, say it has shed some light on a more fruitful path.
The bank's new business plan, put together during Ms. Griego's tenure, includes some shifts in direction that are meant to take advantage of the experiences so far.
Among the changes is a switch toward finding commercial banks to go in as co-lenders, to ensure that market discipline and professional underwriters are focused on the companies. In addition, the bank intends to do more indirect lending, in which it will provide funds to other, more experienced nonprofit organizations in poor neighborhoods and then allow those groups to make the actual loans to needy companies. That is intended to correct what Ms. Griego said had been a major problem: that the development bank was trying to create a lending and underwriting department from scratch.
"We've been reinventing the wheel," Ms. Griego said. "It's expensive, and it doesn't work to have our own people doing all that. We're not going to compete in this market. We're putting people with less experience than commercial bankers out there in this market. It does not make sense."
She added that in working jointly with commercial banks, the aim was to find more resilient and experienced borrowers, not just companies that had been rejected.
"This is like being a doctor and all of your patients have serious cancer," said J. Eugene Grigsby III, director of the Advanced Policy Institute at the University of California at Los Angeles and a member of the bank's board. "The rules we started with say in effect that we deal only with the financial untouchables. We ought to have more flexibility."
He also said the rules on job creation and the need for the businesses to be in the Empowerment Zone should be loosened. "The last thing a lot of start-up companies need is a requirement that they should create a lot of jobs quickly," Mr. Grigsby said. "They have to keep costs down for a while and minimize their payroll to survive."
GOING forward, the bank plans to look for ways to provide not only standard bank loans, known as senior debt, but also equity and subordinated debt to borrowers, since that capital is more "patient." It is longer term and can be used to help attract capital from usual commercial sources, thus getting the borrowers into the private markets more quickly. The bank already has a small venture-capital fund but is looking to expand the ways it invests.
"Coming up with another debt program does not really help this community," said Roberto Barragan, interim president of the Valley Economic Development Center, a nonprofit organization that has done lending deals with the Community Development Bank. Bank officials built their strategy, he said, "on the model of big companies, which can service a lot of debt."
"It's a philosophy that's been pretty much trashed for these small businesses," he added. "They decided on a debt solution before anyone had asked about the real needs."
Mr. Akers of Trinity Knitworks had much the same view. "I didn't need debt," he said. "I needed working capital."
The proposed changes in the bank's business plan have been long in coming. Other institutions have used some of these new ideas with great success.
IT is illuminating, for example, to compare the experience of the Los Angeles Community Development Bank with a private-sector organization called the California Economic Development Lending Initiative. It is a consortium of 45 banks that has a lending capacity of about $65 million, specifically for companies in depressed areas.
The Community Development Bank, which began with $435 million in capital, took two months to start running and 14 months to make its first loan. It was under great political pressure to put money into the community quickly. Almost no one on the staff had extensive commercial banking experience.
The private consortium, by contrast, solicited two grants and used them for a two-year study on how it should operate before it took its first organizational step. Its staff is made up almost entirely of experienced lending officers. Today, the private consortium has made about $29 million in loans, with only 2 percent of the total in default.
George Williamson, the consortium's chief executive, insists that his organization work with commercial banks to make sure that the borrowers stay close to the private markets.
"Having a close relationship with banks is an important part of our strategy," he said. "I would see dealing with companies no bank would lend to as a silly way to proceed."
There are some experts who say that the Community Development Bank has legitimate functions, but that it should get out of direct lending, because it requires too many skills. Instead, they say that it should be only a co-lender with commercial banks, or that it should lend indirectly through other nonprofit groups.
"At this point I think they need to look at the possibility of closing down the direct lending altogether, just close it," Mr. Barragan said. "They should give management of the portfolio to somebody else who has the experience."
Still, Ms. Caines of the Empowerment Zone Oversight Committee said that her group had surveyed the bank's borrowers and that she was slightly surprised by the results.
"They all said the paperwork was overwhelming them," she said. "And it was clear the bank was really weak on technical assistance to these companies. But, truthfully, I expected it to be more negative."
Albert Gold, the chairman of Gold Graphics in Pacoima, a town at the northern end of the San Fernando Valley that lies in the Empowerment Zone, said his business was thriving until the Northridge earthquake in 1994. The roof of the plant collapsed, and Mr. Gold said he was woefully underinsured. He had a strong track record and was able to secure a loan from the Community Development Bank.
"In some ways, the earthquake was the best thing that could have happened to us because it caused us to undertake an involuntary upgrade of all our facilities," he said. "The technology we put in was the technology the market was looking for."
He said he had gone from about 90 employees to about 180. But one big drawback, he said, was the full year it took to have his loan approved and financed -- a frequent complaint about the program.
NOT far from his modern printing plant is a store called Double D Western Wear, another loan recipient. Abel Diaz, the owner, is bitter about his experience. Mr. Diaz said the bank forced him to incur $18,000 in costs, mostly for accounting work and an expensive appraisal of his property, just to get the $420,000 loan, . And in the year it took him to get the financing, his business had declined so much that he actually needed more capital.
"All of us here ran into the same situation," said Mr. Diaz, who has run the store for more than 30 years. "We came to them because we were in trouble and needed the money. What were we supposed to do in that year?"
The bank said Mr. Diaz was in trouble from the start and that it had offered enormous assistance to help him keep afloat.
Mr. Garcia of West Coast Metal Finishing said his experiences speak to the bank's possibilities. On his office walls are photos of himself with President Clinton, the vice president and Mayor Richard Riordan of Los Angeles -- all elements in the dream he says he has experienced.
"You grow up in East L.A., and you don't have anything in this life, and there I was at the White House," Mr. Garcia said, recalling his visit there. "They gave me an opportunity. Who else is going to do that around here?"

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 14, 1999

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3625 words

HEADLINE: A Chief Intent on Raising Eyebrows

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
ONE recent afternoon, Mel Karmazin, the chairman and chief executive of CBS, stormed through the office of the network's late founder, William S. Paley, on the 35th floor of Black Rock, the CBS headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, and collapsed into a chair in the adjoining conference room.
"I've had a busy day," he said, fiddling with his silk tie in a gesture of mock fatigue. "First I worked on Letterman's monologue. Then I wrote all of Howard Stern's jokes for tomorrow. And then, I programmed all the radio stations." 
 No one present -- Mr. Karmazin's public relations envoy, a reporter and a secretary standing at the door -- cracked a smile. It seemed almost plausible.
Three years ago, Mr. Karmazin, a former radio advertising salesman who next year will become the chief operating officer of Viacom-CBS, one of the world's largest producers of news and entertainment, was virtually unknown outside the tiny, tightknit radio industry. Now he is the putative heir to Sumner M. Redstone, 76, Viacom's chief executive.
Yet already Mr. Karmazin is talking about rising further. "When Jack Welch retires," he said, referring to John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of General Electric, which owns the rival NBC, "I plan to buy NBC."
He's not necessarily kidding. He said he believed that Washington could be persuaded to further deregulate the media industry, especially as television audiences continued to migrate to cable channels.
And this is not the first time since the Viacom-CBS merger was announced in September that Mr. Karmazin has gone window-shopping: according to several reports, he has his eye on America Online as an acquisition candidate.
But Mr. Karmazin's all-consuming aspirations raise several questions. What exactly has he accomplished in his three years at CBS? Is his background in advertising broad enough to run not only a network, always considered a public trust, but also a soon-to-be-merged company that will have an $80 billion market capitalization and revenues of $19 billion from movies, broadcasting, cable, publishing and music networks?
Put bluntly, can Viacom-CBS be run successfully by a man who has never seen a television pilot, has rarely made programming decisions and has never supervised creative people on a daily basis? Will his methods of bone-deep cost-cutting and micromanaging work at a company the size of Viacom-CBS? And just what is he thinking about the future of the lightning-paced media industry?
Mr. Karmazin, who leads a quiet life for a media mogul, is a reluctant celebrity, uncomfortable speaking about himself. He is, for example, reputed to be a voracious reader, but when asked about his choices, he snapped: "I'm not going to tell you what books I read. I'm not Oprah. Oprah, you should care about what books she reads. If I were going to form a book club and make lots of money off it, then I would tell you what books I read." (His example shows that he is not a man to miss an opportunity for free promotion. King World -- the distributor of "The Oprah Winfrey Show" -- agreed to merge with CBS seven months ago in a stock swap valued at $2.5 billion.)
When Mr. Karmazin does talk about himself, he sometimes seems awkward, more like a hyperactive 10-year-old boy than a 56-year-old chief executive. He hates to sleep, saying: "Why sleep? It's too boring." So it's not surprising that he rises at 4:30 a.m., without an alarm clock, and rarely takes a vacation, despite owning a beach house at the Jersey Shore.
But his history gives some clues about what he will do at Viacom-CBS, an entity that Mr. Karmazin fondly calls the "largest advertising platform in the world," where he will split duties with Mr. Redstone. It is an advertising behemoth, he has said, that guarantees "unprecedented cross-promotional opportunities around the world."
For Mr. Karmazin, stock price is an obsession, "shareholder value" a mantra he often drops into conversation, and advertising is king.
Mr. Karmazin's roots in advertising go way back. He grew up in Long Island City, Queens, and attended P.S. 1 there. His mother worked in a factory while his father drove a taxi. During high school, Mr. Karmazin was a typist at an ad agency in Manhattan.
UNIVERSALLY known as Mel (reporters who use his full name, Melvin Alan, receive a phone call from a CBS spin doctor with this reprimand: "Ted Turner is not Theodore Turner. Walt Disney is not Walter Disney. And Mel Karmazin is not Melvin."), Mr. Karmazin attended Pace University at night while he worked as an advertising salesman by day.
"The only day I stayed awake in college was the lecture about Supply and Demand 101," he said. His first CBS job, at $17,500 a year, was selling ads for the radio division. In the late 1960's, when his commission exceeded $70,000, his boss balked at his cut; Mr. Karmazin soon left to work for John W. Kluge at Metromedia, the broadcasting company. He married, had two children -- his son owns a small radio broadcasting company in Wisconsin -- and, a few years ago, divorced.
Broadcast advertising sales creates a particularly aggressive, jumpy kind of sales representative, said Norman Pattiz, an old friend who is chairman of Westwood One, the largest radio network in the country and the country's largest supplier of local traffic and news to radio stations. (CBS owns 13 percent of the company's stock and controls 10 percent of the voting power.) "You can't sell yesterday's time," he explained. "So it creates a very intense kind of person. You need to know two things to be a great salesperson. You need to know the business, which Mel does. And you need to ingratiate yourself to the people you are doing business with. And Mel does that, too."
In 1996, Mr. Karmazin was the chief executive of the Infinity Broadcasting Company, which then owned 44 radio stations around the country. He had taken Infinity public in 1992 for $17.50 a share, then sold it to CBS in 1996 for $170 a share, securing his reputation on Wall Street.
That year, using a business strategy that has since become his trademark, Mr. Karmazin approached CBS, which merged with Westinghouse in 1995, and proposed that Infinity buy the company. Instead, CBS acquired Infinity for $4.9 billion that June, and Mr. Karmazin came aboard to run the combined radio operations of Infinity, Westinghouse and CBS, along with its outdoor advertising business. Intent on making his stamp on the company, he was instrumental in persuading Westinghouse to dump its industrial manufacturing assets and to refashion the company under the CBS name.
Michael H. Jordan, then chairman and chief executive of CBS, appointed him to head CBS's station division. Mr. Karmazin rose quickly -- so quickly that in October 1998 he forced Mr. Jordan's resignation, assuming his titles in January. (A spokeswoman for Mr. Jordan, who runs an Internet company in Pittsburgh, said he would not comment.)
IF Mr. Jordan did not sense it, others saw Mr. Karmazin's ambitions.. "He is always comfortable saying: 'I don't have to control everything. Just let me run it.' Once he runs it, his performance allows him to control it," Mr. Pattiz said. "I heard somebody describe him one time by saying, 'Mel is completely without guile. He'll never stab you in the back. He'll stab you in the chest.' "
"Well, that's true," Mr. Karmazin said, hearing the analysis. "I will be totally honest with you -- even if you might not like what I have to say."
But Don Imus, the radio personality whom Mr. Karmazin installed more than 10 years ago at WFAN, one of Infinity's 163 radio stations, knows him well -- and said he believed that Mr. Karmazin, whom he described as "a cross between Lenny Bruce and Don Rickles," had no strategy.
"I really think he goes from one point to the next with no master plan," Mr. Imus said. "I think his goal is to try to get CBS stock to 100."
Indeed, since Mr. Karmazin's arrival, CBS stock has more than tripled, from a low of $15.375 in July 1996 to a close of $51.8125 on Friday.
Jessica Reif Cohen, a media analyst at Merrill Lynch who is one of many loyal Mel Karmazin hagiographers on Wall Street, also said he is single-minded. "He is focused on one thing: bringing the stock up," she said. "Sumner can do the strategic visionary thing, and Mel can be the behind-the-scenes operator, pushing the stock, and that's what he will do."
When Mr. Karmazin arrived at CBS, his goals were few but clear: cut costs and raise revenues so that the stock moves relentlessly higher. To the dismay of many in the news division, he has cut spending on the evening news -- as all three networks have done in recent years -- even as he has invested $30 million to $50 million in a potentially risky morning program, "The Early Show;" it made its debut on Nov. 1.
The rationale is simple. The highest-rated morning program, NBC's "Today," generated $150 million in advertising revenue last year. CBS's previous morning offering had only about one-fourth that amount.
Little wonder that at the "CBS Evening News," Mr. Karmazin is vilified as the man who has continued cuts that began under Laurence A. Tisch, the chairman of CBS from 1986 to 1996, whom news staff members felt had financially handcuffed the news division. According to CBS executives, the "CBS Evening News," under a reorganization instituted by Mr. Karmazin, has continued to reduce its number of camera crews. CBS executives refer to it as surgery, not an amputation, but will not say how many news crews the network has, though they acknowledge that the total is far below the 125 crews fielded by NBC.
Mr. Karmazin makes no apologies. "We've been pretty good at watching expenses," he said. "And we're pretty good at generating revenues. We've always been known to make huge investments in properties that are worth it." For example, Howard Stern, the shock jock Mr. Karmazin hired at WNEW, reportedly has a salary of $20 million a year; Mr. Imus makes at least $6 million, and Leslie Moonves, the president and chief executive of CBS Television, got a raise from to $6 million, from $4 million.
Mr. Karmazin added: "You know, I'm real comfortable getting my own cup of coffee. I don't need a kitchen staff. I'd rather put that money on the screen or in radio, not to behind-the-scenes stuff that is about making my life more comfortable."
After slashing $180 million from the CBS budget last year, Mr. Karmazin has raised revenue. Ad revenue climbed after he and Mr. Moonves started preaching to advertisers that CBS's viewers, while older than those of other networks, were a wealthier and thus better demographic group. But it is unclear whether ad revenue rose because of the demographic push or because of a healthy economy and a big surge in Internet advertising, of which Mr. Karmazin said CBS has managed to garner a majority. CBS's ad rates have increased: for the 1999-2000 season, NBC remains the most expensive with an average unit rate -- the cost for a 30-second prime-time spot -- of $171,114, a drop of around 9 percent from the previous year, according to a survey by Advertising Age published each fall. ABC has an average rate of $165,773, down 3.6 percent.
But CBS, though still in third place, has managed a 27 percent increase, to an average unit rate of $163,773.
Mr. Karmazin's other trick at CBS was to put the sales force on commission, without salary, a measure instituted two years ago and noted throughout the industry.
That is not punitive, he said. "The purpose of it is to have them on your side, so the salespeople don't sit there and say, 'Hey, I did all this work and the big guys get all the money.' " He recently told CBS radio advertising sales managers that he expected to present a sales representative with a $1 million annual paycheck -- a first -- someday soon. His advice to the sales staff is: "Don't give me lame excuses like, 'Oh, Mel, but our ratings are down, wah, wah.' Or, 'there's no activity.' Your job is to create activity."
Significantly, Mr. Karmazin is not a man given to romantic notions about network history. He has said he will sell the network, which analysts say has lost money every year since the mid-1980's , if he cannot make it profitable. (This year, he says it will be profitable.) Asked if he ever senses the presence of Paley's spirit in his office, he said: "His ghost? Well, if it makes a better story for you, sure I feel Paley's ghost." Then he wiggled his fingers, raised his eyebrows and said, playfully, "Whoooo!"
Befitting a man who thinks first of a network as a billboard, not the home of "60 Minutes" -- once even betting Tom Wolzien, a media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, Mr. Wolzien's salary that he could sell the network for more than it was worth -- Mr. Karmazin spends little time worrying about programming. (Mr. Karmazin replies: "Oh, that was a chump-change bet anyway.") He depends on the executives in programming to report to him on an almost-daily basis.
"Mel once said, 'The day that Leslie Moonves asks my opinion about programming is the day I sell all my CBS stock,' " Mr. Moonves said. "That's flattering, but it says a lot about our relationship."
Howard Stringer, chairman of the Sony Corporation of America and a former president of CBS, said that was Mr. Karmazin's style. "He is smart to know what he does not know," he said.
When he moves to the merged Viacom-CBS, Mr. Karmazin is expected to approach his management duties with similar tactics, if Mr. Redstone lets him run the show. By most accounts, the pair's engagement joins two like-minded men from similar backgrounds in a mission to generate more advertising revenue than any other company.
"We are kindred spirits," Mr. Redstone said. "Neither one of us was born with a golden spoon in his mouth. We're both entrepreneurs at heart and we're both driven by the same motivation."
STILL, there has already been a tense moment. Last month, the two appeared to differ over Blockbuster, Viacom's ailing video rental chain. One day, Mr. Karmazin told analysts that it would be best to spin it off, but later that week, in a conference call with reporters, Mr. Redstone shot back that Blockbuster was "not a sick child."
"It is a booming, thriving business," he said, quashing rumors that he would sell it.
Nevertheless, Mr. Karmazin said he had a few concrete plans for the day the merger is approved by the Federal Communications Commission. For one, he wants to integrate music units of Viacom -- MTV and VH1 -- with CBS's radio, advertising and Internet entities in a Web site or series of Web sites.
"Let's assume that the American consumer likes music," he said. "And let's say that music might be something that might be on the Internet. Take our radio stations. Take MTV and VH1, and that's a pretty compelling site. You're able to drive traffic to it because you've got all these billboards and forms of advertising, and I think that's all pretty compelling."
He also intends to scrutinize the children's programming business. "There are interesting opportunities that are still hypothetical," he said. "But they have a lot of children's programming. What if our networks wanted to run some children's programming? That might not be a bad idea." He added that Infinity's radio stations might be a great fit for MTV and VH1 in terms of concert promotion.
The merger also fulfills Mr. Karmazin's longtime desire to own cable properties.
"Up until now, CBS didn't have any cable, and that was a problem," he said. "And now we have cable. We didn't have a major studio and now we have a studio."
None of this will quell the objections raised when the merger was announced, especially from vocal critics in the advertising industry. Because the merger will meld the CBS network, CBS television stations, radio stations and billboards with Viacom's MTV, VH1 and Nickelodeon and the company's stake in the UPN network, some fear that the consolidation will allow Viacom-CBS to charge excessive rates and unfairly corner some advertising markets.
"I don't think what Mel is doing is good for the country," said Jean Pool, executive vice president and director for North American media services at J. Walter Thompson in New York. "I don't think monopolies are good for the country or the economy. Mel is like the robber barons at the turn of the century. And you remember what happened to the oil business and the railroad business at the turn of the last century. They became terrible monopolies that were eventually broken up."
Mr. Karmazin said the new company would "not have, quote, unfair leverage with any constituency at all." He added: "Wherever advertisers want to spend their money, we're going to be there. We're indifferent to where they spend their money, as long as they spend it with us."
Ms. Pool said she did not expect the new company to increase any ad rates before the Senate antitrust subcommittee and the Federal Communications Commission approved the deal. "I am sure Mel is half-joking when he says he wants to buy NBC," Ms. Pool said, "but if that is his dream, he is going to have to be a good boy and at least look as if he is behaving himself."
Jon Mandel, co-managing director of Mediacom, the media services arm of Grey Advertising, said the merger's so-called synergy -- extolled by Mr. Karmazin and Mr. Redstone -- was nonexistent.
"There is no natural fit between Viacom and CBS that makes sense," Mr. Mandel said, noting that audiences watching "60 Minutes" were not also watching MTV. He had one exception: "If you look at music, however, there is a tremendous fit."
Mr. Mandel said the most fundamental issue with the Viacom-CBS deal would be "if Mel ever tries to change the programming."
At CBS, the closest Mr. Karmazin ever came to that occurred when Don Hewitt, the producer of "60 Minutes," and Mike Wallace, one of the program's correspondents, appealed to him in 1998 to not go forward with a plan put forward by Mr. Moonves and Andrew Heyward, the president of CBS News, for "60 Minutes II." One CBS executive said that Mr. Hewitt and Mr. Wallace begged Mr. Karmazin to quash the show, but that Mr. Karmazin listened and said, "Sorry guys, but I'm not going to override Andrew and Leslie."
According to another executive, the encounter had Mr. Karmazin barking: "We're putting on '60 Minutes II' whether you like it or not. If I have to slap the title '60 Minutes II' across 'The Nanny,' I'll do it, but you're going to have '60 Minutes II.' "
 IN either case, it was a good move: "60 Minutes II," despite its low ratings with younger audiences, is ranked 24th in Nielsen ratings, after ABC's "Dharma and Greg" and NBC's "Law and Order: Special Victims Unit." Mr. Karmazin smiled and said only this: " 'The Nanny?' Does that sound like me? I think the team at "60 Minutes" was concerned. I was pleased that they cared so much about the brand name."
Mr. Karmazin is notoriously tough with staff, and has become only tougher.
"If he likes you, it would be great to work for him," Ms. Cohen said. "If he doesn't, it would be a nightmare." And his style is famously brusque.
One former CBS executive said he once attended a meeting with Mr. Karmazin and Fred Drasner, then the co-publisher of The Daily News of New York. After the meeting, according to this account, Mr. Karmazin stood at the elevator, looked at the CBS executive, and said: "The day I fire you, the company's stock will go up $2." (Mr. Karmazin fired him a few months later.)
Some people who know Mr. Karmazin say an early career humiliation is at the heart of his intensity. In the late 1960's, Mr. Karmazin, then at WCBS Radio, tried to get a job at WCBS television. "CBS was dominated by a bunch of guys who were in the job because they looked good and went to the right schools," another executive said. "The network business was great. O and O's were big. Cable was still far over the horizon." (In TV jargon, "O and O" refers to stations that are owned and operated by a network.)
Mr. Karmazin, though, "wore the wide lapels and the hair going out in 18 different directions, his tie undone," this executive said. "He came off as a street tough. And I believe that he was rejected on a cultural basis." Mr. Karmazin still wants to prove them wrong, the executive said.
Mr. Karmazin's spokesman said he had no comment about the story.
Ascending at Viacom-CBS would, of course, be the ultimate payback. Mr. Karmazin said he had no intention of trying to oust Mr. Redstone. But a provision of the merger was that if Mr. Redstone were to step down, Mr. Karmazin would become chief executive of Viacom-CBS. "And that was to satisfy the board members," Mr. Karmazin said. The two are paid identically, but Mr. Redstone also retains the right, until 2003, to dismiss Mr. Karmazin, which doesn't seem to bother him at all.
At a dinner meeting with analysts last week, Mr. Karmazin said that whether he and Mr. Redstone are friendly is "immaterial," stressing instead the assets of the combination. "But," he added, "I expect to be here in 20 years."
To which Mr. Redstone said: "And so do I!"
Mr. Karmazin had little to say about Viacom's movie and book business, but those who know him said he would keep his hands off unless profits eroded.
"What is it that I would want this job for?" he asked. "I enjoy running my company. I like hands-on operations. I don't like the visibility."
But, he added: "I'm very conscious of the fact that I wasn't successful as a kid. I wasn't making a lot of money. I didn't come from a rich family. I was comfortable in that lifestyle. But having all this stuff -- people coming up to you, being in the public eye -- is more, well, unusual for me. I don't enjoy it."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
As the Stock Rally Broadens, The Role of the Fed Grows

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
HERE'S some good news ahead of the meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday: The stock market rally is broadening. More stocks are doing better -- or at least not as poorly as they once were -- compared with the Standard & Poor's 500 Index.
Strategists are generally more comfortable with a broader market; a market with narrow leadership is often headed for a fall. 
 According to one measure, the Laggards indicator produced by Jeffrey M. Warantz, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, 58.8 percent of 7,598 common stocks are trailing the performance of the S. & P. 500 by 15 percentage points or more over the last 12 months. But that is down from a record 77.1 percent in April.
More evidence of the broadening is seen in the Russell 2000 index, which measures smaller-company stocks and is up 17.3 percent from its low for the year in March. On a wider scale, Mr. Warantz said companies with market capitalizations of $10 billion or less were up 15.6 percent, on average, in the second and third quarters of this year. This performance of midcap to small-cap stocks compares with an average decline of 4 percent for companies with capitalizations of more than $10 billion.
And that broadening has occurred while the Federal Reserve has been raising its short-term interest rate target, to 5.75 percent from 5.25 percent. Another increase is possible on Tuesday.
While the Fed was raising its target three full percentage points between February 1994 and February 1995, this index jumped to 44.4 percent from 28.6 percent, meaning that the leadership of the market narrowed significantly as investors chose to switch into the most liquid, big-company stocks that have good, long-term earnings records.
What does all this mean? One interpretation is that even though the market has broadened, the improvement has been only from the narrowest market since the indicator was created in 1971. Now at 58.8 percent, the indicator is still well above the average of 34.9 percent and at the fourth-highest point since 1971. By this interpretation, the performance since May is not as positive as it looks.
"The market was excruciatingly narrow at its worst and it is still narrow at its best," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Another interpretation is that this is just another market indicator that worked in the past but isn't working now. That is the story for many of the guides that equity strategists and Fed policy makers have been using to help them understand the performance of the stock market and the economy in the last half of the 1990's.
In 1973, 1987 and 1990, this indicator peaked and the stock market had a big fall. This time, that hasn't happened yet.
Or the index is proving that investors in general are still confident about the outlook for stocks -- and probably more confident than they were several months ago.
The economy is growing strongly, while inflation still appears in check. Third-quarter operating earnings for the S. & P. 500 have risen 22 percent, according to the First Call/Thomson Financial, and the forecast for growth in the fourth quarter is 18 percent. Further, the outlook for avoiding Year 2000 computer problems is improving.
That optimism could change if the Fed raises interest rates again. The October increase of 0.3 percent in the Producer Price Index for finished goods, excluding food and energy, was bigger than expected and revived worries about a Fed rate increase. But strong productivity numbers and moderate retail sales data, reported on Friday, seemed to calm investors.
With a third quarter-point rate increase, the Fed would finish erasing the three cuts made in the fall of 1998 to counter the impact of Russia's bond default, the near collapse of a major hedge fund and the deepening global financial crisis.
That would set the stage for new concern. Investors may find a third rate increase tolerable because they were just taking back the largess of 1998. But if the economy does not slow down, the speculation will turn to where the Fed goes from here. That means the real test for stocks and bonds won't come until after a third rate increase.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1055 words

HEADLINE: Returns to Senders;
Snail Mail: It's Alive! And It's Mutating!

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
THE United Parcel Service, with its fleet of unfashionable brown trucks and brown-uniformed drivers, picks up big boxes, moves them around the world and then drops them off. Founded in 1907, the company is in many ways a quintessential bricks-and-mortar business, the kind that the new economy of the Internet was supposed to overshadow.
Yet when U.P.S. offered shares to the public last week, investors greeted the new stock with an enthusiasm usually reserved for dot-com ventures whose founders' parents had not even been born by 1907. U.P.S.'s shares quickly shot from $50 apiece to $70, and the company is now worth about $85 billion. It was the largest initial public offering in history, making the early valuations that Wall Street placed on darlings like Amazon.com and Yahoo! look almost old fashioned. 
 At first glance, it appears to be a stirring vote of confidence in snail mail, a debunking of the myth of a paperless society and a harbinger of good things for the United States Postal Service. Neither the telephone nor the fax put a dent in the amount of mail people send. Now, perhaps, the Internet will fail to, as well.
The underlying message, however, is more complicated, and it indicates that the concept of mail is indeed on the verge of changing radically. Mail is really two different things -- letters and packages -- and their fortunes are quickly diverging. One is likely to be all but replaced by e-mail eventually. The other, contrary to some initial expectations, will only grow in importance.
Since Benjamin Franklin created the United States Postal Service in 1775, mail has meant, above all else, the bills and personal letters that come in envelopes, which weigh just a few ounces and are smaller than a human forearm. In fact, the Postal Service was legally barred during its first 138 years from delivering just about anything else. For packages, people used separate "express companies" like American Express and Wells Fargo. Even today, when people hear "mail," they think primarily of the bundle of envelopes waiting in the mailbox, not a package sitting at their door.
But the Internet could eventually usher in a day when almost all those envelopes will contain advertisements, and the majority of mail people really care about will come in packages. The rest -- letters, bills, money and even photographs -- will arrive through the computer, mail experts agree. Already, according to Jupiter Communications, Americans are sending 122 billion e-mails annually, more than half the number of pieces of mail that the Postal Service handles each year.
And that shift promises enormous changes for the largest civilian employer in the United States and one of the few institutions that every American comes into contact with every week.
The Postal Service's rivals, by contrast, are watching their business grow, as U.P.S.'s record-setting day showed. With information shoving aside industry as the fastest-growing sector of the economy, the country today is far more reliant on small goods that can be shipped from point to point. "A billion dollars of G.D.P. created by Microsoft weighs less than a billion dollars of G.D.P. created by Ford Motor Company," said Paul R. Schlesinger, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
At the same time, electronic commerce causes more items to be shipped individually, rather than taken home from the store, and it leads to more returns. Thus the recent success of U.P.S. and Federal Express, and investors' confidence that the two will be making good profits in the decades to come.
The picture isn't so rosy for the Postal Service. It relies on the sending and paying of bills for $17 billion, or almost 30 percent, of its revenue. These pieces of first-class mail, often sent short distances from, say, an electric company to a house in the same metropolitan area, help subsidize the organization's ability to charge just 33 cents for a letter that travels from Santa Fe to northern Vermont and costs more to transport.
But that subsidy won't be around for long. Next year, Internet portals like Yahoo! and a number of large banks will begin allowing people to receive many of their bills over the World Wide Web, pay them with a credit card or directly out of their bank accounts and never lick an envelope. "That's serious business," Bob Krause, the Postal Service's vice president for e-commerce, said, anticipating the loss.
As a result, the volume of first-class mail is likely to decline for the first time in the Postal Service's history, starting in 2003, according to the General Accounting Office. "The Postal Service may be nearing the end of an era," a G.A.O. report concluded last month.
WITHOUT that $17 billion in revenue, or a substitute for it, the post office would have to raise its prices significantly or perhaps even cut back on its six-day-a-week service, Mr. Krause said. The latter would be a historic shift Congress is unlikely to allow. The operation of a post office, after all, is one of the powers the Constitution specifically grants the federal government.
"People like having their own little post office, especially in small towns where it is the center of town," said Stephen Moore, an economist at the Cato Institute who was a member of a Reagan administration commission that tried unsuccessfully to privatize the post office. Other people like knowing a letter they send will be physically held by the recipient, be it a faraway parent or a lover, and that it won't end up being forwarded all over the Internet.
The overall threat to the Postal Service is serious, however, and that is why it is furiously trying to expand its business. This month, it began allowing consumers to return items bought over the Web by printing a postage label from their own computers and billing the suppliers. It also wants to set up an electronic post office where people could conduct secure transactions over the Web.
But the efforts could fail for any number of reasons, including the political debate over whether a federal agency should compete with private companies. If those efforts fall short, some of Postal Service's more than 800,000 jobs will be in jeopardy. And the relatively low price of sending an envelope to any home in the country would rise, much as the stock of U.P.S. might.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Playing Catch-Up With Monopolies

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN President Clinton signed legislation on Friday updating the Depression-era law governing banking, insurance and Wall Street, he was doing little more than allowing Washington to catch up with the sweeping changes that have reshaped the financial services industry over the past few decades.
In Congress, the two parties have yet to really address the public outcry over the health care industry's drive to cut costs. While they dithered, the landscape was abruptly altered again last week when one of the nation's largest managed care companies reversed the trend by returning power over treatment choices to doctors. 
 In an economy that changes as swiftly as this one, driven in particular by breathtaking technological advances, it is clear that government faces a growing challenge in keeping pace with what is happening on the front lines of business.
Securities regulators are struggling to keep up with the rapid growth of on-line stock trading. No one in Washington seems to know quite how to protect consumers against unauthorized use of data about everything from their medical histories to their supermarket purchases.
"Government at every level is totally frustrated," said Thomas J. Donohue, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
Nowhere is the issue playing out more vividly -- or with higher stakes -- than in the Justice Department's antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation, the biggest player in an economically vital industry that has redefined all the nostrums about the importance of speed.
Is the Justice Department pursuing Microsoft over the way the company developed and marketed products that are yesterday's news? Can the case be resolved before the industry is transformed once again? Should the government even be butting into an industry that has thrived because it has developed largely outside the scope of regulation and legislation?
"It's only with the Microsoft case that the law has collided with an area of technology moving so fast as to call the basic premise of federal litigation into question," said John Shepard Wiley Jr., a law professor at the University of California at Los Angeles. "If your remedy is moving at the speed of federal litigation, the question has to be whether the whole thing will be relevant."
LOOKING across a range of issues, from telecommunications to banking to the development of online commerce, consumer advocates say they fear that technology and a general ideological drift toward greater respect for the market has created unwarranted deregulatory zeal.
"No one will be able to stop technology, and that's not the answer here," said Frank Torres, legislative counsel at Consumers Union, an advocacy group. "There are a lot of benefits from technology all through the marketplace. The question is who's looking out for the little guy, and what role should government play?"
The government is by no means unaware of the problem. In the Microsoft case, both the Justice Department and the federal judge, Thomas Penfield Jackson, have been quite successful thus far at keeping the proceedings moving quickly, at least by the standards of antitrust litigation.
More broadly, antitrust law has proven relatively flexible over the past century in dealing with changing business environments. As markets have become more global, for example, antitrust policy has become less hostile to sheer size in assessing mergers and focuses more on whether business combinations benefit consumers.
To some extent, the mismatch between the pace of business and government is an old problem. Legislation, with all the power it holds to create, nurture or cripple industry, can take years to emerge from the maw of partisanship and special interest pleadings. The new financial services bill was tied up for decades by disputes among the affected industries.
Moreover, just because government operates slowly does not mean that its influence on the private sector is reduced. The simple threat of action can often be enough to compel changes. Congress may be all but paralyzed right now over how far to go in giving patients more power to challenge medical decisions by managed care companies and the right to sue when things go wrong. But the H.M.O. that gave power back to doctors last week, United Health Group, was no doubt aware that failure to respond to public and political pressure could lead to legislation with far stricter terms.
A similar pre-emptive strategy might be at work in the Microsoft case. Microsoft might stall the process of getting to a final ruling and imposing any sanctions in the hopes that a friendlier administration will take office in 14 months, or in the belief that its current generation of products will be archaic by the time the process is complete. But the company might just as easily give competitors a bit more running room in response to the antitrust case, or agree to a settlement, accomplishing at least some of what the government set out to do without enduring a protracted legal struggle.
TO many conservatives, the problem is not so much that the government must scramble to keep up as it is that government is trying to stifle entrepreneurial and fast-moving industries precisely because they are difficult to regulate. They fear that in responding to the issues raised by technology and global markets, government is about to do for the 21st-century economy what the antitrust laws and regulatory agencies created a century or so ago did for the 20th century: create a system that gives Washington power over every nook and cranny of the economy.
"The Internet is something many conservatives believe is a model of the free market," said Marshall Wittman, director of government relations at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group. "You have to wonder, will we see by the end of the next century the same degree of regulation in that marketplace as we have now in the general marketplace?"
Still, there seems to be a prevailing belief that even in times of rapid change -- and perhaps especially in such times -- the government should strive to maintain its role in setting rules for the marketplace and enforcing them when they are broken.
"The total free market is a barroom brawl," said L. William Seidman, a former top banking regulator. "The real free market is a prizefight."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Sudan's Slaves and War Get a Second Look

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya

 BODY:
WHAT'S an ambitious senator to do? Get re-elected or awaken the world to slavery in faraway Sudan? That was the crux of a recent episode of "Touched by an Angel." Oversimplified and a mite soppy, the show presented one character who reflected American attitudes toward Sudan (and most African countries for that matter).
"Forget Sudan," says the character. "Waste of time. Not going anywhere. It's a complicated issue no one understands. Trust me." 
 While it is true that the majority of Americans care little about Sudan, a small number care deeply, in part because the country presents such stark issues: Famine, drought and endless aid. Arabs in the north warring with Christians in the south. Slavery and its morally snarled question of self-styled "redeemers" buying humans back.
And so Sudan is becoming that rarity in American foreign policy: an African nation with a grass-roots constituency, however small. American schoolchildren raising money to free people for $50 to $100 apiece. Christian-right allies in Congress worried about the Islamic threat finding common ground with black legislators concerned about slavery. Officials of various aid agencies meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to plead for a new course on Sudan.
These constituencies want the Clinton administration, which is already hard on Sudan, to get tougher still or to loosen up. So what's a superpower to do? Here are a few options:
* Bomb them. Sounds extreme but the choice presents an interesting, if slightly unfair, argument: African leaders often complain that the West does not treat crises in Africa as seriously as elsewhere. If the rest of the world decided that slavery or the absence of peace was intolerable and the Sudanese government refused to take steps, would NATO use the same force it used on Slobodan Milosevic?
Probably not. Administration officials might argue that war in Sudan, while not good for stability in the region, is only one of several conflicts there with less strategic value than, say, eastern Europe. The Sudanese government would also argue that slavery does not exist, although it acknowledges what they call "tribal hostage-taking" of southerners by government-backed northern Arab raiders. But the United Nations and other organizations say they have documented the existence of slavery.
On the other hand, the United States has already bombed Sudan after the terrorist bombing of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania. The result was a public relations disaster. There is considerable doubt that the pharmaceutical plant bombed produced nerve gas or that it was tied to Osama bin Laden, who is accused of directing the attack on the embassies.
THE bombing strike also temporarily increased support for the otherwise unpopular Sudanese government, both locally and among Arab nations.
* Arm the rebels. Even supporters of this option know it is improbable. Yet some in Congress say that America should, as it did in countless cold war conflicts, train and arm the Sudan Peoples Liberation Army, the main rebel group in the South, and other groups.
"It will create a balance of power," said Senator Sam Brownback, Republican of Kansas, who traveled to Sudan this summer. "If this situation was occurring in Europe or the rest of the world -- South America or Asia -- we would be all over it."
The many opponents of this option, including the Clinton administration, argue that the war in Sudan cannot be won by either side. It would only add more weapons to a region with too many already. Some of the rebels are accused of human rights abuses, war profiteering and being as uninterested in peace as the government in Khartoum.
* The China route. The aid officials who met with Ms. Albright advocate a policy endorsed by European nations: engage Khartoum, lessen antagonism and help influence an end to the war.
"Right now the United States has cut itself off from the negotiations," says Peter D. Bell, president of Care USA and one of the aid officials who met with Ms. Albright. "I don't see any cost to the United States in engaging in discussions and engaging in explanations about how the outstanding problems could be resolved."
ADVOCATES say that kind of relationship could include rewarding Sudan for progress toward peace or ending human rights abuses with, for example, an easing of the economic sanctions imposed in 1997.
The Clinton administration seems to be testing this approach, even as it keeps up strong oratory against the government. In her trip to Africa last month, Ms. Albright pledged to pick up half the cost of the next round of regional peace talks on Sudan. This summer, the administration appointed a special envoy to Sudan. But the appointment angered the Sudanese, who saw it as meddling.
* Sit tight. Despite all the talk of a new, more muscular American policy toward Africa -- with greater trade and engagement -- some American officials say bluntly that the overriding aim is not to get too involved in a faraway place like Sudan.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY;
After-Hours Trading: Managers Aren't Thrilled

BYLINE: By RICHARD TEITELBAUM 

 BODY:
After-hours trading is upon us. But who will be doing the buying and selling when the Nasdaq market and New York Stock Exchange start staying open past their current closing time of 4 p.m.? Nasdaq is in the midst of the transition, and the Big Board will make the change next year.
A survey conducted by Midwood Securities, a brokerage firm in New York, suggests that the traders will not be mutual funds, pension funds or insurance companies. In October, the firm surveyed 700 institutional money managers with assets of $500 million to $500 billion; 60 percent of those responding said they would probably not participate in extended trading hours, and of the remainder, almost all said they thought that it would not play an essential role in their business. 
 "If institutions had their way, we wouldn't be extending the hours," said Terry L. March, chief executive of Midwood.
When asked about potential benefits of extended hours, 51 percent said they did not expect any. About one-quarter felt that it would be useful in reacting to company and industry news, economic or political developments and earnings reports.
The managers were also asked about their concerns over after-hours trading. Some 65 percent of the respondents said they were worried about a possible lack of liquidity and 63 percent cited the prospects of increased volatility.
So who are the likely beneficiaries of extended trading? No surprise there -- 68 percent of the managers cited the computerized trading systems known as electron ic communication networks, or E.C.N.'s, many of which already offer after-hours trading.
 RICHARD TEITELBAUM

HEADLINE: Cohen's Top Feat May Be Monetary, Not Military

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10

 BODY:
Of all the offensives he has mounted as secretary of defense, William S. Cohen, a Republican, might be remembered less for the military operations than for persuading a reluctant Democratic president to sign this year's $17 billion spending increase for the Pentagon.
Within that one measure, the members of the armed services received their largest pay increase since 1981, and the Defense Department got its biggest budget increase since the end of the cold war. 
 The budget ends the so-called peace dividend, or nearly 10 years of shrinking armed forces and military budgets after the collapse of Communism in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. And the budget finances the possible deployment of a national missile defense system that has thrown into question decades of arms control treaties.
As the only Republican member of the cabinet, Mr. Cohen was tapped to become the administration's voice on tough national security policies before the Republican-controlled Congress. Instead, Mr. Cohen, a former senator from Maine, may have accomplished the opposite and sold a Republican agenda -- including the military increase -- to President Clinton, who already had a reputation for stealing Republican ideas.
When Mr. Cohen asked Congress to support Mr. Clinton's military spending bill, the only complaint was that it was not big enough. Republicans added $5 billion, increasing the military pay raise and finding money for projects in some of their home districts, so that the military budget for the year totals $268 billion.
With some reluctance the president signed the bill, making the United States military the biggest beneficiary of the federal budget surplus.
For Mr. Cohen, the increase was essential. "If you don't have an adequate budget, you don't get the increases, you don't keep the people, and you don't have a military," Mr. Cohen said in an interview in his office in the Pentagon's executive wing, with its wall of windows facing the Potomac River. "Things tend to deteriorate. We were in that process of things going down, and now we've brought it back up.
What Mr. Cohen called deterioration stemmed from the defense priorities of NATO nations, priorities he now challenges. After the fall of the Berlin Wall 10 years ago this week ended the Communist threat in Europe, the countries in the Atlantic alliance scaled back their military spending in favor of social and economic programs. Now Mr. Cohen is openly pushing the European allies to follow the United States with major increases in their military budgets once again.
He has some allies. Lord Robertson, the new secretary general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said in a visit here that one of his top goals was to convince the European allies that they would have to expand military spending to field modern forces.
"We've got to get to the point where we could do another Kosovo," Lord Robertson said.
On the other side of the ledger, Mr. Cohen failed to persuade Congress to support the administration's more contentious policies. Last month, Republican opposition led to the defeat of the nuclear test ban treaty. But Mr. Cohen refuses to take responsibility for that failure.
"Don't put that on me," said Mr. Cohen, who was called back from an Asian trip to do last-minute lobbying.
Earlier this year, he failed to overcome the Congressional propensity to hold onto local jobs and contracts and could not deliver the votes to close military bases the Pentagon said were no longer necessary. Closing of the bases could have saved the Defense Department billions of dollars in coming years.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is running for President, defended Mr. Cohen, an ally and friend, saying that the defense secretary should not be blamed for losing those battles supported by Mr. Clinton. At the same time, Mr. McCain said, the defense secretary himself did not deserve credit for the spending increases, which the senator said the Republicans would have passed anyway.
But Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, who once worked for Mr. Cohen, said she gave him credit for persuading the president to sign the big budget increase instead of provoking a fight with the Republican-controlled Congress over military spending.
"I'm sure he got the president to sign," Senator Collins said, echoing the perception among Republicans in Congress that Mr. Cohen overcame the president's economic advisers, who had urged a smaller increase for the Pentagon.
But to some, this budget victory signifies that Mr. Cohen has failed to live up to his reputation as an independent thinker, first earned as a young congressman who broke party ranks to vote with Democrats to release the tapes of President Richard M. Nixon in the Watergate investigation.
He has avoided fights with the entrenched Pentagon bureaucracy. His travels are intended to hold together this country's longtime relationships, whether in the Middle East or Asia. And his backing of a national missile defense system to protect Americans from a limited attack by an emerging nuclear power or an accidental missile launching by a major one is the endorsement of a plan that has been on the Republican agenda for years. The plan is a scaled-down version of the "Star Wars" program of the 1980's.
"We're closer to the old cold war Pentagon than we were three years ago," said John Pike, director of programs at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group here.
 
Keeping in Step With the President
Unlike Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, with her backing of forceful military responses to halt extreme human rights violations abroad, Mr. Cohen has kept a low profile in debates over the contentious matters of war and peace.
Perhaps as a result, the air campaign over Kovoso has become known as Madeleine's war, which is fine with Mr. Cohen -- so long as he and the Defense Department get credit for winning that conflict.
"If it's her war, then it's the department's peace," he said.
Samuel F. Berger, the president's national security adviser and the other member of the triumvirate that makes security policy, described Mr. Cohen as modest.
"He is one of the few people who underestimates his own accomplishments," Mr. Berger said.
At the Pentagon, Mr. Cohen is called reserved, cautious and, at times, distant. When he arrived, Mr. Cohen kept on nearly all of the political appointments who were there, adding only three aides. He also followed the basic military plan left by his predecessor, William J. Perry.
"I wanted to continue what he had started," Mr. Cohen said.
He kept in step with Mr. Clinton by initiating programs to protect against the threat of biological, chemical and nuclear terrorist attacks.
Apart from the two military operations fought under his watch, in Iraq and Serbia, Mr. Cohen made his biggest waves with his budget increase and the first financing to deploy a national missile defense system. The first installment of the defensive missile system, which is prohibited under the Antiballistic Missile Treaty signed with Moscow in 1972, would be built in Alaska as a shield to protect all 50 states against attacks by rogue states, in particular North Korea.
Mr. Cohen and his aides say they believe the Russians will agree to modify that treaty -- even though the Russians have said they will not. Instead, Moscow is asking the United Nations to help keep the treaty in tact and stop the United States from deploying a missile defense system.
The ABM treaty remains the cornerstone of most subsequent arms reduction agreements.
 
Growing Into Role Of Military Chief
Shortly after Mr. Cohen appointed Gen. Henry H. Shelton chairman of the joint chiefs of staff two years ago, the general presented the secretary with a book to set the tone for their relationship. The book was "Dereliction of Duty; Lyndon Johnson, Robert McNamara, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and the Lies that Led to Vietnam," by H. R. McMaster (Harper Collins, 1997).
"It's what I never wanted to happen between us, the chairman and the secretary lying and going behind each other's backs," General Shelton said he told Mr. Cohen.
If anything, Mr. Cohen, who has never served in the armed forces, has become the ideal spokesman for the military, General Shelton said. "I trust him implicity to represent the armed forces point of view," the general said.
Mr. Cohen did so forcefully this year by persuading President Clinton to approve the Defense Department budget. Early in 1998, the chiefs put together their budget proposal, calling it "Houston -- We Have A Problem." In it, they set out a dire view of the effect of almost 10 years of shrinking military budgets, saying the cuts had imperiled the armed forces' ability to be ready for combat.
"Before we only had anecdotal evidence," General Shelton said. "This time we had the data we needed. We went up and got the secretary's support and he acknowledged we needed to do something, that we were not taking care of the troops."
In September, Mr. Cohen organized a symposium at the National Defense University, bringing together the joint chiefs and top overseas commanders to help him present the case for the huge budget increase to a special guest: Mr. Clinton.
Two events had helped pave the way for Mr. Clinton to accept the proposal. By early summer the Congressional Budget Office had reported that the budget surplus would run $43 billion to $63 billion. And just days earlier the Starr Report about Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky had been released, raising questions about his ability to survive as president.
All of a sudden there was money for an increase in military spending, and it made sense politically. The president and then the president's aides agreed to the raise.
"That's an extraordinary achievement in a budget that was otherwise static," said Mr. Berger, the national security adviser, who supported increasing the military budget.
As it turned out, Mr. Cohen found almost no opposition to the plan in Congress, which held relatively few hearings on the whole $268 billion spending bill.
Democrats and Republicans said it was reassuring to see their old colleague, Mr. Cohen, sitting across the table with the country's top military leaders, making the arguments for the Clinton administration.
"He's got such a mastery of detail that he can show his case in a strong way," said Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, the ranking minority member of the Armed Services Committee. "Particularly with the end of the cold war, it's kind of counterintuitive that the defense budget should be increased."
