HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Lions Discover Life After Sanders

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN 

 BODY:
Joe Louis Arena in Detroit was packed last month with more than 17,000 people waiting excitedly for the boxer Prince Naseem Hamed to enter the ring. Before Hamed did, the announcer introduced two hometown guys, one of them Barry Sanders.
Sanders, perhaps the most popular athlete in the city's history, was booed. 
 And it was not just a smattering of boos. There were many of them, and they were throaty, heartfelt boos.
Last Sunday, Detroit Coach Bobby Ross had just led his Sanders-less and Herman Moore-less team past the St. Louis Rams to push the Lions' record to 6-2. As Ross was walking off the Silverdome field, he did so to cheers and to one fan's screaming, "Bobby, you're my hero!"
This is called flipping the script. When Sanders decided to quit the team last July, Ross was the villain and Sanders was the hero sticking up for his rights, tired of playing for a team that did not know how to use him and was a constant loser. Ross's job status was even questioned. He was the one who lost Barry Sanders, and he would eventually pay for it.
Then something funny happened on Ross's way to the unemployment line. He showed what a masterly a coach he is, taking a team without its top two stars in Sanders and Moore, a Pro Bowl wide receiver, who has nursed several injuries all year, and guiding it to a 3-0 division mark.
So suddenly Ross is a demigod, and Sanders is one of the most disliked people in and around Detroit. Is this "The X-Files"?
"Nothing surprises me anymore," Ross said last week, chuckling when asked if he was shocked by the Lions' success. "This has been a wild year for us, but it shows what happens if as a team you give yourself a chance."
When it comes to Sanders, Detroit now has a chip on its shoulder. The Lions were angry when most members of the news media assumed they would take a swan dive in the standing without their Pro Bowl running back on the roster. Of course, that was an understandable presumption. How many teams can withstand the loss of their star player and still survive?
Statistically, Detroit isn't doing as well on offense as it did with Sanders last season. At this point last year, the Lions had 1,132 yards rushing, compared with 783 yards now. Total yardage last year at this point was 2,648 yards, against 2,385 now.
But Ross has managed to turn the loss of Sanders into a positive. The Lions have rallied around his absence, and Ross's more conservative game plans have worked. The defense, which against the Rams had all 11 starters on the field for the first time this season, has been outstanding, as have the special teams. Kicker Jason Hanson has connected on 16 of 17 field goals, with half his conversions coming from 47 yards or more. He has hit twice each from 47, 48 and 49 yards and once each from 50 and 51 yards. His accuracy has given Detroit the edge in close games.
The Lions now seem offended when asked about Sanders. "Barry Sanders has nothing to do with this team," safety Ron Rice said last week. "We were 5-11 last year with him. Barry is probably at home watching our games. If you guys see him, tell him I said hi."
As Mike Holmgren showed in Seattle by refusing to bow to the salary demands of his star player, Joey Galloway, the Lions demonstrated that no single player is bigger than the team, even if that player is a future Hall of Famer.
The team owner, William Clay Ford, was asked what would he say if Sanders called. "I'm not going to play that game," he said.
Has he spoken to Sanders recently? "No, nothing has changed," Ford said. "We haven't talked to Barry and Barry hasn't spoken to us."
The current rumor is that Sanders will be traded to Washington next season, though a Redskins official strongly denied that, saying the club had not even thought about acquiring him. Sanders may still return to Detroit, though the chances of that happening are extremely slim.
But if he does return to the Lions, Sanders, for the first time, will have to adjust to the Lions, instead of the Lions having to adjust to him.
 
The Cast Is Changing
This has been one of the quirkiest seasons in a long time, maybe the strangest of this decade, and the novelty of unfamiliar teams dominating the National Football League is being reflected in the fan portion of the Pro Bowl balloting. Fans began voting Nov. 1, and four of the top six vote-getters thus far have never played in the annual Hawaii game.
The top 10 vote-getters as of late last week are: Indianapolis quarterback Peyton Manning (33,380), St. Louis quarterback Kurt Warner (31,547), St. Louis running back Marshall Faulk (29,447), Indianapolis running back Edgerrin James (26,802), New England quarterback Drew Bledsoe (26,328), Indianapolis wide receiver Marvin Harrison (26,009), Tampa Bay fullback Mike Alstott (25,965), St. Louis wide receiver Isaac Bruce (25,380), Washington quarterback Brad Johnson (25,368) and Tennessee running back Eddie George (22,705).
Other Pro Bowl voting tidbits:
*Washington's Champ Bailey is the leading vote-getter among National Football Conference rookies and is second to Dallas's Deion Sanders among all N.F.C. cornerbacks.
*Bailey's teammate Stephen Davis is second to Faulk among N.F.C. running backs.
*Tennessee defensive lineman Jevon Kearse leads all American Football Conference defensive rookies and is second to New England's Willie McGinest among the conference's defensive ends.
*Orlando Pace of St. Louis leads all N.F.C. tackles. His teammate Adam Timmerman is third among the conference's guards.
*Minnesota's Randall McDaniel leads all N.F.C. guards and can increase his league record to 11 consecutive starts in a Pro Bowl.
*Miami's Olindo Mare leads all kickers and has more votes than Doug Flutie, Bruce Smith, Dan Marino, Keyshawn Johnson and Troy Aikman.
Fan voting counts for one-third of the total balloting for the Pro Bowl, with two-thirds split between players and coaches. They vote Dec. 20-21.
 
Boom! He's Got It
One of the most bizarre incidents of the season happened during the Minnesota-Dallas game in the Metrodome last Monday night, and it infuriated Vikings players and coaches.
Vikings wide receiver Cris Carter was running a pass route in the back of the end zone during the fourth quarter when quarterback Jeff George spotted him. George threw the ball and Carter caught it for a 4-yard touchdown pass to give Minnesota a 20-17 lead.
Carter's catch was a tribute to his concentration. A second before the ball landed in Carter's hands, a deafening cannon explosion sounded because the operator of a special cannon and fireworks display pushed the trigger too early. Amazingly, Carter didn't seem distracted.
Vikings players and coaches were furious after the game. And understandably, the operator of the cannon will no longer be near the controls.

HEADLINE: The Most Innovative Figure in Silicon Valley? Maybe This Labor Organizer

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
With a Prada bag and the air of an entrepreneur, Amy Dean is an unlikely labor trailblazer.
But as head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Silicon Valley office, Ms. Dean, at just 37 years of age, has become the labor movement's chief navigator, its Christopher Columbus in the roiling and uncharted seas of the new economy. 
 Working in a flourishing, free-wheeling valley that has hardly welcomed the often stodgy labor movement, she spends her days thinking up ways for unions to be relevant to workers in booming high-tech companies, and labor leaders nationwide are tripping over themselves to copy her ideas.
To help the valley's horde of temporary workers who have no health insurance, she has taken the unorthodox step of creating a nonprofit temp agency that, unlike most profit-making agencies, offers health coverage that temporary workers can afford.
She has established a research institute that has reshaped California's economic debate by churning out weighty studies, including one on the growing gulf between the haves and have-nots in a valley often thought to have mostly millionaire haves.
Through a full-court political press, she and her army of union members have pressured San Jose to enact the country's highest living-wage law, requiring city contractors to pay workers at least $9.50 an hour, nearly double the minimum wage many were earning.
And she has proposed using a hiring-hall concept to provide uninterrupted health and pension benefits to high-tech workers, who often jump from job to job.
"She's a new breed of labor leader," said Harley Shaiken, a professor of industrial relations at the University of California at Berkeley. "She's put a number of issues about Silicon Valley on the public agenda -- inequality, temporary workers and the lack of affordable housing. She's hit nerves in a way that resonates."
Her goal, Ms. Dean acknowledges, is nothing short of turning the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Silicon Valley operation into a model for the rebirth of the labor movement, just as the valley's entrepreneurs have brought about a rebirth of American industry.
So far Ms. Dean's efforts have made a difference in the lives of many of the valley's have-nots. But all her strategizing has failed to strike a chord with the valley's haves, like software designers, who, happy with their stock options, often think unions are as useful as manual typewriters. Her biggest challenge is figuring out a way for unions to connect to these high-tech workers.
Her exploits, especially the living-wage law, are already irking many business executives, fueling worries that labor's growing power is signaling that a valley renowned as a fertile ground for entrepreneurs is turning unfriendly to business.
Ms. Dean put on such a bravura performance in pushing through the living-wage ordinance that business executives speak of her with equal parts awe and anxiety, fearing what her next battleground will be.
When the San Jose City Council was debating the wage ordinance Ms. Dean, all 5-feet-3 of her, came on like a petite field marshal. She packed the chamber with allies, lined up clergymen and community leaders to testify, and, in a sure-voiced speech, nearly brought down the house.
"There's part of me that envies her because she's so good at making an emotional, passionate pitch," said Steve Tedesco, president of the San Jose Silicon Valley Chamber of Commerce, who fought the living-wage proposal, saying it would hurt San Jose's business image. "She's tenacious. She doesn't tilt at windmills."
Instead, she tilts at what she views as economic injustice, and she does so by mobilizing the valley's union movement to back her crusades. Five years ago, Ms. Dean took the helm of the South Bay Central Labor Council, becoming the youngest person to head one of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s 600 local councils.
While many of her fellow Generation X'ers see unions as irrelevant and outmoded, Ms. Dean says she is devoting her life to labor because she is convinced it is the only movement that can lift America's have-nots and stop the nation's rightward tilt.
"Why do I spend so much time in the heart of this new economy working with unions to build a voice for working people?" she said. "It has everything to do with whether we can revitalize an institution that so many people in this country depend on. It's the only vehicle in this country that can balance the political landscape."
Ms. Dean is a rara avis in labor, a movement not exactly known for promoting women, the young or those who spout new ideas. In a movement in which entrepreneurship is usually considered the enemy, she is an entrepreneur par excellence. And in a movement where blue jeans are favored, she wears pumps and gold bracelets, although her Ann Taylor look has not stopped her from earning the nickname the Mother Jones of Silicon Valley.
Convinced that the labor movement should be a social movement, Ms. Dean has refocused the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s operation here so it helps not just unionized workers, but all workers, especially those, like janitors and temps, on the bottom rungs.
When Ms. Dean took labor's helm here, many high-flying high-tech companies were using cleaning contractors that paid their janitors the minimum wage and scant benefits. So, working with the Service Employees International Union, she led a Justice for Janitors campaign to pressure and embarrass giants like Apple Computer so they would force their cleaning contractors to pay janitors higher wages and grant union recognition.
"The labor movement was strongest when we were the moral voice in the community," Ms. Dean said. "That's when people were attracted to us, wanted to be part of us, wanted to be mobilized into action with us. That's when we just weren't seen as a special members club for a few people. Our job has to be helping folks who don't have a voice."
Ms. Dean's central labor council represents 110,000 unionized workers: carpenters, nurses, teachers, but precious few high-tech workers. She acknowledges that labor's traditional contracts-are-everything model is largely irrelevant to high-tech workers because it is based on a 1930's notion of people working at industrial behemoths, not agile start-ups, and of workers spending decades at one corporation, not jumping like grasshoppers between companies.
Recognizing this, Ms. Dean has become the foremost exponent of a provocative theory: that labor should return to its craft guild and hiring hall roots as a way to keep up with the fast-changing high-tech world.
For high-tech workers, who often hold 10 jobs over a career, constantly losing and regaining health and pension coverage, Mr. Dean says unions should be a source of stability and protection. No other institution, she says, is as well-equipped to provide such workers with the two things they say they need most: portable benefits and continual upgrading of their skills.
Like the craft guilds of old, she says, unions could provide high-tech workers with classes in the latest skills, like writing new software languages, and could provide certification that workers have attained specific skill levels.
Then, like construction unions, which have hiring halls, unions could become the place high-tech employers turn to for trained workers. Also like construction unions, high-tech unions could provide uninterrupted health and pension coverage for workers who jump from job to job.
"Is the current model that unions are offering relevant to the knowledge workers of today? No." Ms. Dean said. "Are the principles and benefits that unions offer relevant? Yes."
Hers is a compelling vision for high-tech unions, but if she builds it, there is little guarantee that high-tech workers will come.
Ms. Dean has come a long way from the mid-1980's, when, having just graduated from the University of Illinois, she was planning to pursue a Ph.D. in public policy at the University of Chicago.
But inspired by a grandmother who organized apparel factories, she left academia for a job as an organizer for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in her native Chicago.
In 1989, she moved to San Francisco for that union, partly to follow the man, now an Internet entrepreneur, who would become her husband. Soon she was climbing the ladder at labor's Silicon Valley office, where she made such a mark that John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, tapped her to head a national committee charged with recommending ways to rev up the nation's local labor councils.
Her most innovative work has come in seeking to help the thousands of temporary workers who flood in and out of high-tech companies -- secretaries, clerks, bookkeepers, software testers.
Aided by foundation grants, she has set up a nonprofit agency that is placing temporary workers, for the most part secretaries, who start at $10 an hour, compared with the $8.50 paid by many agencies. Unlike most for-profit agencies, her agency offers low-cost health coverage, paid sick leave and paid holidays and works with a community college to furnish subsidized courses to upgrade the workers' skills.
Ms. Dean has also set up an association, in essence a fledgling union, where temporary workers can compare notes, air grievances and map strategies to win better working conditions. The latest idea is to pressure agencies to adhere to a code of conduct requiring health insurance and a respectable wage.
Eileen Wodula, a secretary tired of bouncing between jobs, said, "This is like a dream come true because it's giving a voice to temporary workers."

HEADLINE: Furor Rises In Canada Over Hunt For Grizzly

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: KHUTZE INLET, British Columbia

 BODY:
Harry McCowan, a grizzly-bear hunting guide, looked harassed.
Boatloads of nature tourists were buzzing up and down this coastal rain forest waterway. Mr. McCowan's taciturn Austrian hunting client was emitting signals of impatience, and while a helper loaded rifles and supplies into a seaplane, a black bear started pawing through the camp. 
 "There are too many people here," grumbled the veteran guide, whose seaplane was stenciled: "Selling the last frontier." While the helper sent the curious black bear bounding back into the woods, he continued: "I used to have a grizzly quota of nine, now I have one. I used to kill three or four. Now, with luck, I will take one."
But judging by the protests at Canada's overseas consulates and the petitions regularly dumped on the desk of the provincial minister of environment, Mr. McCowan may be fortunate to get even that.
British Columbia, which in the 1880's marketed itself in Europe as the "sportsman's Eden," is increasingly defensive about its status as the last Canadian province to allow a major grizzly bear hunt. From an average of 350 grizzlies killed each year through 1992, the annual "harvest" dropped last year to 207.
Under pressure, the province is quietly restricting hunting of one what are among North America's largest land mammals. Under a lottery system introduced two years ago, only a quarter of the residents who apply get permits to hunt the bears. Areas along the border with the United States have been largely placed off-limits to hunting, following American complaints that a grizzly protected under the United States Endangered Species Act can be shot if it wanders across the border.
Toronto's Globe and Mail, echoing the sentiment of many Canadians, wrote in a recent editorial about the grizzly, "Given the scientific uncertainties about how many there are, the knowledge that the population is not large and the fact that the hunt serves no purpose, except giving hunters pleasure, why should it continue?"
Environmentalists agree. "Trophy hunting of North America's slowest-reproducing mammal is just unacceptable," Wayne McCrory, a bear biologist, said over the mess table of a tourist sloop that rocked at anchor here one recent evening. "We wiped them out from half of their range in Canada, and yet we continue to allow them to be hunted here."
As nature tourism soars on Canada's Pacific Coast, grizzly bear hunting shrivels in economic importance. Last year, according to the Environment Ministry, the grizzly hunt generated $700,000 in economic activity, compared with $2.5 billion generated by tourism as a whole.
"The whole concept, in this day and age, does not work that one person, for a few moments of glory, can go out and shoot a grizzly and put it on the wall of his den," said Eric Boyum, the skipper of the tourist ship. "That same bear could live its life, perpetuate the species, and, for tourism, could provide an experience, for many people, not just one."
Environmentalists also say that by having a spring and fall grizzly-hunting season, the province unwittingly provides cover to poachers, who sell bear claws and gall bladders to be marketed in Asia, where they are prized as delicacies. The Environment Ministry estimates that poachers kill up to 200 grizzlies a year.
"Poaching is happening all the time," said Merran Smith, a Sierra Club forest campaigner who lives in northern British Columbia. "In the valley just next door, a bear was found with its paws cut off. The paws and gall bladder go for the Chinese market."
In addition, every year wildlife officers kill about 50 grizzlies deemed a threat to humans. The bears kill about one human a year in the province.
In a fight over numbers, Environment Ministry officials estimate there are about 12,000 grizzlies in the province, while Mr. McCrory and other environmentalists estimate that there are only half that number. In neighboring Alberta, on the eastern side of the Continental Divide, there are about 800 grizzlies. Alberta keeps alive a tiny hunt, issuing about a dozen licenses a year.
In British Columbia, where the professional basketball team is the Vancouver Grizzlies, polls show that city dwellers oppose the hunt while rural residents support it. The Guide Outfitters Association of British Columbia, which represents 237 licensed guides, argues that hunting keeps grizzlies wary of humans and provides jobs to economically depressed rural communities.
Outfitters here say that a ban on hunting grizzlies would simply mean that wealthy hunters would fly over British Columbia to Alaska, where up to 1,200 grizzlies are shot every year. While grizzlies in the lower 48 states are protected as an endangered species, Alaska, where the population is estimated at 65,000, has a fall and spring season.

HEADLINE: Flat Tax Goes From 'Snake Oil' to G.O.P. Tonic

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Four years ago, when Steve Forbes first promoted the idea of a flat tax, he was ridiculed by his fellow Republicans. "A truly nutty idea," said Lamar Alexander. Others, like Bob Dole and Newt Gingrich, heaped scorn, calling it everything from "snake oil" to "voodoo."
But in last month's New Hampshire forum among five Republican presidential candidates, when the question "Do you favor a flat tax?" was posed, three candidates said they favored throwing out the existing federal income tax code and replacing it with a one-rate plan. 
 "Sure, I'm for a flat tax," said Senator John McCain, who said he wanted a system so simple that a tax return could fit on a postcard. The conservative Gary Bauer boasted that his 16 percent flat tax was better than anyone else's.
And Mr. Forbes, who made the flat tax the centerpiece of his 1996 presidential bid, said he was happy that other Republicans were "coming on board."
What a difference four years makes. The flat tax -- having a single income tax rate for all American taxpayers instead of the current graduated set of rates -- is slowly gaining ground as a campaign issue in the Republican presidential race, much the way that school vouchers moved from a back-burner issue popular mainly among conservatives to one that is now embraced by all Republican candidates.
For Mr. Forbes, who has since added other conservative issues to his agenda, this is a bittersweet victory. While other candidates are stealing some of his flat-tax thunder, he can take credit for putting the issue on the political map. "It's almost an unalloyed blessing," Mr. Forbes, who advocates a flat 17 percent income tax, said in an interview. "But people just like it. They feel they are burdened by taxes and are really becoming very enthusiastic about it."
So far, the idea has yet to filter down to Congressional races, and the Republican front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, does not support it. But analysts say it has undeniably potent appeal.
"The flat tax is not quite Republican dogma yet," said Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist and president of Policy Impact Communications, a public relations firm. "But it is something that most Republican candidates want to be for. The flat tax resonates strongly with core Republicans, and it has broad appeal across party and demographic lines. We've seen this before with school vouchers."
Grover Norquist, executive director of Americans for Tax Reform, a Republican anti-tax group, added: "Not everyone will have a completely written-out plan like Forbes. But they are all saying, 'That's the direction I want to go.' "
That direction is to reduce federal income tax rates across the board and provide a huge tax cut on a scale not seen in more than a decade. Tax experts on all points of the political spectrum say the rich will benefit more than the poor. Flat-tax proponents are playing to sentiment against Washington, especially the Internal Revenue Service.
One of Mr. Forbes's biggest applause lines is his vow to abolish the I.R.S.: "Take this monster, kill it, put a stake through its heart and make sure it never rises again to terrorize the American people."
And less money flowing to Washington means less government -- another goal of Republican conservatives. Backers of the flat tax say the economy would prosper even more if tax dollars now sent to Washington were left in private hands.
Liberal critics dislike the flat tax for the same reasons that it is gaining popularity among conservatives: because it would deprive the government of money, and top income tax rates would drop. The Forbes plan would reduce tax receipts to the government by $50 billion a year.
"There are two things that the flat tax is fronting for," said William G. Gale, a tax expert at the Brookings Institution, a Washington research group. "One is tax cuts for the rich -- though while not talking about it and putting it into the guise of simplicity or fairness. And it is an attack on government. It makes more sense to complain about how high taxes are rather than to attack all these wonderful benefits the government is bestowing on the people. The flat tax is a proxy for both those things."
A Republican who remains cool to a flat tax is Mr. Bush, who advocates flattening marginal tax rates by reducing them and eliminating estate taxes. But he has not endorsed a single-rate tax and has said he will have a more detailed tax proposal before the year's end.
Congress, too, has not embraced the idea, even though major elements of a flat tax -- eliminating estate taxes and reducing taxes on wages and capital gains -- have been proposed by various Republicans on Capitol Hill.
The flat tax that Mr. Forbes is pushing would change the entire theory of taxation embedded in the United States Tax Code. It would abolish the current progressive tax system -- one in which lower-income people are taxed at lower rates and higher-income people at higher rates -- and replace it with a single tax rate for everyone, rich or poor.
Current federal income tax rates on wages go from 15 percent to 39.6 percent. For instance, a family earning under $43,000 has a tax rate of 15 percent, one earning over $104,000 has a tax rate of 31 percent and a family earning over $283,000 pays at a rate of 39.6 percent. These are the marginal rates, or what people pay on the last dollars earned.
Of course, taxpayers now have a variety of ways to whittle their taxable income to fall into a lower tax bracket -- everything from mortgage interest payments, to donations to charities, to payments for child care, education and health care can be deducted to reduce taxable income.
A flat tax would replace this progressive system with a one-rate plan; under Mr. Forbes's proposal, for instance, both Bill Gates and the factory worker would pay the same 17 percent of income in taxes. In addition, there would be no deductions, like those for home mortgages, although some politicians, including Mr. Forbes, are beginning to soften on the issue.
Earnings from investments -- capital gains from stock and bond sales and dividend and interest income -- would not be taxed at all. Capital gains are now taxed at a 20 percent rate, and interest and dividends at the same rate as wages.
"The tax system we have now is steeply progressive," said Steve Moore, a flat-tax advocate and director of fiscal policies at the Cato Institute, a Washington nonprofit organization. "The wealthiest 1 percent are paying around one-third of all taxes, and the bottom 50 percent of the people pay only 4 percent of the burden. Anything you do to flatten tax rates will lead to lower taxes on the rich and more to those on the bottom."
Moreover, under a flat tax, it is possible for a wealthy person who lives solely off income from an investment portfolio to pay no taxes at all, while someone working in a factory or driving a cab faces a 17 percent tax bill. To many, the prospect of such glaring inequities between rich and working class is the plan's political Achilles' heel.
"I don't think the flat tax will work for a lot of reasons," said Michael J. Graetz, a professor at Yale Law School and a tax policy official in the Bush administration. "As it's been proposed, it involves a massive tax cut for the very best-off people in society. There will be questions as to why a tax cut ought to be concentrated in that group."
He said taxpayers in the $75,000 to $150,000 income range would be hurt the most under a flat tax.
This is an especially sensitive political point for Mr. Forbes, whose $440 million net worth comes from inherited wealth, and for Republicans in general, as the party tries to shake an elitist image and appeal to new and less-affluent constituencies.
For corporations, taxes would fall to 17 percent from 35 percent under the Forbes plan. In addition, the flat tax would allow corporations to deduct the costs of capital improvements in a single year, rather than spreading them out over time. This would favor young and fast-growing companies, which could see their tax bills wiped out entirely, over older businesses, whose years of heavy capital spending are behind them. A company like, say, Intel, a computer chip maker, would benefit under a flat tax, while older manufacturers like the General Motors Corporation could be hurt, tax experts say.
Corporations would see all other deductions wiped out under a flat tax, and many critics worry that once the tax code no longer provides deductions for workers' benefits -- especially health insurance -- companies will stop providing them.
"Flat-tax advocates are being completely deceptive when they say they are closing loopholes," said Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a Washington nonprofit group. "Au contraire. Calling it a loophole-closing plan is a misnomer. This is more of a loophole-consolidations plan. It's saving the tax breaks that matter -- those that favor the high end and some corporations."
Mr. Forbes defends his flat tax by saying that the economic growth it would unleash would be so great that all Americans, even the poorest, would benefit from new-found wealth. And he said $50 billion in lost tax revenues to the government from a flat tax could be covered by the current $200 billion budget surplus -- which, Mr. Forbes said, should be dedicated to tax relief.
He also predicted that a flat tax would cause the nation's economy, which is already operating at full employment, to grow by 4 percent to 4.5 percent a year.
Yet those rosy predictions have been greeted with skepticism. "Forbes is proposing an enormous tax cut that drawfs anything Congressional Republicans were proposing this year," said J. D. Foster, a former Bush tax adviser and head of the Tax Foundation, a Washington nonprofit organization.
"And he says that the economy, which is now cruising at a 3 percent real growth rate, will suddenly jump to 4.5 percent. Most economists have dismissed that out of hand. Short of annexing Mexico and some Asian countries, I don't know where you get that growth rate."
Moreover, even flat-tax proponents say that Mr. Forbes's 17 percent rate is too drastic a cut in government financing. A 1996 Treasury analysis said a flat tax rate of 20.8 percent would be needed to raise the same revenues as the current system. Even a flat-tax supporter like Mr. Moore of the Cato Institute said a 20 percent tax rate is more realistic -- "17 percent is probably too low."
And if Republicans succumb to political pressure and begin to give back popular deductions -- like the mortgage interest deduction -- tax experts estimate that the number might have to climb even higher.
Even Mr. Forbes is softening his plan. He is offering personal exemptions of up to $36,000 for a family of four. This means that the actual taxes paid under his plan could drop to as low as 10.9 percent for a family earning more than $100,000, a 33 percent tax cut, according to Mr. Forbes's campaign literature. His plan would also allow taxpayers to stick with the current tax system if it worked to their financial advantage.
"What you are beginning to see is a kinder and gentler flat tax," Mr. Moore said. "It isn't the same product talked about four years ago; it's a little more of a politically strategic version. The question is how do you get popular appeal for the flat tax, without all the baggage?"

Here is what Republican candidates for president are saying about taxes, according to each candidate's campaign Web site:
 
GARY BAUER -- "Our current tax code is needlessly complex and deeply unfair. It has been written by lobbyists and special interests who could care less about average Americans."
 
He proposes: A 16 percent flat tax on individuals and corporations. No corporate deductions allowed. Families would receive a $1,400 per person tax credit. Home mortgage and charitable deductions would be retained. Capital gains would be taxed at a 16 percent rate. Estate taxes would be eliminated.
 
GEORGE W. BUSH -- "It is conservative to cut taxes and compassionate to give people more money to spend."
 
He proposes: A cut in marginal tax rates, but does not specify rates. A phase-out of estate taxes. An increase in tax incentives for charitable giving and expansion of tax breaks for education.
 
STEVE FORBES -- "With more personal control you will be free to choose a less burdensome tax system that's simple, honest, fair and a real tax cut."
 
He proposes: A 17 percent flat tax on individuals and corporations, with existing deductions eliminated. Investment income would not be taxed. Estate taxes would be eliminated. Each taxpayer would get an exemption of $13,000 per adult and $5,000 per child. Corporations could deduct capital investments in one year.
 
JOHN McCAIN -- "It is essential that we provide American families with relief from the excessive rate of taxation that saps job growth and robs them of the opportunity to provide for their needs."
 
He proposes: Expansion of the 15 percent tax bracket, which is the lowest. Elimination of estate taxes and the so-called marriage penalty. Simplification of the income tax code and elimination of "special interest loopholes." (pg. 30)

HEADLINE: ANNUAL SPENDING ON MEDICARE DIPS FOR THE FIRST TIME

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Medicare spending declined in the most recent fiscal year for the first time in the history of the program, even as private health insurance plans reported increases of 4 percent to 10percent, new government data show.
The decline was slight -- 1 percent from 1998 to 1999 -- but significant because Medicare has grown every year since its creation in 1965. 
 The reduction in Medicare spending surprised many experts on health policy. Medicare had been growing 10 percent a year when Congress curbed Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and nursing homes in 1997. Lawmakers said then that they intended to slow the growth of Medicare, but they never expected to reverse it.
The savings stem from many causes, including cuts made by Congress, low inflation and efforts to rein in fraud. Those conditions may prove temporary, experts said. Even so, they could relieve worries about the program's long-term stability and make it easier for Congress to provide coverage of prescription drugs or other benefits.
The federal fiscal year 1999 ended on Sept. 30. In April, the Clinton administration reported a slight decline in Medicare spending for the first half of the fiscal year, but said it was a fluke, not a trend. In June, the White House was still forecasting an increase in Medicare spending for the full fiscal year.
But new statistics from the Treasury belie those predictions. Medicare spending fell 1 percent, to $212 billion in the most recent fiscal year, from $213.6 billion in the prior year.
By contrast, when the Balanced Budget Act was passed in 1997, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the government would spend $231 billion on Medicare in 1999 -- or $19 billion more than was actually spent.
"The decline in Medicare spending is a phenomenal development," said Robert D. Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, "considering the increase in the number of beneficiaries and the resurgence of rapid growth in health costs in the private sector."
In a recent survey of 600 large employers, Hewitt Associates, a consulting concern, found that the cost of their employee health benefits increased by an average of 7.8 percent this year, the largest increase since the early 1990's.
One big difference between Medicare and private health plans is that Medicare generally does not cover prescription drugs.
A sharp increase in drug spending is widely cited as a major reason for the increase in the cost of private health plans. Drug manufacturers have developed dozens of effective but costly new medicines, and drug companies have encouraged greater use of their products through advertisements aimed at consumers.
President Clinton and Congressional Democrats are mobilizing a campaign to secure Medicare coverage of prescription drugs. The issue is sure to be hotly debated in next year's presidential election and in many Congressional races.
Medicare spending rose an average of 10 percent a year from 1990 to 1997, then climbed 1.5 percent in the fiscal year 1998.
The decline in Medicare spending in the last fiscal year means that more money remains in the Medicare trust fund to buy health care for people who are elderly or disabled. But it does not solve Medicare's long-term financial problems.
Medicare finances health care for more than 39 million people. The number of beneficiaries has increased about 1 percent a year and will grow faster as millions of baby boomers join the rolls after 2010.
Nobody can say for sure when the growth of Medicare spending will resume. The slowdown has already lasted longer than experts predicted. Congress and the White House agreed this week to restore some of the money cut in 1997. But the amount to be restored, averaging less than $2.5 billion a year, is relatively small, compared with total Medicare spending.
Health policy experts in and out of the government gave these reasons for the drop in Medicare spending:
*Hospitals and other health care providers, scared by the federal crackdown on Medicare fraud, have become more conservative in their billing practices and more diligent in trying to comply with federal rules.
*Hospital admissions for Medicare patients have unexpectedly declined. Even more surprising, the severity of illness for the average patient, as measured by the government, has also declined. So Medicare is paying less for the average patient than it otherwise would.
*Health care providers are taking more time to submit claims, perhaps because they have been preoccupied with efforts to prepare their computers for the year 2000. And the government has been slower in paying claims. These delays temporarily slow Medicare spending, but do not save money in the long run.
*Inflation has been lower than expected. This lowers Medicare spending because payments to health care providers usually include an allowance for inflation.
*In writing rules to carry out the 1997 law, the Clinton administration has restricted Medicare spending more than Congress intended.
The law established complex new formulas to pay health care providers. Marilyn Moon of the Urban Institute, a public trustee of the Medicare trust fund, said that confusion about the new payment rules might have depressed spending.
"A lot of health care providers don't know what to make of the new law and the new rules, so they take a go-slow approach," Ms. Moon said. "They are interpreting the regulations even more stringently than they have to."
William S. Custer, an economist at Georgia State University in Atlanta, said the Medicare cutbacks could indirectly contribute to increases in costs for private health insurers.
"Hospitals, doctors and other health care providers may be unable to give discounts to private health plans because of the financial constraints imposed on them by Medicare," Mr. Custer said. Many hospitals say Medicare does not fully cover their costs, so they find it difficult to cut prices for patients with private insurance.
More than six million Medicare beneficiaries, about 16 percent of all recipients, are in health maintenance organizations, and the number climbs a bit each month. In theory, H.M.O.'s can save money for Medicare.
But federal officials contend that because of flaws in the reimbursement formula, the government spends more, on the average, when patients join H.M.O.'s than it would spend on the same people if they were in Medicare's traditional fee-for-service program.
Enrollment in Medicare H.M.O.'s was lower than expected in the last year. Clinton administration officials cite that as another factor that helps explain why overall Medicare spending was lower than anticipated.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: NOVEMBER 8-12;
Financial Stocks Bask in the Limelight

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
Financial stocks are looking for a little respect, but that's asking a lot, given investors' love of all things technology of late.
Not only were financial stocks like American Express, Citigroup and J.P. Morgan in favor on Friday, but they helped push the Dow Jones industrials higher for the week, to close at 10,769.32. (The newfound enthusiasm did not come at the expense of technology stocks, which led the Nasdaq to its 10th record close in the last 11 sessions on Friday, to 3,221.15.) 
 On Friday, President Clinton signed into law the sweeping overhaul of Depression-era banking laws, opening doors for mergers among banks, securities firms and insurance companies.
Earlier in the day, investors gained confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise rates for a third time this year when the Federal Open Markets Committee meets on Tuesday. Two government reports indicated that inflation was in check.
Joseph Battipaglia, chief investment officer at Gruntal & Company, told Bloomberg News, The economy has overall strength, and there is no inflation underneath it, so the Fed need not take any action next week.
 MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Visiting Pilgrims and Paul Revere

BYLINE: By SETH MARGOLIS; SETH MARGOLIS is a novelist who writes frequently about travel.

 BODY:
IN early October, with the leaves in Central Park just beginning to turn, a New England weekend beckoned as insistently as the beach in summer. My wife, Carole, and I quickly settled on the Boston area. Thanksgiving was approaching, and our children, Maggie, 9, and Jack, 7, knew little of their Colonial roots. We'd introduce them to Pilgrims and minutemen while squeezing in a some leaf peeping -- without breaking the bank, we hoped.
Alas, we weren't alone in thinking October an ideal month for a long weekend in the cradle of American democracy. Every hotel we called was booked solid for every weekend in October -- a popular time for parents to visit their children at the many colleges in and around Boston. The only room we found was at the Renaissance Hotel in Bedford, Mass., about a half-hour northwest of downtown Boston. We were planning to spend two of our three days outside Boston anyway, so we booked a room. 
 "Let's explore Colonial America!" isn't exactly a rallying cry for the Pokemon generation. When it comes to sightseeing, our kids require a steady stream of encouragement, snack breaks and outright bribes to keep them motivated. Luckily, Boston's Freedom Trail, our first destination, is packed with enough historical and gustatory distractions to keep even balky children from getting too cranky. In fact, the best part of the day for Maggie and Jack was following the trail's occasionally elusive red line as it snaked along sidewalks, across streets and into and out of sites -- a red brick road, not to Oz but into history.
Boston sparkled under a bright October sun. The growth in the technology and financial services industries have fueled a spate of new buildings and renovations in recent years. An early stop on the Freedom Trail, the Old State House, resembles a tiny Colonial jewel nestled in a setting of gleaming glass-and-steel skyscrapers. At the National Park Service visitor center across from the Old State House, by the way, you can pick up free activity books for kids; if they complete a series of projects along the trail, a ranger at the last stop will sign their books and anoint them junior park rangers.
At Faneuil Hall Marketplace, another early stop on the trail, the kids insisted on lunch, although it was only 11:15 a.m. Carole and I looked longingly at the stalls selling pot pies, fried clams and other New England treats, but the path of least resistance led to four oversized hot dogs, $2 apiece, followed by a bag of candy corn. "Trail mix," we called it, and headed back to the trail.
We went next to Paul Revere's house in the North End, following the Freedom Trail as it threaded under the elevated Interstate 93, which cuts off the North End and much of the waterfront from the rest of Boston. A huge construction project, "The Big Dig," will submerge this colossal urban mistake, while keeping the existing highway more or less operational. It's a hugely ambitious undertaking, the subject of its own interesting exhibit in a building opposite the New England Aquarium.
The Paul Revere house is a fragile-looking, Tudor-style wood structure whose 320-year survival seems a miracle in a neighborhood of densely packed 19th-century brick tenements. While waiting to enter ($2.50, children 5 to 17, $1), I launched into a minihistory lesson, beginning with "Listen my children and you shall hear" and ending with "The British are coming!"
A guide inside the house sternly informed us that Revere would never have shouted "The British are coming!" -- everyone in Boston was British! Another guide in the second-floor master bedroom encouraged Maggie to try on reproduction Colonial costumes, which brought the era alive for her.
We also took a guided tour of the adjoining Pierce-Hichborn House (also $2.50 and $1), a Georgian-style survivor from 1711 that lacks any important historical associations but offers a particularly good look at middle-class life in 18th-century Boston.
The last stop on the trail was the U.S.S. Constitution, completed in 1797 and anchored across the Charles River in Charlestown. Touring "Old Ironsides," the kids were intrigued by the guide's discussion of the 20 or so "powder monkeys," young children, commissioned for their small size and agility, whose job was to rush between decks during battles carrying powder up from the hold.
None of the guidebooks we'd consulted had bothered to point out the lack of bus or subway service back to Boston. We noticed a few beleaguered families calling for taxis, and were about to follow suit when we discovered a ferry nearby that runs every 15 minutes, costs just $1 and affords beautiful views of the Boston skyline. It deposited us on Long Wharf, right next to the New England Aquarium, thus deciding for us what to do next.
The centerpiece of the aquarium is a four-story tank teeming with sharks, giant turtles and a variety of exotic fish. For an entry fee of $12, $6 for children, visitors can climb or descend a circular ramp, Guggenheim Museum style, to view the marine life at various depths (and take in a sea lion show, which we missed). Jack got his second wind in the Aquarium, mimicking the fishes' strangely human expressions as they returned his gaze. We all welcomed the break from the 18th century.
Dinner soon beckoned. There's an outpost of the Legal Seafood chain directly across from the Aquarium, but somehow we weren't in the mood for fish. I'd heard that the South End was the new SoHo of Boston, so we took the subway back to our car and drove there for dinner. Tremont Street is the dining hub of the neighborhood, its sidewalks teeming with fashionable young Bostonians and lined with enticing restaurants and cafes. Most were neither wallet- nor kid-friendly, however, so we were fortunate to find the casual and inexpensive Mildred's, at 552 Tremont.
Later, the kids insisted on a swim in our hotel's indoor pool. Even at 9 p.m. there were several children splashing around. What the Renaissance lacked in central location it made up in value and amenities. Our attractive room, with two double beds, was just $99 -- you can't beat that rate in Boston. Besides the pool, the Renaissance has a small fitness center and indoor and outdoor tennis courts.
After touring Revolutionary America on Saturday, we traveled further back in time on Sunday to the nation's earliest roots, in Plymouth -- 45 minutes south of Boston. Plymouth Rock, where the pilgrims supposedly landed in 1620, is covered by an elaborate portico on the edge of Plymouth Harbor. It's one of those tourist shrines, like the "Mona Lisa," that can't possibly live up to its reputation. At least it was free.
Far more interesting is the nearby replica of the Mayflower, which costs $3.75 to $5.75 to board. It's almost impossible to imagine 102 passengers (and 30 crew members) crammed into so small a ship along with their furniture, clothes, food and provisions for the New World, not to mention their livestock.
Plymouth offers many harbor-side spots for a seafood lunch. We headed for the cafeteria-style Lobster Hut on the Town Wharf. Our tab for a tasty lobster roll, bowl of clam chowder, two platters of lightly fried clam strips and four sodas was $29.
Plimoth Plantation, a re-creation of the original settlement a few miles outside of modern Plymouth (it uses one of a number of early spellings), was our next stop. (Admission costs $16 and $9, but can be combined with a Mayflower II ticket for a slight savings.) We had expected to breeze through the plantation -- the word "re-creation" struck terror in our purist hearts -- but we were quickly won over by its uncanny authenticity and earnest spirit.
We visited more than a dozen houses, amazed at how small, dark and primitive they were. Actors in Colonial garb portrayed the settlers, expertly answering questions in beautiful Shakespearean English. The kids enjoyed asking about daily life in the plantation; one of their favorite questions, on glancing around the one-room houses: "But where did everyone sleep?" (Answer: On straw mats on the floor.) Outside the plantation's walls, we also visited a small re-creation of a Wampanoag home.
We'd planned to tour Plymouth itself. We'd also promised the kids a swim at the hotel in return for meltdown-free sightseeing. Guess how we spent the late afternoon?
After drying off and changing for dinner, we headed to Cambridge. Having spent nearly an hour the previous day looking for parking in Boston, this time we drove to the Alewife "T" stop, about 15 minutes from our hotel, parked in a huge covered lot ($4 for the day), and arrived in Harvard Square 10 minutes later.
Cambridge may be a college town, but there's actually plenty to enchant young children. As we wandered the streets looking for a restaurant, we passed numerous street performers, including a rock band jamming Rolling Stones hits and a pair of actors on stilts performing "The Phantom of the Opera."
We ate at the Algiers Coffee House, a lively, casual restaurant on Brattle Street, just a block from Harvard Square. The chicken kebabs, lamb sausage and hummus were all delicious, and the tab was a digestible $29. During our after-dinner stroll through the Harvard campus, the kids agreed that Cambridge would be a cool place to attend college. This seemed a good opportunity to underscore the importance of schoolwork. Midlecture, the children become unaccountably distracted by a street juggler and ran ahead.
Our final day was spent in Concord and Lexington. Concord was at its autumnal peak when we pulled in, its numerous Colonial houses nestled cozily in breathtaking yellow and red foliage.
We stopped by the visitor center for a quick introduction to the town's history, then walked to the North Bridge, where the "shot heard round the world" was fired. An unusually moving site, the tiny wood bridge brought home the scale of the early battles, in which small groups of men fought at perilously close range.
Concord has many historic houses. In the interests of family harmony, we decided to concentrate on one. The Old Manse, near the North Bridge, proved a good choice: Nathaniel Hawthorne lived there, Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote there and Henry David Thoreau gardened there. Standing outside the Old Manse, one can easily imagine the anguish of its original owner, the Rev. William Emerson (Ralph Waldo's grandfather), as he watched, from the same spot, minutemen and redcoats firing at each other from opposite ends of the small bridge.
Maggie and Jack remained energetic, so we pushed on. In nearby Lexington we toured the Buckman Tavern, the only building on the Green still standing from April 19, 1775, when Battle of Lexington was fought.
The tavern (admission, $4 and $2) provides wonderful insights into 18th-century life, but we liked the etymological revelations best. For example, still visible behind the bar are scratch marks used by the tavern owner to track how many pints and quarts of ale his customers had consumed -- "minding his p's and q's."
We were all flagging now, but so close to the Hancock-Clarke House, just off the green (also $4 and $2), that we made it there for a fitting last stop. Built in 1698 and furnished in Colonial style, it was the house where Samuel Adams and John Hancock were sleeping when Paul Revere arrived to warn them of the advancing British troops. So what if he never really shouted "The British are coming!" Our kids had heard him loud and clear.
 
The bottom line: from Pilgrims to redcoats
Our family of four spent about $195 a day on our hotel, meals and sightseeing during our weekend in the Boston area.
 
Getting There
Driving is the most economical way for families in the Northeast to get to Boston, though you'll wish you never saw a car once you try to park. Garages run about $25 for 24 hours.
Frequent Amtrak service is available. From New York, the trip takes about five to six hours, and costs $48 to $69 each way. Children 2 to 15 pay half fare with an adult. Information: (800) 872-7245.
Once you've disposed of your car, the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority (M.B.T.A.), (617) 222-3200, will get you just about anywhere you want to go; The subway system, the T, costs just 85 cents for most rides. A Visitor Passport, for unlimited subway, bus and ferry rides, costs $5 a day, or $9 for three consecutive days.
 
Where to Stay
The Renaissance Bedford Hotel, 44 Middlesex Turnpike, Bedford, (781) 275-5500, caters to business travelers during the week. The $99 weekend rate includes a spacious double room, with a free cot available. For an added $15, two people can enjoy the hotel's large breakfast buffet.
On our next trip, we will try to stay at the Newbury Guest House, 261 Newbury Street, (617) 437-7666. Its 32 rooms run $110 to $155, with parking available for $15 a day. This bed-and-breakfast in the Back Bay was built as a private house in 1882, and entering it feels like stepping into a Henry James novel.
 
Where to Eat
If possible, plan your walk along the Freedom Trial so that you end up at the Faneuil Hall Marketplace for lunch or dinner. Virtually every cuisine is represented among the 40 stalls and restaurants in the Quincy Market building. Most stalls are open 10 a.m. to 9 p.m., and noon to 6 p.m. Sunday.
We enjoyed the pita pizzas and the delicious frittatas at Mildred's, a casual spot at 522 Tremont Street, in the heart of the newly chic South End. Four entrees and sodas, with two desserts, cost us $29; (617) 426-0008.
In Cambridge, you'll find several inexpensive restaurants catering to college students. We had a good meal at Algiers Coffee House, which is upstairs in Brattle Hall at 40 Brattle Street, one of the nation's oldest movie houses. It features a small choice of entrees, including kebabs and lamb sausage (about $8 or $9), as well as many coffees and teas; (617) 492-1557.
At the self-service Lobster Hut on Town Wharf in Plymouth, the clam strips are lightly fried and served with fries and cole slaw ($4.95 at lunch, $7.25 at dinner). The lobster roll ($6.50) is also excellent, as is the view of the harbor; (508) 746-2270
When we asked for a budget-friendly restaurant at the Visitors Information Center in tony Concord, the otherwise helpful representative rolled her eyes. But she directed us to two inexpensive spots in the heart of town, the unpretentious Milldam Store, 55 Main Street, (978) 369-2854, for simple sandwiches and soups, and the Brigham's outlet at 17 Main Street, (978) 369-9885.
 
What to See
You can follow the Freedom Trail on your own -- allow at least half a day -- or opt for a 90-minute abbreviated tour led by a National Park Service ranger. The free tours begin at the Park Service office at 15 State Street. Schedules: (617) 242-5642. Most sites on the trail are open daily, and several, including the U.S.S. Constitution and Old North Church, are free. Others, including the Paul Revere and the Pierce-Hichborn Houses charge $2.50, or $1 for ages 5 to 17. Information: (617) 523-2338.
At the New England Aquarium, Central Wharf, (617) 973-5200, www
.neaq.org, winter admission is $12, and $6 for children 3 to 11 (prices will rise 50 cents on Jan. 1). The fee includes the sea lion performances, given at least four times a day.
In Plymouth, there's no charge to view the Rock, but admission to the Mayflower II is $6.50 and $4 for ages 6 to 12. Admission to Plimoth Plantation is $16, $9 for ages 6 to 12. Combination tickets are $19 and $11; (508) 746-1622; www.plimouth.org.
Guided tours of the Old Manse, 269 Monument Street, Concord, (978) 369-3909, are $5.50 and $3.50 for children 6 to 12. Concord is accessible by M.B.T.A. train from North Station.
In nearby Lexington, the Buckman Tavern and Hancock-Clarke House charge $4, $2 for ages 6 to 16. Combination tickets for both, as well as the Munroe Tavern, are $10 and $4. The Lexington Historical Society, (781) 862-1703, operates all three. M.B.T.A. buses run from the Alewife Station of the Red Line to Lexington, except on Sunday. There is no public transportation between Lexington and Concord. SETH MARGOLIS

CORRECTION-DATE: November 28, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
The Frugal Traveler column on Nov. 14, about a weekend in the Boston area, referred incorrectly to its geography and to the availability of transportation to and from the Charlestown Navy Yard. The Charlestown neighborhood, where the Constitution is anchored at the Navy Yard, is on the Inner Harbor, not the Charles River. For the return to downtown Boston from the yard, the No. 93 bus stops outside Gate 4; there is also a ferry, which the author took.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Predicting Sunny Days For Latin Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
THOSE analysts who last year consigned Latin America to a long convalescence after the economic crises in Asia and Russia and the near collapse of Long Term Capital Management might want to think again.
Summer is about to start south of the Equator, and the Latin economies, which were not hurt as badly as many feared a year ago, are looking much livelier. 
 The stock markets are doing well, too. From the start of the year through Thursday, the 58 Latin American equity funds tracked by Lipper Inc. have posted an average total return of 30.9 percent.
Analysts are excited about the potential for further gains: Based on price-to-earnings ratios, Latin stocks are still very inexpensive compared with those of other parts of the world.
Carlos Asili, Latin American equity strategist for J. P. Morgan, took some time last week to discuss how the coming year is shaping up for Latin stocks. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. Latin stocks have been very strong for the last couple of weeks. Why is that?
 
A. When the European and American bond markets began their strong rally, that was a big positive for Latin equity markets. Also, during the period this summer when the American stock market was correcting, there were net inflows into international equity funds. Some of that money went into Latin funds. Finally, there is a sense that the Latin economies have bottomed out and are in a recovery phase.
 
Q. Do you agree that the worst is over for these economies?
 
A. Our economists have forecast that growth will show a steady acceleration in Latin America through the end of next year, to an annualized year-over-year rate of 4.4 percent by the fourth quarter of 2000.
The drivers will be Chile and Mexico. Brazil will be a little weaker than those countries, with growth of about 2.5 percent in the first half of the year, accelerating to 3.5 percent in the second half. And Argentina should see its economy accelerate in the second half of the year.
 
Q. Latin stocks and economies are hostage to what happens in American and European bond markets. Do you fear a rise in interest rates in the developed world?
 
A. It is very likely we will see bond yields back up some, but we will not return to the levels we hit three weeks or a month ago.
And while fixed-income spreads between emerging-market bonds and Treasuries have narrowed, we think they could narrow further.
At the height of the crisis last year, rates on emerging-market bonds were as high as 17 percent above U.S. Treasuries, according to the J. P. Morgan emerging-markets bond index. Now, that spread is around 9.8 percent. Conservatively, we could get a further 2.5-percentage-point improvement in those bond spreads.
It depends on the country, but in Latin America a 1.5-percentage-point compression in those spreads could lead to an expansion in price-to-earnings ratios on stocks of 20 percent to 30 percent.
 
Q. Political instability is often another source of potential concern in emerging markets. Do you see potential problems in any of the major Latin countries?
 
A. No one can say that nothing bad will happen, but at this point the outlook looks positive.
I feel comfortable about political stability in Argentina, Chile and Mexico, which will hold presidential elections next summer. There is a lot of confidence in Mexico.
Of the four major investible countries, Brazil is the country where there is some risk. That is not because of impending elections, but because of the future of economic reform and liberalization.
 
Q. How do you see the rally continuing? And do you have a list of stocks that are trading as American Depository Receipts in this country that you like?
 
A. Recently, the stocks that have outperformed have been the telecommunications companies, which are by far the most liquid. Telmex, Telebras and Televisa have all moved up significantly. As the rally matures, we expect it to broaden out.
There are at least 10 stocks that are liquid, trade A.D.R.'s and have very good bottom-up fundamentals.
In Mexico, Coca-Cola Femsa, which has risen around 5 percent this week, still offers good value. Two conglomerates we like are Grupo Alfa and Carso. Cifra, a retailer, is another.
In Brazil, we like some of the retailing stocks. We just upgraded Pao de Azucar. We like Tele Norte Leste, a telecommunications company. And we like Brazilian steel stocks CST and CSN, which are selling at valuations that are among the most compelling in the world.
And in Chile, we like Endesa, an electricity company.

HEADLINE: Better Perks Resonate in Boom Times

BYLINE: By MICHELLE LEDER

 BODY:
HIS name may not be familiar to anyone but his own employees, but chances are you've heard about what Al Galdi has done: given new BMW's to any employee who has worked at his company for at least a year.
During the last six months, Mr. Galdi has handed out BMW keys to 34 of his 45 employees. The cars, which are leased, cost him about $9,000 a year each, including insurance. Needless to say, turnover at Arcnet, an architectural engineering firm in Holmdel, N.J., has been virtually nil since Mr. Galdi began offering the perk in June. Employees who leave have to give back the cars. 
 They also lose out on other goodies, like $100 gift certificates on their birthdays, health club memberships and a cash bonus equal to 25 percent of their annual salary on the fifth anniversary of their employment.
About once a month, Mr. Galdi says, he asks his employees if they would rather have cash. The answer is always no.
"They seem to really like the programs," he said, "because it helps with their quality of life."
You could probably count on one hand, and perhaps even one finger, the number of employers in the New York metro area who are handing out keys to BMW's. But with the economy booming and unemployment at record lows, many employers are trying to come up with new and interesting perquisites.
"It's not so much about rewarding, but retaining," said Michael A. Keane, managing consultant at Watson Worldwide, a consulting firm in Morristown, N.J. "When it comes to employees, it's basically a seller's market, and many companies are having to make extraordinary efforts."
A recent survey by the outplacement firm Lee Hecht Harrison found that the top two perks on employees' wish lists were health club memberships (58 percent) and flextime (57 percent). That's not what most employers are providing: A.T.M.'s on premises (25 percent) and travel services (15 percent), according to a survey of more than 1,000 employers conducted by Hewitt Associates, a compensation consulting firm.
"Employers need to ask themselves how they can make themselves different from everyone else," said Ray Baumruk, who helped conduct the study for Hewitt.
Perks vary widely from company to company and within particular industries. High-tech firms tend to have the most innovative offerings, like on-site massages, concierge services, even quiet rooms where workers can nap. Blue-chip companies, particularly those on suburban campuses, tend to focus more heavily on time-saving perks like on-site dry-cleaning and film drop-off.
For example, the 500 employees at Xerox's corporate headquarters at Stamford, Conn., are able to work out at an on-site fitness center, order meals from the company cafeteria for dinner and drop off dry-cleaning when they get to work in the morning; it's usually ready to be picked up the next day. On-site massage therapy -- a perk offered at other Xerox locations, but not in Stamford -- is in the works, said Christa Carone, a spokeswoman.
One difference from several years ago is that the perks are for a larger pool of workers. At Arcnet, even the receptionist qualified for a BMW. Last month, Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer that has stores in Hicksville, N.Y., and Elizabeth, N.J., pledged cash bonuses amounting to a day's worth of sales, $80 million worldwide, to its employees, from the snack bar staff and stock clerks to the president. Each employee will end up with $2,435 when checks are distributed this month, said Marty Marston, a spokeswoman for Ikea North America. Retailing tends to be among the lowest-paying type of employment, so the one-time bonus could equal a month's pay for some.
But even companies that can't afford to provide a car or a day's sales have plenty of options. Many perks being offered today cost the employer virtually nothing, but still create plenty of good will. Men's Wearhouse, a large California retailer that operates about 20 stores in the New York metro area, has signed up 120 local employers, including Citibank and New York University, for its V.I.P. program, which gives a company's employees 10 percent off on Men's Wearhouse purchases.
Transitchek, a program that allows employees of enrolled companies to set aside up to $65 a month before taxes for public transportation commuting costs, also provides savings on corporate taxes. Each month 7,000 to 8,000 employers in the New York area participate in the program, said George Serventi, Transitchek director.
"A lot of these things are in the interest of the employers who are doing them," said Helen Darling, a consultant at Watson Worldwide's Stamford office.
Even costly perks often pay off in the end. Lipton Child Care Centers, a Washington company that operates backup child care centers in Manhattan, White Plains and Jersey City, says that employers still save money because parents don't need to miss work when their regular child care provider isn't available. The service has attracted employers like the National Hockey League, the National Basketball Association, Philip Morris, Pepsico and Texaco, as well as newer, smaller companies like Knight Securities of Jersey City.
Stephanie Bernstein, director of human resources for Knight, a Nasdaq market maker, said she and several other parents were able to sell Knight's chief executive on the idea of backup care, even though Knight, like many other brokerage firms, mostly employs single men.
"There were a couple of people here, myself included, who would get into a situation and be jammed," Ms. Bernstein said. Now, for an annual fee of $50, she and other Knight parents have access to the Lipton center in the lobby at Newport Center.
At Dialogic Corporation, a Parsippany technology company recently bought by Intel, the company's 1,000 employees have access to a corporate concierge, who is able to arrange things like dinner reservations, family vacations and oil changes for cars. Dialogic pays LesConcierges of San Francisco for the service, but employees have to pay for individual requests. Other Dialogic perks include an on-site fitness center, a free coffee and juice bar, and heavily discounted soda.
"This is all aimed at making it comfortable for people to be here longer than 40 hours a week," said Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits. Though Mr. Cardinal said the company hadn't tried to figure out whether the concierge service and other perks were paying off for the company, he said that turnover had been lower than expected.
Still, at most companies, benefits are limited to items like health and life insurance and a retirement plan. Mr. Keane, the consultant at Watson Worldwide, estimated that only 15 to 20 percent of all companies offer what he described as nontraditional perks. That could grow if the economy continued to prosper.
"A lot of companies are being pretty cautious, because once you add it, it becomes hard to take it away," said Alan M. Johnson, managing director at Johnson Associates, a Wall Street compensation consulting firm.
Many consultants and even the companies that provide the perks wonder what will happen to the programs when the economy takes a turn for the worse. Employees who have grown used to the perks may be unwilling to give them up.
"We all know it's going to be difficult to take these things away," Mr. Cardinal said. Given the choice of layoffs or reducing perks, most employers would probably reduce the perks, consultants say.
But not Mr. Galdi. When business slowed down a few months ago, he said he had to lay off several employees. But he has no plans to stop handing out BMW's or cut back on any of the other benefits Arcnet employees receive.
"I'm in the service business," Mr. Galdi said, "and having employees that are happy and hard-working is good business for me."
 
Like a Front Desk at the Office
SO what exactly does a corporate concierge do? Just about anything, as long as it's legal.
"I never know what each day will bring," said Pam Wildrick, a corporate concierge at Dialogic Corporation, a technology company recently acquired by Intel Corporation. "People come in and they drop their problems on my desk."
In the year and a half since Ms. Wildrick began working at Dialogic's Parsippany headquarters, she's done everything from picking up gifts for spouses who have forgotten a birthday or anniversary to locating a clock that ticks backward to finding a guide to take an engineer through dense jungle in Costa Rica. In a typical month, she fields 230 to 250 requests from Dialogic's 1,000 employees.
Though Ms. Wildrick works in Parsippany, she's actually an employee of Les Concierges, a 13-year-old San Francisco company that provides concierge services to companies. (In the past, she had worked for several nonprofit groups in Morris County, including a stint as president of the Junior League and director of communications and special events for the Arts Council of the Morristown Area.)
Though the concierge concept is popular in California, particularly in the Silicon Valley, corporate concierges are still relatively new in the New York area.
"There's a lot of potential in the New York area," said Phil Wexler, Les Concierges' executive vice president. The company recently reached an agreement with Goldman Sachs to begin providing concierge services to its employees early next year.
Ken Cardinal, Dialogic's director of compensation and benefits, said the service was popular. One part of Ms. Wildrick's job involves arranging for oil changes and other routine maintenance on employees' personal cars while they are working, saving the employees valuable time on the weekends.
So is there anything Ms. Wildrick won't do?
Yes. She won't hire strippers, though she has been asked to.
Though that's not illegal, Ms. Wildrick said she just didn't feel comfortable arranging that kind of entertainment for Dialogic employees, even if it took place off-site.
"That one just crosses the line," Ms. Wildrick said. MICHELLE LEDER
