SECTION: Section 7; Page 10; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1435 words

HEADLINE: The Metamorphosis

BYLINE: By Maxine Kumin; Maxine Kumin's most recent book is "Selected Poems 1960-1990." Her memoir, "Inside the Halo and Beyond," will be published next spring.

 BODY:

CROSSING
 A Memoir.
 By Deirdre McCloskey.
 Illustrated. 266 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $25. 
 When I received "Crossing," I wondered why the editors had not designated it for review by someone gay, or someone involved in the transgendered community. Reading it, I realized that I -- a lifelong heterosexual woman -- need this book. All of us need to consider the way our culture shapes gender expectations and makes unspoken but profoundly rigid gender assignments based on physical appearance, apparel, gait, gestures, voice and so on.
Early in the memoir, the former Donald McCloskey refers to being "read" by others: casual passers-by, shoppers in a department store, patrons in a bar, professional colleagues. Each of us is read daily, and we read others. When the author was still what he thought of as a male heterosexual cross-dresser lightheartedly exploring his hobby, the game was to cross-dress so successfully that he was read as female and thereby "passed." McCloskey concludes there are two patterns governing transsexuality: "Either you've always known you were of the wrong gender or you've constructed a psychological dam against the realization, which suddenly breaks, usually in mature adulthood." His dam burst in his sixth decade.
This is not a new story. When the British journalist and travel writer James Morris made his transition to Jan Morris in the 1970's, his account, "Conundrum," transformed gender crossing from a dubious enterprise to one of somewhat bizarre respectability. I was dimly aware that articles had appeared in Harper's Magazine, The Boston Globe, Worth magazine and The Chronicle of Higher Education about the decision by the renowned economist and historian Donald McCloskey at the age of 52 to undergo all the requisite procedures to become Deirdre McCloskey.
But it had not occurred to me that there was a brisk trade in pornographic magazines targeted at cross-dressers. I did not know that conventions of them assembled regularly in reputable hotels around the country, that chat rooms for cross-dressers provided means for this group to mingle electronically, despite geographic distances, and often to arrange to meet offline.
I did not know how difficult and how expensive it is to change sex, or that more than 25,000 Americans have done so. Just for starters, the cost of getting rid of a male beard by electrolysis is a minimum of $10,000. Sessions under local anesthesia can run as long as seven or eight hours at a stretch. Since only about 40 percent of the hairs treated are killed at each attempt, retreatments -- strippings" -- are necessary. Only an "active" follicle can be destroyed; there is no way to tell in advance the stage of growth of a treated follicle. At the second treatment, the percentage of regrowth is reduced to 36; the third leaves 21.7, and so it proceeds. McCloskey was still going back for retreatment after two years of womanhood. But before making the commitment to extirpating the beard, McCloskey scheduled removals of hair on the backs of the hands, then arms, then back, legs and stomach. The dedication required for this monumental task is mind-boggling.
After hair removal came a tummy tuck and breast augmentation. Then facial reconstruction: reduction of the eyebrow ridge by grinding down the bones; cheek and jaw surgery, an operation to reduce the nose, move the hairline forward, point the jaw, lift the eyebrows. The first voice operation was not successful, nor were subsequent ones. Retraining the existing voice proved a better solution. "Get a tape recorder," Deirdre was advised. "Place your voice forward. Speak in your head instead of your chest. Articulate more clearly. No harsh onsets."
"Crossing" details the often excruciating physical procedures undergone in making the transition, but the book's major focus is on the gradual emotional evolution the writer experienced traversing from man to woman. McCloskey was married, the father of two grown children, when he made the leap.
Sadly, his son, daughter and former wife turned away from this new person. His sister and one of her academic colleagues played a sinister role in trying to thwart him. They conspired to have him committed as mentally incompetent -- unfit to sign papers for optional surgical procedures. They devised a theory that he was manic and that his mania could be treated with psychopharmacology, much as in the 50's psychiatry thought that homosexuality could be overcome with electroshock. Twice during his determined journey into womanhood, they managed to have him incarcerated -- handcuffed, locked away where he could not harm himself, at first in the University of Iowa Hospital's mental ward and later in the University of Chicago Hospital -- to await evaluations by psychiatrists whose knowledge of his situation was less than rudimentary.
The shrinks he had the misfortune to encounter seemed still to be operating at a pre-60's level. At that time, the profession's "standards of care" required a two-year waiting period before a would-be transsexual could have surgery. The American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders is what transsexuals fear. In 1997 the American Psychological Association declared that it "opposes all portrayals of lesbian, gay and bisexual people as mentally ill," and the psychiatric association adopted that code in 1998. Gender crossers are still waiting for the gender identity "disorder" to be removed from the list of mental illnesses.
The family rift has not shown signs of closing. But Deirdre McCloskey's mother and brother have been bulwarks of support, and her sister is moving toward reconciliation. She has finally stopped calling her "Donald."
I admire the unflinching direct narrative the author employs: no self-pity; no denying the years he spent cross-dressing before the "epiphany," the coming to terms with the ultimate goal; no verbal reprisal against the wife or the sister, only a little directed at the psychiatrists; much praise of and gratitude to the Dutch academic community in Rotterdam, which unquestioningly took McCloskey in as a visiting professor.
The final surgery to remove the male genitalia and replace them with a neovagina took place in Australia in 1996: "Being able to say you are finished, complete, really a woman by the no-penis criterion is the most powerful rhetoric for acceptance of behavior. . . . In our medicalized culture the ceremony that seals the agreement is the operation." In McCloskey's case, the neovagina had to be fashioned from a portion of the small intestine and manually dilated every day, a chore that took about half an hour and was, at least initially, quite painful.
While McCloskey is silent on sexual gratification after the surgeries, she is refreshingly articulate on the female sex: "She had started to forget what it was like to be a man. . . . She forgot what it felt like to not understand relationships because you find them boring. Or to feel that you are by rights the local hero. Or to feel that people should serve you. Or most superficially and most fundamentally to think of men as 'we' and women as 'they.' "Transgendering has made her a feminist.
Far more important to her than the possibility of sexual intimacy in the future is being accepted as a woman among women. Being elected president of the Economic History Association, she says, "was glorious, affirming." After the final surgeries, including a second face lift, she is "read" less and less. Her career survives, seemingly undamaged.
The total cost of her transformation to date comes to about $90,000, far higher than average because she had so much cosmetic surgery and voice surgery, together with surgeries to repair those surgeries. Travel between Iowa and Dallas (electrolysis), San Francisco (cheek and jaw surgery), Philadelphia (voice operation) and Australia (genital replacement) in search of the best procedures also has to be factored in. A variety of wigs while she experimented with how to wear her own hair, the acquisition of an extensive wardrobe, do not come cheaply. Then there were legal fees as she untangled the web woven by her sister, and fees to the mental hospitals where she was held against her will. Despite having to overcome so many roadblocks and despite the outright failure of some of the cosmetic surgeries, Deirdre McCloskey is not bitter. Even rejection by her children is met with sorrow, not anger. This is a woman worth knowing. She has given us a highly readable, dramatic account of her crossing.

LENGTH: 870 words

HEADLINE: Carrying Coals to Newcastle, or Seaweed to Long Island

BYLINE: By MARY CUMMINGS 

 BODY:
SEAWEED, seaweed everywhere, and not a bite to eat.
Well, not quite. Long Island waters are indeed rich in seaweed (though, happily, Long Island beaches are seldom piled high with it). And there is indeed seaweed you can eat: seaweed salads sold in local seafood shops, seaweed wraps wherever sushi is served, rockweed garnishes on restaurant entrees, pills and powders from the health-food store. 
 But the seaweed Long Islanders see on the beach is almost never the seaweed they eat. Nor is it the seaweed the spa at Gurney's Inn in Montauk uses for its signature seaweed wrap. And although gardeners recognize seaweed as a fine fertilizer, rich in minerals and trace elements, no enterprising horticultural entrepreneur has seen fit to harvest and market it locally.
In fact, a highly informal investigation recently uncovered just two instances of local seaweed harvested for local use. Make that three if you count the occasional gardener who finds it useful as mulch, four if an old-timer's tale of packing seaweed around the bottoms of barns to keep the cold out is historically valid.
More recently, a true, documented case of organized seaweed collection for commercial use occurred in 1979 when the International Health and Beauty Spa at Gurney's Inn first began offering its seaweed body mask and wrap using kelp harvested daily for the purpose at Montauk Point.
Today, "we get it from France," said the spa director, Suzanne Lieder. As the spa literature boasts, the source is Laboratoires Euroderm, which uses "the highest grade of pure fresh seaweed and marine plants, harvested meticulously under strict French government regulation from pollution-free ocean water off the coast of Brittany."
Mind you, no one is suggesting that local waters are impure or that the home-grown seaweed is inferior. It just takes too long to refine the Montauk harvest and make it usable, Ms. Lieder said. Evidently it didn't take long to discover that shortcuts wouldn't work. At least one patron complained back in 1979 that spending 20 minutes under heat lamps, snugly wrapped in a cocoon of seaweed that smelled vaguely of fish, left her anything but soothed and revitalized.
At the George Braun Oyster Company in Cutchogue, Ken Homan reported one other borderline case of commerce in local seaweed.
"We sell quite a lot to chefs in the Hamptons," said Mr. Homan, referring to rockweed, the seaweed of choice among local chefs who pride themselves on their presentation. Perhaps the most common seaweed found on local beaches, rockweed is that brown, leathery plant with the little air pockets that beg to be popped. Mr. Homan said he normally bought it at the Fulton Fish Market in New York. But occasionally, when some chef has an urgent need and there's no time for a city run, his father and 8-year-old son are commissioned to "run down and gather some."
The seaweed salads increasingly available at seafood shops come mainly from the West Coast, Mr. Homan said. California is also the source of most of the seaweed products used locally in Japanese restaurants, said Chef Toyo of Sen in Sag Harbor, who said he also imported some products from Japan. In the Northeast, Larch Hanson's Maine Seaweed Company has a mailing list of 100 seaweed enthusiasts and retailers scattered throughout the United States and Canada, whom he supplies with edible and fertilizer seaweeds harvested from offshore beds.
So what's wrong with Long Island seaweed, and why isn't anyone harvesting it?
George Kraemer, who is looking into the potential for seaweed cultivation on the East Coast at the State University at Purchase, says he doesn't think anything is wrong with it. He and three fellow scientists recently received financing from Long Island Sea Grant for a project they hope will demonstrate that local cultivation of nori (the red seaweed Porphyra, used primarily as the wrapping for sushi rolls) could not only give the region a piece of an industry with annual revenues of $1.8 billion but also promises to help clean local waters.
The idea, he said, is to grow the seaweed in conjunction with fish farms. Effluent from fish farms, Mr. Kraemer said, can have the same deleterious nutrient-loading effect on waters as municipal sewage, while increasing the likelihood of ecologically and economically damaging algal blooms. Previous experiments have shown that growing seaweed near fish production can remove excess nutrients from the fin fish effluent, he said, citing an example from Chile, where red seaweed was integrated into salmon mariculture and reduced the release of nitrogen and phosphorus by 56 and 94 percent, respectively.
If the project pans out, the future may see some very positive developments on the local seaweed front. For if nori, with its healthful nutritional content, can remove excess nutrients from the waste streams of fish farms before they foul local waters, everyone wins. Fish farmers stay on the right side of environmental law; the water is cleaner; the potential for algal bloom outbreaks is reduced, and a new, potentially profitable, aesthetically and ecologically correct industry is born. The day when sushi rolls come wrapped in native nori may not be far off.

HEADLINE: Nostalgic Medicine

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The hypocrisy of doctors who have applauded the decision by United Health Group to suspend preauthorization for testing and treatment decisions is breathtaking (front page, Nov. 9). 
 Why the nostalgia for the time, not long ago, of double-digit yearly health care inflation and unnecessary health care expenditures?
No study has found any evidence that managed care review resulted in systematic undertreatment or statistically significant adverse outcomes. In fact, review had scarcely begun to take effect when an unholy alliance of doctors and misled consumers began to create the current atmosphere of hysteria.
A look back to a time when doctors' decisions were not subject to review does not inspire confidence in our ability to make health care affordable or available.
 
JONATHAN SANDS, M.D.
Indianapolis, Nov. 11, 1999

HEADLINE: To Get a Surplus

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alice M. Rivlin (Op-Ed, Nov. 12) says that "a tax cut would hurt prospects for economic growth by encouraging more consumer spending and forcing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates and avoid inflation." 
 Curtailing consumer spending can't bring us anything but trouble. Doesn't the Federal Reserve implicitly recognize the catastrophic dangers of deflation as it walks the tightrope of controlled growth?
The larger our economy grows, the more room there will be for Social Security benefits. We can handle this without a misguided and puritanical effort to eliminate the federal debt.
MEREDITH NICHOLSON
Casa Grande, Ariz., Nov. 12, 1999

LENGTH: 1188 words

HEADLINE: Granddaddy of Computer Trade Shows Is Remaking Its Global Gigs

BYLINE: By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

 BODY:
Comdex, the Las Vegas exhibition that is the king of computer trade shows and the jewel in the crown of its sponsor, ZD Events, opens today for the 20th consecutive year.
In those two decades, Comdex has grown from a humble gathering of technology fans into the flagship in an international armada of trade shows. Even now, ZD Events is erecting booths in Israel for the opening of the first Comdex/Israel 99 show on Nov. 30 and mapping logistics for the third Expo CommChina South, which opens the same week in Guangzhou. A week later, it's the fourth annual Comdex India show in New Delhi. 
 The sun, it seems, never sets on the ZD Events empire. Virtually every week, somewhere in the world, the company is setting up or tearing down a computer trade show. Today, ZD Events produces 100 shows, including 22 Comdexes, in 25 countries, and this year it is adding a show in Greece as well as in Israel. Next on its list of target markets are Sweden, Saudi Arabia, South Africa and Turkey.
Comdex in Las Vegas is the undisputed top dog, the world's largest computer trade show. ZD Events says it expects the event, which attracted 4,000 computer enthusiasts and dealers in 1979, to draw roughly 202,000 people this year. They will trek through a million square feet of exhibition space in search of the next trend in computing technology. While that turnout would mark a decline from the show's peak of 215,000 in 1996, Comdex remains a cash cow for ZD Events and the biggest brand in the computer trade show business.
But a huge transition is under way for Comdex.
The glory days of the one-size-fits-all computer show are past, replaced by smaller, more focused gatherings -- an enormous and still-growing crop of executive seminars and single-subject conferences. As the high technology industry enters the post-PC era in which the Internet is king, it is hardly surprising that a decidedly PC-centric trade show would face substantial change.
"Where people get their information is changing," said Alan Meckler, who founded the popular series of Internet World shows before selling to Penton Media Inc. last year. "The problem that Comdex has is that the PC is finished as an innovator."
And with the Internet supplying customers with up-to-the-minute product information and industry news, they no longer must attend conventions to stay up to date. Even at Internet World's New York show, which soared to 70,000 attendees in only a few years, attendance is flat, Mr. Meckler said, adding, "Niche shows are the rage now."
ZD Events is already beginning to reinvent the show, even dubbing it "dotComdex" in its recent marketing campaign.
"It's part of our branding campaign to try to put Comdex at the epicenter of all decisions about technology relating to the Internet economy," said Peter Shaw, executive vice president of ZD Events, which is part of Ziff-Davis Inc., the leading publisher of computer magazines.
Thanks to its magazine publishing roots, ZD Events can offer technology companies something its competitors are hard pressed to match: packaged deals that include both a trade-show presence and advertising in some of the largest computer magazines in the business, said Mandana Hormoiza, an analyst at Lazard Freres & Company in New York.
At the same time, ZD Events is building a research and development unit called ZD Studios, charged with creating new, typically highly focused events for corporate clients like Sun Microsystems, for which it produces the JavaOne show.
Still, the company is not about to abandon its general shows just yet.
"We see there's a trend toward vertical industry events," Mr. Shaw said. "But if you look around the globe, every country with an information technology industry, except for the U.K., looks to have a center of gravity with a Comdex show that covers a broad spectrum."
The Comdex brand has undergone transitions before.
In 1995, the Interface Group, the company that founded the show, sold its trade show division to Softbank, the Japanese conglomerate, for $800 million. Within a year, Softbank also bought a majority stake in Ziff-Davis, eventually merging the two operations. Today, Softbank owns 70 percent of Ziff-Davis, which operates ZD Events as one of five units. Ziff-Davis stock, which went public in May 1998, has fluctuated widely in price in the last year -- from just above $8 a year ago to a high of $29 last March and a closing price of $17.1875 last Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.
Another Ziff-Davis unit, ZDNet, tracks its stock separately.
In July, after Softbank announced that it would focus on Internet-only companies, Ziff-Davis said that it had hired investment bankers to help it sell off its business units. Softbank has already sold off Ziff-Davis's market research business to Harte-Hanks for $101 million in cash.
Mr. Shaw said several potential suitors had expressed interest in buying all or parts of Ziff-Davis, though he declined to name them.
Though Ziff-Davis has been steadily losing money the last few years, its losses have narrowed recently. For the third quarter, the company lost $14.9, compared with a loss of $27.6 million for the quarter last year. Revenue rose 10 percent, to $232 million.
The company's trade show division accounted for much of the improvement; 23 percent of Ziff-Davis's revenue came from ZD Events. Besides Comdex, ZD Events' other big brands include Network+Interop, which is geared to network managers, and Seybold Seminars, a series of shows related to desktop publishing. But the division's future growth, say both analysts and Ziff-Davis officials, lies in ZD Studios.
Despite uncertainty over its ownership, ZD Events continues to open new shows abroad, typically with local business partners familiar with the trade show landscape. In India, for example, the show organizer is Business India Expositions, an 11-year-old event management company. Without a local partner to arrange the show, ZD Events officials say, the risk of making a cultural gaffe or other business mistake is too high. In South America, for example, ZD Events has learned there is no point in presenting a keynote address in the morning because no one will show up until noon.
"We think globally, but we try to act locally," said Jason Chudnofsky, chief executive of ZD Events.
For local attendees, the draw is the big-name speakers from Silicon Valley that the Comdex brand is able to attract. The benefit for ZD Events is that its foreign shows tend to feed its United States operations. As foreign companies learn the advantages of trade show marketing, Mr. Chudnofsky said, they start making the trek to the United States. For American technology companies, consultants and analysts who attend ZD Events' overseas shows, the international circuit can be costly and exhausting, but many say it is worth the effort.
"I send people to nearly all these events," said Howard Anderson, founder of the Yankee Group market research firm and most recently a venture capitalist. "It seems like it's one long, endless caravan."
A caravan that starts and ends in Las Vegas.

HEADLINE: Two Cities, Two Leaps of Faith;
Columbus Pins Its Dreams on a Jazzy New Science Center

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 11

 BODY:
"Is this, like, Gilligan's Island's lost temple or something?" the teenager asked.
The short answer was yes. In front of him, and a dozen of his classmates from a southern Ohio high school, was a junglelike environment with a maze of pathways and bridges connecting temples and caverns, jazzed up with laser effects and populated by gargoylish icons, each representing a quality -- like inspiration or perseverance -- that is an element of problem solving. By listening to the figures' instructions and those of actors serving as guides, visitors are coaxed to collect the elements of a code, a la Indiana Jones, that will gain them entrance to a "secret" tomb. 
 The exhibit, called "Adventure," is one of the seven "learning worlds" that are the heart of the new Center of Science and Industry here. The $125 million museumesque attraction is actually the reincarnation of a 35-year-old institution that was in a historic building downtown.
The new structure, which opened on Nov. 6 and is known as COSI Columbus, is just west of downtown, on 17 acres nestled in a bend in the Sciota River. It is intended to revitalize the city's riverfront and bolster its regional and national profile, with its grafting of art and entertainment onto the enterprise of kindling a love of science and learning in, to use the apt cliche, children of all ages.
"You'll notice they don't use the word 'museum' in the name; that's an important point," said Kathleen M. Fox, executive director of the Ohio Arts and Sports Facilities Commission, the administrator of the state grants to the new center. Part theme park, part theater, part interactive laboratory, and created with an installation artist's sense of provocation, the center hopes to draw 900,000 or more people annually.
The building, by the Japanese architect Arata Isozaki, makes use of the riverfront facade of a former high school, onto which the architect has fitted a 960-foot-long curved concrete facade that resembles nothing so much as an overturned canoe. Inside, length is the defining feature. The exhibits are in spaces that branch off from wide hallways running uninterrupted on three floors.
There is some conventionality to the exhibits. One learning world, "Gadgets," is devoted to, well, gadgets, and allows visitors to do the kinds of fooling around with gears and magnets that is the foundation of the Exploratorium in San Francisco and other science centers. But the center largely has the feel of something new; the main teaching tool is the immersion of the visitor in a world of artifice.
"What we do and how we do it are distinguished by strongly themed environments," said Kathryn D. Sullivan, a former astronaut who is the center's president and chief executive officer. "That's rather different from most places."
Most science museums, anyway. But the learning worlds borrow heavily from Disneyland and other theme parks. In "Oceans," for example, visitors enter through the hull of a simulated shipwreck (wittily christened "Indomitable") and engage with exhibits illustrating the properties of water in the environment of an undersea cave watched over by a mammoth statue of Poseidon.
In "Progress" visitors walk Hope Street and Fear Street (change occurs at the intersection -- get it?) in Progress, Ohio, circa 1898, then pass through a darkened hall and emerge on the same set of streets in 1962.
And in "Life," which deals with birth, aging and death (a sign at the door warns that the exhibit contains potentially disturbing subject matter), there are human fetuses in stages from one to seven months, videotaped interviews with men and women who know they are dying and forthright exhibits on breast and testicular cancer, as well as more lighthearted fare like an actual meal decomposing under glass and an organ that plays, instead of music, the sounds of bodily functions.
"Life" is clearly aimed at older visitors , and on one day last week it was free of the crowds and cacophony in the other learning worlds. It will also include, when it is complete, an exhibit that could easily go in a gallery or a modern art museum, one that raises resonant philosophical and emotional issues: a reconstruction of an actual auto accident that killed three of the five occupants of a car. The crumpled car is already on display, complete with debris from the road. Added to it will be videotaped interviews with relatives of the dead and, most provocatively, computer-generated comparisons of what would have happened had the driver engaged the brakes an instant sooner or an instant later.
Aside from the whiz-bang effects throughout, "Life" is the new center's most concerted effort to stretch its visitor profile.
"Since I came here three years ago, I've heard three sets of comments over and over about the old COSI," Ms. Sullivan said. "One is, 'I went there all the time when I was a kid.' Two, 'My kids used to love it.' The third is, 'I take my grandkids there all the time.' I want to add one more: 'I go there when . . . .' "
Throughout the center, designers have largely avoided the convention of informational plaques, preferring to engage rather than to explain. In one part of "Oceans," for example, visitors can control the shape and flow of an air vortex within a tube of water, but nowhere is there an explanation of the suction principal that makes it work.
"The biggest hurdle is getting people over their expectation of a museum as a place of didactic, fact-based learning," said Joseph D. Wisne, the center's vice president for design and production, who oversaw 25 exhibit designers. Instilling wonder is the goal, he said, though each exhibit was designed with a "learning outcome" in mind.
Surveys indicate that people are leaving the place fully persuaded they have learned something. Mr. Wisne added, however, that tinkering is still possible based on visitor reactions in the opening weeks. Staff members wander through the exhibits with the express purpose of answering questions.
"What we don't want is people feeling compelled to spend their time in here reading," he said. "But if they need help, they'll tell us."
The new center is a mammoth project for this expanding state capital of 700,000, known as a test-market city and the home of the Limited, Nationwide Insurance and the Wendy's hamburger chain. Columbus is often overshadowed by the state's other population centers, and the center is clearly intended as a foundation for growth, the centerpiece of $2 billion in planned economic development. It was built with the substantial cooperation of the state government, which provided $55 million, the city government ($25 million) and corporate and individual support ($46 million). It opened debt-free, without granting any corporate sponsors labeling rights to the individual exhibits or product placement within them.
"We made it very clear that learning was the motivation for COSI," Ms. Sullivan said. "It is not a marketing opportunity. We expected our funders" -- whose support is noted on plaques outside the individual exhibits -- "to say, 'We are proud to help COSI present these environments.' "
All of this testifies to the confidence that the community has had over the years in the science center, which has a history of producing popular traveling exhibitions on subjects like the science of sports and space travel. Its "Kidspace" exhibition has been replicated in dozens of museums around the world. The city, home of Ohio State University and the high-tech research company Battelle, has long seen itself as science-friendly. And, of course, John Glenn is the quintessential Ohioan. For all these reasons, the project was deemed appropriate as a identity-making emblem, a launching pad for the city's reputation in the next century.
"Ohio is really a collection of city-states, each with its own identity," Ms. Fox, the state commission director, said. "You're a Clevelander or a Cincinnatian or a Toledoan first. Columbus is a city with much less history than those other places. It wasn't built on transportation or industry; it was chosen as the capital, largely for its central location, and developed as a center for government. But with Ohio State and the science-based companies that have grown up here, an institution that will teach young people the elements of science and technology makes sense."
The hope is that the center will elevate the status of Columbus as a destination city, at least within the Midwest, if not nationally. The old COSI drew a substantial percentage of its visitors from out of state; now the prospects are greater.
"The city gets many Japanese visitors because of the Honda assembly plant in Marysville, and we get a lot of Middle Eastern visitors because of O.S.U.," said Paula Spence, chairwoman of the COSI fund-raising board. "The mere fact that this building is here will attract attention in Europe and the Middle and Far East."
Eventually, Ms. Spence said hopefully, "when you say Columbus, you'll no longer have to put 'comma, Ohio,' after it."
In the meantime, the center has to succeed on its own.
"Do I know if we've placed all the right bets? No," Ms. Sullivan said, adding, in not very scientific language, the center's continuing task: "We've got to concentrate on how people are feeling about it. How do we make it sing?"

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 15, 1999

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2009 words

HEADLINE: A Microsoft Remedy: Antitrust Experts Offer Prescriptions

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14

 BODY:
Groups of experts from a score of universities nationwide are preparing recommendations for the government as the Justice Department and 19 states prepare for the penalty phase of the Microsoft antitrust trial early next year.
If Federal District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson finds Microsoft guilty of antitrust violations -- as his exhaustive findings of fact published nine days ago indicate he will -- a new proceeding will determine what should be done to be sure Microsoft can no longer illegally wield monopoly power. 
 A committee led by Timothy Bresnahan, a Stanford University economist, is preparing recommendations for the Justice Department, and a professor familiar with the panel's work said that it was likely to call for changes that would restructure Microsoft or its products in some way.
Herbert Hovenkamp, an antitrust expert and law professor at the University of Iowa, is among the academics and consultants working for the states. In an interview last week, he said, "If the findings show significant abuse of monopoly power, then the appropriate remedy is to break up the monopoly -- not to hobble the company or try to regulate it."
For his part, William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, said he would like to settle the case and would be willing to consider any settlement proposal that protects the company's ability to add any features it wants to the Windows operating system.
In an interview in the issue of Time magazine that reaches newsstands today, Mr. Gates was asked whether he might accept one oft-suggested remedy -- ordering Microsoft to publish the source code for Windows so competitors could create operating systems that are compatible with the vast library of software written for Windows. Mr. Gates said:
"The only thing that we know for sure would be bad for consumers is anything that blocked us from being able to innovate Windows, or anything that made it so that when people buy Windows they don't know what is in it. Beyond that we'll be as pragmatic as we can."
Late last week, The New York Times interviewed five other academic authorities or former government officials who maintain a direct professional interest in the case but are not attached to either Microsoft or the government. All have followed the case closely and have studied the judge's findings of fact.
Each was asked what remedy he would choose, if he had the power to impose a solution. Three called for structural remedies. Two said they believed that remedies keeping Microsoft intact but forcing the company to modify its behavior would be sufficient.
But all agreed on one point: Any remedy should be "self-executing," as several of them put it. In other words, once imposed it should not require further oversight or interference from the courts or the government. On that point, at least, the Justice Department, the state attorneys general and, most likely, Judge Jackson agree.
 
Nicholas Economides
Professor of economics
New York University
Mr. Economides teaches economics, including antitrust issues and computer networking. He has written academic papers on the case, but said, "I am not now and have never been involved in any litigation involving Microsoft."
Mr. Economides would institute remedies that correct the specific allegations raised in the government's case but would have little effect on future behavior because, he said, "one has to be very careful to be sure that the remedy is not worse than the present situation."
He described himself as an admirer of Microsoft, adding, "I don't see how consumers were hurt when they were given a browser free, and Microsoft has not raised the price of its operating system." A key conclusion in the judge's findings is that Microsoft's decision to tie its Internet browser to the Windows operating system was an anticompetitive act.
Mr. Economides would force Microsoft to rewrite its contracts with many or all of its partners, customers and suppliers, "to be sure that the violations in the suit" -- like Microsoft's restrictive contracts with online service providers -- "will not happen again." Of the concern that Microsoft might find a way to evade contract restrictions, Mr. Economides said, "I have confidence that smart lawyers will be able to work it out."
He also said he would require Microsoft to publish many of the software codes known as application programming interfaces that allow other software companies to "hook their programs to Windows." Netscape and other companies have accused Microsoft of withholding those as penalty for failing to comply with requests from Microsoft. But he would force Microsoft to publish the codes only for Netscape and the other companies that were part of the lawsuit.
Other companies facing similar problems in the future would have to make their own cases in court, he said. If stronger remedies were imposed, Mr. Economides averred, "consumers would lose."
 
William J. Baer
Former director
Bureau of Compliance
Federal Trade Commission
The trade commission shares antitrust enforcement with the Justice Department, and Mr. Baer ran the agency's enforcement office until last month. He supervised the commission's antitrust investigation of Intel, which ended with a settlement last March. But Mr. Baer was not working for the agency when it last investigated Microsoft, in the early 1990's.
While Mr. Baer said he had not steeped himself in the merits of the specific remedies under discussion, he was clear on the principles he would work to uphold.
"If you start with a monopoly company that has unlawfully limited competition," he said, "the goal of any remedy has to be more than telling them, 'Go out and sin no more.' That approach would allow the monopolist to maintain the benefits it has gained from illegal use of its monopoly power.
"What you want to do is move the market back in the direction it would have gone but for the unlawful conduct. So the remedy has to be something structural."
While Mr. Baer was not willing to suggest a specific solution, he did say: "It would be something like licensing their source code, spinning off part of the company. Whatever it is, it should be self-executing.
"But my key point is this: What kind of lesson does a monopolist take if he is told, 'Please don't do this any more,' and is allowed to keep all of his ill-gotten gains? If the judge found that Microsoft obtained its position illegally, then Microsoft should have to pay for it.
"A structural remedy also sends a signal to any possible future monopolists that they don't want to go down this road."
 
Robert Litan
Director of economic studies
Brookings Institution
While deputy assistant attorney general in the Justice Department's antitrust division, Mr. Litan negotiated the consent decree with Microsoft that resulted from the department's previous antitrust investigation of the company in 1995. The present case began when the Justice Department charged that Microsoft had violated that 1995 agreement.
Mr. Litan said he now believes another conduct remedy of the sort agreed to in 1995 "just invites more lawyering."
"Microsoft lawyers would immediately go to work going around it," he said. "It's like a dam. Leaks would spring, and you'd constantly be trying to stop them.
"So my proposal," he added, "would start with breaking the company in two -- one operating system company and another with everything else. But if you stop there, it'll be fraught with all kinds of problems. You'd have to continually be supervising the operating system company" to make sure it did not pursue other anticompetitive practices.
"So therefore I'm attracted to the idea of breaking the operating system company into three equal companies -- all with identical properties and activities. And then you let these three operating system companies loose to compete."
William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, would choose which company he would lead -- one of the three operating-system companies, or the fourth one holding all of Microsoft's other products and services.
But the company's other senior leaders could not go with Mr. Gates. They would have to be spread themselves among the other new companies. And the $18 billion in cash reserves Microsoft holds would be divided among the four new companies, too.
Critics of this idea, or variations of it, say they worry that consumers would soon be faced with incompatible operating systems. Mr. Litan said that would not occur in the short term because the companies would start with the same operating system code.
And if, as expected, the systems eventually diverged, other companies would spring up to write what he called "bridging programs" that would let software for one operating system work with the others.
"With these companies competing with each other, you'd get more innovation, and that's the goal," he said. "It may be that the trade for that" is the risk of incompatibility.
In the end, Mr. Litan concluded, "the operating system market will probably collapse over time."
"There may be just one left, one winner," he said. "But whoever won would be severely chastened by this case."
 
Robert E. Hall
Economist
Stanford University
Mr. Hall comments on and writes about the case but said, "I enjoy the position of being neutral."
Of his proposed remedy, he said, "I can't claim that it will solve every problem. But the real issue is being sure that the remedy does more good than harm. So I think it needs to be conservative and clean."
Mr. Hall said he "admired the quality of the economic arguments in the judge's findings." And one good way to address them, he added, would be to prohibit Microsoft from "conditioning the sale of Windows licenses to computer manufacturers on anything other than the manufacturers' ability to pay for the license and to respect Microsoft's intellectual property."
Evidence presented during the trial showed that Microsoft threatened to withhold Windows from I.B.M. and Compaq Computer when those two companies engaged in other actions Microsoft did not like.
"A remarkably large number of problems shown in the suit would be resolved with this," he said.
Mr. Hall said he would also force Microsoft to revise its contracts to prevent predatory or exclusionary dealings. That would ensure that Microsoft did not condition its dealings with other companies on their willingness to support other Microsoft products or ventures, he said.
Mr. Hall acknowledged that his proposed remedies were "modest." But, he added, "I think this whole system is gong to work -- and work without strangling Microsoft."
 
Steven Salop
Professor of economics and law
Georgetown University
Mr. Salop has worked as a consultant for many computer and software companies, including some of Microsoft's competitors. He has also written about the case. And to him, "the record is sufficiently strong to support a strong structural remedy."
He added that a conduct remedy -- forcing the company to rewrite contracts or modify its behavior -- "is too intrusive and regulatory."
"It's not in the interests of the economy, or of Microsoft," he said. "What they want is to get this behind them once and for all so they get on with what they say they want to do, and that is innovate."
So Mr. Salop advocated "a hybrid remedy" -- exactly the same proposal Mr. Litan offered for dividing the company into four parts.He rejected the idea long favored by the states of forcing Microsoft to auction the source code for Windows so that other companies could use it to develop competing operating systems.
"The source code is not well documented," he said. "It's not like the recipe for the new Coke; there are 30 million lines of code. You need access to information from Microsoft employees. So these new companies would start with a real technological disadvantage. Microsoft would leave them in the dust."
The beauty of his idea, he said, is that it is one-time and clean. "And we'd have competition in the operating system market."

HEADLINE: In Kansas City, Few Trains, but New Life in the Station

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 14

 BODY:
It required new laws in two states, sales-tax elections in five counties and an act of Congress, as well as a major corporate giving campaign, but Kansas City's monumental Union Station has finally been restored to the grandeur it once enjoyed as a centerpiece of the nation's passenger rail network.
Even as construction crews raced to finish the $250 million restoration and expansion of the station, the completed portions opened to the public last week after a spate of events toasting large donors and volunteers. 
 Very few passenger trains pass through Kansas City now, so the station's restored Grand Hall, with its 95-foot ceiling and three 3,000-pound chandeliers, is to serve as a public space, surrounded by new restaurants, shops and offices. The station, second in size in this country only to Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan, is envisioned as a vast indoor plaza, a gathering place intended to help draw people back to the center of the city.
The station opened in 1914 with nearly one million square feet of space. It has been expanded in this new incarnation with a 300,000-square-foot wing on the west side to house Science City, described by its creators as a place of "recreational learning." Science City is projected to draw a million paying visitors a year.
"We are creating an educational attraction for all ages," said David A. Ucko, president of Science City and the Kansas City Museum, which will manage it. "There will be a high degree of emotional engagement, and everything will be contextual, nothing abstract. There will be a lot of humor. This won't be a deadly serious place."
Those who planned, argued and campaigned for years to put together the complicated financing package for Union Station are so pleased with the results that even before the reopening they were talking of returning to the voters and asking them to extend the culture sales tax, which made the restoration possible. The idea would be to use the tax to finance a wider array of cultural offerings. Supporters said the rebirth of the station, whose architectural features are similar to those of Grand Central and Union Station in Washington, has brought a new sense of metropolitan spirit on both sides of the Missouri-Kansas line, a border across which some of the vilest actions of the Civil War occurred.
Civic leaders are daring to dream of what else might be financed by extending the eighth-of-a-cent culture tax beyond 2002, when the station restoration will be paid off. Possibilities include creation of a publicly financed arts endowment, which could benefit museums like the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, performance groups like the Lyric Opera and the Kansas City Symphony, and smaller organizations.
Other noncultural possibilities include updating the stadiums in which the football Chiefs and baseball Royals play and improving the very limited public transportation system, which serves one of the most sprawled metropolitan areas in the country.
The new Arts Council of Metropolitan Kansas City was formed partly to look at how a culture tax or other public money might be sought for the arts.
"Kansas City is in the top quartile of cities for private funding of the arts," said Jan Kreamer, president of the Greater Kansas City Community Foundation and an organizer of the arts council. "But we are near the bottom in public funding."
Two regional neighbors, Denver and St. Louis, have adopted taxes for cultural purposes, she said. But she added that no specific proposals would be formulated here until public surveys on the issue are completed. Joan Israelite, president of the Arts Council, said its creation was part of a great expansion of arts and cultural activity. "We're on the verge of a cultural renaissance," she said.
The financing of the area's cultural and other needs has grown increasingly complicated as development has spread into the five counties in Kansas and Missouri that make up the metropolitan region, and into a second tier of surrounding counties in both states as well. More than 100 municipal and other governmental entities are involved, and the principal city, Kansas City, Mo., has become a smaller piece of the whole even though its population is growing slightly.
Unlike most other metropolitan areas that reach across state lines, this region's population of 1.7 million is fairly evenly divided between the two states, as are business and industry, and people here seem to view the state line as the de facto heart of the city. Booming Johnson County, Kan., with 20-some suburban cities, rivals Kansas City proper in size and economic clout. Kansas City, Kan., much smaller and poorer than Kansas City, Mo., or Johnson County, maintains a strong industrial base.
A century and a half ago civic leaders of the two Kansas Cities laid out their principal arteries within walking distance of the other state; Union Station was built just blocks east of the state line.
"The fact is that we function as an economic city-state," said Jack Holland, an investment banker who began working on the bistate financing concept 15 years ago.
He was part of a group called Kansas City Consensus, which formed in the early 1980's to look at how Kansas City could continue to pay for cultural and recreational offerings while much of the core city's economic power was being lost to the suburbs. From that group the idea of the bistate tax emerged in 1985.
The group recommended a sales tax instead of a property tax because a sales tax could be applied uniformly throughout the metropolitan area. By contrast, assessed valuation for a similar piece of property might vary from county to county and state to state.
Supporters of the bistate tax said they found many examples around the country of culture taxes and of metropolitan area taxes that crossed county lines, but no examples of a tax that crossed a state line.
After passage of the enabling legislation in Kansas and Missouri in 1993, representatives from each state decided what projects to propose to voters. Although arts and other culture groups had been the driving force behind passage of the legislation, they had trouble agreeing on a package of programs and institutions to support.
In the end everybody could agree only on raising money to restore Union Station. Its beauty, even in its abandoned and unmaintained state, and the emotional attachment felt by people across the area made the station "the perfect candidate for election," said Jack Craft, a lawyer who led the culture-tax campaign in Missouri. "It's handsome, and it doesn't talk."
Next, advocates of the tax had to deal with the almost legendary distrust that Kansans have of the politicians in Kansas City, Mo. "So a lot of safeguards were built into the Union Station operating agreement,"said Steve Rose, a suburban newspaper publisher who ran the culture-tax campaign in Kansas.
A separate legal entity was created to own and operate the station, and an agreement was drawn up that, if the restoration project should fail at some point, ownership of Union Station would pass not to the city of Kansas City, Mo., but to the community foundation headed by Ms. Kreamer. Still nervous about the outcome of the voting, the advocates of the tax mounted what Mr. Craft said was the most expensive political campaign ever conducted in the Kansas City region, costing slightly more than $1 million. Some advertising and public relations concerns donated services.
On Nov. 5, 1996, the culture tax went before the voters in the five counties. It passed with more than 60 percent of the vote in four, losing only in Wyandotte County, site of Kansas City, Kan., the poorest county in the metropolitan area.
The tax is raising $118 million of the cost of restoring and expanding the station. An additional $100 million was raised from private contributors; the rest is coming from federal money.
Forty million dollars of the estimated $250 million price tag was set aside as an endowment whose income will pay part of the operating costs for Science City and Union Station. The rest of the $18 million operating budget is to come from paying visitors to Science City and from leasing the office and commercial space.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1080 words

HEADLINE: Net Investors Wary About Trade Talks With China

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Nov. 14

 BODY:
As the United States and China continued marathon negotiations today on China's possible entry into the World Trade Organization, nobody watched the to-and-fro more anxiously than entrepreneurs and investors in the Internet.
China's Internet industry has been in a state of suspension since September, when the nation's top communications official suddenly reaffirmed a longstanding ban on foreign investment in Chinese Internet service providers. While any trade agreement was not expected to deal specifically with the Internet, analysts said it could clarify Beijing's stance toward its bubbling online industry. 
 For restless cyberspeculators, such clarity could not come soon enough. Intel, Yahoo and other American companies rushed into partnerships with Chinese Internet providers before Beijing's warning. But new deals are being held up as investors try to guess the intentions of the Chinese official, Wu Jichuan, the minister of information industries.
"It has cast a big shadow over the industry," said Duncan Clark, a partner at BDA China, an Internet consulting firm in Beijing. "People think of it as unfinished business."
Mr. Wu said he would issue new rules on foreign investment by the end of the year. A trade agreement could have a decisive influence on those regulations because it is expected to open China's telecommunications sector to outsiders. Mr. Wu has cited the existing ban on foreign ownership of telecommunications providers as the justification for keeping foreigners out of the Internet.
"I find it very hard to believe there could be a W.T.O. deal at the same time China is imposing a complete ban on foreign investment in the Internet," said Gordon G. Chang, a partner who advises Internet companies in the Beijing office of the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.
Part of the problem in predicting China's Internet policy is that it crosses industry boundaries and intrudes into politically sensitive areas. Internet service providers, which connect users with state-run gateways to the global Internet, could be opened up as part of an agreement to open state telephone companies.
But Internet content providers could face stricter regulations, like those put on the film and publishing industries. Beijing continues to block a handful of foreign Web sites, and the authorities have begun warning Chinese Internet providers not to provide links to news services on foreign Web sites.
Some analysts say China could strangle the industry in its crib if it does not allow in foreigners. Although the number of online users in China almost doubles every year -- it is projected to grow from 2.4 million in 1998 to 16 million in 2003 -- China needs software technology from the United States to develop more sophisticated businesses in areas like electronic commerce.
"Even a momentary dip in enthusiasm in China will put it behind," Mr. Clark said. "It's like a hothouse flower: if you break the window and let in the cold air, you will kill it."
Left unsaid is that China's Internet entrepreneurs could miss out on a rich payday. China.com, a Hong Kong-based Internet provider for the mainland market, raised $84 million in a recent stock offering on the Nasdaq exchange that valued the company at $1.5 billion. Mainland Web companies with names like Sina.com and Sohu.com had hoped to reap similar riches from the market.
Publicly, the entrepreneurs are keeping up a confident front. They say they are plowing ahead with plans to raise capital and find foreign partners. They say Mr. Wu's recent dictum was part of a power struggle between conservatives and liberals in the Communist Party. And they say the government will come to accept the futility of trying to control a medium as anarchic as the Internet.
"The attitude of most investors is, 'We're going to ignore this. Eventually Beijing will lighten up,' " said Hanson Cheah, the executive director of Asia Tech Ventures, a venture capital firm here that specializes in Internet companies. But he added, "If we're wrong, we're dead."
Such caveats may be wise, given China's tense political climate and Beijing's mounting suspicion that the Internet can be used as a tool for subversion. Despite a sweeping crackdown on a spiritual movement known as Falun Gong, the government has been unable to prevent its members from using the Internet to spread news throughout China. The Chinese authorities recently arrested a student in northeastern China after he posted information about Falun Gong on the Internet.
Beijing's ambivalence toward the Internet may benefit Taiwan and Hong Kong, which are far more hospitable to foreign investors and share a common language with their mainland neighbor. America Online recently announced a partnership with China.com to introduce an America Online service in Hong Kong. The company hopes to break into the mainland, but for now, it regards Hong Kong as a reasonable staging ground.
Not all Chinese Internet entrepreneurs think open markets are an unqualified benefit. Edward Zeng, the founder of Sparkice I-Com Ltd., a three-year-old e-commerce venture in Beijing, said that letting in foreign companies without any restrictions could squash some nascent local companies.
"AOL has the money, the technology and the global consumer base," Mr. Zeng said. "If they want to set up an AOL China, nobody could compete with them."
The more likely possibility, he acknowledged, is that America Online would choose a Chinese partner to set up such a service. Mr. Zeng's own company is building an e-commerce business to sell Chinese products to consumers overseas. And he is scouting for foreign partners, a process that he says has been slowed down by the worries about China's Internet policy.
So like the political bosses in Beijing, Mr. Zeng is torn. He believes that China's Internet industry would grow faster if it were open to foreigners. But he worries about small local companies like his. In addition to his global venture, Mr. Zeng runs a string of Internet cafes and is starting a domestic e-commerce business. He plainly does not relish the prospect of competing against Amazon.com or Ebay.
Mr. Zeng, who spoke to Mr. Wu at a conference in Shanghai in October, said the minister's statements about the Internet had been misunderstood. Mr. Zeng said he believed the government's goal was not to seal off China's Internet business, but to set the stage for controlled development.

Under Wall St. Pressure, Bottler to Field Questions
In a highly unusual move, Coca-Cola's largest bottler plans a conference call with analysts and investors today that a spokeswoman said was intended to clarify questions about pricing and other issues that surfaced at a beverage conference in New York earlier this month.
The bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, is under pressure from Wall Street. The company has seen its stock battered this year -- especially since Nov. 3, when it said at the industry conference that the price it pays for the prime ingredients for soft drinks would rise at twice the usual rate next year. HEADLINE: A U.N. Watchdog Exits to Applause

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
Five years ago, under pressure from the United States, where an anti-United Nations lobby was growing on the political right, the General Assembly created a watchdog office to fight corruption and mismanagement within the organization.
On Friday, a German Foreign Ministry official, Karl Theodor Paschke, ended his nonrenewable term leading that office, having uncovered millions of dollars of fraud or abuse. 
 For the first time, the United Nations began dismissing employees quickly, recovering losses by confiscating their pensions and property, and turning over criminal cases to public trials in national courts rather than allowing malfeasance to disappear quietly. In the international legal limbo of the United Nations system, offenders may still be transferred rather than disciplined, but Mr. Paschke hopes this will be less likely in the future.
In Washington, there was parting praise for Mr. Paschke from a spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and a frequent critic of the United Nations. The spokesman, Marc Thiessen, said Mr. Paschke had taken on an enormous job in trying to reform "a very dysfunctional institution" and that the work must continue. He said that the experience proved that Congressional pressure, which led to the creation of Mr. Paschke's office, pays off.
Mr. Paschke has worked against a backdrop of unrelenting criticism from a group of developing nations, which objected to the appointment of an inspector general from an industrial nation and has blocked approval of several of his major reports. But two of his biggest cases of fraud involved Americans.
One bilked the United Nations out of about $500,000 in Geneva by setting up phony training programs, then collecting expenses for nonexistent participants. The other colluded with a travel agency in Croatia to defraud the organization for travel costs. The first was tried and convicted in Switzerland, the second in a federal court in New York.
"Clearly no one can accuse me of blurred vision," Mr. Paschke said of critics in the developing world.
Secretary General Kofi Annan has not yet chosen a replacement for Mr. Paschke, who as head of the Office of Internal Oversight Services ranked as an under secretary general.
Mr. Paschke, 64, is a former spokesman and former personnel and management chief in the German Foreign Ministry who from the outset supported more openness in the United Nations. A lawyer by training, he expanded auditing throughout the organization and sent inspectors around the world, shaking up distant offices unaccustomed to surveillance.
In an interview, Mr. Paschke said that five years of looking for trouble had taught him that corruption and mismanagement at the United Nations "are not better or not worse than in any other big bureaucracy." Problems may be more difficult to deal with, however, because of the nature of the organization and the circumstances in which it has to operate in remote, dangerous regions.
"It is a myth to believe that this organization could ever be run like a big multinational business," he said. Improved management techniques, which Mr. Annan has backed or instigated, could make a difference, Mr. Paschke said, but he added that the nature of the organization remains a barrier to fundamental change.
"This is a very political organization, a multicultural organization, an organization with a board of directors from 188 countries," he said. "Consensus management is very difficult to achieve."
Just defining corruption is not easy, as Mr. Paschke's periodic reports and thousands of recommendations attest. Is taking a free trip at the expense of a United Nations contractor unethical? Not in most member countries. Putting friends or relatives on the payroll? That is standard operating procedure in many places -- not always excluding western Europe and the United States.
Add to the mix an international civil service of very uneven quality. "This organization, until very recently, has never chosen senior staff on their management abilities," Mr. Paschke said. The result is a lack of hands-on direction, giving opportunities to wrongdoers.
"The farther away from headquarters, the more risky the environment gets," he said.
Mr. Paschke's office, which has no power to prosecute, soon identified three areas of United Nations activity where corruption arises most frequently: in peacekeeping operations, emergency relief activities and general procurement.
In such operations, United Nations officials say, ad hoc arrangements often have to be made without consultation. Many transactions in countries at war or in crisis have to be handled in cash in the absence of functioning banking systems. Local contractors, and sometimes governments, take advantage, demanding inflated payments for urgently needed goods or services. Bookkeeping is patchy, often nonexistent, especially in private organizations through which the United Nations must often work in the field.
The United Nations observer mission in Angola was examined in some detail in Mr. Paschke's last annual report, published in October. There, a resident auditor found a contractor submitting multiple photocopies of invoices, resulting in double payments totaling $30,000.
Over four years, the mission bought all airline tickets from one Johannesburg travel agent, and paid the agent more than $1.7 million without seeking approval from any superiors, the report found.
Although the Angolan government was required to give free office space to the United Nations mission -- sent to help the country recover from a devastating civil war -- Mr. Paschke's office found that various landlords had collected about $13 million in rent.
In some countries, the United Nations inspectors and auditors found government officials collecting taxes and duties on aid materials that were supposed to be imported free.
Around the world, Mr. Paschke has found the organization robbed through currency speculation, careless or nonexistent record-keeping, misuse or disuse of acquired materials (amounting to $22 million at a single supply base in Brindisi, Italy), petty cash disappearances ($3.9 million is still missing in Somalia), the loss of expensive vehicles and fraudulent claims of all kinds.
For example, two field staff members of the peacekeeping department, since dismissed, submitted $222,345 in forged education bills for their children. At the Economic Commission for Africa, $30,000 vanished when two employees began writing checks to themselves. In some cases, Mr. Paschke has advocated complete overhauls of offices abroad.
"Reform does not happen overnight," he said. "But we have been an agent for change."

HEADLINE: Daniel Margolies, 89, Lawyer And a Nuremberg Prosecutor

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Daniel Margolies, a lawyer with a long career in public service, including membership in the team of American prosecutors at the war-crimes trials in Nuremberg after World War II, died Nov. 6 at a hospital in Aurora, Colo., a suburb of Denver. He was 89.
Partly because of the fluent German he learned while doing postgraduate research on medieval manuscripts in Germany in the early 1930's, Mr. Margolies was assigned to interrogate and help build a case against the 24 major Nazi leaders in preparation for the Nuremberg trials, which began in November 1945. 
 Mr. Margolies's account of the trial, included in "Eyewitnesses at Nuremberg" by Hilary Gaskin (Arms and Armor Press, 1990), contains chilling excerpts of his questions and the banal responses they elicited.
"We would say," Mr. Margolies recalled, " 'Well, here's a document that you issued, saying that all the inhabitants of such and such a town should be shot -- Is this your signature?' and 'Why did you do this?' And he would say, 'Well, somebody or other had destroyed a truck,' or something, 'and we had to maintain a certain amount of respect.' "
Mr. Margolies married Harriet Zetterberg in London in 1945, while they were both helping to prepare the indictments.
She then joined Mr. Margolies as a member of the prosecution team in Nuremberg, but when Gen. George S. Patton Jr. decreed that there would be no room in the American Zone for the wives of his officers, Harriet Margolies dropped her married name so she could live with her husband in the hotel in Nuremberg where the prosecutors were housed.
They were, according to "The Nuremberg Trial" by Ann Tusa and John Tusa (Atheneum, 1984), "the only sinners with a marriage license."
Harriet Margolies died in 1986.
Daniel Margolies was born in Cleveland, Ohio, on April 12, 1910. After graduating from Harvard in 1931, he traveled to Germany to study medieval manuscripts. He returned after a year, graduated from Harvard Law School in 1936, and then moved to Washington where he lived for most of the next 50 years.
He began his career investigating unfair labor practices for a Senate subcommittee presided over by Senator Robert M. LaFollette Jr., the Wisconsin Republican. He then worked in the Office of Price Administration and the Office of Economic Warfare.
One of the earliest draftees in World War II, Mr. Margolies worked for the Office of Strategic Services in London and in occupied Germany before becoming a prosecutor at Nuremberg.
After the trials, Mr. Margolies joined the State Department and later the Foreign Service. He was the economics counsel in the United States Embassy in London from 1957 to 1960 and in Leopoldville, Congo, now known as Kinshasa, from 1960 to 1962.
Returning to Washington in 1963, Mr. Margolies worked on Latin American affairs and then as foreign policy adviser to the President's Science Advisory Committee.
Mr. Margolies is survived by two children, Mary Margolies DeForest of Denver and David Margolies of Oakland, Calif.

HEADLINE: If It's Monday, This Must Be Turkey

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 14

 BODY:
As a candidate in 1992, Bill Clinton criticized President George Bush for excessive globe-trotting. But in his nearly seven years in office, Mr. Clinton has taken more foreign trips, spent more time overseas and assembled larger and costlier entourages than any president before.
He has been to summit meetings, and seen big game in Botswana. He has held tete-a-tetes with heads of state and strolled the Great Wall of China. He has visited troops in Bosnia and viewed Michelangelo's masterpieces in the Sistine Chapel. 
 "There are a few places still left on the list he hasn't been," Joe Lockhart, the White House press secretary, remarked recently. "And we have 15 months to rectify that."
When Air Force One touched down late tonight in Ankara, President Clinton began a trip through southern Europe that will eclipse Mr. Bush's last remaining travel distinction, the record for number of nations visited by an American president.
Until now, Mr. Bush had visited more countries than any other president: 60 stops in just four years. Mr. Clinton will knock Mr. Bush off that perch in the days ahead.
After a state visit in Ankara, Mr. Clinton will fly to Istanbul for a security conference. Then he is off to a meeting on progressive governance in Florence; a state visit to Greece; the first-ever stop by an American president in Sofia, Bulgaria; and a visit to American troops stationed in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
By the trip's end just before Thanksgiving, Mr. Clinton will have stopped over the course of his presidency in 63 nations, many of which have never before been host to an American president. Mr. Clinton, according to State Department historical records, was the first United States chief executive to set foot in Botswana, the first to stop in Kuwait and the first to visit Denmark, Slovenia and South Africa.
Already, Mr. Clinton has left the United States more often than any other president. His visit to Oslo last week for events commemorating the death of Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel was Mr. Clinton's 44th overseas trip, almost as many sojourns as Mr. Bush and Ronald Reagan amassed in their combined three terms. And, according to White House records, Mr. Clinton has already spent nearly 200 days out of the country, considerably more time than any predecessor.
Presidential travels can focus the spotlight on countries that often feel ignored. "We don't expect a magic wand," said a Bulgarian official in Washington. "But if President Clinton pats us on the shoulder, he may give a signal to private businesses to start looking at us."
The cost of the trips has riled some of Mr. Clinton's detractors on Capitol Hill. In the course of just over three months in 1998, the president's trips to Chile, China and six African countries cost an estimated $72 million, according to a recent study by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress.
The total number of officials and others who traveled at government expense in connection with the three trips exceeded 2,400 people, excluding Secret Service agents, the accounting office report said. Although the report did not directly compare Mr. Clinton's entourage with those of past presidents, administration officials say presidential travel has grown more elaborate and complicated over the years.
Ten advance teams traveled to Africa in the months leading to Mr. Clinton's visits in Ghana, Uganda, Rwanda, South Africa, Botswana and Senegal. The bulk of the $42.8 million cost for the Africa trip -- the longest trip to the continent by any American president -- fell on the Defense Department, which flew 98 airlift missions to deliver vehicles and other equipment from various locations in the United States and Europe. The Pentagon also provided 13 Army and Marine Corps helicopters in Africa and set up temporary medical evacuation units in five countries.
"I encourage people to go and see the world," said Senator Craig Thomas of Wyoming, one of the Republicans who asked for the cost accounting of the president's travel. "I am not an isolationist. I don't expect him to pack his own lunch or use frequent flier miles. But I expect this president and all presidents not to be excessive about the cost."
Presidential aides say that travel costs are high for good reasons and that overseas visits benefit the United States economy more than they sap the treasury.
"There is a high cost of providing physical security to the president when he's overseas and providing secure communications," Mr. Lockhart said. "We are the lone remaining superpower in the world. The president needs the ability to handle any crisis any time, anywhere. That comes at a cost."
"The kind of engagement around the world that the country deserves does cost money," Mr. Lockhart added, "but I think the president believes that it's money well spent."
The makeup of Mr. Clinton's entourages has been scrutinized from the start. On his first overseas trip to Japan and Korea, he briefly considered taking his mother-in-law; his daughter, Chelsea, and three of Chelsea's teenage friends. He traveled with his personal secretary, Betty Currie, to Africa shortly after she testified before the grand jury investigating him. His aides studiously avoided taking any United States businessmen along to China during controversies over campaign contributions and technology transfers.
First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton has traveled considerably. Of her 51 trips to such far-flung countries as Nepal, Iceland, Morocco and Uzbekistan, 23 have been solo ventures (with an entourage but without the president). She will travel along for part of the trip through Europe, and advisers said both her schedule and the president's had to be meshed while planning the complicated, politically sensitive itinerary.
White House aides point out that political opponents have found ulterior motives just about every time Mr. Clinton's Air Force jet has left United States airspace.
His first trips in 1993 -- to Canada, Korea and Japan -- were seen as efforts by the young president to show that he really could handle foreign affairs. The barrage of travel early in his second term was written off as the beleaguered chief executive's trying to escape investigations back home. Now, with the end of his presidency growing near, Mr. Clinton is said to be on a farewell tour.
"There is always an inclination for a president to want to say goodbye to his peers around the world, and I think that's the phase we're in now," said Marlin Fitzwater, press secretary to former Presidents Bush and Reagan. "Also, he is becoming less relevant. If no one pays any attention to him here, he can go oversees and find that everyone cares."
Mr. Fitzwater remembers candidate Clinton's urging Mr. Bush to stay home more often. "It's time for us to have a president who cares more about Littleton, N.H., than about Liechtenstein, more about Manchester than Micronesia," Mr. Clinton said back then.
White House aides say Mr. Clinton's real point was not Mr. Bush's travel schedule but his seeming lack of focus on domestic policies. Balance is essential, Mr. Clinton's advisers say, pointing to the trip that the president sandwiched in between Oslo and Athens this month -- an antipoverty tour with a domestic focus and stops no more exotic than Newark and Hartford. (It was his second such tour this year.)
And although the current trip will allow the president to see some prime tourist draws, advisers say it is full of serious foreign policy pursuits. The trip's goals, said Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, are nothing less than "promoting stability in the Balkans, democracy in Serbia, reconciliation in the Aegean, a settlement on Cyprus, peace in the Caucasus and integration of Russia into the global community."
Despite all his travel, Mr. Clinton does not appear overly jet-lagged. On his travel wish list in the year 2000, aides say, are trips to southern Asia, Latin America, the Middle East, Africa and Europe.
Yet there are limits even for a president with a gassed-up jet at his beck and call. Diplomacy can sometimes interfere with desire.
Mr. Clinton postponed a trip to India and Pakistan after dueling nuclear tests in those countries and now faces the sticky question of whether to visit the region in the wake of last month's coup d'etat in Islamabad.
"The president has wanted to visit the region for some time, and he continues to want to do so," Mr. Berger said. "The coup in Islamabad complicates that situation, but at this point no decisions have been made."
Mr. Clinton also bypassed Nigeria during his 1998 tour of Africa to protest the military leadership there, although he welcomed the newly elected president, Olusegun Obasanjo, to the White House last month.
Political considerations have also prevented President Clinton from touching down in Havana, where Fidel Castro has frustrated the United States for 40 years. "I hope someday we'll all be able to travel to a democratic Cuba," Mr. Clinton said at his very first presidential news conference, on March 24, 1993.
