HEADLINE: Communist Losing Bid For Top Job In Ukraine

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, Nov. 14

 BODY:
President Leonid Kuchma was heading for a second term today, according to early results that indicated a convincing victory over a Communist who had frightened many voters with his calls to turn back to the Soviet era.
With about 66 percent of the votes counted, Mr. Kuchma had won 56.5 percent and the Communist Party chief, Petro Symonenko, had 37.5 percent, the Central Elections Commission reported. Voter turnout was 73.8 percent, it said. 
 Mr. Kuchma, 61, focused his campaign on warnings that Mr. Symonenko would revive the restrictions of the Soviet era.
The president has pledged to continue market reforms and a foreign policy that centers on close ties with western Europe, the United States and NATO. But he failed to revive the economy or crack down on rampant corruption during his first term, and most analysts doubt there will be a dramatic turnaround.
Mr. Symonenko, who tried at the last minute to convince voters that they had nothing to fear, admitted today that their fears were too great.
He had pledged to maintain rights to private property, support private business and restore churches despite the Communists' atheistic policies. But the Communist program also called for a state-planned economy with heavy subsidies for major industries, price controls, halting the privatization of state assets, a ban on land sales and a likely government monopoly on foreign trade.
Despite widespread dissatisfaction with Mr. Kuchma, a return to Soviet-style life seemed even more frightening to some Ukrainians. Even impoverished Ukrainians were voting for Mr. Kuchma today, seeking to avert a Communist comeback and preserve whatever stability they might have.
"I've marched enough under red flags in my life," said one Kiev factory worker, Oleksandr Plakhotniuk.
Mr. Symonenko, 47, was second in the first round of voting on Oct. 31, when Mr. Kuchma failed to gain an outright majority.

HEADLINE: Why Trade Will Win

BYLINE: By Gordon G. Chang; Gordon G. Chang is a lawyer based in Beijing for an American firm.

DATELINE: HONG KONG

 BODY:
Many Americans seem to think it is vital that we find a way to get China into the World Trade Organization. The United States trade deficit with China, likely to reach $60 billion for 1999, is already the worst case of imbalance in all of our foreign trade -- imports from China are now about five times higher than our exports there. If China can't be drawn into the disciplined framework of the W.T.O., the alarmist thinking goes, the United States may never be able to sell widely in the huge Chinese market.
A W.T.O. agreement, the proponents think, would lead rapidly to lower Chinese tariffs and a fixed timetable for measures to open China as a market. Failure to lock up a deal now could mean the earliest that China could join would be three years from now, at the conclusion of the round of trade negotiations that begins in a couple of weeks in Seattle. 
 But the worrying is wrong. America need feel little urgency to get China into the W.T.O. The Chinese economy is in big trouble, and ultimately it cannot be rescued without further economic reform of the kind that will let foreign businesses operate far more freely and fairly. Whether there is an agreement or not, China is going to have to liberalize its economy.
A trade agreement now, before the inevitable structural reform, might have little positive effect anyway. China, after all, does not always live up to its agreements as foreign nations see them. Ask the elderly Falun Gong practitioners who were dragged by their hair from Tiananmen Square this month, for example, about Beijing's adherence to the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which it signed last year. Chinese citizens have human rights, but only as their government defines them.
Foreign investors know that China has a similar genius for reinterpreting economic agreements as its ministries make new rules.
What China cannot interpret away are the signs of its own economic failure. Two years of deflation have taken their toll. Heavy government spending has not worked to restart domestic consumption. China is now an addict in the debt markets. It builds roads and bridges and dams and hands out increases in pay and pensions and benefits, but it cannot persuade its citizens, who evidently see hard times ahead, to become bigger spenders.
At the core of the problem, China's state-owned enterprises are dying, noncompetitive even in its restrictive system. Beijing forced domestic commercial banks to lend them money that, as it turns out, will never be paid back, leaving the banks with bad and nonperforming loans that some estimate at $500 billion.
Obsolete inventory scars balance sheets. Foreign investment sinks monthly. Corruption eats away at the fabric of society, and, most telling of all, foreign currency flees the country. China claimed its economy grew 7.8 percent last year. Adjust the statistics for exaggeration and subtract out economically useless production, and China barely had positive growth. The country has tens of millions unemployed or underemployed citizens, with millions more young people ready to enter the job market.
All of this is why, despite all of the anti-American sentiment in China these days, Chinese negotiators have been talking so intensely in the last few days to Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative. And it is why, W.T.O. or no W.T.O., China will open its economy.
Take telecommunications, one area of contention with the United States. China's telecommunications ministry is trying to prohibit foreign investment, but Beijing has staked much of its future on the growth of technologically advanced industries. Its leaders know that the fast way of building them is with the technical and financial help of foreigners.
In banking, another controversial area, the future is even clearer. After failures of China's nonbank financial institutions, the country is facing an acute shortage of liquidity and is accelerating the relaxation of rules that hampered foreign bankers. Perhaps even more important, its troubled domestic banks have begun to benefit from foreign know-how and will need more of it.
Deng Xiaoping, President Jiang Zemin's illustrious predecessor, talked about making China rich and strong. Mr. Jiang knows that, in these troubled days, his country cannot go it alone in reaching that goal. China will move forward, whether inside or outside the W.T.O. At the end of the day, it really doesn't matter which it is.

HEADLINE: For Three Interns, Fatigue And Healing at Top Speed

SERIES: LIFE, DEATH AND MANAGED CARE: A Welcome to the Real World -- Second of four articles.

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
The interns felt they had to watch "E.R.," because it was about them. Or it was about them spiced with a lot more melodrama. Sometimes it was silly. Sometimes it was maudlin. Sometimes it was all too real.
One evening on "E.R.," an intern nearly comatose from working all night miscalculated a dosage because her vision was blurry, sending a patient into cardiac arrest. As she watched, weary herself from the tornado of work these early weeks, Dr. Jennifer James thought, "Wow, that's really true"; her vision got blurry as well during overnight duty. And then she worried a little more about her long hours and the paralyzing possibility that she might do something wrong. 
 What with New York's much-publicized assault on interns' hours, Dr. James and the other new recruits might have expected the issue to have gone away. Instead, as St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center struggled to cope with relentless cost pressures, hours seemed to be driving everyone crazier than ever before.
Everyone talked about hours. Opinions flew back and forth. Were the interns working too long for their own and their patients' good (as the interns themselves insisted) or not long enough (as many of the senior doctors felt just as passionately)? Were their brains active or inactive when they did that lumbar puncture at 4 in the morning?
Dr. James's days were merciless assaults on her circadian rhythm. They started in the dark, and seemed never to end. She came out of sleep slowly, everything swaying foggily before her. Since her husband insisted on further rest, she flicked on a flashlight to rummage through her bureau for clothes. Then she ate a soundless breakfast.
She and the other interns lived in apartments opposite Roosevelt Hospital, the buildings preternaturally quiet since their inhabitants were perpetually at work or asleep. So many ate at the Olympic Flame Diner on 60th Street that it was christened the resident dining room. Everything proceeded so fast in their lives that one resident conserved precious nanoseconds by having coffee delivered to his door.
As she hurried across the street to the hospital, amid waves of rumpled white coats, Dr. James mulled the day's prospects: it was her "Good Day," which, in the converse thinking of the hospital, meant she was likely to be swamped with work. Sure enough, once she was inside the residents' room, with its sharp smells of moldering food from the night workers, the senior resident, after a chummy, "Hiya!" inquired, "What are you, Jennifer, good day?"
"Yes, Good Day," she replied, and three patients and two sets of transfer orders were flung at her. She woke up fast.
The interns sorted their days into three categories: Good Days, Bad Days and Call Days. On Call Days in some rotations, they officially worked from 8 a.m. until 8 the following morning (in practice, closer to 10:30 or noon). You only admitted patients on Call Days. A Bad Day was the day after call, when supervisors tried to be easy on the fatigued interns. Good Days came between Bad Days and Call Days, when you were supposedly reinvigorated and the hospital felt free to pile on the work.
So Good Days really became Bad Days, and Bad Days came closer to being Good Days. Given that the interns never felt fully rested, all days felt like Mediocre Days interspersed with Hideous Days.
Hours had become a hot issue a decade ago, when, after the death of 18-year-old Libby Zion at New York Hospital, the state fortified supervision and barred residents from working more than 80 hours a week and 24 hours straight. Before then, interns at St. Luke's-Roosevelt had worked in excess of 100 hours and commonly went 48 hours straight caring for patients.
Now, schedules called for six-day, 80-hour weeks, with Call Days coming every fourth day on the wards and every third day in intensive care. Undoubtedly, the workload had eased up -- some.
To the older doctors, though, the new work rules threatened to render the interns soft. They hated the rules and seemed to make no great effort to ensure that they were enforced. As they saw it, patient care was being compromised and teaching hours lost; each time a patient was handed off to another doctor, they argued, something was sacrificed in the "continuity of care."
"Society is pushing doctors to be cops and firemen," Dr. Michael Lesch, the chairman of the department of medicine, liked to say. "You work shifts and you don't take the patient home with you. How would you like to have a 14-hour surgical procedure and after 8 hours they change doctors? They do it in Sweden."
This inevitably led to a lesser-of-two-evils debate: Who would you rather be treated by -- a walking zombie who knew your case or an alert intern who did not? Dr. Lesch's choice was the exhausted intern familiar with his case, not a night-shift worker.
Dr. James voted for the alert intern, especially with hospitalized patients so much sicker these days. She had only to assess herself during the latter hours of call. Tiredness blanketed her, blotting out much cerebral activity. Her speech was hesitant.
And the issue had been muddied even further by staff cuts and other new demands on the interns.
Toward the end of her rotation in intensive care, she was averaging 120 hours a week, in clear violation of the law. Some Call Days, she worked 30 hours straight. Occasionally, she went 12 days without a full day off. Fatigue dogged her like a bad back.
The emotional toll made her even more exhausted. She had a 62-year-old leukemia patient. On rounds, her supervisor said there was a 99 percent chance he would die within 24 hours. Just yesterday the man had joked with her: "This sure isn't like 'E.R.' "
"No it isn't," she had laughed.
Now she felt heartbroken.
Addled interns on the floors were juggling a blur of up to 20 patients at a time, far beyond the 12-patient limit set by the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education. Interns were supposed to handle only five admissions a day, though the hospital had its own limit of six, because of insufficient manpower. On weekends, interns commonly had as many as eight. Small wonder they called admissions "hits." One intern would ask another after a night on call, "What was the damage?" and the groggy reply would be, "I really got hurt last night."
Dr. James and the others lamented that, among other things, they had no time for the reading or noon lectures essential to their education. The discontent escalated. Finally, they had had enough. In mid-August, the residents held a meeting and drafted a petition listing their grievances.
Dr. Lesch met with them and acknowledged that they were right in their outrage. He promised to advertise at once for four more residents. The help was sorely needed. One of the original interns had quit, overwhelmed. He had returned home to Japan and an uncertain future.
 
'I Need a Doctor'
Every time he put his hand on another patient, Dr. Edward Lathan felt he was learning something. He was amazed at how much responsibility he was given. After he examined someone in the Roosevelt Hospital emergency room, he would sit down with his supervisor, who would grill him: "What do you think?" "Did you see the X-ray?" "Why didn't you see the X-ray?" But there were also times when the supervisor would get that icy look that meant, "Have you seen that chart rack?" In the grand sense, the E.R. was a game of ever-increasing speed, of lives slipping from one state to another, and it was called Clear the Rack.
There were days when the intern faded and the physician-to-be came into focus, and vice versa. Dr. Lathan sent a woman to be X-rayed for a possible fracture. X-ray sent her right back. Please remove her earrings and necklace. "I get so tired of telling them," said the radiologist. A man was crashing, and Dr. Lathan hooked him up to an oxygen mask. He stared incredulously. Why wasn't he improving? It helped if you turned on the oxygen.
There were infinite distinctions to be learned, certain managed-care phone numbers to call for permission to let patients pass Go and enter the hospital. "You wait 45 minutes and no one calls back," he said. "Meanwhile, there are five more patients."
He could be excused in his incomprehension, for Dr. Gregg Husk, the department chairman, felt bewildered himself. "It's like good luck in knowing what I'm supposed to do -- what phone number I call and what behavior I'm supposed to follow so everyone is ecstatically happy," he said. "If we admit someone and we didn't make the right phone call, it affects revenue. Many people don't have a medical card on them. They didn't plan on getting shot that day."
Everything imaginable showed up -- ear cut on a dresser, "poisoned" by tap water, nail in the foot. And more often than not in this age of emergency room as primary-care physician for the poor and uninsured, the precipitating reason was less than life-threatening, never less so than when an agitated woman arrived by ambulance with a broken fingernail. The sub-specialist needed was a manicurist.
Next night, three patients were "going down" simultaneously. "I need a doctor," a nurse shouted. She looked straight at Dr. Lathan. He felt he was watching something on a screen.
The man had congestive heart failure. Dr. Lathan talked soothingly, coaxing him to relax, as he listened to his lungs. They were filled with fluid. He kept talking, buying time, acting superficially calm as he silently prayed for a supervisor. Why was the staff so thin? At last the supervisor came.
When he left work, Dr. Lathan had to force himself to eat. He could never go straight to bed. His thoughts had to settle first. "You spend the whole day in the emergency room giving," he said one evening. "When you get home, you wonder, when do you get to take?"
 
Indignities of Internship
Dr. Bryan Holland was already on overload when a nurse appeared to report that an I.V. had to be replaced.
"Can you do it?" he asked.
"He's a hard stick," she said, jargon for someone with veins difficult to locate. Sometimes it was truly a hard stick (a drug addict with deflated veins or an obese patient with veins obliterated by fat), but often it was a nurse deflecting work.
It was not what he had signed up for, being treated as a "scut monkey." True, scut work had always been part of the bargain. But cuts in support staff sometimes heaped more work on interns.
Scut work had elastic meaning, but tended to cover things like taking blood, attaching I.V.'s, transporting patients and writing progress notes. Dr. Holland figured half his day was given to paperwork alone. The parameters of scut work widened when the hospital began requiring that all orders be entered into the computer. Many of the supervisors -- known as attendings -- did not care to be bothered learning the electronic notation. Just like that, the interns became data-entry clerks.
Internship also came with certain hazing rituals. In the clinic, the attendings stressed the importance of not giving children foul-tasting medications. Several times, Dr. Holland was told to sample various concoctions for suitability. The attendings knew full well which tasted like candy, which like sewage. But they delighted in watching him wince his way through the rancid offerings.
Even the dress code got the interns exercised. Residents had to wear thigh-length white jackets, while attendings and chief residents wore knee-length ones. It was a demarcation of the strata of the hospital. Dr. James and the other interns detested the short coats, feeling they looked "stupid," especially with their pockets full of instruments and books. For a while, a rash of medicine residents flouted the rules and donned long coats. Their superiors told them to get them off.
 
Hurry Up and Wait
It took time to figure out the clinic. Everything was on parade, an awesome randomness of complaints -- a rash, a headache, asthma, a bum foot. Much of it was detective work. The criminal was disease.
Dr. James had just seen a 65-year-old woman, petite and confused. The other day, she said, her legs had felt hot and she'd had chest pain. Now Dr. James was in line, waiting to review the case with an attending. It was almost like a bakery -- take a ticket. She would see a patient, talk with an attending, return for a final word with the patient. Sometimes she got right in. Sometimes, like now, she was third in line. Patients waiting for interns, interns waiting for attendings. Everyone waiting.
Seated before the attending, Dr. James went over the woman with chest pains.
The attending said, "It could be a viral thing. It would be good to know what she was doing when she felt the pain and exactly what it felt like."
"I tried to get that," Dr. James said. "She wasn't sure."
"I'll go in and ask some questions," he said. "They always tell a different story when the attending comes in."
He went in and said: "Now inside your chest, did it feel like butterflies in there?"
The woman said, "It felt slow."
A nurse poked her head in: "There are three waiting."
Dr. James had someone scheduled every half-hour, yet she often needed twice that much time. This was the new equation of the teaching hospital -- trying to balance economics, instruction and patient care -- and it often didn't equate.
Not so long ago, interns spent nearly all their time on the wards. Now, under the confinements of managed care and enhanced treatment techniques, most of the work of medicine got done not in hospitals but in doctors' offices. Internship had begun to change accordingly: the year before, the outpatient portion of a medicine resident's training rose to 33 percent from 25; for pediatric residents, it went to 50 percent from 25. The clinics, the theory went, would help mold a doctor for a new era of preventive medicine and primary care -- one who would enter practice attuned to interpersonal relationships.
For Dr. James, that meant spending Friday afternoons at her "continuity" clinic, where patients would be assigned to her for the entire three-year residency, as well as several monthlong clinic rotations.
Yet, she was still spending the bulk of her time on the wards. And though she liked the clinic because it mimicked her future life ("I'm beginning to feel like a real doctor," she said. "It's cool."), much of it was bread-and-butter medicine, and she felt she learned more on the floor. The supervisors seemed to treat the clinic as a sideline. If she didn't finish her work on the floor before clinic, she would have to return in the evening. "When you go to the clinic, it's on top of everything else," she said.
Plus, the clinic seemed to allow little time for teaching. On the floors, patients remained for days, not minutes. The interns heard about them at length during daily rounds. In the clinic, the attendings were under pressure to keep patient flow speedy. Insurance paid the same if a visit took two minutes or two hours. One attending in the clinic habitually spent a lot of time teaching and questioning. Dr. James dreaded seeing him on busy days. By teaching so much, he put her behind schedule.
"There's less time to soak things in and put it on the table and discuss it," said Dr. Lesch. "When do I get a chance in clinic to talk about ethics? How do I teach the difference between treating a patient and managing a patient? How do I teach someone to be kind? How do I teach someone how and when to be scared?"
A 26-year-old woman appeared with a numb hand. Ultimately she didn't need Dr. James. She needed a hand specialist. What she got was Dr. James. She had waited two hours to see her. She had waited a week for the appointment, after having been to the E.R. This was the gatekeeper theory of managed care -- no one went to a specialist until the primary care doctor said so.
Dr. James said so; she also said she did not understand this delay. The woman had carpal tunnel syndrome. The E.R. doctor had known she needed a specialist. Dr. James's role, as she put it, was "basically just to do the paperwork."
Naturally empathetic, she tried to spend time listening to patients, to win people over with fraternization, to counsel them on preventive care. Also, arguably the most important thing the interns learned was how to elicit information. What did it mean when a woman told Dr. James: "I've got something like an infection in my mouth. Also pain in my back. And in my ear, a little noise. It goes and comes back." What did it mean when someone said, "I just feel weird."
And yet the clock was always ticking away money. She had learned in medical school that, on average, doctors let patients speak no more than 16 seconds before interrupting them. A man came in and his heart was racing. Turned out he had just scampered out to feed the parking meter. Let him sit for 20 minutes and check him again was the counsel of the attending. The hospital should have just paid the parking ticket.
That patients felt dehumanized in this beat-the-clock environment was a much-heard truth. Dr. James had been taught certain techniques so patients would not feel rushed even as they were being rushed. Take a deep breath before entering, so your speech is unhurried. Sit down rather than stand up, if only for a second. When you enter, don't walk right to the patient, but meander around insouciantly as if you have nothing else to do.
As much as she could, Dr. James did sit down with patients. But she didn't always remember the deep breath, and she usually forgot about her footwork. She headed straight for the patient.
 
Diagnosis: Managed-Careitis
In the early-morning gloom, a woman in her late 60's arrived at the E.R. with her daughter. She had chronic obstructive coronary disease. She had been discharged just the day before. She had a fever. She was disoriented. Her respiration was slowing down. An attending instructed Dr. Lathan to insert a breathing tube. Ten minutes later, her blood pressure began to drop. Five more minutes and the doctors were trying to revive her. A half-hour later, she was dead.
The daughter began wailing and banging on the door of her mother's room. Fearing she would break the glass, the doctors let her in.
Dr. Lathan's first interaction with death came in college, and he had reacted less to the death than to the conduct of the doctors, who were so detached they joked as they worked on the faltering patient. "I didn't think that was anything to laugh about," he recalled. "I wasn't going to be that way."
Now, with his own first death, he felt like crawling into a corner, but it was the beginning of his shift and there were patients waiting. His whole countenance changed. He was bothered that the woman had been sent home in this new world of quick movement, though who knew if it had contributed to her death? He remembered the crying, the anguish of the daughter. No, there was nothing funny in his mind.
You dealt with a lot in the E.R. other than medical care. You dealt with people who showed up with a feigned complaint that was really an interest in free food. You dealt with people who wanted a "drive-through," in and out as fast as it took to acquire a burger and fries at McDonald's. You dealt with people who "eloped," walked out unannounced, labs and diagnosis still pending.
And you got people whose primary emergency was that they had had to wait too long for an appointment with their managed-care doctor. Or they came with the self-diagnosis that they hated their managed-care doctor. They had managed-careitis.
Here now was an elopement. The man kept saying, "Beer, beer, beer." The nurse told him, "No beer." His beverage of choice unavailable, he yanked out his I.V. and left.
Sardonic epithets were part of the medical experience, best used out of public earshot. "Noncitizens" were people who went to jail or abused drugs and alcohol. Hopeless cases sometimes got referred to as Tobash (Take Out Back and Shoot in the Head). The elderly women who showed up out of loneliness were Lol in Nad (Little Old Ladies in No Apparent Distress).
During a long night with the usual overtones of tragicomedy, a 65-year-old Medicaid patient came in, a manic depressive of devout religious beliefs. He had not left his apartment in 10 years, feeling it was God's will that he stay put pending a sign to the contrary. His wife decided his illness was the sign and called an ambulance. He complained of frequent and painful urination. Glucose was entering his urine. He was given insulin and hydration.
Normally, it might have been sufficient to follow him up at the clinic. But who knew what he would decide once he was home? It was hard to make appointments 10 years hence. Yet Dr. Lathan had to struggle to get him approved for admission. "You have to tell a good story," he said.
The attending argued hard and the man got in. What became of him, Dr. Lathan did not know. He had a woman with a nosebleed.
 
'Buy the Ticket, Take the Ride'
Several months into the year, an 87-year-old woman with platelet disease was sent to the E.R. by her private physician and admitted to the floor. The intern who admitted her was due to leave and handed her off to the incoming intern. The woman needed a platelet transfusion, but the newly arrived intern instead ordered plasma, which did her no good. Later, he defended himself by pointing out that plasma and platelets were adjacent on the computer. The woman died, and might have anyway, though there was no certainty of that. Procedural changes were instituted, but the human dimension of the case was seized on as a teaching tool by the administrators, for they felt it resonated to the heart of ethics and doctoring.
The setting was one of the medicine department's Morbidity and Mortality conferences, or M. & M.s, where the doctors alternated with somber recitals of their mistakes and tried to learn from them. Every Friday, the week's "expirations" and other "adverse outcomes" were laid out in an especially clubby forum, closed to outsiders, with all information protected by statute from use in a lawsuit.
To interns still so uncertain of so much, it seemed that the crushing hours and rushed state of medicine only encouraged error. They had all made small blunders. A few times, exhausted while on call, Dr. James had written notes on the wrong patient's chart. When she returned later, the notes made no sense. She corrected them. Her worst mistake, in her view, had been ordering a CAT scan of a patient's head instead of the chest. Afterward, she was a mass of guilt. But she was unaware of anything she had done that had harmed a patient.
Still, she was unusually fastidious, for she felt she had a propensity for mistakes. Underlying her anxiety was a weakness for malapropisms. In medical school, friends told her she was bound to tell a patient, "You have cancer . . . oh, I mean a cold."
For the most part, the conclusion at M. & M.'s was that the patient was unharmed, and those who died would have anyway. The cases covered a wide range. An intern gave a 70-year-old woman four times the proper dose of amiodarone, a drug for an irregular heartbeat. She became hypertensive, but recovered. A man had a CAT scan before surgery for bleeding in the brain. Normally, the patient would lie on his back. In error, the technician programmed the machine to suggest he was on his stomach. The film came out so marked. The surgeon initially operated on the wrong side of the brain. The hospital found no adverse effect, but ordered that all films be manually marked; the technician, who had other performance problems, was dismissed.
And then there was the platelet woman.
Dr. Lesch's preaching that day got at something that was happening as cost pressures shaped and twisted medicine like a piece of clay. Young doctors, the administrators felt, were less inclined to feel culpable when they did something wrong. It was not them, it was a system that, as the interns kept hearing, had stolen so much of their autonomy. The system didn't let them do it right. Ship the blame elsewhere -- to a computer, to the next shift, to the head of the hospital, to society itself.
Dr. Lesch had often told the interns, and told them again now, that when they handed patients off, they should be as detailed as during rounds. (That rarely happened. To the interns, these were hollow murmurings that misread the exigencies of their lives. "That could take an hour, and we don't have an hour," Dr. James said. Often sign-outs lasted five minutes. Sometimes, an intern would sign out to another while passing in the hall, as if transferring a baton in a race.)
The room was stone silent as Dr. Lesch said that if someone was sick, getting off on time no longer mattered, rules or no rules. Nothing mattered except giving the best possible care until you could pass the patient on to someone who fully understood his condition. Your name was on the chart; you were responsible. As Dr. Lesch put it, "You buy the ticket, you take the ride."
Dr. James and the others left the meeting visibly shaken. For some time, she double- and triple-checked everything she entered into the computer. She had bought the ticket.
 
A Zebra or a Horse?
It being a Monday, the dogs came. They played with the sick children and enacted well-rehearsed stunts (catch a treat in the air, bow). Other times, a clown performed.
The doors of the Roosevelt pediatric floor were painted sky blue and festooned with stars and a rainbow, while the doors of the rooms were bright yellow, a color scheme meant to bring joy to an inherently unhappy experience. A large board kept track of patients, and when one was discharged, Dr. Holland drew a happy face next to the name. Now and then, to torment an arriving intern, those leaving would ink in imaginary patients to make the ward seem more frenetic. One day, Clinton, Starr and Lewinsky were all pediatric patients.
But Dr. Holland saw a lot of sadness on the floor. And while the interns hoped to learn detachment without becoming jaded, that art did not come quickly to him.
He treated several girls who had tried suicide. Boyfriend problems. You always knew the suicides by the black rings around their mouths, residue from the activated charcoal pumped into them in the E.R.
There was a 13-year-old girl with a brain tumor. She was getting radiation after surgery, but it was all too late to do much good. Her parents were poor. She kept asking, "How much is this costing my mother?" Not long after being discharged, she died.
"It bummed me out for several days," Dr. Holland said. "Her medical issues were to control her pain. It was all we could do. And she was worried about the expense."
He kept discovering nuggets that jelled into an education. One day his supervisor asked him the most common side-effect of a tonsillectomy and adenoidectomy. Nightmares was the answer, and a good thing for parents to know.
The school year brought a spate of fictitious ailments. A 13-year-old boy showed up complaining of a stomach ache. Dr. Holland felt his abdomen. "You don't look at your fingers, you look at the patient's eyes," he said. The boy didn't even wince. Dr. Holland told the attending it was a charade. The attending felt the stomach. Now the boy winced. The attending proceeded to teach Dr. Holland something he had read in no textbook. He ordered the boy to do jumping jacks. The boy was practically laughing as he effectively executed them.
Another day, Dr. Holland was working the cardiology clinic under Dr. Richard Golinko. There was a medical cliche among the teaching doctors: "If you hear hoofbeats, assume it's a horse, not a zebra." This meant that when commonplace symptoms suggested an obvious diagnosis -- a horse -- the odds were overwhelming that that was what was wrong. Expect the common, a horse, not the uncommon, a zebra. Dr. Holland, though, was beginning to wonder. He had already seen a number of zebras.
Now, Dr. Holland examined a 16-year-old girl who collapsed after complaining of chest pain. When an adult has chest pain, the first thought is the heart. With a child, it's the last. Dr. Holland examined her and found nothing amiss. He spoke to Dr. Golinko. "You could try Rolaids," Dr. Golinko said. "It could be an ulcer."
Dr. Holland said: "It doesn't sound like she's making anything up. She seems well taken care of. She has braces." (In the clinic, where poor and often poorly cared for children predominate, braces are a sign of committed parents.)
Dr. Golinko threw out other possibilities: "She may be having sexual problems that could manifest themselves in psychosomatic complaints." Her sister had migraines, and some people get migraine-like pains elsewhere in the body. Finally, it was agreed to schedule her for a sonogram to see if it was a zebra or a horse.
 
'This Gloom and Doom Feeling'
The greatest satisfaction came from seeing her patients progress and go home. And Dr. James experienced a lot of that. But there was little satisfaction when patients piled up into gridlock.
She was at Roosevelt on Team C, the cardiology team. She had a dozen patients. The evening brought five more. She did not feel she had a handle on everyone. At 1 a.m., she did what she had never imagined doing -- she cried. "It's not my fault," she said. "I'm just getting slammed." Not until 5 p.m. did she leave the hospital. She had been on since 7 a.m. the previous day.
She insisted on a real life, and she and her husband took in a movie or a meal out every week. Again and again, she fell asleep before the movie ended. She nodded off at dinner. She subscribed to the New England Journal of Medicine and Annals of Internal Medicine, but the issues piled up unread.
She worked Thanksgiving and had 18 patients at one point. Morose about being on duty, she had a friend cover for her for two hours, not sure if this was even proper, and rushed over to relatives for some semblance of a Thanksgiving dinner.
She was so tired she failed to fulfill a cherished Christmas tradition. She always made about 20 angel tree ornaments for friends and relatives. This year, she did doctor angels, their skirts fashioned from old scrubs. But she made only 10.
Friends remarked that she had lost weight. It was the Intern Diet -- no food.
One morning, after a frantic and food-free night, she began eating a yogurt during rounds. The attending's voice rose in reprimand: "We don't eat on rounds." She threw it away. "I felt like, what's the problem?" she said. "I wasn't going to take it into the patient's room and drop it on him. It really gets me when they take away your basic human rights -- sleep, food, freedom."
It was that forlorn, nether juncture of her internship. The initial excitement had dissipated. The end was not near. It was cold and bleak outside. The hospital seemed to suck not only the energy but the very soul out of you. "I've had this doom and gloom feeling," she said. "I've actually asked myself, 'Have I made the right decision?' "
Her husband noticed that her left eye was drooping, which she ascribed to lack of sleep. Her legs were swollen from standing so much. "It's gotten to the point where I haven't been even flossing my teeth," she said. "I just go home and go to bed. And so my gums started bleeding."
The night before, she had called a medical-school friend and poured out her heart. She told her how she was so tired and not sleeping, and then how she spent the days worrying about not sleeping, which made her even more tired. Her friend, a fatigued intern herself, commiserated as best she could. But she was falling asleep.
 
Life, Death and Managed Care
 On July 1, 1998, Drs. Jennifer James, Edward Lathan and Bryan Holland began their internships at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, an institution struggling to thrive in the age of managed care. As they started out, filled with medical-school idealism and what they saw as sensibly scaled-down ambition, they found themselves preoccupied by the most concrete things -- finding the bathrooms, finding time to eat, keeping their first patients alive. What they weren't doing was thinking much about commerce and what it might mean for their own medical training. Today: Endless debates over interns' hours . . . trying to learn more at twice the speed . . . and paperwork, paperwork, paperwork.

HEADLINE: Tight Labor Supply Creates Jobs for the Mentally Disabled

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
A bit fretful about joining the work force, Virginia Andrajewski, 56, turned to a fellow employee on her new job at the Crowne Plaza Hotel and whispered, "Am I doing all right?"
Told she was doing splendidly, Miss Andrajewski, who has mental retardation, broke into a broad smile as she stood behind a laundry table, neatly folding pillowcases into a tall pile. 
 As a flourishing economy exhausts the nation's labor supply, more employers are courting disabled workers like Miss Andrajewski, whose talents were long overlooked.
"I'd like to say we hired Virginia because we're just a good corporate citizen," said Bob King, the general manager at the Crowne Plaza here in the Wisconsin capital, where the unemployment rate is less than 2 percent. "But the truth is, we hired her because she's a good, loyal and dependable worker, and our business needs her."
On the job less than a month, Miss Andrajewski recently earned a wage increase to $6.65 an hour, which surprised and delighted her when she opened her check.
"This is all new to me, but I sure do like it," said Miss Andrajewski, whose warm manner and dry wit have made her popular with colleagues in the hotel laundry. "For a long time, I was just floating along."
Charles Lakin, the director of the Research and Training Center on Community Living in Minneapolis, said, "There has been incredible growth in the number of people with intellectual disabilities going to work for pay."
"We've gone from just getting a job for these people to sitting down and asking them about their career aspirations," he said referring to the center, a government-supported group that studies the integration of people with developmental disabilities in the larger society.
From 1988 to 1996, employment increased more than 300 percent among people served by state mental retardation agencies, Mr. Lakin said. Some 337,000 adults with mental retardation hold jobs, about 17 percent of the more than 2 million Americans of working age who have cognitive disabilities. Of those working, nearly half have jobs in competitive employment, while the others work in jobs subsidized for people with disabilities.
While the severity of developmental disabilities varies widely, Mr. Lakin said, the vast majority of disabled people can work, and almost all of them want to. Despite the increasing movement into the job market, people with developmental disabilities still have a high unemployment rate.
The level of employment is highest among young adults with mental retardation who have left school in the last five years, with about 23 percent holding "competitive," or unsubsidized jobs, according to Arc, an advocacy group for people with mental retardation.
Just last month, President Clinton directed government employers to aggressively recruit workers with disabilities.
And a bill pending in Congress would sharply increase the ranks of disabled workers by allowing them to keep their Social Security health benefits if they take jobs. Fear of losing benefits has been a roadblock to increasing employment among people with disabilities.
The changing fortunes of people with mental disabilities are part of a trend, experts say, reflecting a broader change in societal views of the mentally retarded, especially among younger people who were raised in what are called mainstreamed classrooms, where disabled children learn with other youngsters, and were taught that diversity means more than different races or religions.
The self-image and expectations of the mentally retarded, and their families, have been enhanced in recent years, as advocacy groups for disabled people have become a potent political force.
Notions of the proper role for the mentally retarded were far different when Miss Andrajewski was young. She was kept at home most of her life by her parents, a custom of a time that called for the retarded to be sheltered, but rarely challenged. Moreover, people with retardation were not always welcome in public.
"In those days, if you were retarded, that was that, and there was nothing more to be done," said Miss Andrajewski's older sister, Victoria Peetz, who farms in Prairie du Sac. "My mother simply took care of her. Virginia never used the telephone. She didn't even know how to make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich."
Now Miss Andrajewski is taking dance lessons, learning to swim and calling relatives on the telephone. She soon will join the choir at St. Bernard's Catholic Church.
"My sister has come alive," Mrs. Peetz said. "It is so wonderful to see."
After her mother died in August, Miss Andrajewski was placed in a home with another woman with mental retardation and a caretaker. Her caseworker referred her to a job broker for people with disabilities, Successful Work Options, which promptly found several employers looking for help.
"Virginia said she wanted to fold clothes, since that's what she did at home," said Doug Quinn-Gruber, a manager at the job broker. "So I called the Crowne Plaza, and they were very receptive."
While more employers are willing to hire disabled people, the unemployment rate remains very high among the nation's adults with mental retardation, said Steven Eidelman, the executive director of Arc.
Some corporations have been recruiting workers with mental retardation for years, including McDonald's and Marriott. Several studies of such workers show they tend to be at least as productive as their fellow workers.
"Employers have finally figured out this isn't charity, it's good business," Mr. Eidelman said.
For all the talk about highly technical jobs, he said, employers desperately need workers willing to complete simple tasks dependably.
"I don't care what company it is," Mr. Eidelman said, "if you show up, you're eager to work and you get along with your co-workers, you're going to keep your job."
People with mental retardation are working as janitors and gardeners, grocery clerks and office receptionists, toll collectors, farm hands and short-order cooks, among many other occupations. In some cases, they are rising to supervisory jobs.
Young people with mental retardation today receive much better education and job training than in earlier times, which makes them more valuable to employers, he said.
But people with disabilities still face barriers. A janitor with mental retardation who worked at Chuck E. Cheese here lost his job recently after a company official visited the restaurant and told the manager to discharge the man, a suit filed against the restaurant says. A group of people with mental retardation, People First, recently held a protest march at the restaurant.
Workers are so hard to find in Madison that the Crowne Plaza pays a $100 bonus to any employee who makes a reference that results in someone's being hired.
A supervisor in the laundry room, Diane Kasuboske, acknowledged that she was initially skeptical when she heard that a woman with mental retardation was going to work in her department.
But then she saw Miss Andrajewski work.
"She did 120 pillowcases today," said Ms. Kasuboske, arching an eyebrow with admiration. "She's a perfectionist. She rubs her fingers across each pillow case, so any hint of wrinkle is gone."
Besides being a good worker, Miss Andrajewski has helped lift worker morale, her colleagues said. Along with being warm and kind, it is clear she cares about her laundry mates, and admires their skills. One recent afternoon at work, she spoke several times about her worry for a co-worker named Jesse, who was absent because his sister was having surgery for cancer that day.
"I wonder how Jesse is doing," she said with a look of concern, shaking her head slowly.
Another day, she turned to a fellow worker and confided, "You know, I've never been so close to so many people."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Mayor's Harsh Style: Despite Critics, No Plans to Change

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Verbal combat seems to sustain him. When he is not questioning the motives of various judges, he is dismissing possible successors as unworthy, assailing the integrity of reporters and cutting short citizens who dare to challenge him on his weekly radio program.
As ever, he is the classroom know-it-all, the professional scold, the John Calvin of city government, so much so that caricaturists routinely portray him in an apoplectic state. When people were asked in a recent New York Times/CBS News poll what his name brings to mind, 37 percent said either that Rudolph W. Giuliani was the mayor or the man who cleaned up New York City. But 17 percent answered with one of the following: bad temper, harsh personality, stubborn, dictator. 
 He is also on a losing streak, loudly picking fights in the courts and at the polls that he does not win. On Friday came yet another loss: a federal judge ruled that his administration had improperly retaliated against an AIDS service organization -- known for aggressively protesting the Mayor's policies -- by effectively blocking it from receiving $2.4 million in federal money.
For most politicians, all this would spell trouble. Consultants would suggest a softening around the edges. End news conferences with "Be well," maybe. Wear sweaters that highlight eye color. Adopt a smile that does not look as if it hurts.
But Mr. Giuliani is not like most other politicians. As he closes out his sixth year in office and prepares for a possible run for the Senate next year, his advisers say he has no plans to refine his abrasive tendencies. Naomi Wolf will not be coaching him on becoming a beta male anytime soon.
The aides say there are three basic reasons that the Giuliani-for-Senate camp wants to let Rudy be Rudy. First, one aide explained, "It would be artificial if all of a sudden he became Pat Boone." Second, as the City Hall joke goes, no consultant would dare to suggest that he tap into his feminine side. Finally, there is this: In Mr. Giuliani's case, aggression seems to be a positive thing.
The Times/CBS poll indicates that the Republican mayor's popularity has not suffered as a result of recent battles infused with his caustic style of debate, including his failed attempt to cut public financing to the Brooklyn Museum of Art for an exhibit that he found offensive. Even though the poll indicated that most people disagreed with him on that issue, his favorability rating still had climbed since the last poll, in the spring, while that of his likely opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, fell.
In fact, Mr. Giuliani exudes such self-righteous confidence that he often seems to turn defeat to his advantage. Besides the court drubbing over the museum, he lost a City Charter revision referendum by an overwhelming margin and lost court battles over access to the City Hall steps and the rights of an organizer with antiwhite views to hold a youth rally in Harlem.
Any other politician facing the race of his career would bury these humiliations on his resume. But Mr. Giuliani celebrates them as reflecting the qualities that many people admire in him: unyielding on principles and willing to stand up to racists, deluded liberal judges and elitist museum directors who embrace what he considers smut.
His advisers acknowledge that a race between Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton would be close and would focus on wooing the small pool of undecided voters.
They also agree that unlike city residents, upstate voters have yet to be exposed to the full force of Mr. Giuliani's personality; his streetwise swagger may not play so well in Herkimer County. For now at least, his television advertisements tend to show a grinning mayor presiding over a glittering city.
There is also the question, with the election still a year away, whether Mr. Giuliani's combative style will eventually wear thin.
"It would make some sense for him politically to temper his personality a little bit over the next year, because it may get tiresome," said Steven Cohen, vice dean of the School of International Public Affairs at Columbia University. "If he has a debate with Hillary Clinton, he needs to chill out a little bit."
Even so, his supporters say, Mr. Giuliani's style is not losing any voters, and in fact may be winning a few.
"You either like him or you don't," said one person close to the mayor. "I've sat in with a lot of consultants, and they tell him: 'You are Rudy Giuliani and this is what brought you to the dance. You have to be what brought you to the dance.' "
And while Democrats may privately hope that he explodes on the public stage someday -- say, during a debate with Mrs. Clinton -- some concede that his style has not alienated voters so far.
"He's in your face, confident, aggressive, and undeviating," said former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat who received Mr. Giuliani's cross-party endorsement during his failed re-election bid in 1994. "Some people will find that disconcerting; some people will find it wearying. But the essential question is whether he's competent to the task. And the elections show that people think he's competent."
Phil Friedman, a consultant to Democrats, agreed. "So far he's proven the pundits wrong," he said. "He's fought with nearly everyone, lost to nearly everyone, been criticized by nearly everyone. And gone up in the polls."
The last few months demonstrate that weight loss and Friday-afternoon golf outings have not softened Mr. Giuliani's assertive, somewhat impolitic ways.
During his weekly radio program, for example, the mayor is often pleasant, helping callers to navigate city bureaucracy. But he rarely shies from opportunities to scold, whether to question the parental skills of a woman whose 18-year-old son -- a robbery suspect -- was shot to death by the police, or to harangue a caller complaining about a pet ferrets ban.
His administration spent much of the summer pushing a referendum proposal to change a city law to prevent the city's public advocate, Mark Green, a liberal Democrat, from succeeding him if he were elected to the Senate in 2000. After criticism that the mayor's hubris, not good government, was behind the plan, the administration dropped the idea from its list of proposals for changing the City Charter.
Still, the administration's approach galvanized the city's unions and Democrats in opposition. On an Election Day with little voter turnout, Mr. Giuliani was handed a rare and embarrassing political loss; his administration's proposals were defeated by a three-to-one margin.
Meanwhile, the mayor was losing several fights over the First Amendment and free speech. His penchant for parting shots at judges prompted the Association of Trial Lawyers for America to complain, "It has become a disturbing trend that a few public officials and candidates try to make political points by unfairly attacking the judiciary and the fair administration of justice."
But the issue that best captured the Giuliani paradox -- of burnishing his reputation by losing in the courts -- centered on the Brooklyn Museum of Art's "Sensation" exhibition, which featured, among other controversial works, a portrait of the Virgin Mary decorated with elephant dung and cutouts from pornographic magazines.
The mayor went all out to oppose the exhibit. He blocked the public financing for the museum, tried to have the museum evicted from the city-owned building and reveled in portraying the exhibit as anti-Catholic and its supporters as ethically suspect.
In a scathing rebuke two weeks ago, a federal judge accused the city of tampering with the First Amendment and ordered it to back off. But by then, the Giuliani campaign had already sent out a fund-raising letter in which the mayor criticized Mrs. Clinton for supporting the museum's right to hold an exhibit that "aggressively attacks the Catholic faith" and includes "pieces glorifying pedophiles."
In fact, his advisers claim to see hidden victory in all these defeats. In the loss over the charter referendum, for example, they say the united effort by unions and Democrats to defeat the Giuliani administration will remind voters of "the bad old days," as one aide put it, of union domination, economic recession and the bloated government of liberal city Democrats.
Democrats say this assessment of the referendum is particularly delusional; they say Mr. Giuliani paid the price for his unrestrained arrogance. But some Democrats agree that the clash over the Brooklyn Museum is another story.
"It's a tossup politically," Mr. Cuomo said. "I disagreed with him. But it's as likely to be good for him as not. The people he offended he didn't have to start with. And the people whose support he earns are some of the upstate Republicans, some of the moderates and the conservatives in an increasingly conservative era."
Myron Magnet, the editor of City Journal, a magazine published by the generally conservative Manhattan Institute, said the museum debate supported the Giuliani-as-crusader theory, one that the mayor has propagated. It holds that he had to be tough to battle the entrenched Democratic machine to restore civility, cut crime and reduce welfare.
"He was taking on a structure that had a lot of things wrong with it," Mr. Magnet said. "Since he has succeeded, it's kind of hard to quibble with the methods that he used. Everybody who stood in his way, everybody who believes that the old ways and old ideas were correct, feels that his combativeness is unjustified, shrewish. But that's because their ox is gored. And this Brooklyn case is a perfect example."
Mr. Giuliani has said he is truly offended by the exhibit, and not motivated by politics. But Mr. Cohen of Columbia said that if that were the case, then some diplomacy would have been in order.
"If he really wanted to affect what was going on at the museum, he could have done so quietly, behind the scenes," Mr. Cohen said. "But he chose to make a public issue out of it."
The professor added, "He's a very smart guy."

HEADLINE: Signs of Landmark Accord In U.S.-China Trade Talks

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Monday, Nov. 15

 BODY:
It appeared that the signing of a landmark international trade agreement was imminent today as Chinese officials told journalists at 2:30 this afternoon to line up outside the Trade Ministry to witness a possible signing ceremony.
No details on the substance of the agreement were yet available. 
 The negotiators had met for five hours this morning on the sixth day in closed-door talks on China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
China's entry into the trading agreement was an important goal for President Clinton as well as the Chinese government, which hopes to accelerate economic modernization.
The negotiations were given a lift on Saturday when the Americans, led by Charlene Barshefsky, the trade representative, and Gene Sperling, a presidential economic adviser, were called to a meeting with Prime Minister Zhu Rongji.
Ms. Barshefsky had publicly threatened to return to Washington, citing a lack of progress in the initial three days.
But after the meeting with Mr. Zhu, who is known here as a leading advocate of free markets and economic change, the two sides plunged back into detailed negotiations on Saturday night. They met again three times on Sunday.
For political and economic reasons, both countries wanted the talks to succeed. But the United States said it would approve China's entry into the global trade organization only if China makes sweeping commitments to cut tariffs and allow wider foreign investment in domestic industries such as telecommunications, banking and securities.
To preserve political support for an agreement at home, President Clinton also needs to keep protections for domestic textile producers, including a gradual phasing out of existing import quotas.
Many Chinese leaders would prefer to introduce foreign competition more gradually, fearing that unemployment could surge in the short run and that cherished state industries might sink.
Another point of contention involves how easily the United States could suspend trading privileges if it suspects Chinese firms are dumping products abroad below cost.
China had hoped to join the World Trade Organization, which sets rules for commerce among its 134 member nations, by the end of this month so that it could take part in a new round of global trade negotiations scheduled to begin Nov. 30 in Seattle.
But first it must complete side agreements with major partners, mainly the United States and the European Union.
The United States and China have engaged in intermittent talks on the trade organization for more than a decade. They came close to agreement in April, when Mr. Zhu offered major concessions in Washington.
But relations between the two countries soured temporarily after American planes bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, last May during the Kosovo conflict, and industries here that feel imperiled by open markets have lobbied for China to dig in against some American demands.
Aboard Air Force One on Sunday, Mr. Clinton said of the negotiations: "It is impossible to predict the outcome. They're still there and they're still talking."

HEADLINE: 'Japanese Only' Policy Takes Body Blow in Court

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 14

 BODY:
After Ana Bortz arrived from Brazil six years ago, she like many foreigners who live here -- grew used to the countless means employed by the Japanese to enforce distinctions between themselves and others.
She endured the bureaucratic devices, like the re-entry permits foreigners need to return to Japan even when they already have a visa, and the fingerprinting that every outsider has to undergo to get a temporary resident's card. 
 She even became inured to the way Japanese avoid sitting next to foreigners on the subway. Or, worse for her, the almost daily stereotyping of Brazilians as criminals in the local press.
But what Ms. Bortz, 35, a reporter for a Brazilian satellite television network, said she had not been prepared for was being escorted out of a jewelry store in Hamamatsu City where she lives, because, as the store's owners stated adamantly, they had a policy of refusing people of her nationality.
So, setting off what may one day be looked back on as the Japanese equivalent of Rosa Parks's defiance of bus segregation in Montgomery, Ala., Ms. Bortz took on the discrimination against foreigners in Japan's courts, and to the surprise of many, not least herself, she won.
"This sort of thing is a very big problem in Japan, but its discussion has remained taboo," Ms. Bortz said. "This country has signed international conventions against discrimination but has never wanted to deal with the subject domestically. For a country that talks about getting a chair on the Security Council, these kinds of attitudes are just shocking."
More than the victory of an individual, the Bortz case is already being seen by many foreigners grappling with the legal system here as an invaluable precedent in their antidiscrimination struggle.
In English, Japan's 1946 Constitution, largely written by American officials during the military occupation, states that "all of the people are equal under the law and there shall be no discrimination in political, economic or social relations because of race, creed, sex, social status or family origin."
In the Japanese version, however, "all of the people" is rendered "kokumin," essentially meaning all Japanese people.
In the absence of Japanese laws covering the treatment of foreigners, the judge in the Bortz case said that the country must abide by its international treaties. In 1996, 31 years after the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination was adopted by the United Nations, Japan finally signed it, becoming the 148th country to do so.
"This was an illegal act against an individual," ruled Tetsuro So, a Shizuoka District Court judge, who cited Japan's treaty obligation last month in awarding Ms. Bortz $47,000 in damages. "Ejecting the plaintiff from the store merely because she was a Brazilian was unfair." Because the judgment was based on international law, it cannot be appealed under Japanese law.
Ms. Bortz's lawyer, Hideyo Ogawa, said: "Frankly speaking this case's influence will be very big. Just as I didn't know of the existence of this treaty beforehand, neither did most other lawyers."
The store owner, Takahisa Suzuki, has not been giving interviews. In court he said that he had asked Ms. Bortz to leave because her behavior was "unnatural." He and his wife also said that fears of crime by Brazilians is justified, and hence does not constitute discrimination.
For years many foreigners living in Japan have suffered silently when landlords denied them housing. They have put up with employment contracts that treat them differently from Japanese, and have been turned away from public establishments like bars, restaurants and hot baths with signs in their windows reading "Japanese Only."
The Bortz case is among a wave of challenges being brought by foreigners who say that if they can do nothing about the famous Japanese standoffishness toward outsiders, they can at least insist on equal treatment before the law.
Cynthia Worthington, an American, has been battling what she says is the disparate treatment of Japanese and foreign faculty members almost from the day she was hired by Kumamoto University as a professor of English in 1993.
Dr. Worthington was hired after responding to a job listing for a full-time position, and was subsequently told that as a foreigner, what she would be given was "special irregular" status.
"We were employed on a year-to-year basis, we were not entitled to prefectural housing, we couldn't join the credit union and we didn't get bonuses," she said. "They were calling us part-time workers, and yet they were giving us full-time responsibilities, in the classroom, on committees and with research. The only difference was that we were foreign."
Three years ago, Dr. Worthington, along with other foreign faculty members, formed a union to pressure the university into offering them the same treatment it accorded its Japanese staff. They went on strike and drew support from the community, eventually earning the attention of a parliamentary labor committee that got the university to back off, at least temporarily, from its efforts to get rid of the troublesome foreigners altogether.
"Foreigners are discriminated against in Japan, period," Dr. Worthington said. "What has changed is that people are trying to do something about it."
In one victory after years of complaints by foreign embassies, Japan will end the fingerprinting of foreign residents next April.
Japan has always stood out as a stubbornly near-monoethnic nation, not only proud of it but also fiercely attached to the idea.
It has the lowest percentages of immigrants and expatriate workers of any advanced industrialized nation -- about 1 percent of the population. Naturalization, even for Koreans who have lived here for generations and fought in wars for Japan, is extremely difficult. On average, fewer than 20 people are legally recognized as refugees each year.
Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, has been one of the rare Japanese voices for change.
"Japanese people are relatively monoethnic," she said in a speech in Tokyo recently, urging her country to consider globalization in terms of cultural openness. "We live under the illusion of one ethnic race, one culture. A monoethnic island of prosperity won't survive in the 21st century."
David Aldwinckle, 34, an American university professor who has lived in Japan for 12 years, has made the notion of bringing multiculturalism to the country something of a personal crusade. Living in the northern city of Sapporo, he has fought discrimination against foreigners for years, organizing quiet protests against hot baths that deny access to non-Japanese, or insisting that he and his Japanese wife be listed in marriage records the same way any Japanese couple would be.
The challenge now for Mr. Aldwinckle is to obtain Japanese citizenship. The process is kept so exclusive that more foreigners are naturalized each week in the United States than in Japan in an entire year. Indeed, rejections are known to occur over something as minor as a speeding ticket.
"I have often sat and wondered why things are this way in Japan," Mr. Aldwinckle said. "There is a real fear and misunderstanding of things that are different. They don't know how to deal with things that are abnormal to them, and they are afraid of what will happen if the differences are allowed to stand."

HEADLINE: Historians Revisit Slaughter on the Plains

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: MISSOULA, Mont.

 BODY:
The wanton slaughter of millions of bison in the 19th century by white hide hunters, abetted by a military intent on subjugating Indians, is probably the most famous conservation horror story in United States history.
The problem with this tale, a growing number of scholars and historians say, is that it is not true. As portrayed in a number of controversial new books, the real story of the decline of the buffalo involves a significant change in climate, competition for forage and cattle-borne disease. Another major factor, the authors say, were Indian tribes, empowered by the horse and gun and driven to hunt buffaloes for the profits that came from hides and meat. 
 "What most people don't consider in their 'Dances With Wolves' version of history is that Indians were involved in the market," said Dr. Dan Flores, the A. B. Hammond professor of Western history at the University of Montana. "They were cashing in on buffalo in the 1840's as their principal entree into the market economy, and very few species are able to survive when they become a commodity."
White hunters who killed buffaloes by the millions in the 1870's and 1880's played a major role in the demise, said Dr. Flores, but only as the coup de grace. "The hide hunters are not off the hook," he said. "They share the burden of the final mop-up. But without their involvement, the buffalo would probably have only lasted another 30 years." That is because their numbers had been so greatly reduced by the other factors.
The buffalo studies are part of a continuing debate about the role of Indians in Western history. In "The Ecological Indian" (W. W. Norton, 1999), for example, Shepard Krech III, an anthropologist at Brown University, argues against the romantic image of the Indian as the first environmentalist. When Indians had had the means and the motive, he says, they abused nature for profit.
Dr. Flores, whose work on buffalo has appeared in The Journal of American History and elsewhere, is writing a book on bison under contract with Yale University Press. And Dr. Drew Isenberg, an assistant professor of history at Princeton, has a book called "The Destruction of the Bison: An Environmental History, 1750-1920," which will be published by Cambridge University Press in April.
Not everyone subscribes to the new wave. Dr. Vine Deloria Jr., a professor of history at the University of Colorado at Boulder and a member of the Standing Rock Sioux, finds the revisionism preposterous. "It's nonsense," he said. "The Indians did not make any appreciable dent in buffalo numbers in the Northern Plains. It's anti-Indian stuff."
Indians were involved in the buffalo market, scholars generally agree. Their acquisition of horses and guns made buffalo hunting much easier. As steamboats started plying the Missouri River into the heart of buffalo country in the 1840's, hide hunting by the Kiowa, Blackfeet, Sioux and other Plains tribes soared.
For the first time, there was a way to haul the bulky robes back East, where they became popular as a covering during cold weather travel and for leather goods. Indians found they could trade the robes for firearms, lead balls, gunpowder, blankets, textiles, pots and pans and whiskey.
Dr. Isenberg estimates that before the 1840's, 60,000 Plains Indians were killing half a million bison a year for sustenance. After the robe trade began in the 1840's, that total went over 600,000 a year, "clearly into unsustainable range," he said.
While white hunters killed more buffaloes (their total throughout the West is estimated at four million), Dr. Flores argues that Indians concentrated their killing on buffalo cows, which had more tender meat and were much easier to skin and treat, resulting in severe damage to the herds' reproductive capacity.
Environmental factors play large roles in newer histories of the West. For example, Dr. Flores says that the study of tree rings, or dendrochronology, suggests that Indians were so effective in decimating the buffalo because climate had already weakened and diminished the herds.
From the 1500's to the mid-19th century, a period known as the little ice age, tree rings show that the climate in the West was much colder than normal. That favored the grasses buffaloes eat, and they flourished. When a long, widespread drought ended the little ice age in the mid-1800's, the grasses changed and the bison population crashed just as the tribes began market hunting.
At the same time, Dr. Flores said, buffaloes began having to compete for forage with horses that were brought by the Spaniards to North America in the 1500's and later went feral. By the 1800's, Dr. Flores estimates, two million horses were sharing the range with the buffalo.
Dr. Flores and the others also differ from their predecessors in their use of Indian sources. Many bands of Indians, for example, kept a record of events, often symbols painted on bison robes. The Northern Plains tribes kept winter counts of buffaloes on buffalo hides, while the Kiowa, in the south, kept calendars. "The symbol for 'many buffalo,' a circle with a dot in the middle, appears numerous times from 1800 to 1840 in the Kiowa calendars," Dr. Flores said. "But after 1840 it appears only once."
Such counts are crucial to the debate over who or what killed off the bison, but all sides agree that estimates are a tricky business.
In the past, historians estimated bison numbers at 40 million to 60 million, sometimes as many as 75 million. But Dr. Flores has tried to calculate how many buffaloes the range could support by analyzing 1910 census data on cattle, and has concluded that in good years the range could hold only 20 million to 24 million. After the little ice age, at the time of the Civil War, buffalo numbers may have been as low as 10 million to 12 million, he said.
But his calculations have been criticized by Dr. Deloria, who says that comparing fenced-in livestock with free-roaming buffaloes is an inappropriate comparison.
Dr. Calvin Luther Martin, who taught history at Rutgers and lived with Eskimos for two years on the Alaskan tundra, also disagrees. Dr. Martin, the author of a new book on Indian life, "The Way of the Human Being" (Yale University Press), argues that to judge Indians by contemporary environmental standards "is patent foolishness."
The Indians were caught between two worlds and two realities, Dr. Martin said. "They don't translate into each other," he said, adding that Indians had no concept of being wasteful.
And the claim that competition with horses would have affected the buffalo has also been criticized by Dr. Valerius Geist, an ecologist who is an emeritus professor of environmental science at the University of Calgary in Alberta. Dr. Geist, author of "Buffalo Nation: The History and Legend of the North American Bison," (Voyageur Press) noted that bison had evolved on the prairie with other large mammals. "Flores is a historian playing ecologist," Dr. Geist said.
Finally, the new bison scholarship also casts doubt on another major tenet of buffalo history: that the destruction of the herds was a conspiracy between the United States Army and hide hunters who did the killing.
"I don't think there was a conspiracy by any means," Dr. Isenberg said. "The army was happy to see hide hunters, but they were not commanding them to kill bison."
Dr. Flores traces the notion of a conspiracy to the memoir of a Texas buffalo hunter named John R. Cook, called "The Border and the Buffalo." According to the book, the Gen. Philip H. Sheridan, the Indian fighter, urged the Texas Legislature not to pass a law that would protect the buffaloes remaining there and instead to create a bronze medal for the hunters "with a dead buffalo on one side and a discouraged Indian on the other."
Dr. Flores said he had found no record of General Sheridan's speech to the Legislature and believed it was apocryphal. The notion of a conspiracy, he said, has become fact through repetition.
Dr. Flores said he had recently discovered letters in which General Sheridan wrote that he was concerned about the demise of the buffalo. After hearing in October 1879 about the killing of thousands of buffaloes by hide hunters near Miles City, Mont., General Sheridan sent a telegram to Washington, saying, "I consider it important that this wholesale slaughter of the buffalo should be stopped."
Dr. Isenberg denies that the new work on the buffalo is anti-Indian.
"It's romantic to imagine Indians as always living in harmony with nature," he said. "But they are people who did many things right and who also made mistakes. If you want to see them as a real people and not a romantic notion, then you have to look with a clear eye at these kinds of things. None of us have any animus toward Indians."
