HEADLINE: Many Winners and Some Losers in Trade Accord With China

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
For American International Group, the giant insurer, the new trade agreement with China is a long-awaited go-ahead to sell insurance everywhere in China, not in just a few cities. AT&T sees the door open to provide Internet services in China. But Milliken & Company, the big textile manufacturer -- forecasting doom -- says that President Clinton's negotiators have signed a death warrant for textile makers in America.
Many industries -- commercial banking, auto and aircraft manufacturing, farming and food processing, investment banking, electronics, money management -- hailed the agreement yesterday between China and the United States as a wonderful opportunity to expand rapidly into the giant Chinese market. The Clinton administration gave its blessing to China's entry into the World Trade Organization in exchange for numerous market-opening concessions. 
 "Right now, we have $200 million in revenue from selling insurance in China and I expect that to grow to a very big number in the future," said Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman of American International Group, which has been selling life insurance to the Chinese since 1992. The agreement would allow the insurer to greatly increase the number of its branch offices, which now number only four, and expand into property and casualty insurance -- well ahead of other American insurers just moving into China.
The dissonant notes came mainly from textile makers, although a spokesman for the computer software industry said his people would withhold judgment until they knew the details of the agreement dealing with piracy. "We are cautious in endorsing anything until we have seen the final ink dried on the paper," said Dan Duncan, a vice president of the Software and Information Industry Association.
The piracy rate for business software has been 95 percent in recent years, which means that for every 100 copies of Microsoft Office software exported to China, 95 are copied illegally, Mr. Duncan said. "One has to wonder why the rate has stayed so high over the years unless there is some government involvement."
Textile import quotas now limit the shipment of yarn and cloth to the United States from China's modern and low-cost textile industry, which is big enough to supply the entire world, said John F. Nash, counsel for Milliken in Washington. The World Trade Organization requires its member countries to phase out tariffs and quotas, but American manufacturers had counted on 10 more years of limits on Chinese imports, until 2010, Mr. Nash said. The new agreement, however, specifies Jan. 1, 2005.
"The administration and Congress are spending our jobs like drunken sailors," Mr. Nash said, arguing that many of the 551,000 people still employed in American textile factories could lose their jobs as a result of the accord. The deal reached in Beijing is subject to Congressional approval.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. also objected strenuously to a deal with a country with a poor human rights record and numerous violations of labor standards. In a statement that promised fierce opposition to Congressional approval, John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "The agreement reached this weekend deals away our democratic principles and most cherished values, and we will fight it."
But the cheering from corporate America carried the day. "China is the only place in the world where you can go and see economic development right in front of your eyes," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "If China comes alive, they are going to really need advice and insight from global financial service companies like ours."
American commercial banks are big beneficiaries. Since 1997, they have been allowed to provide services to foreign companies operating in China. Now they will gradually be allowed to provide services to Chinese companies, making loans, handling currency transactions and providing other services. "Based on our understanding of the terms, the agreement provides a very significant liberalization in China's financial services market," said a spokesman for Citigroup, which has seven offices in China.
For the first time, American money managers, including the big Wall Street brokerage houses and mutual funds like FMR's Fidelity, Vanguard and T. Rowe Price, will be allowed to form joint ventures with Chinese companies, owning up to 33 percent at first and as much as 49 percent in a few years. Just as these companies rushed into Japan when that nation opened its gates, they most likely will rush into China, where they see a fresh supply of investor cash.
"The Chinese are big savers," said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs International.
Telecommunications companies see themselves as big potential winners. AT&T, whose operations are limited now to providing services for 50 foreign multinational companies in China, sees the agreement as the first step in allowing American companies to invest in Chinese Internet providers. "Internet is the biggest area that we are currently excluded from," said Bruce Jackson, AT&T's vice president for global marketing.
Motorola also viewed the agreement, or at least the sparse details available yesterday, as a new Chinese willingness to permit foreign investment in mobile phone systems and other telecommunications services -- providing Motorola with an expanded market for the cell phones, pagers and semiconductors that Motorola already manufacturers in China.
"Any expansion in investment opportunities in China translates into opportunities for Motorola," said Norman Sandler, the company's director of strategic issues. "Motorola itself might invest in new wireless ventures, foreign or Chinese, and sell equipment to them."
Automakers, whose sales in China are still tiny, hailed a provision in the agreement that will let foreigners provide the Chinese with car loans, but most said they were waiting to see the final terms before judging its benefits. And Caterpillar Inc. pointed to China's new willingness to let foreign companies distribute their own products exported to China, replacing Chinese distributors.
"We are allowed to own one dealership now and we would set up more, although how many more we don't know yet," said William Lane, Caterpillar's director of governmental affairs. "This is just the first bite of the apple" he added. "By joining the World Trade Organization, China will be obligated to permit further market openings."
Farm organizations said that China had moved in the right direction in lowering tariffs on food imports, although Gene Paul, president of the National Farmers Organization, cautioned: "This is not going to change the current situation of low prices. I've read that China had a record corn crop, and we have to realize that ships run both ways."
Electronics manufacturers expressed concern that the Chinese government would press foreign manufacturers to buy supplies from state-owned Chinese companies. But in general, United States corporations saw in the treaty a new willingness by China's leaders to abide by international rules of trade and to avoid conflict.
That is certainly the view at Boeing, which has always sold aircraft to Chinese airlines. "This treaty brings us a huge step toward creating a normal business relationship between the two countries," said Tim Neale, a Boeing spokesman. "And in that climate we can be very successful."

HEADLINE: Suit Says I.N.S. Undercut Honduran Aid Effort

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
Lawyers accused the Immigration and Naturalization Service yesterday of undermining a federal program that offers work permits to Honduran immigrants so they can help relatives at home recover from the devastation of Hurricane Mitch.
In a class-action lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, four immigrant advocacy groups said the agency's processing center in Vermont had failed to provide short-term work permits to thousands of Hondurans who have been entitled to them for months. 
 In early January, Hondurans living in the United States were offered the chance to apply for temporary protected status under a law that protects some foreign nationals from deportation when their home country has been devastated by armed conflict or a natural disaster.
Hurricane Mitch struck Honduras and other parts of Central America in October and November 1998. The immigration service immediately announced that it would suspend deportations to the affected countries as a humanitarian gesture; when the full extent of the damage became clear, Attorney General Janet Reno expanded the gesture with the offer of temporary protected status.
Lawyers for the Honduran immigrants said yesterday that officials in Vermont had improperly demanded documentation from immigrants that was not legally required for temporary protected status, further delaying the issuance of permits. The program for Hondurans is set to expire on July 5, 2000.
Immigration officials in Washington acknowledged yesterday that there had been problems in processing some applications.
"Over all, there was a misunderstanding or misconception on the part of the Vermont Service Center," said Bill Strassberger, an I.N.S. spokesman. "Their understanding of the regulations was that there was more documentation required than actually was necessary. That's now been clarified and we are working to get the applications processed."
The lawsuit and the official response underscored recurrent problems at the Vermont center, which handles immigration cases from states along the East Coast from Maine to Virginia. Applicants for citizenship and for green cards have waited as long as three years -- longer than in other regions -- for the Vermont center to locate and then process their requests. Its handling of the Honduran program has drawn criticism from immigration lawyers.
Nearly 107,000 Hondurans nationwide applied for the benefit by the August deadline, and nearly 70,000 had received a work permit as of the first week of November, according to the agency.
However, of the nearly 36,000 requests for work permits received at the Vermont center, 21,000 were sent back with a demand for more information. No other service center in the country raised questions about so many applications.
To receive the legal right to live and work in the United States while their country is rebuilding, Hondurans had to show they had resided in the United States since Dec. 30, 1998, and had not traveled outside the country since Jan. 5, 1999.
But many applicants to the Vermont center received letters telling them they had to prove, instead, that they had resided in the country before Dec. 30, 1998. Some were told they had to prove they had not traveled outside the United States since the day they had arrived.
Not only were the demands illegal, the lawsuit charges, but the agency ignored a legal obligation to issue temporary permits so that applicants could get jobs while their files were being processed.
"Temporary protected status is nothing new -- it has been used with dozens of countries," said Charles Wheeler, a lawyer at the Catholic Legal Immigration Network in San Francisco. "The I.N.S. has never requested this level of documentation."
Most of the Hondurans who applied for the temporary protected status are in the country illegally, immigrant advocates said. They may be unemployed or working at black-market jobs for low wages. A work permit would give them a chance to earn more and send more to their families, Mr. Wheeler said.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
EAST TIMOR: U.N. MISSION ON WAY
A stalled human rights mission to East Timor, created to assess the abuses committed in September by pro-Indonesian militias, was finally approved by the United Nations and sent on its way by the Economic and Social Council. Rights groups and diplomats have criticized the two-month delay, saying evidence will have disappeared. Eleven countries, mostly from the Middle East and Asia, voted against sending an investigating team. Russia also voted no. Barbara Crossette (NYT) 

PAKISTAN: 4 EX-AIDES ON TRIAL
As hundreds of paramilitary troops guarded the building, four senior officials from the deposed government of Nawaz Sharif appeared in a Karachi antiterrorism court accused of kidnapping, conspiracy to murder and attempted hijacking. The accused, Shahid Khaqan Abbasi, Ghaus Ali Shah, above, Rana Maqbool and Aminullah Chaudhry, said they were not guilty of a plot against Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took over in a coup. Barry Bearak (NYT)
 
NORTH KOREA, U.S.: BERLIN TALKS
North Korean and American officials met in Berlin to resume a new round of talks on relations. The talks follow an announcement by Washington that it was easing longstanding economic sanctions in exchange for North Korea's pledge to freeze long-range missile tests. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CHILE: BISHOPS' PINOCHET PLEA
In their first public pronouncement since Gen. Augusto Pinochet was arrested in London last year, the bishops of the Chilean Catholic Church called on Britain to release the former dictator on humanitarian grounds. General Pinochet, who is fighting extradition to Spain on torture and other rights charges, has suffered minor strokes in recent months. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
CANADA: PLUTONIUM PROTESTS
After protests from Mohawk Indians and some Canadian mayors, the United States Department of Energy has decided not to ship to Canada as much as 33 tons of plutonium from old nuclear weapons for use in commercial reactors to produce electricity. The project had been seen as a contribution to disarmament by Prime Minister Jean Chretien. After opposition grew, American officials decided to destroy the plutonium. James Brooke (NYT)
 
MEXICO: MAYORAL CANDIDATE
Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, from the state of Tabasco, won overwhelmingly in primary elections to pick the candidate for mayor of Mexico City from the left-of-center Party of the Democratic Revolution, which has governed the city since 1997. But Mr. Lopez Obrador faces questions over legal residency requirements. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
CUBA: DISSIDENTS TALKING
Cuba's small internal opposition held a second day of meetings with leaders from Spain, Portugal and Latin America before the start of a regional summit meeting of 21 heads of state today. They were the first talks ever held in Cuba between foreign heads of state and dissidents opposed to President Fidel Castro's Communist rule. (Reuters)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: U.N. REPORT ON AID
In a report to the Security Council, Secretary General Kofi Annan said 12 million tons of food had been imported by Iraq in three years under the program that allows monitored oil sales to pay for urgent civilian needs. Mr. Annan also said he would like to see the government of Saddam Hussein do more to improve basic health care with the money now available. Barbara Crosssette (NYT)
 
ISRAEL: PRESSURE ON SPEAKER
Parliament's speaker said he was being pressed by Chinese and Israeli officials to cancel a meeting with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, but that he would go ahead with the meeting as planned on Nov. 24. Cabinet ministers and the Chinese ambassador have warned Avraham Burg that his meeting would damage efforts to increase trade with China. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
SUDAN: CHARTER PROPOSALS
Proposals to amend the Constitution to reduce the powers of President Omar al-Bashir, left, will be debated in Parliament tomorrow despite pleas by the presidency for a postponement. The amendments provide for creation of a prime minister answerable to Parliament and for direct elections of governors of the country's 26 states. Parliament's speaker, Hassan al-Turabi, said the president should submit his own amendments if he has any. (Agence France-Pressse)
 
EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: BELARUS PACT NEAR
Russia and Belarus will sign a treaty of union, combining some political and economic functions, at a Nov. 26 ceremony, the foreign ministry said. The treaty is part of long-running discussions over merging the two nations into a single state, a goal believed to be years away. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: DEBT RELIEF SOUGHT
Russia wants the London Club of creditors to write off $12 billion of the $32 billion in Soviet-era debt still owed to foreign commercial banks, Finance Minister Mikhail Kasyanov said. He said creditors want the remaining debt converted into Eurobonds or another secure instrument, a demand Russia may grant if other issues are resolved at talks beginning today. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: BEEF SUIT STARTED
Britain formally asked Brussels to begin legal action against France, which has defied the European Union and refused to end its ban on British beef over fears that it is tainted with mad cow disease. But Prime Minister Tony Blair said he did not want to embark on a "ludicrous sort of tit-for-tat trade war" with France. Sarah Lyall (NYT)
 
MACEDONIA: WINNER DECLARED
Deputy Foreign Minister Boris Trajkovski, left, the government candidate, won the presidency in what international monitors said was a generally fair runoff. The opposition Social Democratic Alliance of ex-Communists said it did not recognize the result. It called the vote a fraud masterminded by Mr. Trajkovski's center-right party and the biggest Albanian party. (Reuters)
 
FRANCE: TOLL RISES
The death toll from weekend floods in southwest France has reached 27, and rescuers said people were still missing. Most affected by the overflowing rivers were small towns and villages in the valley around Carcassonne. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
FRANCE: SCIENTOLOGISTS ON TRIAL
Five French members of the Church of Scientology, denounced in France as an unwelcome sect, were found guilty in Marseille of fraud and attempted fraud, with one sentenced to six months in jail and a $16,000 fine. The court accused them of extortion for "purification treatments" and vitamin cures. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
ITALY: CRAXI CAN RETURN
A judge ruled that former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, a fugitive in Tunisia after being convicted in two corruption cases, could be put under "hospital arrest" in Milan. Friends of the former Socialist leader, 65, who suffers from heart trouble, want him to have treatment in Italy, but the question of whether he would have to serve his sentences has not been resolved. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

HEADLINE: THE TRADE DEAL: THE PROSPECTS;
White House and Business Groups To Push Congress on China Pact

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
The Clinton administration and business groups prepared an intense campaign today to win approval in Congress for China's entry into the World Trade Organization, facing opposition from conservatives who object to almost any dealings with China and liberals who say the trade pact would be bad for workers.
Members of both parties said the deal would most likely be approved in the House, the more difficult of the two Congressional battlegrounds, based on the solid bipartisan majority that granted China a one-year extension of favorable trading terms earlier this year. The Senate tends to be more supportive of free trade measures than the House. 
 But neither the supporters nor the opponents were taking the outcome for granted, given the volatility of the relationship between the United States and China and the political sensitivity of trade issues heading into an election year.
"It's going to take an awful lot of work," said Representative David Dreier, a California Republican who is chairman of the House Rules Committee and a leading advocate of bringing China into the trade group.
Congress would not vote on the agreement itself, but on whether the United States should permanently grant China normal trading privileges, which is in effect a condition of the deal. Since 1974, Congress has had to vote annually on whether to retain a normal trading relationship with China, a process that critics of China have used to express their displeasure with Beijing.
Eager to win greater access to the huge market in China -- and stung by criticism that they had been ineffectual in rallying support for past trade votes -- business groups promised an all-out campaign to get the deal enacted.
"We were asked by the administration if we could deliver the votes," said L. Craig Johnstone, senior vice president for international economic and national security affairs at the United States Chamber of Commerce. "We said we could and we will."
Many industries -- commercial banking, auto and aircraft manufacturing, farming and food processing, investment banking, electronics, money management, filmmaking -- hailed the agreement today as an opportunity to expand rapidly into the giant Chinese market. Business groups had complained to the administration last spring when the president rejected an earlier deal with the Chinese. Mr. Clinton had walked away from the proposal fearing that he would have been unable to secure sufficient support in Congress.
Republican Congressional leaders have been generally supportive of a deal with China, but were cautious in their reaction today. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said that there were still "significant questions" about the deal's effects on human rights, religious freedom and the economic relationship between the two countries, and that he was reserving judgment until he could study the agreement.
Even if, as expected, the Republican leadership ultimately joins the White House in pushing for the agreement, the proposal is still sure to set off a bitter debate uniting some of the most conservative Republicans and the most liberal Democrats against centrists in both parties.
Citing what they said were human rights abuses, the spread of nuclear and conventional arms, a lack of concern for environmental issues and the prospect that increased trade would result in some American workers' losing their jobs, a spectrum of groups said they would try to block or modify the agreement.
John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., called the deal "a grave mistake," and said it was "disgustingly hypocritical" of the administration to claim to be keeping the interests of working people in mind even as it negotiated with a regime that routinely violates human rights.
Opposition to the deal by human rights advocates could also give an opportunity to conservative Republican candidates like Steve Forbes and Gary Bauer to win support from the right wing of their party, whose leading candidate, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, supports the deal.
Representative Dana Rohrabacher, a Republican from California, said the agreement was a "raw deal" for workers and consumers because it would institutionalize tariff advantages held by China.
"On top of that, we'd be putting our stamp of approval on having a gangster regime coming into yet another international body and thinking that in some way that body is going to civilize the regime," he said, "when in fact it's more likely that the organization itself will be corrupted by having the world's worst human rights violator in its midst."
Administration officials said they would press hard to get the deal approved, probably in the first few months of next year.
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, told reporters in Turkey, where President Clinton was traveling today: "I believe that when Congress has an opportunity to study the terms of this, recognize the tremendous benefits to American industry and American workers around the country, and the protections that we obtain for import-sensitive industries in this agreement, that there will be broad support for it."
The administration won support today from Human Rights Watch, an advocacy group that said China's entry into the trade organization "could increase pressure for greater openness, more press freedom, enhanced rights for workers and an independent judiciary."
But the White House is primarily counting on business groups. Administration officials have consulted with business lobbyists to gauge support for a deal in Congress and to plan strategy for winning approval.
The Business Roundtable, which represents the country's largest corporations, has readied a plan to tout the benefits of the deal in 71 key Congressional districts. In Iowa, for instance, the group has hired a political organizer, Bill Menner, to get businesses and interest groups working on behalf of the agreement.
Mr. Menner said he planned to turn to groups like the Iowa Farm Bureau Federation and other employers in the state, like Diamond V Mills, a soybean processor in Cedar Rapids, and the headquarters of Roto-Rooter in West Des Moines, to make a public case for the deal and call their members of Congress.
The Business Roundtable also plans to run newspaper advertising in Iowa emphasizing the economic benefits the deal would bring to farmers and other groups.
"We hope that when push comes to shove," Mr. Menner said, "the case we can make about the benefits of trade with China will carry the day."

HEADLINE: Employees From Microsoft Give Gore an Icy Reception

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore stepped into the lion's den today, facing down hundreds of Microsoft employees smarting from the judicial finding that their company had bullied its rivals and stifled competition. And he told them just what they did not want to hear: that competition is fundamentally a good thing.
With 300 people packing an auditorium on the computer giant's campus, the vice president talked about "unfair use of market dominance in one sector to stifle innovation in another sector." He added, "If competition is valuable, which I think it is, then antitrust laws have a place in embodying the values of our country." And at another point, he said, "The values that are inherent in the antitrust laws are ones that are sound, in my opinion." 
 Mr. Gore was virtually echoing the heart of the federal government's case against Microsoft, and the atmosphere here in the company auditorium went icy at his words.
Mr. Gore trooped out to Microsoft as just another candidate for president. He was following in the footsteps of several of his rivals, including former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, his sole Democratic challenger, and several Republicans, including Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona.
But Mr. Gore had the added burden of representing an administration that has ferociously pummeled Microsoft in court. Complicating his task as a candidate is the fact that, as one questioner pointed out, Mr. Gore is probably the most "technologically savvy" candidate ever to run for president.
And he had the misfortune to have had an earlier meeting here rescheduled so that today's visit came just 10 days after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court found in a devastating assessment that the company had monopoly control over PC operating systems and that it wielded that power in ways that hurt American consumers.
Mr. Gore tried at first to avoid commenting on the case. But he was relentlessly questioned about his views. Isn't government interference more of a threat to consumers than Microsoft? he was asked. Isn't it a dangerous invasion of privacy when the government can cull and regurgitate someone's e-mail messages to use against him in court?
Perhaps most pointedly, one employee told Mr. Gore that he shared his Democratic social values and wanted to vote for him but felt deeply conflicted because of the administration's "favorable reaction to a ruling that says we're harming consumers."
William Kovacic, a law professor specializing in antitrust cases at George Washington University, said afterward that Mr. Gore had put himself in "an extraordinarily difficult position." But, Mr. Kovacic said, "the issues the case raises are so fundamental to the future of the company and of innovation that it's perfectly reasonable for people to ask what his views are."
Mr. Gore has a precedent for commenting on such cases. When Boeing acquired McDonnell Douglas in 1997, Mr. Gore went to the home of Boeing in Seattle and said the United States would fight efforts by Europe to block the merger. Mr. Kovacic said Mr. Gore's stance in favor of Boeing's monopoly, and in favor of the American company's pre-eminence in the aircraft sector, stood in contrast to the administration's opposition in the case of Microsoft.
"Microsoft has a lot of domestic enemies, and a lot of them are in Silicon Valley, and they have thrown a lot of cash at both parties, but in particular to the Democrats," Mr. Kovacic said. "Microsoft has a legion of enemies who hold it in contempt. And that's a tricky issue for the White House. Do you attack the pre-eminent symbol of American information technology success or safeguard the interests of their Silicon Valley opponents?"
Mr. Gore turned the conversation to one of values, mentioning support for research and development, dealing with inequality and then said: "And yet another value that I think is important in our country is competition. And competition can be stifled both by unwise and unhealthy government action and also by private action on the part of companies that want to unfairly use market dominance in one sector to stifle innovation in another sector."
Despite this grim judgment, Mr. Gore has tried to portray himself as a friend of the high-tech industry, going so far earlier this year as to call himself the father of the Internet. He has promoted tax credits for research and development, and today he threw around terms like quantum computing and Moore's Law with abandon.
He also noted that one of his daughters, Karenna, had worked briefly at Slate, Microsoft's online magazine. And one of his former employees, Ginny Terzano, once Mr. Gore's press secretary, has just been hired by Microsoft to head its lobbying office in Washington, D.C.
But it is not clear what kind of affinity William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman, may have for Mr. Gore. Mr. Gates was not on hand for today's visit, having a prior commitment at a conference.
There has been considerable debate over Mr. Gates's political leanings and speculation that he wants to drag out the lawsuit until a new president takes office and appoints a new chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division.
Microsoft gave $1.3 million last year to candidates in both parties. Microsoft employees have been more generous to Republicans this year than to Democrats. They gave $29,000 to Mr. Bush and $13,000 to Mr. Gore.
Several employees who attended today's session with Mr. Gore reflected the computer industry's stance that electoral politics had little to do with their success. A cluster of employees, who declined to give their names, said they were more interested in Mr. Gore's views on education and on health care than on the antitrust case because, as one put it, "the administration doesn't have much say in the overall economic growth of the last 15 years."
But Mr. Gore's comments did not appear to win him many friends. "I appreciate him being honest," one employee said. "But I'm not encouraged. He was on the side of the government."

HEADLINE: New Battles Erupt In A.T.M. Fee War As Banks Retaliate

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Lashawanda McCullom, a 30-year-old nurse, put her credit union's cash card into a Bank of America automated teller machine here, punched in her secret code and requested a withdrawal. The machine spit out her card and flashed a message: "Due to a recent vote by the Santa Monica City Council, the convenience of this A.T.M. is now available to Bank of America cardholders only."
Ms. McCullom, who expressed mild frustration at being denied her cash, was caught in the cross-fire of a skirmish over A.T.M. surcharges that now seems to be breaking into a full-fledged war. Suddenly, the fact that it costs an extra $1.50 or so to get money out of a cash machine seems to have tapped into some deep well of public resentment -- or at least politicians believe it has. 
 This oceanside suburb of Los Angeles last month passed the nation's first local ordinance banning banks from charging noncustomers for using their A.T.M.'s. San Francisco voters approved a similar measure earlier this month. California's two largest banks, Bank of America and Wells Fargo Bank, retaliated by closing off noncustomer access to their machines, which is why Ms. McCullom could not get her money Friday. And late today, a federal judge in San Francisco issued a preliminary injunction barring both cities from enforcing their ordinances.
The ruling by Judge Vaughn Walker could slow down but not derail efforts in other cities and states to enact similar bans. The New York City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said today that he planned to propose such a law and the Los Angeles City Council has instructed the city attorney to study the city's authority to enact a ban.
The Department of Defense has also proposed a ban on such surcharges on all military bases. Connecticut and Iowa already ban such surcharges under pre-existing laws and three other states -- Wyoming, Arkansas and Mississippi -- have price caps on the surcharges.
"Consumers just find the surcharge sort of the fee that broke the consumer's back, so to speak," said Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut, which is now battling the banking industry in court. "Consumers see no reason for it. They regard it almost as a personal insult. It has evoked an emotion that is quite astonishing."
How widespread the bans will become remains to be seen. Santa Monica and San Francisco are both liberal, not typical cities. Consumer groups have failed to get any state to enact such a ban and Alfonse M. D'Amato, when he was senator from New York, never got very far with his attempt to legislate a nationwide prohibition. Representative Bernard Sanders, an independent from Vermont, re-introduced a bill this month that would ban surcharges, and another bill that would authorize cities and states to outlaw the fees.
Critics say it is unreasonable to charge consumers for access to their own money.
"Banks are basically holding our money hostage," said Jon Golinger of the California Public Interest Group. The United States Public Interest Research Group found that 93 percent of banks surveyed impose such a surcharge, up from 71 percent in 1998 and 15 percent in 1996. Nationally, such surcharges appear to generate about $2 billion to $3 billion a year or more for A.T.M. operators.
Critics also say that in many cases consumers are being charged twice for each withdrawal. If a Wells Fargo customer, for instance, takes money out of a Bank of America machine, Wells Fargo charges that customer $2 for using a "foreign" A.T.M., about 50 cents of which goes to reimburse Bank of America. But Bank of America itself charges $1.50 for use of its machine by a noncustomer, bringing the total fee for retrieving as little as $20 of one's own money to $3.50.
The Santa Monica and San Francisco ordinances, as well as the regulation in Connecticut, bar only the $1.50 surcharge levied by the A.T.M. owner, not the fees imposed by a bank on its own customers.
Part of the frustration over the surcharges stems from what is a general proliferation in banking fees in an era of deregulation and from the fact that A.T.M. use was once free. "People see the way banks are trying to charge for everything under the sun," said Walter L. McCaffrey, a New York City councilman from Queens who is helping draft the proposed legislation there. "The original position was that A.T.M.'s were not a profit center."
Banks say it is their right to charge for services. If consumers do not want to pay they can use their own bank's A.T.M.'s. Without surcharges, they said, there would be fewer A.T.M.'s and less convenience for consumers.
"You're not going to find too many people who are willing to give the service for free," said Terry E. Zink, senior vice president in charge of A.T.M.'s for Wells Fargo. "The biggest issue is whether or not consumers have the right to pay for services they want."
What is perhaps most unusual about this battle is that only a few years ago, the forces were on the opposite sides. The banks, through two major networks that link A.T.M. machines, prohibited the surcharges. Legislators in 15 states enacted laws overriding the prohibition.
Banks initially shunned fees to encourage people to use the machines. They viewed A.T.M.'s not as money makers but as cost-savers, a way to cut down on the number of tellers.
But then some banks as well as some nonfinancial companies began realizing that charging customers would make it economical to put A.T.M.'s in remote locations and away from banks themselves. Moreover, the prohibition on surcharges raised antitrust issues because it made it difficult for nonbanks to be in the A.T.M. business because there would be no way to recover their costs. This led to the state laws allowing the fees and to the decision in 1996 by two major national A.T.M. networks -- Visa's Plus and Mastercard International's Cirrus -- to lift the prohibition on surcharges.
Since then the number of A.T.M.'s has nearly doubled to 227,000 from 123,000 in 1997, according to the American Bankers Association. Most of the new machines are not at banks and savings and loans but at supermarkets, malls, airports, amusement parks and other so-called off-premise locations. Indeed, slightly more than half of all A.T.M.'s are now off premise, according to Bank Network News, a Chicago based newsletter.
Moreover, about half of all new A.T.M.'s -- including most of the off-premise ones -- are owned by companies other than banks, saving and loans or credit unions, according to Speer & Associates, an Atlanta consulting firm. These companies include Electronic Data Systems, the computer services company, the Publix Supermarkets chain and smaller companies that have gone into business just to provide A.T.M.'s. Many retailers own their A.T.M.'s, but some merely collect a fee from A.T.M.'s in their stores that are owned by others.
The San Francisco and Santa Monica laws allow these nonfinancial institutions to levy the surcharges, under the theory that they do not gain savings from having fewer tellers. The Connecticut rule, however, bars surcharges on all machines. The New York ordinance has not been drafted yet but could be similar to the California ones.
While consumer groups say that bank fees are well in excess of what it costs for an A.T.M. transaction, some bankers say they are losing money on A.T.M.'s even with the surcharges. And they say prohibiting surcharges will force closure of many A.T.M.'s.
"Without the surcharge, there's no way a lot of off-premise A.T.M.'s can be profitable," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, who studied the matter for the American Bankers Association.
Evidence on this question is mixed. Connecticut has only about two-thirds of the number of A.T.M.'s per million people as the nation as a whole, according to Bank Network News. But Iowa has almost as many machines per capita as the nation as a whole and more than some states that allow the surcharges.
In the preliminary ruling in San Francisco today, Judge Walker agreed with the arguments of Bank of America, Wells Fargo and the California Bankers Association that local ordinances are pre-empted by federal regulations. The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, a federal regulator, has intervened in the case on the side of the banks.
Banks have won decisions on these grounds in Iowa and Connecticut, but the ban on surcharges in those states remains while the decisions are being appealed. But a 1990 decision by the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which covers California and other Western states, found that a federal law does allow some room for states to regulate A.T.M.'s.
Critics of the surcharges say they favor the big banks under the theory that consumers, to avoid the fees, will put their accounts in banks that have the most machines. "When a business can gain customers by raising prices, that's not what competition is all about," said Adam Radinsky, deputy city attorney for Santa Monica.
Some smaller banks and credit unions have pushed for free A.T.M. use or have banded together to offer free use to one another's customers, to better compete with bigger banks. Still, many smaller banks impose the surcharges.
Even in Santa Monica, some people think the whole controversy is overblown.
"I think Santa Monica is overstepping its rights trying to impose business practices on the banks, and I think the banks are being vindictive and hasty in trying to make a statement back to the city of Santa Monica," said Katrina Osio, a 33-year-old marketing director of an Internet company. "I just think it's childish."

LENGTH: 409 words

HEADLINE: Opening China's Markets

 BODY:
The Clinton administration appears to have salvaged the trade agreement with China that it could have concluded in April if President Clinton had not rejected it. The new agreement, announced yesterday in Beijing, paves the way for China to join the World Trade Organization, committing it to obey rules that apply to all other major trading partners.
Zhu Rongji, the Chinese prime minister, offered much the same terms seven months ago on a visit to the United States. Mr. Clinton's last-minute rejection, based on his fear that Congress would not go along, embarrassed Mr. Zhu and gave his domestic critics time to build opposition to an arrangement that would have accelerated China's push toward freer markets. Since April the administration has scrambled to correct its blunder. Yesterday it succeeded. 
 The new terms appear about as bold as the old ones. China promises to cut tariffs below those of many of America's other trade partners. It agrees to end export subsidies, give American exporters the right to distribute goods and open up Chinese markets to American farmers, banks, insurance, telecommunications and Internet companies.
By one calculation, the agreement will do little for the Chinese economy because its exports already enjoy unfettered access to American consumers. One exception is textiles and apparel. The new terms grant the Chinese an important concession -- the United States will phase out quotas on Chinese goods as fast as it phases out quotas on textiles from other trade partners. This provision will not hurt American manufacturers, since Chinese apparel sales mostly come at the expense of other third world exporters.
But by a second calculation, the impact on the Chinese economy could be profound. By joining the trade organization, China's market advocates now have the weight of international law on their side. Mr. Zhu expects trade accords to tilt domestic debate over economic reform in his favor.
There are critics who say that China will not live up to its trade promises, and that the trade organization is incapable of forcing it to do so. Perhaps. But with China outside the organization, the United States has no real leverage. With Chinese membership, the United States can marshal international sanctions for violations. Besides, the imposition of the rule of law on trade might strengthen the hand of domestic forces fighting for the rule of law for the rest of Chinese society.

HEADLINE: United States May Yet Lose Its Vote in U.N. General Assembly

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Appropriating nearly $1 billion in back dues and assessments to the United Nations might not be enough to prevent the United States from losing its vote in the General Assembly next year, United Nations officials say.
A senior United Nations official estimated that the United States must come up with at least $350 million by the end of December to avoid forfeiting its vote. But legislation worked out by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, would initially pay only $100 million. 
 The possibility of the United States' losing its vote is real because the United Nations charter says that any country falling two years behind will be stripped of its right to vote until it repays the debt. Usually only nations mired in poverty fall sufficiently behind to lose their votes.
But a senior Clinton administration official expressed confidence that the gap could be covered by pooling the first payment with funds being appropriated in a bill for the Departments of State, Commerce and Justice.
The Helms-Biden legislation authorized $926 million in payment over three years. But it also attached the following conditions, which other countries are likely to challenge:
* The other 187 member countries must accept the $926 million as payment in full and agree not to keep billing for the remaining arrears. The United Nations says Washington owes nearly $1.6 billion, using different calculations and counting expenses that the United States has refused to pay for political reasons.
* The United States' share of the United Nations budget must be trimmed to 22 percent from 25 percent, which Washington has been paying for years.
* The United States' share of peacekeeping costs must be cut to 25 percent from 31 percent.
* The United Nations budget cannot include any growth in spending, even allowing for inflation. The budget has not risen in dollar terms since since 1994, said Catherine O'Neill, the director of the United Nations office in Washington.
The United States is the biggest contributor to the United Nations but also its biggest debtor, accounting for more than 60 percent of the total owed by member countries.
Losing the General Assembly vote for nonpayment would not affect the United States' seat and vote in the Security Council or its veto power as one of the council's five permanent members. But the loss of the assembly vote would be a setback to the nation's prestige and influence in the organization, which has been declining as the arrears pile up.
The debt was on the minds of a group of lawmakers who visited the United Nations headquarters today.
"I think it is tragic that we will have not paid our dues up to this point," Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, said. "I'm very embarrassed about it."
Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, said the effect of the new legislation would not be seen until it was in draft language. "My understanding from conversation with folks in Washington is that we will be able to fulfill our obligations," he said. "It would be truly outrageous that after all this time we still don't pay our bills."
The senior administration official said some provisions in the Helms-Biden legislation, like reducing the United States' share of the United Nations' cost, might be possible once Washington offered the money. "If we have a check in hand," the senior official said, "the climate for reforms will be greatly improved."
